献给大卫和伊莱恩

For David and Elaine

我从十二岁起就迷上了吉他。从很多方面来说，我的生活就是一场关于吉他的长谈，只是被我弹奏那些该死的东西所带来的无数小时的深深乐趣所打断，以及一些不太愉快的时间花在了需要做的事情上，这样我才能回来玩耍和谈论它们。

I’ve been obsessed with the guitar since I was twelve. In many ways my life has been one long conversation about the guitar, interrupted only by the countless hours of deep pleasure I have playing the darn things, as well as some less pleasant time spent doing what needs to be done so that I can get back to playing and chatting about them.

——佩里·比克曼，爵士吉他手

—Perry Beekman, jazz guitarist

 

首先你学习乐器，然后你学习音乐，然后你忘记所有这些，只是演奏。

First you learn your instrument, then you learn the music, and then you forget all that s**t and just play.

——查理·帕克

—Charlie Parker

调整

TUNING UP

 

成为音乐剧需要什么？

What Does It Take to Become Musical?

 

音乐家是天生的还是后天培养的？

Are musicians born or made?

我一生都想成为音乐人，但我总是认为我从来没有机会。我的耳朵很笨拙，我的手指也很笨拙。我没有天生的节奏感，音高感也很差。我一直很喜欢音乐，但从来不会唱歌，更不用说弹奏乐器了；在学校里，我开始相信，无论我多么努力，我注定是一个旁观者，而不是参与者。

All my life I wanted to become musical, but I always assumed that I never had a chance. My ears are dodgy, my fingers too clumsy. I have no natural sense of rhythm and a lousy sense of pitch. I have always loved music but could never sing, let alone play an instrument; in school I came to believe that I was destined to be a spectator, rather than a participant, no matter how hard I tried.

 

随着年龄的增长，我发现我的机会只会越来越少。一旦我们完成学业，我们的生活往往会关注执行而不是丰富。无论我们是养家糊口的人还是照顾者，我们的成功都是通过结果来衡量的。我们应该理解，实现这些成果所需的工作应该迅速且秘密进行。如果传统观点是正确的，那么当我们成年时再学习任何新东西就为时已晚了。小孩子也许可以学任何东西，但如果你想学法语，你应该从六岁开始。

As I grew older, I figured my chances only diminished. Our lives, once we finish school, tend to focus on execution rather than enrichment. Whether we are breadwinners or caretakers, our success is measured by outcomes. The work it takes to achieve those outcomes, we are meant to understand, is something that should happen quickly and behind closed doors. If the conventional wisdom is right, by the time we are adults it’s too late to learn anything new. Children may be able to learn anything, but if you wanted to learn French, you should have started when you were six.

 

 

直到最近，科学才支持这一理论。事实上，发展心理学领域的每个人都坚信学习的“关键时期”。这个想法是，存在可以学习复杂技能的特定时间窗口；如果你在窗户关闭时还没有学会它们，那么你永远也学不到。案件结案。

Until recently, science supported this theory. Virtually everybody in developmental psychology was a firm believer in “critical periods” of learning. The idea is that there are particular time windows in which complex skills can be learned; if you don’t learn them by the time the window shuts, you never will. Case closed.

但关键时期的证据却出人意料地薄弱。例如，考虑一下经常被引用的吉妮的案例，她是一个不幸的女孩，多年来被锁在一个安静的房间里。当吉妮十三岁时越狱时，她第一次接触语言，但她始终无法说一口流利的语言。她的词汇量足以让她入门，但她的语法一团糟，充满了诸如“Spot Chew Glove”和“Applesauce buy store”之类的话语。这是否意味着精灵的语言关键期已经过去了？大多数人都这样解释她的案例，但另一种不常被考虑的解释是，吉妮无法学习语言可能部分归因于她早期遭受的情感创伤（也许还有营养不良）。她的案例与关键期假说是一致的，但它肯定不能证明这一点。

But the evidence for critical periods is surprisingly weak. Consider, for example, the often-cited case of Genie, an unfortunate girl who was locked in a silent room for many years. When Genie escaped at the age of thirteen, she was exposed to language for the first time, and she was never able to become fluent. Her vocabulary was good enough to get her started, but her grammar was a mess, filled with utterances like “Spot chew glove” and “Applesauce buy store.” Does this mean that Genie’s critical period for language had passed? Most people interpret her case that way, but another explanation, less often considered, is that Genie’s inability to learn language may have come in part from the emotional trauma (and perhaps malnutrition) she had suffered early on. Her case is consistent with the critical period hypothesis, but it certainly doesn’t prove it.

 

实际上研究关键时期的人越多，数据就越不稳定。尽管成年人很少能达到与儿童相同的流利程度，但科学研究表明，差异通常更多地与口音有关，而不是与语法有关。与此同时，与普遍的看法相反，并没有什么神奇的窗户会在青春期开始的那一刻突然关闭。事实上，近年来，科学家们已经发现许多人能够以接近母语的流利程度学习第二语言，尽管他们只是从成年人开始学习。

The more people have actually studied critical periods, the shakier the data have become. Although adults rarely achieve the same level of fluency that children do, the scientific research suggests that differences typically pertain more to accent than to grammar. Meanwhile, contrary to popular belief, there’s no magical window that slams shut the moment puberty begins. In fact, in recent years scientists have identified a number of people who have managed to learn second languages with near-native fluency, even though they only started as adults.

 

如果关键时期并不像人们曾经认为的那样坚定，那么对于许多怀有秘密梦想的成年人来说，一个充满可能性的世界就会出现——无论是学习一门语言，成为一名糕点师，还是驾驶一架小型飞机。像这样的任务，无论看起来多么不切实际，也无论最终成功与否，都可能带来意想不到的好处，不仅是为了他们的最终目标，也是为了旅程本身。锻炼大脑有助于维持大脑的可塑性（神经系统学习新事物的能力）、防止退化以及保持血液流动。除了对我们的大脑有潜在的好处外，对我们的情绪健康也有好处。与短暂的快乐相比，实现持久的幸福可能没有比追求有助于我们拓宽视野的目标更好的方法了。

If critical periods aren’t quite so firm as people once believed, a world of possibility emerges for the many adults who harbor secret dreams— whether to learn a language, to become a pastry chef, or to pilot a small plane. And quests like these, no matter how quixotic they may seem, and whether they succeed in the end or not, could bring unanticipated benefits, not just for their ultimate goals but for the journey itself. Exercising our brains helps maintain them, by preserving plasticity (the capacity of the nervous system to learn new things), warding off degeneration, and literally keeping the blood flowing. Beyond the potential benefits for our brains, there are benefits for our emotional well-being, too. There may be no better way to achieve lasting happiness— as opposed to mere fleeting pleasure— than pursuing a goal that helps us broaden our horizons.

 

 

从小学开始，我的每一次音乐尝试都以失败告终。几年前，我第一次尝试弹吉他，我的朋友丹·莱维汀（Dan Levitin）（他还没有完成他的书《这是你的音乐大脑》）好心地提出要给我上几堂课。当我练习一两周后回到他身边时，他很快意识到我的小学老师很久以前就意识到了：我根本没有节奏感。丹给了我一个节拍器，当这没有帮助时，他给了我一些小学老师无法提供的东西——诊断：先天性心律失常。

Still from grade school onward, every musical attempt I made ended in failure. The first time I tried to play guitar, a few years ago, my friend Dan Levitin (who had not yet finished his book This Is Your Brain on Music) kindly offered to give me a few lessons. When I came back to him after a week or two of practice, he quickly realized what my grade school teachers had realized long ago: that I had no sense of rhythm whatsoever. Dan offered me a metronome, and when that didn’t help, he gave me something my grade school teachers couldn’t—a diagnosis: congenital arrhythmia.

但我从未失去对比赛的渴望。就关键时期而言，音乐还没有像语言那样得到系统的研究，但肯定有一些艺术家起步较晚，但仍然成为一流的音乐家。汤姆·莫雷洛（Tom Morello）是《Rage Against the Machine》的吉他手，也是《滚石》史上第 26 位最伟大的吉他手，他直到 17 岁才开始演奏。帕蒂·史密斯直到二十多岁才考虑成为一名职业歌手。还有爵士吉他传奇人物帕特·马蒂诺 (Pat Martino)，他在 35 岁时因脑动脉瘤而重新学习弹奏；还有新奥尔良键盘传奇人物约翰博士 (Dr. John)，他在 20 岁时将自己的主要爱好从吉他转向了钢琴。二十一岁时（他的左手无名指在酒吧斗殴中受重伤），并在四十八岁时赢得了他五次格莱美奖中的第一个。

And yet I never lost the desire to play. Music hasn’t been studied as systematically as language in terms of critical periods, but there are certainly artists who started late and still became first-rate musicians. Tom Morello— guitarist of Rage Against the Machine and Rolling Stone’s twenty-sixth-greatest guitarist of all time— didn’t start until he was seventeen. Patti Smith scarcely considered becoming a professional singer until she was in her mid-twenties. Then there is the jazz guitar legend Pat Martino, who relearned how to play after a brain aneurysm at the age of thirty-five, and the New Orleans keyboard legend Dr. John, who switched his primary allegiance from guitar to piano at the age of twenty-one (after his left ring finger was badly injured in a barroom fight) and won the first of his five Grammy Awards at the age of forty-eight.

 

由于我的心律失常，我并没有达到如此高度的愿望，但在三十八岁时，在我进入研究生院并成为认知心理学教授很久之后，我意识到我对音乐的渴望并没有消失。我想知道我是否可以克服我的内在限制、我的年龄和我的天赋不足。也许很少有人比我更有音乐天赋，但很少有人比我更渴望能够演奏。

Given my arrhythmia, I had no aspiration of reaching such heights, but at thirty-eight, long after I had gone to graduate school and become a professor of cognitive psychology, I realized that my desire to become musical wasn’t going away. I wanted to know whether I could overcome my intrinsic limits, my age, and my lack of talent. Perhaps few people had less talent for music than I did, but few people wanted more badly to be able to play.

 

 

奇怪的是，我的第一缕希望来自于一款电子游戏，我买了它，因为它可以改善我的节奏。当然，我指的游戏是《吉他英雄》，也许是我玩过的最无脑但最有趣的游戏。如果你还没有看到它，基本前提是彩色点从屏幕​​顶部落下，与音乐同步，作为玩家，你的任务只不过是按下塑料吉他上匹配的彩色按钮及时与落下的点。

My first ray of hope came, oddly enough, from a video game, which I bought with the idea that it might improve my rhythm. The game I am referring to is, of course, Guitar Hero, perhaps the most mindless yet entertaining game I have ever played. In case you haven’t seen it, the basic premise is that colored dots fall from the top of the screen, in time with music, and as a player your mission consists of nothing more than the pressing of matching colored buttons on a plastic guitar in time with the falling dots.

它的有趣之处在于，每当玩家在正确的时刻按下按钮时，游戏就会播放一段音乐片段，从而产生玩家实际上正在播放歌曲的错觉。

What makes it fun is that the game plays a snippet of music each time the player presses a button at the right moment, yielding the illusion that the player is actually playing a song.

 

或不。如果一个人的时机足够糟糕（就像我最初的那样），你会听到嘟嘟声而不是音乐片段，更糟糕的是，人群开始发出嘘声。打得够糟糕，观众就会把你嘘下台。我非常清楚这一点，因为每次我尝试演奏开场曲——一首令人遗憾的 1970 年代蓝调摇滚乐曲，Foghat 的《Slow Ride》——观众很快就开始发出嘘声，声音越来越大，直到歌曲中途停止。通过，不可避免地伴随着相当残酷和缺乏想象力的信息，告诉我我“失败了”。随着失败的增多，我被带回到四年级，当时我试图学习吹竖笛（巴洛克时期流行的一种穷人的长笛），但我在音乐上太天真了，无法通过。“玛丽有只小羊羔。” 《吉他英雄》可能无法替代真正的吉他，但对于像我这样的音乐白痴来说，《吉他英雄》似乎遥不可及；很快我就收起了游戏，回到了平凡的生活。

Or not. If one’s timing is bad enough (as mine was initially), you hear a beep instead of the musical snippet, and worse, the crowd begins to boo. Play badly enough, and the crowd boos you off the stage. I know this rather too well, because every time I tried to play the opening song— a regrettable piece of 1970s blues rock called “Slow Ride,” by Foghat— the crowd soon began to boo, louder and louder, until the song stopped midway through, inevitably accompanied by the rather brutal and unimaginative message informing me that I had “failed.” As the failures piled up, I was brought back to fourth grade, when I had tried to learn to play the recorder (a sort of poor man’s flute that was popular in the Baroque era) and was so musically naive I couldn’t get past “Mary Had a Little Lamb.” Guitar Hero might be a poor substitute for real guitar, but for a musical dunce like me even Guitar Hero seemed out of reach; I soon packed the game away and returned to my ordinary life.

 

但后来发生了一件有趣的事情。我的妻子雅典娜 (Athena) 出差探望朋友回到家，她对演奏《吉他英雄》的对应版本《摇滚乐队》时的乐趣赞不绝口。

But then a funny thing happened. My wife, Athena, returned home from a trip to see friends and raved about how much fun she’d had playing a counterpart to Guitar Hero called Rock Band.

 

 

我们的《吉他英雄》出柜了，我的新生活就这样开始了。再试一次，但这一次有了 Athena 的反馈（告诉我什么时候按下按钮太早，什么时候按下按钮太晚），我终于成功地从头到尾播放了“Slow Ride”，没有任何嘘声。 。我激动得几乎说不出话来。我第一次尝到准音乐上的成功——简直令人陶醉。

Our copy of Guitar Hero came out of the closet, and thus my new life began. Trying again, but this time with the benefit of Athena’s feedback (telling me when I was pressing the buttons too early versus when I was pressing too late), I finally managed to play “Slow Ride” all the way through, with nary a boo. I was so excited I could barely speak. My first taste, ever, of quasi-musical success— it was nothing short of intoxicating.

几个星期以来，我一直在练习，很快我就开始变得越来越好。我从未进入过专家模式，但我最终通过了中等模式并开始沉迷于一个不同的问题。我不想打电子游戏来消磨晚年，但如果我能在塑料控制器上取得进步，我能学会弹真正的吉他吗？我开始想：坚持和对音乐终生的热爱能否克服年龄和天赋的缺乏？就此而言，任何年龄段的人是如何成为音乐人的？

For weeks, I kept practicing, and soon I started getting better and better. I never made it to expert mode, but I eventually got through medium and became obsessed with a different question. I didn’t want to while away my later years playing a video game, but if I could make progress with a plastic controller, could I learn to play a real guitar? I began to wonder: Could persistence and a lifelong love of music overcome age and a lack of talent? And, for that matter, how did anyone of any age become musical?

 

是时候找出答案了。

It was time to find out.

 

 

对于外星科学家来说，音乐——以及创造音乐的欲望——可能是人类最令人困惑的方面之一。例如，任何物种都可能有新陈代谢，任何相当聪明的物种也可能有交流系统；最终我们期望它也能发展政府和法律体系。但这些生物也会尊重随时间变化的声音模式吗？我想知道他们是否有创作自己音乐的愿望？

To an alien scientist, music— and the desire to create it— might be one of the most puzzling aspects of humanity. Any species, for instance, would presumably have a metabolism, and any reasonably intelligent species would likely also have a system of communication; eventually we would expect it to develop systems of government and law, too. But would such creatures also revere patterns of sound that vary over time? I wonder, would they have any desire to make their own music?

有一天，也许我们会找到答案，但现在，有一件事是明确的：我自己制作音乐的愿望是不可否认的。我已经到了这样的地步：要么现在，要么永远。我开始阅读科学文献。孩子们是如何学习音乐的？有成人课程吗？

Someday, maybe we will find out, but for now, one thing was clear: my own desire to make music was undeniable. I had reached the point where it felt like it was now or never. I began to read up on the scientific literature. How did children learn music? Were there any lessons for adults?

 

令我惊讶的是，尽管对儿童进行了很好的研究，但对我这个年龄的人却几乎没有任何系统的研究。似乎没有人知道成年人是否可以在晚年学习乐器，我们对音乐知之甚少，对音乐也知之甚少。一般来说，关于成年人学习新技能的能力的文献比我想象的要少得多。我们知道记忆力会逐渐衰退，但我能找到的关于音乐后期学习的唯一真正可靠的结果尤其是完美音高（孤立地识别单个音符的能力）。为此，人们确实必须早点开始，但对我和其他晚开始的人来说幸运的是，很明显，完美的音高比必需品更奢侈。艾灵顿公爵没有，伊戈尔·斯特拉文斯基也没有（就此而言，乔伊·雷蒙也没有）。

To my surprise, although children had been well studied, there was hardly any systematic research on people my age. Nobody seemed to know much about whether adults could pick up an instrument late in life, and it wasn’t just music that we knew little about; the literature on the capacity of adults to learn new skills in general was far sparser than I had imagined. We know something about gradual declines in memory, but the only truly firm result I could find with respect to the late learning of music in particular concerned perfect pitch (the ability to identify a single note in isolation). For that, one must indeed start early, but lucky for me and anyone else starting late, it is also quite clear that perfect pitch is more luxury than necessity. Duke Ellington didn’t have it, and neither did Igor Stravinsky (nor, for that matter, did Joey Ramone).

 

其他几项研究表明，较早开始的音乐学习者比较晚开始的成年人具有某种优势，但大多数研究并不能控制练习的总量。当谈到音乐的其他方面，例如即兴创作或作曲的能力，甚至学习简单的旋律时，几乎没有引人注目的文献。尽管许多研究都表明练习越多，效果就越好，但令人惊讶的是，很少有研究比较不同年龄的人进行相同练习量时会发生什么。

Several other studies show some kind of advantage for music learners who began earlier in life over adults who began later, but most of those don’t control for total amount of practice. When it came to other aspects of music, such as the ability to improvise or compose, or even to learn a simple melody, there was almost no compelling literature. Although any number of studies have shown that the more you practice the better you get, startlingly few have compared what happens when people of different ages get the same amount of practice.

 

如此基本的科学问题为何仍然没有答案？我想了好几个月，直到蒙特利尔麦吉尔大学一位说话温和但思路异常清晰的心理学教授卡罗琳·帕尔默（Caroline Palmer）终于向我解释了答案。问题并非缺乏科学兴趣；这是缺乏主题。要学习一种乐器，你需要投入大量的工作——一万个小时是一个经常提到的（如果有点过分）数字——而要进行适当的研究，你需要相当大的参与者样本，这就是说一大群有足够承诺的成年新手。没有人研究过从四十二岁开始投入一万小时练习的成年人的结果，因为这个年龄段的大多数人都有生活和责任。一般四十二岁的人可能每周上一到两次课，但最终孩子、工作或年迈父母的负担常常会占据上风；很少有成年音乐学习者愿意像青少年那样投入时间。没有学科，就没有科学。

How could such a basic scientific question remain so unanswered? I wondered about this for months, until Caroline Palmer, a soft-spoken but exceptionally clear-thinking professor of psychology at McGill University in Montreal, finally explained the answer to me. The problem wasn’t a lack of scientific interest; it was a lack of subjects. To learn a musical instrument, you need to put in a lot of work— ten thousand hours is an oft-mentioned (if somewhat oversold) number— and to do a proper study, you’d need a reasonably large sample of participants, which is to say a big group of adult novices with sufficient commitment. Nobody has studied the outcomes of adults who put in ten thousand hours of practice starting at the age of forty-two because most people of that age have lives and responsibilities. Your average forty-two-year-old might go to lessons once or twice a week, but eventually the burdens of a child, a job, or an aging parent often take over; few adult learners of music are prepared to invest the kind of time that a teenager has. No subjects, no science.

 

那一刻，我决定成为一只小白鼠。从道德上讲，我无法强迫其他成年人练习一万小时，但我可以在自己身上进行实验。碰巧，我的休假即将到来，这会给我比平常更多的空闲时间，我决定看看如果我全身心投入音乐一两个月——或者只要我可以站立。如果像我这样不调调的人能够取得进步，也许任何人都有希望。

At that point, I decided to become a guinea pig. I couldn’t ethically force other adults to practice for ten thousand hours, but I could experiment on myself. As it happened, I had a sabbatical coming up, which would give me more free time than usual, and I decided to see what would happen if I devoted myself to music full-time, for a month or two— or as long as I could stand. If someone as tuneless as I could make progress, perhaps there was hope for anyone.

 

 

在我的旅程开始时，一项研究给我带来了一线希望。

At the outset of my journey, one study in particular gave a glimmer of hope.

多年来，关键时期最有力的科学证据不是来自人类，而是来自动物。为了正确确定关键时期的存在，需要进行一项实验，在仔细控制的环境中饲养幼年动物。

For years, the strongest scientific evidence for critical periods came not from humans but from animals. To properly establish the existence of a critical period, one needs to do an experiment in which young animals are raised in a carefully controlled environment.

 

在有关关键时期的文献中，最有影响力的实验之一来自饲养仓鸮。事实上，谷仓猫头鹰有点像蝙蝠：它们严重依赖声音来导航。然而，与此同时，它们的视力比蝙蝠通常的视力更好，并且其中之一它们孵化后做的第一件事就是用耳朵校准眼睛，将听到的与看到的对齐。这使得它们能够使用声音提示来帮助它们在黑暗的夜间世界中导航。但眼睛和耳朵之间的精确映射不可能在出生时就被硬连线，因为听觉信息的导航功能取决于两耳之间的精确距离，而该距离会随着动物的成长而变化。

In the literature on critical periods, one of the most influential experiments came from raising barn owls. Barn owls, as it happens, are a little like bats: they rely heavily on sound to navigate. At the same time, however, they can see better than bats typically do, and one of the first things they do after hatching is to calibrate their eyes with their ears, lining up what they hear with what they see. This allows them to use sound cues to help them navigate in their dark nocturnal world. But exact mapping between eyes and ears cannot be hardwired at birth, because the navigational function of the auditory information depends on the exact distance between the two ears, and that distance changes as an animal grows.

 

猫头鹰如何校准视觉世界和听觉世界？斯坦福大学生物学家埃里克·克努森（Eric Knudsen）通过在虚拟现实世界中饲养猫头鹰来探索这个问题，在虚拟现实世界中，棱镜将一切移动了二十三度。这扰乱了猫头鹰的正常视觉能力，并迫使猫头鹰调整其视觉世界的内部地图。棱镜安装得越早，猫头鹰就越能应对改变的世界。年轻的猫头鹰可以很容易地学会补偿扭曲，而年老的猫头鹰却不能。

How do owls manage to calibrate the visual world with the auditory world? The Stanford biologist Eric Knudsen explored this question by raising owls in a kind of virtual reality world, in which prisms shifted everything by twenty-three degrees. This disrupted the owl’s normal capacity to see and forced the owl to adjust its internal map of the visual world. The earlier the prisms were installed, the better the owls were able to cope with the altered world. Young owls could easily learn to compensate for the distortion, whereas old owls could not.

 

如果那是我读过的唯一一篇论文，我就会放弃吉他。但我很快就偶然发现了一项较新的、不太为人所知的研究，克努森在这项研究中发现，年长的猫头鹰毕竟并非完全没有希望。尽管克努森最初的结果仍然成立——成年猫头鹰肯定不如小猫头鹰那么灵活——成年猫头鹰通常可以到达同一个地方，只要它们的工作被分解成更小的步骤。成年猫头鹰无法一次性掌握二十三度的扭曲，但如果将工作分解为更小的部分，它们就可以成功：几周六度，再几周十一度，等等。

If that were the only paper I had read, I would have given up on the guitar right there. But I soon stumbled on a more recent study, less widely known, in which Knudsen discovered that older owls weren’t entirely hopeless after all. Although Knudsen’s original results still stand— adults definitely aren’t as flexible as baby owls— adult owls can often get to the same place, so long as their job is broken down into smaller bite-size steps. Adult owls couldn’t master twenty-three degrees of distortion all in one go, but they could succeed if the job was broken down into smaller chunks: a few weeks at six degrees, another few weeks at eleven degrees, and so on.

 

也许我没有天赋，也许我老了（或者至少不再年轻），但我愿意慢慢来。如果我们像猫头鹰一样一点一点地接近它们，像我这样的成年人能获得新技能吗？

Maybe I didn’t have talent, and maybe I was old (or at least no longer young), but I was willing to take it slow. Could adults like me acquire new skills if we approached them bit by bit, owl-style?

 

这本书是关于我如何开始区分我的音乐臀部和我的音乐肘的，但这不仅仅是关于我：它还关于任何年龄的人（幼儿、青少年或成人）如何学习一些东西的心理学和脑科学像乐器一样复杂。

This book is about how I began to distinguish my musical derriere from my musical elbow, but it’s not just about me: it’s also about the psychology and brain science of how anybody, of any age—toddler, teenager, or adult—can learn something as complicated as a musical instrument.

学习演奏乐器需要什么？当学习说话看起来如此容易和如此自然时，是什么让学习新技能如此费力？小孩子真的有优势吗？成年人可以通过定向练习来弥补差距吗？

What does it take to learn to play an instrument? What makes learning new skills so labor-intensive, when learning to talk seems so easy and so natural? Do kids really have an advantage? Can adults make up for any disparity with directed practice?

 

一路上，我惊叹于音乐的奇迹以及人类创造和享受音乐的渴望。我研究音乐本身的本质以及它如何在文化和生物学上演变。我探讨了真正的专家与业余爱好者的区别，并揭穿了“音乐本能”的神话，同时表明天赋确实存在。

Along the way, I marvel at the wonder that is music and the human desire to create and enjoy it. I take a look at the nature of music itself and how it evolved culturally and biologically. I explore what separates true experts from mere amateurs and debunk the myth of a “music instinct” yet show that talent really does exist.

 

同时，我问学习音乐是否让人变得更聪明，并调查如何成为一名好老师。父母应该鼓励孩子弹奏真正的乐器，还是应该放松下来，让孩子弹《吉他英雄》？

At the same time, I ask whether learning music makes people smarter and investigate what it takes to be a good teacher. Should parents encourage their children to play real musical instruments, or should they relax and let their kids play Guitar Hero instead?

 

我一手拿着吉他，另一只手拿着笔记本电脑，开始了解人类重塑的局限性，以及人类，无论年轻还是年长，无论有才华还是其他，如何变得音乐。

With a guitar in one hand and a laptop in the other, I set out to understand the limits of human reinvention and how humans, young and old, talented or otherwise, become musical.

 

 

带我去河边

TAKE ME TO THE RIVER

 

制定计划

Forming a Plan

 

由于我的年龄和明显缺乏才能，很明显，采取小规模的方法是合适的。作为一名发展心理学家，我从日常工作中了解了自己对语言的了解，因此我强烈怀疑自己学习演奏乐器的唯一现实希望就是完全沉浸其中。我想，每隔一周演奏三分钟，我并没有比学习飞行更多的机会来成为音乐人。在沉浸式课程中学习第二语言的孩子比偶尔接触第二语言的孩子表现要好得多，这可能是因为人脑需要大量的接触才能学习任何复杂的东西，而且如果我们两次练习之间的时间太长，我们往往会忘记新的东西巩固我们所学知识的会议。像铃木方法这样的流行音乐教育范式基于沉浸式教育并非偶然，并且没有理由期望成年人能够免除高剂量定期接触的需要。

Between my age and my manifest lack of talent, it was clear that a bite-size approach was in order. Knowing what I do about language from my day job as a developmental psychologist, I also strongly suspected that my only realistic hope of learning to play an instrument was to become completely immersed. I figured that I had no more chance of becoming musical by playing three minutes every other week than I had of learning to fly. Kids who learn second languages in immersion programs do vastly better than kids with more occasional exposure, presumably because it takes the human brain a great deal of exposure to learn anything complicated, and we tend to forget the new stuff if we take too long between practice sessions to consolidate what we’ve learned. It is no accident that popular music education paradigms like the Suzuki method are based on immersion, and there is no reason to expect that adults would be exempt from the need for high doses of regular exposure.

为什么像音乐这样的技能需要如此深厚的奉献精神？

Why is it that skills like music require such profound dedication?

 

 

世界领先的专业知识专家、认知心理学家安德斯·埃里克森（Anders Ericsson）提到了成为任何领域专家的两个重要关键。首先是大量的练习。经常被引用的数字“十年”或“一万小时”是基于爱立信对从国际象棋到小提琴等领域的专家的研究。这并不是说一个人花五千个小时一事无成，但毫无疑问，练习和技能之间存在着很强的相关性。

The cognitive psychologist Anders Ericsson, the world’s leading expert on expertise, mentions two vital keys to becoming an expert in any domain. The first is a ton of practice. The oft-quoted figure “ten years” or “ten thousand hours” is based on Ericsson’s research into experts in domains ranging from chess to violin. This is not to say that one gets nowhere with five thousand hours, but there can be no doubt that there is a strong correlation between practice and skill.

但仅靠练习是不够的。成千上万的人在年轻时上过音乐课，但记忆很少或根本不记得。

But practice alone is not enough. Hundreds of thousands of people took music lessons when they were young and remember little or nothing.

 

专业知识的第二个先决条件是埃里克森所说的“刻意练习”，即一种持续的自我评价意识，关注自己的弱点，而不是简单地闲逛和发挥自己的优势。研究表明，旨在弥补弱点的实践比原始工作时间更能预测专业知识；为了好玩而重复你已经知道的事情并不一定能有效地达到新的水平。大多数人在大多数时候所做的大部分练习，无论是为了学习吉他还是提高高尔夫球水平，几乎没有效果。大多数学习者迟早会达到一个平台期，重复他们已经知道的内容，而不是与自己的弱点作斗争，此时进步就会变得缓慢。

The second prerequisite of expertise is what Ericsson calls “deliberate practice,” a constant sense of self-evaluation, of focusing on one’s weaknesses rather than simply fooling around and playing to one’s strengths. Studies show that practice aimed at remedying weaknesses is a better predictor of expertise than raw number of hours; playing for fun and repeating what you already know is not necessarily the same as efficiently reaching a new level. Most of the practice that most people do, most of the time, be it in the pursuit of learning the guitar or improving their golf game, yields almost no effect. Sooner or later, most learners reach a plateau, repeating what they already know rather than battling their weaknesses, at which point progress becomes slow.

 

埃里克森的刻意练习理念，不是随便乱搞，而是针对特定的弱点，这与一个被称为“最近发展区”的旧概念有一定关系，即当学生解决一些超出他或她能力范围的事情时，学习效果最好。目前达到的目标，既不太难也不太容易。例如，在课堂环境中，一组研究人员估计，最好的安排是让孩子们在大约 80% 的时间里取得成功；超过这个数，孩子们就会感到无聊；少了，他们往往会感到沮丧。对于成年人来说肯定也是如此，这就是为什么众所周知，视频游戏制造商会投资数百万美元进行游戏测试，以确保挑战级别始终处于既不太容易也不太困难的最佳位置。

Ericsson’s notion of practicing deliberately, not just fooling around but targeting specific weaknesses, bears some relation to an older concept known as the “zone of proximal development,” the idea that learning works best when the student tackles something that is just beyond his or her current reach, neither too hard nor too easy. In classroom situations, for example, one team of researchers estimated that it’s best to arrange things so that children succeed roughly 80 percent of the time; more than that, and kids tend to get bored; less, and they tend to get frustrated. The same is surely true of adults, too, which is why video game manufacturers have been known to invest millions in play testing to make sure that the level of challenge always lies in that sweet spot of neither too easy nor too hard.

 

 

我自己的旅程始于我们在行业中所说的试点研究——一项规模相对较小的探索性研究，旨在看看进一步的投资是否可能获得合理的回报：八月底的两周。我妻子的家人在加拿大拥有一座湖边小屋，我们几乎每年夏天都会去那里，我决定今年夏天我将把这两周的时间花在音乐上，而不是做其他事情。刚刚在《吉他英雄》中取得了小小的成功，距离我三十九岁生日还有六个月，我决定现在是时候了。

My own journey began with what we call in my trade a pilot study— a relatively small-scale exploratory study to see whether further investment might plausibly pay off: two weeks, at the end of August. My wife’s family owns a lakeside cottage in Canada, which we visit nearly every summer, and I decided that this summer I would devote those two weeks to music and nothing else. Fresh from my modest success with Guitar Hero, six months shy of my thirty-ninth birthday, I decided that now was the time.

到我们一年一度的夏季度假胜地时，我几乎带了我拥有的所有音乐设备。我不能玩并不意味着我不能买。我有一个卡西欧键盘、一把便宜的原声吉他（eBay 特价）和一小堆音乐书籍，其中包括《弹奏钢琴》！和完整的吉他演奏家，以及我手机上的一堆听力训练应用程序。我很认真地对待这种沉浸感：我每天练习，每天两个、三个、四个，甚至六个小时，大约一半弹钢琴，一半弹吉他。因为我是一个完全的初学者，所以我的目标只是熟悉一些音乐最基本的元素、单个音符，尤其是和弦，它们是三个或更多音符一起演奏的组合。*

To our annual summer retreat I brought nearly every piece of musical equipment I owned. Just because I couldn’t play didn’t mean I couldn’t buy. I had a Casio keyboard, a cheap acoustic guitar (an eBay special), and a small pile of books on music, including Play Piano in a Flash! and The Complete Guitar Player, along with a pile of ear-training applications on my cell phone. And I was serious about the immersion: I practiced every day, two, three, four, even six hours a day, roughly half on piano, half on guitar. Because I was a complete beginner, my goal was simply to become acquainted with some of music’s most basic elements, individual notes and, especially, chords, which are combinations of three or more notes played together.*

 

 

钢琴的基础知识相对容易；吉他很残酷。在钢琴上，很容易找到音符并形成基本和弦。每一个十二个键重复相同的基本模式。白键在重复之前弹奏音符 C、D、E、F、G、A 和 B；中间的黑键可演奏所谓的升号和降号，例如升 C 号和降 B 号。将手指放在 C、E 和 G 上，用这三个音符就形成了第一个和弦，即 C 大三和弦。通过一对简单的规则，演奏任何大调和弦和小调和弦变得相对容易。一个人总是可以形成一个大和弦，例如，从某个特定的音符（称为根音）开始，然后向右数四个键（包括黑色和白色），然后再向上三个键。

The rudiments of piano came relatively easy; guitar was brutal. On piano, it’s easy to find the notes and form the basic chords. Every twelve keys the same fundamental pattern repeats. The white keys play the notes C, D, E, F, G, A, and B before repeating; the black keys in between play the so-called sharps and flats, such as C-sharp and B-flat. Place your fingers on C, E, and G, and with those three notes you’ve formed your first chord, the C major triad. With a pair of simple rules it became relatively easy to play any of the major and minor chords. One can always form a major chord, for example, by starting with some particular note, known as the root, and then counting four keys (both black and white included) to the right, and then heading up three more.

例如，C 大调的构成是从 C 开始，到 E，最后以 G 结束。

C major, for example, is formed by starting with C, heading to E, and ending with G.

 

 

按照同样的规则，但从D开始，数到升F和A，就得到了D大调和弦中的三个音符：D、升F和A。看起来很简单。

Following the same rule but starting from D, one counts up to F-sharp and A, yielding the three notes in the chord of D major: D, F-sharp, and A. It seemed so simple.

 

尽管钢琴既简单又数学，但我知道它不适合我。我已经在键盘上度过了足够多的人生了。拨动吉他弦时那种身体上的亲密感吸引了我。吉他显然会更难入门，但在一两周内，我确信这是我真正想演奏的乐器。

As straightforward and mathematical as piano is, I knew it wasn’t the instrument for me. I had spent enough of my life at a keyboard already. Something about the physical intimacy of plucking guitar strings called to me. The guitar was obviously going to be harder to break into, but within a week or two I was convinced that it was the instrument I really wanted to play.

 

 

起初，我对自己的决定感到后悔。所有的事情，即使是像单独弹奏一个音符这样简单的事情，对吉他来说似乎都更困难。在钢琴上弹奏一个单独的音符只需敲击一个琴键，而在吉他上弹奏一个音符（除非是所谓的空弦）通常需要两个动作，每只手一个，同步协调。

At first, I regretted my decision. Everything, even something as simple as playing a single note all by itself, seemed harder on the guitar. Whereas playing an isolated note on a piano requires nothing more than striking a key, playing a single note on the guitar (unless it’s a so-called open string) generally requires two actions, one from each hand, coordinated in synchrony.

对于像我这样的惯用右手的人来说，左手负责按动，这意味着在正确的时间沿着吉他琴颈的正确位置按住正确的一组琴弦。品丝是横跨吉他琴颈狭窄宽度的细金属线。左手的任务是夹紧琴弦，靠近给定音品的上侧，而不是像初学者想象的那样，位于音品之间的中间，以尽量减少外部振动。与此同时，另一只手（对于惯用右手的人来说是右手）负责拨动或弹奏琴弦。（起初，这一切似乎都是倒退的，因为较弱的手必须将自己扭曲成各种快速的形状；只有当你开始幻想演奏弗拉门戈时，你才会看到右手的工作会变得多么困难。）

For a right-hander such as myself, the left hand does the job known as fretting, which means holding down the right set of strings at the right time at the right place along the neck of the guitar. Frets are the thin metal wires that run across the narrow width of a guitar’s neck. The left hand’s mission is to clamp the strings down, close to the upper side of a given fret— not halfway between frets, as a beginner might imagine— so as to minimize extraneous vibrations. Meanwhile, the other hand (right for a right-hander) has the job of plucking or strumming the strings. (At first this all seems backward, since the weaker hand has to contort itself into all sorts of rapid shapes; it’s only when you start fantasizing about playing flamenco that you see how hard the job of the right hand can become.)

 

演奏和弦甚至更加复杂，部分原因是您在任何时候只能在任何给定的弦上演奏一个音符；形成和弦需要你形成横跨多根弦的奇怪的左手形状。即使您知道如何在钢琴上形成大和弦的四合/三合数学，通常也不是很明显在哪里可以找到吉他上必要的音符；相反，初学者别无选择，只能记住一系列晦涩难懂的形状。即使一旦记住了手指应该放在哪里，同时按住所有手指，每个手指都完美对齐，而不会产生一种称为音调嗡嗡声的难闻噪音，这绝不是一件小事。在最初的几周里，光是这个挑战就似乎几乎不可逾越; 随着一首歌的节奏，我的手从一个和弦移到下一个和弦，这个想法似乎很滑稽。

Playing a chord is even more complicated, in part because you can play only one note on any given string at any one time; forming a chord requires you to form weird left-hand shapes that span across several strings. Even if you know the four-up/three-up mathematics of how to form a major chord on a piano, it’s often not at all immediately obvious where to find the requisite notes on the guitar; instead, the beginner has little choice but to memorize an obscure series of shapes. And even once one memorizes where one’s fingers are supposed to go, there is the by no means trivial matter of holding them all down at the same time, each perfectly aligned, without creating a foul noise known as fret buzz. For the first several weeks, that challenge alone seemed almost insurmountable; the idea of shifting my hand from one chord to the next in time with a song seemed almost comical.

 

但不知怎的，我并没有被吓倒。湖边的天气很好，让公婆们很开心的是，我每天都坚持练习，很少表现得好像我对自己在做什么有丝毫的了解。

Yet somehow I remained undeterred. The weather by the lake was nice, and much to the amusement of my in-laws, I kept at it, practicing every day— rarely appearing as if I had the slightest idea what I was doing.

 

 

几周后，我的第一个真正的突破出现了，当时，在去佛蒙特州一个小镇参加家庭聚会的路上，我在一家音乐商店停下来，翻阅了那里的吉他入门书籍部分。正是在那里，我发现了大卫·米德的速成课程：原声吉他。

My first real breakthrough came a couple weeks later, when, on a road trip to a family reunion in a small town in Vermont, I stopped in a music store and poked through its section of beginning guitar books. And it was there that I discovered David Mead’s Crash Course: Acoustic Guitar.

在接下来的 7 天里，米德的书成了我的圣经；我一次又一次地完成了它。米德没有灵丹妙药。弹吉他所需的手部扭曲仍然很困难，但他的“速成课程”将吉他分解成像我这样的老猫头鹰可以轻松消化的那种一口大小的小块。它让我更好地了解节奏的基础知识，并帮助我超越简单的和弦和孤立的音符，掌握更大单位（例如音阶）的重要性。

For the next seven days, Mead’s book became my bible; I worked through it exercise by exercise. Mead had no magic bullets; the contortions of the hand that the guitar required remained difficult, but his “crash course” broke guitar down into just the sort of bite-size morsels that an old owl like me could easily digest. It gave me a better sense of the basics of rhythm and helped me move beyond simple chords and isolated notes to grasp the significance of larger units, such as scales.

 

音阶是自然组合在一起的升序（或降序）音符组，传达特定的情绪或感觉，例如快乐的大调音阶或悲伤的小调音阶。最著名的音阶是 C 大调音阶，由钢琴键盘上的白色音符表示：C、D、E、F、G、A、B，然后回到 C（想想 do-re-mi-fa-sol-拉-蒂-多）。正如我后来发现的那样，不同的音阶会引发不同的情绪，部分原因是音符之间的关系不同，部分原因是每个音阶与不同音阶都有自己的一套强烈的文化关联。例如，歌曲“生日快乐”就是大调音阶的音符编排，而滚石乐队“Paint It Black”的令人难忘的旋律则是和声小调音阶的编排。

Scales are ascending (or descending) sets of notes that fit together naturally, conveying a particular mood or feel, such as the happy major scale or the sadder minor scale. The most famous scale is the C major scale, represented by the white notes on a piano keyboard: C, D, E, F, G, A, B, and back to C (think do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-do). As I was to discover later, different scales elicit different moods, in part because of the different relationships between notes and in part because each scale has its own set of strong cultural associations with different scales. The song “Happy Birthday,” for example, is an arrangement of notes from the major scale, while the haunting melody of the Rolling Stones’ “Paint It Black” is an arrangement of a scale known as the harmonic minor.

 

在初学者可能学习的音阶中，最简单的一种是蓝调小调五声音阶，仅由五个音符组成。我很快发现，小调五声音阶是摇滚乐和布鲁斯音乐的支柱，用于无数吉他独奏，从吉米·亨德里克斯的“Hey Joe”到 Dire Straits 的“Money for Nothing”。很快它就成为我音乐生活的主要内容，也是我有一天可能能够创作自己的音乐的第一个暗示。一旦我开始适应我的第一个音阶，我的摸索开始变得微弱的音乐性。我婆婆抬起头来。当她第一次听我的演奏时，即使只有几秒钟，我也觉得我终于明白了一些事情。

Among the scales a beginner might learn, one of the simplest is the bluesy minor pentatonic, which consists of just five notes. The minor pentatonic, I soon found out, is a mainstay of rock and roll and the blues, used in countless guitar solos, from Jimi Hendrix’s “Hey Joe” to Dire Straits’ “Money for Nothing.” Soon it became a staple of my musical life—and a first hint that I might someday be able to make up my own music. Once I began to be comfortable with my first scales, my fumblings started to become faintly musical. My mother-in-law looked up. When she listened to my playing for the first time, even if it was only for a few seconds, I felt I was finally on to something.

 

 

受此鼓舞，我放下了所有正在读的书，不再看电视，全身心投入到对音乐的追求中。我每天都坚持练习，甚至还买了一把旅行吉他，以便在从新西兰到阿布扎比的火车站和机场开讲课的路上继续练习。

Thus encouraged, I set aside all the books I was reading, stopped watching television, and devoted myself full-time to the pursuit of music. I committed myself to practicing every day, even buying a travel guitar so that I could keep practicing when I was on the road to give lectures, trundling it through train stations and airports from New Zealand to Abu Dhabi.

并喜欢其中的每一分钟。

And loved every minute of it.

 

无论出于何种意图和目的，学习音乐很快就成了一种瘾。每个新音符、每个新和弦、每个新音阶、每个新节奏都让我更接近我极度渴望的东西：创作自己音乐的能力。甚至像“小军鼓通常出现在二号和四号上”这样的基本观察也被视为启示。当我读到一些新的神经影像学研究表明，新知识可以带来与摄入强效可卡因相同的多巴胺激增时，我只能点头表示同意。随着别人的歌曲及时按下塑料按钮是一回事；创造我自己的音乐，这是一次冒险，似乎把我带入了一个新的地方：冥想、美丽、令人陶醉。

Learning about music soon became, for all intents and purposes, an addiction. Each new note, each new chord, each new scale, and each new rhythm brought me closer to something that I desperately longed for: the capacity to make my own music. Even basic observations like “the snare drum usually comes on the two and four” came as revelations. When I read some new neuroimaging studies that suggested that new knowledge can bring the same sort of surge of dopamine one might get by ingesting crack cocaine, I could only nod my head in agreement. Pressing plastic buttons in time with someone else’s song was one thing; creating my own music another, an adventure that seemed to bring me into a new place altogether: meditative, beautiful, intoxicating.

 

 

伴随着所有这些美丽而来的是其他东西：这是重新连接我自己的大脑的漫长过程的第一步。

Along with all that beauty came something else: a first step in what was to be a long process of rewiring my own brain.

德国神经科学家托马斯·埃尔伯特 (Thomas Elbert) 领导的神经心理学家团队将一系列不同的大脑成像技术结合在一起，以研究大脑对手指的表征发生了什么变化，这是最早检验音乐练习对大脑影响的研究之一。就像一个人学习演奏乐器一样。

One of the first studies to examine the effects of musical practice on the brain came when a team of neuropsychologists led by the German neuroscientist Thomas Elbert combined an array of different brain-imaging techniques together in order to investigate what happens to the brain’s representation of fingers as a person learns to play an instrument.

 

如果您上过心理学或神经科学课程，您可能会记得一张著名的图片，如下所示：*

If you have taken a class in psychology or neuroscience, you may recall a famous picture that looks like this:*

 

 

插图的要点是双重的。首先，这张图清楚地表明了这样一个事实：身体的每个部分在大脑中被称为初级运动皮层的区域都分配有一块特定的神经组织；其次，它还说明了这样一个事实：分配的皮质空间的确切数量因身体部位而异，越敏感的区域获得的脑组织就越多。手指和嘴唇受到的影响很大，但膝盖后部几乎没有。（您可以借助大头针和值得信赖的朋友来确认这一点。当朋友用大头针轻轻戳您时，闭上眼睛。在具有大量皮质表征的区域，您将能够轻松地区分紧密间隔的针刺；在光皮质表示，有时您将无法区分两个靠近但不相同的针孔。）

The point of the illustration is twofold. First, the picture makes clear the fact that each part of the body has a specific piece of neural tissue assigned to it in the area of the brain known as the primary motor cortex; second, it also illustrates the fact that the exact amount of cortical real estate allocated varies from one body part to the next, with more sensitive areas getting more brain tissue. Fingers and lips get a lot, the back of the knee hardly any. (You can confirm this with the aid of a pin and a trusted friend. Close your eyes as the friend gently pokes you with the pin. In areas with heavy cortical representation, you will be able to easily discriminate closely spaced pinpricks; in areas with light cortical representation, you will sometimes be unable to distinguish two pinpricks that are close together but not identical.)

 

迈克尔·梅泽尼奇 (Michael Merzenich) 和其他人的早期工作表明，这些区域之间的界限并不完全固定。例如，一只失去中指的猴子可能会将分配给中指的一些初级皮层重新分配给相邻的手指。同样，对于先天性失明的人来说，大脑有时最终会带走一些通常用于视觉的神经组织，并将其用于听觉。音乐练习是否可以类似地重塑大脑？

Earlier work by Michael Merzenich and others had shown that the boundaries between these areas aren’t entirely fixed; a monkey that lost its middle finger, for example, might reallocate some of the primary cortex that was assigned to its middle finger to an adjacent finger. Similarly, in people who are born congenitally blind, the brain sometimes winds up taking some of the neural tissue that would normally be used for vision and using it for hearing. Could music practice similarly rewire the brain?

 

确实可以。埃尔伯特和他的团队以九名弦乐演奏者（六名大提琴手、两名小提琴手和一名吉他手）为对象，发现弦乐演奏者将异常大量的皮层表征分配给了他们选择音符的左手手指，这可能会产生两个好处。首先，它使弦乐演奏者能够更好地控制手指，其次，它可能使他们对手指收到的反馈更加敏感，使他们能够更准确地了解手指的位置，甚至给定弦的拉紧程度对于弹奏正确的触感至关重要。

Indeed it could. Focusing on nine string players (six cellists, two violinists, and a guitarist), Elbert and his team discovered that string players dedicated an unusually large amount of cortical representation to the fingers of their note-selecting left hands, likely yielding two benefits. First, it gives string players greater control of their fingers, and second, it may make them more sensitive to the feedback that their fingers receive, allowing them a more precise mental picture of where their fingers are, and even of how taut a given string is—vital for playing with the correct touch.

 

从那时起，数十项研究进一步推进了埃尔伯特的基本结论，即音乐家的大脑与非音乐家的大脑不同，不仅在感觉运动皮层上，而且在其他大脑区域，例如颞平面（听觉皮层后面的一个区域，与音调感知有关）、小脑（与节奏有关）和胼胝体的前部（前部），胼胝体是连接大脑两侧的厚纤维组。大脑，也许是因为它在协调左右手方面的作用。

Since then, dozens of studies have furthered Elbert’s basic conclusion, that the brains of musicians differ from those of nonmusicians, and not just in the sensorimotor cortex but also in other brain areas such as the planum temporale (an area just behind the auditory cortex that is implicated in pitch perception), the cerebellum (implicated in rhythm), and the anterior (frontward) part of the corpus callosum, the thick set of fibers that connects the two sides of the brain, perhaps because of its role in coordinating the left and the right hands.

 

为了与这些物理差异保持一致，音乐家的大脑对音乐相关参数的轻微偏差反应更加敏感，例如音高、节奏和音色（区分一种乐器与另一种乐器的声音特性，例如小提琴的声音与声音）长笛）。音乐家和非音乐家之间的差异部分取决于音乐家选择的乐器。小提琴手的大脑对小提琴的声音特别敏感，而小号手的大脑似乎专门针对小号。歌剧歌手在代表发声器官和喉部的初级体感皮层部分表现出专门化。（人们只能对普林斯感到好奇，他以演奏吉他、键盘、贝斯、鼓、萨克斯管和口琴而闻名。）

In keeping with these physical differences, the brains of musicians respond more sensitively to slight deviations in musically relevant parameters such as pitch, rhythm, and timbre (the sonic properties differentiating one instrument from the next, such as the sound of a violin versus the sound of a flute). The differences between musicians and nonmusicians depend in part on a musician’s instrument of choice; the brains of violinists are especially sensitive to the sounds of violins, and the brains of trumpeters appear to be specialized for trumpet. Opera singers show specializations in the part of the primary somatosensory cortex that represents vocal articulators and the larynx. (One can only wonder about Prince, who has been known to play guitar, keyboards, bass, drums, saxophone, and harmonica.)

 

 

这些研究都提出了一个重要的问题，对于像我这样的初学者来说尤其重要：音乐家的大脑之所以不同，是因为他们生来如此，还是因为他们投入了所有的时间练习？关于最初的差异（这可能代表了通俗称为天赋的生理基础），目前还没有人确切知道，但最近的一项研究非常清楚地表明，练习确实至少会导致神经差异。

These studies all raise an important question, especially salient for a beginner like me: Are musicians’ brains different because they are born that way or because of all the hours they put into practicing? With respect to initial differences (which could represent a physiological basis for what is colloquially known as talent), nobody yet knows for sure, but one recent study made it very clear that practice does indeed at least contribute to neural differences.

哈佛大学神经科学家戈特弗里德·施劳格 (Gottfried Schlaug) 领导的团队从五岁开始对两组儿童进行了两年的追踪，其中一半正在学习乐器（钢琴或小提琴），另一半则没有。一开始，参加课程的孩子和没有参加课程的孩子之间没有明显的差异。只是十五个月后，已经出现了明显的神经变化：参加课程的孩子——尤其是那些进行过广泛练习的孩子——在控制手部运动的大脑区域、胼胝体以及被称为赫施尔听觉区的右侧初级听觉区域表现出更大的生长。回。练习可能并不完美，但它绝对对大脑有影响。

A team led by the Harvard neuroscientist Gottfried Schlaug tracked two groups of children for two years, starting at the age of five, half of whom were taking lessons in a musical instrument (piano or violin) and half of whom weren’t. At the outset, there were no apparent differences between the kids who took lessons and those who didn’t. Just fifteen months later, there were already clear neural changes: children who took lessons— especially those who had practiced extensively— showed greater growth in the brain regions that control hand movements, in the corpus callosum, and in a right primary auditory area known as Heschl’s gyrus. Practice might not make perfect, but it definitely has an effect on the brain.

 

当然，实践的证据并不是反对天赋的证据。施劳格可能有最好的证据证明练习的重要性，但他也为天赋留下了空间。当我问起他自己孩子的情况时，他毫不犹豫。他说，练习很重要，但每个孩子找到适合他或她天赋的乐器仍然很重要。音乐家的大脑很可能与音乐水平较低的同行不同，原因有两个，而不是一个：练习和天赋。

Of course, evidence for practice is not evidence against inborn talent. Schlaug might have the best evidence for the importance of practice, but he still leaves room for talent, too. When I asked him about his own children, he didn’t hesitate. Practice matters, he said, but it was still important that each child find a musical instrument that was a good fit to his or her innate talents. In all likelihood, the brains of musicians differ from those of less musical counterparts for two reasons, not one: both practice and talent.

 

当然，大脑研究也反映在行为中。这不仅是因为音乐家的胼胝体较厚，而且是因为他们的胼胝体较厚。他们的大脑更擅长理解音乐，例如检测音高差异和节奏的细微变化。在五到七岁儿童的大脑成像研究中，儿童大脑变化的程度与行为变化的程度相关。在运动技能以及旋律和节奏辨别力的测试中，参加音乐课的孩子很快就超过了没有参加音乐课的孩子，而在这些任务上表现出最大进步的孩子是那些大脑变化最大的孩子。

Brain studies have, of course, reflections in behavior. It’s not just that musicians have thicker corpora callosa; it’s that their brains are better at comprehending music, in processes such as detecting differences in pitch and slight variations in rhythm. In the brain-imaging study of five-to seven-year-olds, the magnitude of children’s brain changes correlated with the size of behavioral changes. In tests of motor skills and melodic and rhythmic discrimination, kids who took music lessons quickly overtook kids who didn’t, and the kids who showed the most improvement on these tasks were the ones whose brains changed the most.

 

 

总而言之，有抱负的音乐家必须掌握至少三套不同的技能。他们必须发展自己的耳朵和大脑，以便能够识别旋律（作为歌曲前景的基本曲调）和和声（作为伴奏）。他们必须掌握时间、节奏和节奏。他们必须协调他们的肌肉，他们的两只手协调在一起的速度，在钢琴上可以在一分钟内接近一千八百个音符（在复杂的和弦中，双手的每个手指都在全职工作）。关键在于，最终所有这些技能必须很好地整合在一起，以便它们可以在任何一首单独的音乐作品的整个过程中同时、连续地演奏。

All told, aspiring musicians must master at least three distinct sets of skills. They must develop their ears and brains so that they can recognize melodies (the basic tunes that serve as a song’s foreground) and harmonies (which serve as accompaniment). They must master time, tempo, and rhythm. And they must harmonize their muscles, coordinating their two hands together at a rate that on a piano can approach eighteen hundred notes in a minute (in complex chords, wherein every digit of both hands works full-time). The kicker is that ultimately all of these skills must be so well integrated that they can all be performed simultaneously, and continuously, throughout the course of any individual piece of music.

工程师可能会将这种分类称为任务分析；我认为这是一个巨大的挑战。必须完成的大脑重新布线的数量几乎是巨大的。我迫切希望所有这些神经重新布线都有捷径，但作为一名认知心理学家，我知道得更清楚。流畅地演奏需要重新连接我的整个大脑，从颞叶到前额皮质，这是没有办法解决的。是时候开始破解了。

Engineers might call this taxonomy a task analysis; I’d call it a gigantic challenge. The sheer amount of brain rewiring that must be done is almost overwhelming. I wished desperately that there were shortcuts to all that neural rewiring, but as a cognitive psychologist I knew better. Playing smoothly would entail rewiring my whole brain, from my temporal lobes to my prefrontal cortex, and there was no way around that. It was time to get cracking.

 

*正如我后来了解到的，一些吉他手扩展了和弦的定义，以包括某些音符对，例如“强力和弦”（参见词汇表），既不是大调也不是小调，而是介于两者之间，这给摇滚和重金属带来了它们侵略性的感觉。

* As I was to learn later, some guitarists extend the definition of chords to include certain pairs of notes, such as the “power chords” (see glossary), neither major nor minor but somewhere in between, that give rock and heavy metal their aggressive feel.

*细心的读者会注意到，这个 G 级版本的感觉运动皮层中没有生殖器。幸运的是，对于我们物种的繁殖来说，生殖器在触觉空间的神经表征中得到了相当大的覆盖。

* The careful reader will note the absence of genitals in this G-rated version of the sensorimotor cortex. Luckily for the reproduction of our species, the genitals receive considerable coverage in the neural representation of haptic space.

 

学习爬行

LEARNING TO CRAWL

 

音乐是植入大脑的吗？

Is Music Built into the Brain?

 

即使在婴儿第一次见到阳光之前，他或她可能已经被音乐包围了几个月。可以肯定的是，音质有点令人沮丧。低音相对容易听见，但大部分高音会在胎儿周围的羊水中消失；这几乎就像婴儿在游泳池底部听音乐一样。不过，低保真比无保真要好。学习声音和音乐的过程早在婴儿开始自主呼吸之前就开始了。即使抛开从外界传来的任何经过过滤的声音，也有很多东西可以听：心跳、呼吸和准妈妈声音的规律调制，这些声音部分通过骨传导在内部传播。到最后三个月结束时，成长中的胎儿开始吸收至少一些所经历的东西。

Even before a baby first sees the light of day, he or she is likely to have been surrounded by music for months. To be sure, the sound quality is kind of dismal. Bass sounds are relatively audible, but most of the treble gets lost in the amniotic fluid that surrounds the growing fetus; it is almost as if the baby were listening to music from the bottom of a swimming pool. Still, lo-fi is better than no-fi. The process of learning about sound and music starts long before the baby begins to breathe on its own. Even putting aside whatever filtered sounds pass through from the outside world, there’s plenty to listen to: heartbeats, breathing, and the regular modulations of the expecting mother’s voice, which travels on the inside in part through bone conduction. And by the end of the final trimester, the growing fetus begins to take in at least some of what comes through.

无论是基因的产物还是早期经验的产物，或者（更有可能）两者兼而有之，人类音乐性的一些先驱在生命的早期就出现了。但有多少音乐被植入我们的基因组呢？我们的音乐性有多少是通过课程、练习和聆听来之不易的？

Whether as a product of genes or early experience, or (more likely) both, some of the precursors of human musicality emerge very early in life. But how much of music is wired into our genomes? And how much of our musicality is hard-won, through lessons, practice, and listening?

 

 

如今，谈论人类时很流行一种说法，就好像我们生来就具有“音乐本能”，类似于诺姆·乔姆斯基和史蒂文·平克所说的我们与生俱来的语言本能。

It is very popular these days to talk about humans as if we were born with a “music instinct,” akin to the language instinct that Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker suggest we are born with.

但流行的东西并不总是正确的。乍一看，我们可能生来就有音乐本能的观点似乎很有道理。例如，匈牙利神经科学家伊斯特万·温克勒 (István Winkler) 在一项研究中表明，熟睡的新生儿的大脑可以向识别所谓的相对音高迈出第一步，在相对音高中，音乐不是根据确切的频率而是根据之间的间隙来理解的。笔记。当婴儿在一系列较小的跳跃中听到较大的音乐跳跃时，他们的大脑会表现出常见的惊讶程度。

But what is popular is not always true. At first glance, the notion that we might be born with a music instinct seems pretty plausible. In one study, for example, the Hungarian neuroscientist István Winkler showed that the brains of sleeping newborns could make a first step toward recognizing so-called relative pitch, in which music is understood not in terms of exact frequencies but in terms of the gaps between notes. When infants heard large musical leaps amid a series of smaller leaps, their brains displayed a common measure of surprise.

 

在另一项研究中，温克勒和他的同事表明，清醒的新生儿的大脑对低音底鼓突然消失的反应不同，而低音鼓是重复的四拍长鼓模式。在第三项研究中，他们发现婴儿的大脑似乎能够识别音色的变化，或者当一个音高由多个乐器演奏时。我们还知道新生儿可以区分协和音（和弦的音符平滑地融合在一起）和不协和音（和弦的音符相互冲突）。但这些基础知识与对音乐的真正理解并不相同，后者在未来的几周、几个月和几年中缓慢地展开。

In another study, Winkler and his associates showed that the brains of awake newborns responded differently to the sudden absence of bass kick drum in an otherwise repetitive four-beat-long drum pattern. In a third study, they found that infants’ brains appear to recognize changes in timbre, or when a single pitch is played by more than one instrument. We also know newborns can distinguish consonance (in which the notes of a chord blend together smoothly) from dissonance (in which the notes of a chord clash). But these rudiments aren’t the same as a genuine understanding of music, which unfolds more slowly, over the weeks, months, and years that are yet to come.

 

另一个早期里程碑大约在两个月大时到来，这是第一个审美偏好：到那时，婴儿已经开始更喜欢听和谐音而不是不和谐音，而不仅仅是区分两者。（有趣的是，一项研究表明，幼年黑猩猩也可能更喜欢和谐音而不是不和谐音，尽管它们对音乐的整体兴趣水平较低，这也许表明和谐音和不和谐音之间的差异更多地与灵长类动物大脑如何工作的动态，而不是音乐本身固有的任何东西。）

Another early milestone arrives by about the age of two months, a first aesthetic preference: by then, infants have begun to prefer listening to consonance rather than dissonance, and not just to distinguish between the two. (Intriguingly, one study suggests that infant chimpanzees, too, may prefer consonance to dissonance, even though their overall interest level in music is low, perhaps suggesting that the difference between consonance and dissonance has more to do with the dynamics of how primate brains work than with anything intrinsic to music per se.)

 

大约六七个月时，婴儿开始对旋律的形状变得敏感。如果有足够的接触，他们可以检测到音符何时发生变化，识别短旋律，即使它的音高已向上或向下移调，有时甚至可以记住几个星期的旋律。

By around six or seven months, infants start to become sensitive to the shapes of melodies. Given enough exposure, they can detect when a note has changed, recognize a short melody even when it has been transposed upward or downward in pitch, and sometimes remember melodies for weeks.

 

在某些方面，小婴儿甚至可以发现自己领先于成年人，尤其是在进行精细的听觉区分方面。例如，一项研究表明，十个月大的婴儿比成年人更能注意到在他们自己的文化中不常见的节奏偏差，这一发现与语言有直接的相似之处，小婴儿对某些语言很敏感。其文化中的成年人无法识别的语言差异。例如，年幼的日本儿童可能能够区分l和r的声音，而他们的父母则无法区分。

In some ways, young infants can even find themselves ahead of adults, especially in making fine auditory distinctions. One study, for instance, suggests that ten-month-olds are better able than adults to notice deviations in rhythms that aren’t common in their own culture, a finding that has a direct parallel in language, where young infants are sensitive to some linguistic distinctions that adults in their cultures can’t recognize. Young Japanese children, for example, might distinguish the sounds of l versus r where their parents can’t.

 

一些研究人员甚至认为，婴儿生来就有完美或绝对的音高，也就是说，有能力识别任何给定音符的确切频率，至少在相对不具有音乐性的音符序列中是这样。但这样的观察是有争议的，婴儿当然不具备某些受过训练的音乐家那样的绝对音高。经过训练的具有绝对音高的成年人不仅可以识别音符，还可以命名它；没有婴儿能做到同样的事情。（当然，许多婴儿长大后会音盲或节奏受损，这可能是由于基因的融合和音乐经验不足，而几乎所有正常的孩子都设法掌握他们的母语。）

A few researchers have even argued that babies are born with perfect or absolute pitch, that is, the capacity to recognize the exact frequency of any given note, at least in relatively unmusical sequences of notes. But such observations are controversial, and babies certainly don’t have absolute pitch in the sense that some trained musicians do. Trained adults with absolute pitch can not only recognize a note but name it; no infant can do the same. (And of course many infants grow up to be tone-deaf or rhythmically impaired, perhaps because of a confluence of genes and inadequate musical experience— whereas virtually all normal children manage to master their native language.)

 

 

所有这些都让音乐本能的想法在哪里？尽管对于大多数孩子来说，大多数时候，节奏和音调的基础知识在生命的第一年结束时就已经就位，但最初的敏感性很小节奏和音高不是交响乐的组成部分。当谈到人类生来就有“音乐本能”的概念时，实际上有几个理由持怀疑态度。

Where does all of this leave the idea of a music instinct? Although for most kids, most of the time, the rudiments of both rhythm and pitch are in place by the end of the first year of life, a small initial sensitivity to rhythm and pitch does not a symphony make. When it comes to the notion of humans being born with a “music instinct,” there are in fact several reasons for skepticism.

首先也是最重要的事实是，无论哪种音乐的基础可能是与生俱来的，对于大多数人来说，从那里到任何被认为是系统音乐的东西都是一个漫长而艰难的过程。即使一般的婴儿只需要几个月的时间就能认识到他或她自己文化的音乐的一些基本节奏，但大多数孩子直到至少有两个音符时才真正意识到存在离散音符的事实 - 如果那时。尽管偶尔有一些五岁的神童拥有罕见的完美音高现象并设法通过耳朵学习弹钢琴，但大多数孩子在早期都遇到了困难。

First and foremost is the fact that no matter which rudiments of music might be inborn, for most people it is a long, hard slog from there to anything recognizable as systematic music. Even if it takes your average baby only a few months to recognize some of the basic rhythms of his or her own culture’s music, most children don’t really work out the fact that there are discrete notes until they are at least two— if then. Notwithstanding the occasional five-year-old prodigy who possesses the rare phenomenon of perfect pitch and manages to learn to play piano by ear, most children struggle early on.

 

例如，当谈到唱歌时，幼儿经常在音符之间颤抖，而不落在任何特定的位置，产生一种走调的声音，听起来有点像小提琴初学者。最终，大多数（但不是全部）孩子开始掌握歌曲的总体轮廓，例如歌曲何时开始高音和低音结束，但即便如此，大多数孩子仍然经常错过许多单独的音符。（就我自己而言，音高完全是个谜；我通过歌词记住了歌曲，但我基本上忘记了曲调。）

When it comes to singing, for example, toddlers often warble between notes without landing in any particular spot, yielding a kind of out-of-tuneness that sounds a bit like a beginning violinist. Eventually, most (but not all) kids start to grasp the general contours of songs, such as when a song starts high and ends low, but even then most kids often miss many of the individual notes. (In my own case, pitch was a complete mystery; I remembered songs by their lyrics, but I was largely oblivious to the tune.)

 

我们的耳朵也需要数年的时间才能发育。即使是基础知识，比如认识到大和弦听起来更快乐，小和弦听起来更悲伤，也可能需要很多孩子直到学前班结束。更微妙的能力，比如检测出乎意料的和弦，而不是明显跑调的和弦，发展速度甚至更慢。孩子们也很难注意到前景旋律背后的背景和声，甚至可能不会注意到背景和声是否不和谐。

It also takes our ears years to develop. Even basics, like recognizing that major chords tend to sound happier and minor chords sound sad, can take many kids until the end of the preschool years. More subtle capacities, like detecting chords that are merely unexpected rather than blatantly out of key, develop at an even slower pace. Children also have trouble paying attention to a background harmony that looms behind a foreground melody and may not even notice if the background harmony is dissonant.

 

节奏并不容易，任何参加过幼儿园圣诞盛会的人都可以证明这一点。虽然婴儿在七个月大的时候就可以随着音乐跳舞，但他们要到几年后才能随着音乐跳舞。归根结底，孩子们最初的努力唱，这通常是他们制作音乐的第一次尝试，通常令人钦佩，但很少特别具有音乐性。即使孩子们到了小学，大约一半的孩子仍然只理解歌曲的大致轮廓，而不是将歌曲视为特定音高的集合；对于许多孩子来说，准确的旋律感是在小学时期才形成的（对于那些天赋较差的人来说，如果有的话，则要晚得多）。掌握保持调性的能力通常需要数年时间。用一篇学术文章中礼貌但严厉的话说，“孩子们进入学校时就带有明显的学习歌曲歌词的倾向，但他们学习和重现歌曲旋律成分的能力却与此不相匹配。” 对于我们中的一些人来说，这些挣扎一直持续到成年。当我开始整个项目时，我的妻子将我在唱歌方面的努力描述为“可爱但跑调”。（后来我发现，我并不孤单：至少有 10% 到 15% 的人从未学过调性唱歌。）

Rhythm is no easier, as anyone who’s ever been to a nursery school Christmas pageant can attest. Although babies can bop along to music by the time they’re seven months old, they can’t bop in time to music until a few years later. In the final analysis, children’s first efforts to sing, which is often their first attempt at producing music, are often admirable but rarely especially musical. Even when children reach grade school, about half still understand only the broad contours of songs, rather than seeing songs as collections of specific pitches; a precise sense of melody comes late, in grade school for many children (and much later, if ever, for people less gifted). Mastering the ability to stay in key often takes years. In the polite but damning words of one academic article, “children enter school with a clear disposition towards learning the words of songs [that] is not matched by an ability to learn and reproduce the melodic components of [those] songs.” And for some of us, these struggles persist well into adulthood. When I started this whole project, my wife described my efforts at singing as “cute but tuneless.” (As I later discovered, I was not alone: at least 10 to 15 percent of the population never learn to sing in key.)

 

 

与其他一些生物相比，例如斑胸草雀等鸣禽，人类早年并没有那么令人印象深刻。当一只年轻的斑胸草雀年满九十天时，它已经学会了唱自己的歌曲，风格是从导师那里听到的，具有扎实的节奏感和音高感——而年轻的斑胸草雀就能做到这一切没有任何明显的纠正或反馈。很少有人能说出同样的话。虽然几乎每个三岁的孩子都掌握了自己的母语，但有很多三十三岁的孩子却无法凭着纸袋唱歌。例如，还有一些证据表明鸟类比大多数人类具有更好的音高感。与此同时，人类无需音乐也可以过上完全正常的生活。据说美国第二十六任总统西奥多·罗斯福很有趣，西格蒙德·弗洛伊德可能也是如此。无法唱歌的雄性斑胸草雀很难找到伴侣。

Compared with some other creatures, such as songbirds like the zebra finch, human beings just aren’t that impressive in their early years. By the time a young zebra finch reaches the age of ninety days, it has learned to sing its own song, styled on one it hears from a tutor, with a solid sense of rhythm and pitch— and the young zebra finch manages all of this without any obvious correction or feedback. Few humans can say the same. Whereas nearly every three-year-old masters his or her native language, there are plenty of thirty-three-year-olds who can’t sing their way out of a paper bag. There is also some evidence, for example, that birds have a better sense of pitch than most humans. At the same time, humans can lead perfectly normal lives without being musical. Theodore Roosevelt, twenty-sixth president of the United States, is said to have been amusical, and Sigmund Freud may have been, too. A male zebra finch that was unable to sing would be hard-pressed to find a mate.

所有这些对于我们生来就有音乐本能的假设来说有点糟糕。更糟糕的是我们大多数人在努力掌握乐器的过程中面临着巨大的挑战。尽管有大批六岁的孩子尝试拉小提琴，但绝大多数人除了他们的血亲之外，对任何人来说听起来都不是那么好。鼓手通常需要数年的时间才能学会独立移动他们的四肢，而吉他手（正如我开始意识到的那样）需要花费很多时间才能学会顺利地改变和弦。人类显然比黑猩猩或猴子对音乐有更多的天生兴趣，但与普通的椋鸟或反舌鸟相比，人类的孩子远不及班级的前列。

All of this is a bit bad for the hypothesis that we are born with a music instinct. Even worse is the enormous challenge that most of us face in our efforts to master musical instruments. Although there are legions of six-year-olds trying to play violin, the vast majority don’t sound that good to anyone but their blood relatives. Drummers typically take years to learn to move their limbs independently, and guitarists (as I was starting to realize) take many moons to learn to change chords smoothly. Humans clearly have much more innate interest in music than do chimpanzees or monkeys, but compared with your average starling or mockingbird, human children are nowhere near the front of the class.

 

我们擅长的地方是后来；如果我们人类下定决心，我们几乎可以比我们的动物亲属做得更好。凭借我们在语言、文化、教学和闲暇时间方面的天赋，如果我们努力工作，我们就能真正擅长某件事；没有歌手能够创作巴赫或贝多芬的交响曲。但是，如果说我们当中最有才华的人能够创作出伟大的艺术作品，如果他们将一生奉献给这种追求，这与说普通人真正具有与生俱来的音乐天赋并不是一回事。一个很好的类比可能是滑雪：人类肯定可以学会在崎岖不平的冰雪覆盖的山坡上高速滑行——如果他们进行练习的话——但这并不意味着我们生来就知道如何绕过大亨。

Where we excel is later; if we humans set our minds to it, we can do almost anything intellectual better than our animal kin. Drawing on our gifts of language, culture, teaching, and leisure time, we can get really good at something if we work hard at it; no songbird will ever compose the symphonies of Bach or Beethoven. But saying that the most talented among us can produce great works of art if they devote their lives to that pursuit is not the same thing as saying that the average Joe is genuinely born with a gift for music. A good analogy might be skiing: human beings can surely learn to zip down bumpy snow-covered hills at high speeds— if they put the practice in— but that doesn’t mean we are born knowing how to carve around moguls.

 

 

事后看来，音乐惯例很大程度上是后天习得的，而不是根深蒂固的，这一点并不令人感到意外。在语言学中，有许多候选语言的详细和特定方面可能是跨文化通用的，例如词性。相比之下，在音乐中，共性却少之又少，而且往往非常微弱。例如，大多数音乐可能围绕某种中心声音展开，但西方的“调性”概念并不典型。音阶通常包含不超过六个或七个音符（可能作为函数（人类记忆的限制），但常见的半音阶有十二个，一些作曲家已经尝试将音阶分成十九个等分。大多数音乐都是围绕节奏组织的，但宣叙调却不是。即使是像旋律这样看似基本的东西，在歌曲的过程中音符从一个音高变化到另一个音高，也不是所有形式的音乐都常见的；有些音乐几乎完全基于节奏，音调最多是事后的想法。事实上，现代听众认为理所当然的一些东西——比如大调和弦、小调和弦，以及和声的整个概念——在世界上许多音乐体系中都是不存在的。强有力的普遍语法是有道理的，但音乐本身可能没有什么特殊的语法。

In hindsight, the idea that the conventions of music are largely learned rather than hardwired shouldn’t entirely come as a surprise. In linguistics, there are many candidates for detailed and specific aspects of language that might be cross-culturally universal, like parts of speech. In music, by contrast, universals are few and far between— and often very weak. Most music may, for example, revolve around some sort of central sound, but the Western notion of “tonality” is hardly typical. Scales generally contain no more than six or seven notes (possibly as a function of human memory limitations), but the common chromatic scale has twelve, and some composers have experimented with dividing the scale into nineteen equal divisions. Most music is organized around rhythms, but recitatives are not. Even something as seemingly basic as a melody in which notes change from one pitch to another over the course of a song is not common to all forms of music; some music is based almost entirely around rhythm, with pitch at most an afterthought. Indeed, some of the things that modern listeners take for granted— like major and minor chords, and the whole notion of harmony— are absent in many of the world’s musical systems. There’s a case to be made for a strong universal grammar, but there may be little that is specifically innate about music.

 

如果音乐是我们学习的东西，而不是直接源于本能的东西，那仍然并不意味着婴儿必须从头开始他们的音乐之旅。在我们星球上的所有物种中，人类在很多方面都很特殊。我们可能不是最强壮或最快的，但我们非常擅长将旧的脑组织重新用于新的任务。例如，阅读并不是与生俱来的，也不是在我们的进化过程中直接选择的。它只有大约五千年的历史，而我们这个物种的历史可以追溯到几百万年前。但阅读利用了一组早于阅读本身的电路，例如用于检测单词声音、识别精细视觉细节以及在不同感官之间建立联系的电路。

If music is something that we learn, rather than something that falls directly out of a hardwired instinct, that still doesn’t mean that babies must start their musical voyages from scratch. Among all the species on our planet, humans are special in many ways; we may not be the strongest or the fastest, but we are exceptionally good at repurposing old bits of brain tissue toward new tasks. Reading, for example, is not innate, and was not directly selected for over the course of our evolution; it’s only about five thousand years old, and our species has a history that goes back millions of years. But reading draws on a set of circuits that predate reading itself, like circuits for detecting the sounds of words, recognizing fine visual detail, and drawing connections between different senses.

当我们听音乐时，我们从大脑颞叶皮层（或多或少位于耳后）的电路开始，几乎所有其他灵长类动物（从猴子到黑猩猩）都共享这些电路。无论您是捕食者还是猎物，良好的音调感以及声音随时间变化的感觉都可以帮助您导航和识别危险。与我们的大脑重新利用旧电路的这一概念相一致音乐的一个事实是，大脑用于声学区分的工具比单独音乐所需的工具要精确得多。结果是，即使我们生来不是为了听音乐，我们也拥有充足的工具来帮助我们完成这项工作。

When we listen to music, we start with circuits in the temporal cortex of the brain (more or less behind the ear) that we share with virtually all other primates, ranging from monkeys to chimpanzees. Whether you are predator or prey, a good sense of pitch and of how sounds change over time can help you navigate and identify danger. Consistent with this notion of our brain repurposing old circuitry for music is the fact that the brain’s tools for acoustic differentiation are far more precise than would be necessary for music alone. The upshot is that even if we aren’t born to listen to music, we are well stocked with tools that can help make that job manageable.

 

人类获取音乐的能力很可能不仅来自于良好的耳朵，还来自于其他三种才能。第一个是通过文化和教学吸收知识的一般能力，伴随着有时悠闲的生活方式，使我们有时间掌握新技能——从制作石器（就像我们的祖先那样）到玩俄罗斯方块，再到使用说明书驾驶汽车传播。第二个是与其他哺乳动物共享的神经结构，它本质上寻求不同类型的感官信息（例如声音和运动）之间的联系。例如，婴儿可以识别出他们听到的元音何时与伴随面部的嘴巴动作匹配（或不匹配）。

In all probability, humans’ capacity for acquiring music probably derives not just from good ears but also from a trio of other talents. The first is a general ability to soak up knowledge through culture and teaching, accompanied by a sometimes leisurely lifestyle that allows us the time to master new skills— from making stone tools (as our ancestors did) to playing Tetris to driving cars with a manual transmission. The second is a neural architecture, shared with other mammals, that inherently seeks links between different types of sensory information, such as sound and motion. Babies, for instance, can recognize when a vowel that they listen to matches (or fails to match) the mouth movements of an accompanying face.

 

第三？我们的语言天赋。

The third? Our gift for language.

 

语言和音乐一样，在很大程度上取决于节奏，也取决于补偿音高差异的能力。例如，我们需要识别单词的音调，无论是低音男中音（想想达斯维德）还是米老鼠假声。我们调换音乐的能力——识别以两种不同调演唱的旋律——很可能是我们天生识别语音能力的副产品，而不是某种音乐进化的直接产物。对于节奏和音高来说，情况可能也是如此。

Language, like music, depends heavily on rhythm, and also on the ability to compensate for differences in pitch. We need to recognize words, for example, at whatever pitch they are uttered, whether in a low baritone (think Darth Vader) or in a Mickey Mouse falsetto. Our ability to transpose music— to recognize a melody sung in two different keys— could well be a by-product of our inborn capacity to recognize speech, rather than a direct product of some sort of musical evolution. The same may turn out to be true for rhythm and pitch.

 

 

那么，一个合乎逻辑的问题是，在每个孩子的一生中，语言先于音乐还是语言先于音乐呢？

A logical question, then, is about which comes first in the lifetime of an individual child, does language precede music or the other way around?

令人惊讶的是，只有两项研究直接提出了这个问题。第一个结果表明，如果有选择，婴儿更喜欢母亲的声音而不是器乐。唯一的其他研究来自我自己的实验室同样证明儿童的主要吸引力是言语而不是音乐。在我们的实验中，我们有一个正在进行的项目，研究七个月大的婴儿以及他们如何识别抽象模式，例如la ta ta等一串音节中出现的abb模式。在语言方面，婴儿学得很快：听完《la ta ta, ga na na》配乐两分钟后，他们就能轻松地区分wo fe fe（同样的老abb故事）和wo fe wo（新的aba结构）。

Surprisingly, only two studies have directly asked this question. The first showed that, given a choice, infants prefer their mother’s voice to instrumental music. The only other study comes from my own lab and equally attests to children’s chief attraction being to speech rather than to music. In our experiments, we had an ongoing project studying seven-month-old infants and how they come to recognize abstract patterns, such as the abb pattern that is present in a string of syllables like la ta ta. When it comes to speech, infants are quick learners: after just two minutes of hearing a la ta ta, ga na na soundtrack, they can easily distinguish wo fe fe (same old abb story) from wo fe wo (new aba structure).

 

但经过一系列针对言语的研究后，我们尝试了音乐，令我们自己有些惊讶的是，我们发现婴儿在检测音乐中的类似模式方面几乎没有那么擅长。像 C、D、D 这样的音符序列完全吸引了婴儿，但尽管如此，婴儿无法掌握由音符组成的模式，除非他们有机会先听到语音音节。婴儿最初最感兴趣的似乎是语言，而不是音乐。

But after a series of studies looking at speech, we tried music and, somewhat to our own surprise, discovered that babies weren’t nearly as good at detecting comparable patterns in music. Sequences of musical notes like C, D, D thoroughly engaged the infants, but nonetheless infants couldn’t grasp the patterns when they consisted of musical notes, unless they’d had a chance to hear the speech syllables first. Speech, not music, appears to be the sound that holds the greatest initial interest for infants.

 

如果音乐的一部分可能是预先连接的并且与音乐特别相关，那么它可能就是节奏和动作之间的联系。当我们听到音乐时，我们的身体想要跳舞，即使对于我们研究的一些最小的孩子也是如此。在一项有趣的研究中，发展心理学家劳雷尔·特雷纳（Laurel Trainor）以有规律的节奏间隔弹跳七个月大的婴儿，发现他们更关注与弹跳模式一致的节奏模式，而不是与弹跳模式不一致的节奏模式。但即使在这里，也不清楚正在发生的事情对于音乐来说是否真正具有特殊性，而不是我之前提到的更普遍趋势的一部分，即跨模式匹配：无论刺激是什么，婴儿都会喜欢它任何两种意义上的信息都会结合在一起（例如当一组声音与一组闪烁的灯光同步发出咔哒声时）。音乐和动作之间的耦合可能只是这种更广泛趋势的一个更具体的实例，而不是任何类型的音乐专用硬件的反映。

If there is one part of music that might be pre-wired and specifically tied to music, it would probably be the connection between rhythm and motion. When we hear music, our bodies want to dance, and that’s true even for some of the youngest children anybody’s studied. In one fascinating study, the developmental psychologist Laurel Trainor bounced seven-month-old babies at regular rhythmic intervals and discovered that they paid more attention to rhythmical patterns that coincided with patterns of bouncing than to rhythmical patterns that didn’t coincide with the bouncing. But even here, it’s not clear that what’s going on is genuinely special to music, as opposed to being part of a more general tendency that I alluded to before, known as cross-modal matching: no matter what the stimulus, babies like it when information in any two senses goes together (such as when a set of sounds click in synchrony with a set of flashing lights). The coupling between music and motion may just be one more specific instantiation of this broader tendency, rather than a reflection of any sort of special-purpose hardware for music.

 

 

证据就在人类大脑的布丁中。如果人类真的生来就对音乐有一种特定的本能，我们可能会期望找到一块特定的脑组织来适应音乐，而不是其他任何东西，就像大脑底部附近被称为梭状回的一个点对音乐的反应更大一样。面对任何其他类型的刺激。

The proof lies in the pudding of the human brain. If humans really were born with a specific instinct for music, we might expect to find a specific hunk of brain tissue to be tuned to music and nothing else, much as a spot near the bottom of the brain known as the fusiform gyrus responds more to faces than to any other kinds of stimuli.

相反，过去十年中进行的许多音乐脑成像研究都指向了一个相当不同的方向：不是针对单一专门的音乐区域，而是针对大脑区域的巨大混合——前额皮质，颞叶的一部分被称为颞上回、布罗卡区、颞平面、杏仁核——其中没有一个似乎是全职致力于音乐的。相反，几乎所有在音乐中发挥作用的东西都有一个单独的“日常工作”；当大脑听音乐时，它会兼职做第二个职业，而它最初并不是为了这个职业而进化的。

Instead, the many brain-imaging studies of music done in the last decade all point to a rather different direction: not toward a single specialized music area, but toward a vast mélange of brain regions— the prefrontal cortex, a portion of the temporal lobe known as the superior temporal gyrus, Broca’s area, the planum temporale, the amygdala— not one of which appears to be dedicated full-time to music. Instead, virtually everything that plays a role in music has a separate “day job”; when the brain listens to music, it moonlights in a second career for which it did not originally evolve.

 

例如，布罗卡区在音乐中发挥着关键作用，但如果该区域具有主要功能，那么它就是语言中心。位于韦尼克区的颞平面也是如此。颞上回在音乐中是不可或缺的，但它对于各种听觉分析也是必不可少的，无论我们是在听语音、音乐还是电子游戏的声音。小脑显然在音乐节奏中发挥着重要作用，但多年来人们都知道小脑是各种音乐或其他运动的关键角色。杏仁核对于音乐情感的感知很重要，但你不需要有音乐才能有杏仁核；杏仁核与从恐惧到欲望和焦虑的一切事物有关，涉及范围广泛（大部分是非音乐的）物种。意外的和弦可能会触发杏仁核，但电击也会触发。杏仁核或我刚才讨论的任何其他区域都不是专门为音乐量身定制的；如果大脑中存在特定于音乐的区域，目前还没有人能够识别它。每一个我提到的大脑区域——杏仁核、颞上回、颞平面——早在人类出现之前就已进化，并且存在于许多非音乐物种中。

Broca’s area, for example, is a key player in music, but if that area has a principal function, it’s as a center for language. Ditto for the planum temporale, which lies within Wernicke’s area. The superior temporal gyrus is indispensable in music, but it is essential for all kinds of auditory analyses, whether we are listening to speech or music or the blips and bangs of a video game. The cerebellum clearly plays a role in musical rhythm, but it’s been known for years that the cerebellum is a key player in all kinds of movements, musical or otherwise. The amygdala matters for the perception of musical emotion, but you don’t need to have music to have an amygdala; the amygdala is implicated in everything from fear to lust and anxiety, in a vast range of (mostly nonmusical) species. Unexpected chords might trigger the amygdala, but so will electric shocks. In no way is the amygdala, or any of the other regions I just discussed, specifically tailored to music; if there is a music-specific region in the brain, nobody has yet been able to identify it. Every brain area that I have mentioned— the amygdala, the superior temporal gyrus, the planum temporale— evolved long before human beings did and is found in many nonmusical species.

 

如果你着眼于大脑的发育，而不是它的解剖结构，也可以得出同样的论点。例如，当人们发展音乐技能时，人们会产生更多的灰质，但随着人们学习杂耍或学习打字，灰质也会增加。灰质的增加是对一般学习的诊断，而不是学习音乐的具体标志。大脑当然可以获得音乐能力，但这并不意味着它是专门为此目的而进化的。

The same kind of argument can be made if you look at the development of the brain, rather than its anatomy. People develop more gray matter when they develop skill in music, for example, but gray matter has also been shown to increase as people learn to juggle or learn to type. Gray-matter increase is a diagnostic of learning in general, not a specific sign of learning music in particular. The brain can certainly acquire a facility for music, but that doesn’t mean it specifically evolved for that purpose.

 

 

最重要的是，我们生物学的某些部分几乎是不可避免的，比如我们肺部的分支部分和我们有两只眼睛的事实。但音乐头脑却不是。只有经过多年的努力，或者至少是积极的倾听，音乐思维才会发展起来，其中为语言、技能学习和听觉分析等其他目的而进化的大脑部分会逐渐被用来做一些新的事情。

The bottom line is that some parts of our biology are all but inevitable, like the branching part of our lungs and the fact that we have two eyes. But the musical mind is not. A musical mind develops only if we put in years of hard work, or at least active listening, in which parts of the brain that evolved for other purposes such as language, skill learning, and auditory analysis are gradually co-opted into doing something new.

就我们最终变得有音乐性而言，这是因为我们有能力随着时间的推移，通过刻意的练习，缓慢而费力地调整广泛的神经回路整体，而不是因为音乐回路从一开始就存在。

To the degree that we ultimately become musical, it is because we have the capacity to slowly and laboriously tune broad ensembles of neural circuitry over time, through deliberate practice, and not because the circuitry of music is all there from the outset.

 

 

这并不容易

IT DON’T COME EASY

 

人脑的问题

The Trouble with the Human Brain

 

正如我们所看到的，音乐更像是一生的旅程，而不是几周的项目，更像是国际象棋而不是跳棋。尽管音乐的许多基本原理自然地适合人类的思维，但掌握细节是一个持续的项目。我很快发现，每一个新的和弦和每一个新的音阶都需要大量的练习；我也开始与专业音乐家交谈，发现他们也将掌握音乐视为一种持续的追求。事实上，我遇到的每一位音乐家都声称自己仍在学习中。没有人声称已经完全掌握了他或她的手艺。例如，帕特·梅森尼 (Pat Metheny) 是我有幸见到的最有成就的音乐家之一。他被广泛认为是世界领先的爵士吉他手之一，但即使在四十年后，他仍然毫不怀疑自己正在继续发展自己的技艺。尽管他取得了诸多成就（截至撰写本文时已获得十八座格莱美奖），但他仍然坚持学习；例如，每次梅瑟尼演奏时，他都会写日记——通常有六到八页长——分析哪些有效，哪些无效，以便使后续的演出（和录音）变得更好。

Music, as we have seen, is more like a lifelong journey than a few weeks’ project, more chess than checkers. Although many of the rudiments of music fit naturally with the human mind, mastering the detail is an ongoing project. As I soon discovered, every new chord and every new scale took significant amounts of practice; I also started talking to professional musicians and discovered that they too see mastering music as an ongoing pursuit. Virtually every musician I met professes to still be learning; not one claimed to have fully mastered his or her craft. Pat Metheny, for instance, is one of the most accomplished musicians I had the pleasure of meeting; he is widely acknowledged to be one of the world’s leading jazz guitarists, yet even after four decades, he has no doubt that he is continuing to develop his craft. For all his accomplishments (eighteen Grammys as of this writing), he still keeps studying; every time Metheny plays, for instance, he keeps a diary— typically six to eight pages long— analyzing what worked, and what didn’t, in order to make subsequent shows (and recordings) even better.

在后面的章节中，我们将更深入地探讨专家们认为的是什么我们知道初学者不会，但在我们考虑如何成为真正的大师之前，了解音乐新手面临的挑战非常重要。

In a later chapter we’ll delve more deeply into what it is that experts know that beginners don’t, but before we can even consider what it takes to be a true master, it’s important to understand the challenges that confront the musical novice.

 

 

我首先遇到的困难之一就是令人恼火的音乐字母表，我喜欢将其视为十二对七的暴政。在西方音乐中，每个八度都准确地分为十二个音符，但西方音乐字母表只包含七个基本字母：C、D、E、F、G、A 和 B。这种基本但几乎不可避免的并置构成了一个对于任何有抱负的音乐家来说，这是第一个挑战，而且这是一个令人难以置信的挑战。

One of the first things I struggled with was the aggravating musical alphabet, which I like to think of as the Tyranny of Twelve Against Seven. Every octave is, in Western music, divided into exactly twelve notes, but the Western musical alphabet contains just seven basic letters, C, D, E, F, G, A, and B. That fundamental— but nearly inescapable— juxtaposition poses one of the first challenges for any aspiring musician, and it’s a doozy.

除了 C、D、E、F、G、A 和 B 等所谓的自然音符外，每个八度音阶还包含五个（而不是七个）称为升号的插入音：C#（发音为“升 C”）、D#、 F#、G# 和 A#——但是（初学者必须学习的词汇）没有 E# 或 B#。

In addition to the so-called natural notes of C, D, E, F, G, A, and B, every octave contains five— not seven— interlopers known as sharps: C# (pronounced “C-sharp”), D#, F#, G#, and A#—but (in the vocabulary that beginners must learn) no E# or B#.

 

 

从开始到结束，八度音阶的字母表相当混乱，依次为 C、C#、D、D#、E、F、F#、G、G#、A、A#、B，然后返回 C。学生还必须面对这样一个事实：每个升号都是降号的同义词；例如，升 C 调也称为降 D 调。* )

From start to finish, the rather confusing alphabet of the octave runs C, C#, D, D#, E, F, F#, G, G#, A, A#, B, before returning to C. (The student must also cope with the fact that each of the sharps is synonymous with a flat; C-sharp, for instance, is also known as D-flat.*)

 

对于机器来说，这种有点奇怪的字母表没什么大不了的。然而，对于人类思维来说，这是一场灾难：我们看到一个从 C 到 C#、D 到 D# 的字母表，我们情不自禁地想象 E 会变成 E#。每次E到F时，新手都会感到困惑。

For a machine, that somewhat peculiar alphabet would be no big deal. For the human mind, though, it’s a disaster: we see an alphabet that runs from C to C#, D to D#, and we can’t help but imagine that E will go to E#. Every time E goes to F, the novice gets confused.

 

如果不是十二对七的暴政，学习音乐字母可能很容易。相反，升调和降调的不规则性使整个冒险变成了一场噩梦。

If it weren’t for that Tyranny of Twelve Against Seven, learning the musical alphabet might be easy. Instead, the irregularity of the sharps and flats turns the entire adventure into a nightmare.

 

 

除非你尝试（至少短暂地）一起演奏，否则你无法真正理解新手音乐家的痛苦。

You can’t really appreciate the novice musician’s pain unless you try, at least briefly, to play along.

所以这里是：

So here goes:

 

A 上方的一个半音（一个音符的另一种说法）是多少？（答案：A#。）

What’s one semitone (another way of saying one note) above A? (Answer: A#.)

C上面一个半音是多少？（答案：C#。）

What’s one semitone above C? (Answer: C#.)

B 下面一个半音是多少？（答案：Bb，发音为“降B”。）

What’s one semitone below B? (Answer: Bb, pronounced “B-flat.”)

现在，快点，C 低一个半音是多少？

Now, quick, what’s one semitone below C?

如果您像大多数人一样，您至少一开始会想说降 C，但“正确”答案是 B。

If you’re like most people, you were at least initially tempted to say C-flat, but the “correct” answer is B.

 

当您开始处理和弦和音程时，所有这些都会变得更加困难，因此必须计算几个音符的间隙。哪个音符比 D 高七个半音——是 A 还是 A#？即使经过几个月的学习，我仍然发现做这种练习非常困难，就像在没有一张纸的情况下尝试将 712 乘以 47 一样。

All of this gets even harder when you start dealing with chords and intervals, and thus must count across gaps of several notes. Which note is seven semitones above a D— is it an A or an A#? Even after months of study, I found doing this sort of exercise ridiculously hard, like trying to multiply 712 by 47 without the benefit of a sheet of paper.

 

 

在研究生院，我研究了儿童如何习得语言，与史蒂文·平克（Steven Pinker）合作开展我们通常认为的过去时项目。这个想法是利用英语的过去时作为一种熔炉，以更广泛地理解语言发展如何运作。人们知道孩子们会犯某种错误，被称为过度规则化，例如用“break”代替“broke”，用“goed”（甚至“wented”）代替“went”；我的任务是找出原因。

In graduate school, I studied how children acquire language, working with Steven Pinker on what we often thought of as the Past Tense Project. The idea was to use the past tense of English as a kind of crucible for understanding how language development worked more broadly. Children were known to make a certain kind of error, known as overregularization, as in “breaked” instead of “broke,” “goed” (or even “wented”) instead of “went”; my mission was to figure out why.
