当时流行的一种理论是，孩子们只是在记忆不同声音之间的关系；“ring”末尾的“ing”与“rang”末尾的“ang”相关，就像“sing”末尾的“ing”与“rang”末尾的“ang”相关一样。 “唱”；遵循特定模式的动词越多，类比就越好。“破坏”和“破坏”之间的关系是否是“假”和“伪造”之间考虑不周的类比的产物？

One popular theory at the time was that children were simply memorizing the relations between different bits of sounds; the “ing” at the end of “ring” was correlated with the “ang” at the end of “rang,” just as the “ing” at the end of “sing” was correlated with the “ang” at the end of “sang”; the more verbs there were following a particular pattern, the better the analogy. Could the relation between “break” and “breaked” be the detritus of an ill-considered analogy between “fake” and “faked”?

 

当平克和我仔细研究了数万个儿童言语的例子时，我们发现最流行的理论并不完全正确。孩子们确实受到了类似的不规则动词的影响——如果孩子知道“唱歌”和“喝”等遵循类似模式的动词，那么他或她就更有可能正确地回答“ring”——但不会受到类似的规则动词的影响；孩子说“坏了”的可能性并不取决于他或她碰巧知道了多少像“假”这样的规则动词，这破坏了类比理论的主要预测之一。

As Pinker and I pored over tens of thousands of examples of children’s speech, we discovered that the most popular theory wasn’t quite right. Children were indeed influenced by similar irregular verbs— a child was more likely to get “ring” correct if he or she knew other verbs like “sing” and “drink” that followed similar patterns— but not by similar regular verbs; the chance that a child would say “breaked” didn’t depend on how many regular verbs like “fake” he or she happened to know, undermining one of the main predictions of the analogy theory.

 

相反，即使是相对年幼的孩子（大约两岁半以上）似乎也会以不同的方式对待规则动词和不规则动词；不规则形式是他们从记忆中提取出来的东西——当他们可以的时候——而每当他们不记得特定的不规则形式时，规则形式就是由规则产生的（“添加'-ed'以形成过去时”）。过度规范化（例如“破坏”）结果是比任何人想象的都要罕见，但当它们发生时，它们似乎是孩子们使用简单规则即兴创作的东西。

Instead, even relatively young children (past the age of about two and a half) seemed to treat regular verbs and irregular verbs differently; irregulars were something that they pulled out of their memory— when they could— while regulars were produced by a rule (“add ‘-ed’ to form the past tense”) whenever they didn’t already remember a specific irregular form. Overregularizations (like “breaked”) turned out to be much rarer than anyone had imagined, but when they happened, they seemed to be something that kids created on the spur of the moment, using a simple rule.

 

孩子们似乎几乎在一夜之间就学会了这条规则。在短短几周内，学习英语的孩子就从经常不改变其常规过去时态动词（说“我昨天走”）到系统地改变几乎所有动词（“我昨天走”）。过度规则化是一种附带损害：有时孩子们知道正确的不规则过去时形式（“我打破了玻璃”），有时他们不知道，在这种情况下，他们将动词视为规则的，而过度规则化（ “破碎”）结果。加“-ed”的规则很容易学，但不规则的例外却要花很长时间；孩子们（和成人英语学习者）需要几年的时间才能完全掌握不常见的不规则动词的过去时，例如“flee”（“fled”）和“bear”（“bore”）。

Kids seem to learn that rule almost overnight. Within a matter of weeks, English-learning children go from frequently leaving their regular past-tense verbs “uninflected” (saying things like “I walk yesterday”) to systematically inflecting just about all of them (“I walked yesterday”). Overregularizations are a kind of collateral damage: sometimes kids know the correct irregular past-tense form (“I broke the glass”), and sometimes they don’t, in which case they treat the verb as if it were regular, and overregularization (“breaked”) results. The rule to add “-ed” is easy to learn, but the irregular exceptions take forever; it takes kids (and adult learners of English) years to fully master the past tense of infrequent irregular verbs like “flee” (“fled”) and “bear” (“bore”).

 

规则很简单；特质很难。罕见的特质异常困难。（对于任何不完全受规则支配的事物，我们听到的次数越多，就越容易记住，这就是为什么“生日快乐”的旋律比你第一次听到的歌曲更容易记住的原因更糟糕的是，尽管孩子们在没有明确指导和刻意练习的情况下以某种方式设法自动掌握不规则动词，但音乐的不规则性以及十二对七的暴政所带来的所有复杂性，只能通过努力来掌握。

Rules are easy; idiosyncrasies are hard. Infrequent idiosyncrasies are exceptionally hard. (For anything that is not perfectly rule governed, the more often we hear it, the easier it is to remember, which is why it is easier to remember the melody to “Happy Birthday” than to a song you just heard for the first time last week.) Worse, although kids somehow manage to master their irregular verbs automatically, without explicit instruction and deliberate practice, music’s irregularities, and all the complications that ensue from the Tyranny of Twelve Against Seven, can only be mastered with hard work.

 

 

在我开始学习吉他之前，我认为最糟糕的不规则例子是德语复数系统。有人说ein Kind（“一个孩子”，单数），但zwei Kinder（“两个孩子”，复数），加上er； ein Auto（一辆车），zwei Autos（两辆车），添加s。总而言之，根据你的计算方式，至少有九种不同的形成复数的方式，学习者别无选择，只能全部记住。正如马克·吐温在一篇名为《糟糕的德语》的文章中所说：

Until I started learning guitar, I thought that the worst possible example of irregularity was the German plural system. One says ein Kind (“one child,” singular) but zwei Kinder (“two children,” plural), adding er; ein Auto (one car), zwei Autos (two cars), adding s. In all, there are, depending on how you count, at least nine different ways of forming plurals, and the learner has little choice but to memorize them all. As Mark Twain once put it, in an essay called “The Awful German Language”:

没有学过德语的人根本不知道这是一门多么令人费解的语言。肯定没有另一种语言如此草率和无系统，如此难以掌握和难以捉摸。一个人以一种最无助的方式在其中被冲来冲去，到处漂流。最后，当他认为自己掌握了一条规则，为在十个词类的普遍愤怒和混乱中休息提供了坚实的基础时，他翻开书页，读道：“让学生仔细记下以下例外。” 他仔细观察，发现规则的例外比实例还多。

A person who has not studied German can form no idea of what a perplexing language it is. Surely there is not another language that is so slip-shod and systemless, and so slippery and elusive to the grasp. One is washed about in it, hither and thither, in the most helpless way; and when at last he thinks he has captured a rule which offers firm ground to take a rest on amid the general rage and turmoil of the ten parts of speech, he turns over the page and reads, “Let the pupil make careful note of the following exceptions.” He runs his eye down and finds that there are more exceptions to the rule than instances of it.

 

 

吉他，就像德语一样，充满了令人发狂的违规行为。其中一个问题与注释的布局方式有关。在钢琴上，音符和琴键之间存在所谓的一对一映射。每个音符（例如中音 C）恰好对应一个键，不多也不少。更重要的是，一旦知道了基本字母，整个钢琴键盘就变得清晰起来：C、C#、D等等，从钢琴的左边缘到右边缘一遍又一遍地重复。

Guitar, like German, is filled with maddening irregularities. One problem has to do with how the notes are laid out. On a piano, there is what is known as a one-to-one mapping between notes and keys. Each note (middle C, for example) corresponds to exactly one key, no more, no less. What’s more, once one knows the basic alphabet, the entire piano keyboard becomes clear: C, C#, D, and so on, repeating over and over again from the left edge of the piano to the right.

 

相比之下，有抱负的吉他手必须记住如下所示的图表：

The aspiring guitarist, in contrast, has to memorize a diagram that looks like this:

 

 

吉他上的音符，突出显示中间的 C。

Notes on a guitar, with middle Cs highlighted.

这些音符沿着吉他琴颈长度的木条延伸，统称为指板。

These notes, which run along a wood strip that runs the length of the neck of the guitar, are collectively known as the fretboard.

 

 

音符的顶行对应于所谓的第一弦，第二行对应于第二弦，依此类推。从左往右读第一行，第一个音符（如果您在不按住任何品格的情况下“打开”弦乐）会得到 E。如果您按住第一个品格上方的该弦（由第二列表示）图中，吉他发出F音符；如果你将琴弦压在第三品上方，你就会得到一个 G 音。

The top row of notes corresponds to the so-called first string, the second row to the second string, and so forth. Reading the top row from the left, the first note— what you get if you play the string “open,” without holding any frets— is E. If you hold down that string just above the first fret, represented by the second column in the diagram, the guitar produces an F note; if you hold the string down just above the third fret, you would have a G.

 

让这一切变得特别复杂的是，任何给定的音符都可以在许多不同的地方演奏。这极大地扩展了高级吉他手形成和弦的选择，但让可怜的初学者感到困惑，他们必须学习所有这些。钢琴家只有一个中音 C，位于键盘的中间，而吉他手则有四个选择并必须掌握所有四个音品：不仅是第二弦、第一音品，而且还包括第三弦的第五品品，就此而言，第四弦的第十品品，以及在许多吉他中第五弦的第十五品品。（电吉他通常至少有 20 个音品，这为第六弦的第 20 品品上的额外 C 留下了空间。）

What makes all this particularly complicated is that any given note can be played in many different places. This greatly expands the ad vanced guitarist’s options in forming chords— but bewilders the poor beginner, who has to learn them all. Whereas the pianist has only one middle C, smack in the middle of the keyboard, the guitarist has four choices and must master all four: not just the second string, first fret, but also the fifth fret of the third string, and for that matter the tenth fret of the fourth string, and in many guitars the fifteenth fret of the fifth string. (Electric guitars generally have at least twenty frets, which leaves room for a bonus C on the twentieth fret of the sixth string.)

 

了解？我当然没有。当我尝试学习读乐谱时，这个挑战变得尤其令人心酸。即使我能记住高音谱号的上面一行代表音符 G，我也不知道我实际上应该演奏吉他上的众多 G 中的哪一个。

Got that? I certainly didn’t. This challenge became especially poignant when I tried to learn to read music; even when I could manage to remember that the upper line on the treble clef stood for the note G, I wouldn’t know which of the many Gs on the guitar I should actually be playing.

 

 

由于大脑本身的结构，不规则现象很难被学习。

Irregularities are so hard to learn because of the structure of the brain itself.

计算机配备有随机存取内存芯片，可以形成一个组织整齐的内存系统（其中每个条目都有一个特定的位置来存储每个特定的信息位），而我们的记忆则分散在海马体和大脑皮层等地方。前额皮质更像是装满照片的鞋盒，塞得满满的，但组织得不是特别好。我们不像机器那样依赖编号位置，而是依赖暗示我们需要的信息的“提示”或“提醒”，而不告诉我们具体在哪里可以找到它。

Whereas computers are endowed with random-access memory chips that allow for a neatly organized system of memory (in which every entry has a specific place for each particular bit of information to be stored), our memories, scattered across places such as the hippocampus and the prefrontal cortex, are more like shoe boxes full of photographs, crammed to the gills but not particularly well organized. Instead of relying on numbered locations, as machines do, we rely on “cues” or “reminders” that hint at the information we need, without telling us specifically where we can find it.

 

结果是我们并不总是能找到我们需要的东西。任何给定的提示通常都与许多不同的记忆相关联，而我们需要的记忆可能会与我们不想要的其他记忆一起模糊，就像当我们试图记住我们的车停在哪里时，结果却对昨天的位置感到困惑。比现在的位置。不规则动词很难学习，因为它们属于容易混淆的家族——“sing”变成“sang”，但“bring”变成“brought”。任何对我们不完美的记忆力要求很高的技能对我们来说必然是困难的人类要学习，吉他也不例外。国际象棋大师必须熟记开局；音乐家必须记住大量的细节。

The consequence is that we can’t always find what we need. Any given cue is often associated with many different memories, and the memory we need may blur together with other memories we don’t want, as when we try to remember where our car is parked, only to get confused by where it was yesterday rather than where it is presently. Irregular verbs are difficult to learn because they come in families that tend to blur together—“sing” goes to “sang,” but “bring” goes to “brought.” Any skill that makes heavy demands on our imperfect memories is necessarily hard for us humans to learn, and guitar is no exception. Chess masters must memorize the openings; musicians must memorize reams of details.

 

指板的六行十二个音符名称很快就模糊在一起了。当您意识到普通孩子需要五六年才能掌握不规则动词时，您就会开始理解为什么指板如此要求。

And the fretboard’s six rows of twelve note names quickly blur together. When you realize it takes your average child five or six years to master irregular verbs, you start to appreciate why the fretboard is so demanding.

 

 

当然，即使我知道每个音符在哪里，我也离成为一名像样的吉他手还差得很远。除了对记忆的纯粹要求之外——不仅是单个音符，还有旋律、歌词以及伴随它们的和弦序列（称为和弦进行）——至少还有其他三件事会使任何给定的技能难以学习。一项技能可能需要精确的感知掌握，例如识别特定的声音或形状；可能需要多块肌肉之间精确的时间协调；这可能需要肌肉本身的发展。

Of course, even if I knew where every note was, I wouldn’t be close to be ing a decent guitarist. Beyond the sheer demands of memory—not just for the individual notes but also for the melodies, lyrics, and sequences of chords (known as chord progressions) that accompany them—at least three other things can make any given skill hard to learn. A skill may require precise perceptual mastery, such as recognizing particular sounds or shapes; it may require precise coordination in time between multiple muscles; and it may require development on the part of the muscles themselves.

事实证明，音乐需要这三者。音乐几乎与所有运动一样，都需要仔细协调肌肉控制。与国际象棋（以及许多团队运动）一样，音乐需要快速的模式识别（尤其是在与合奏团一起即兴演奏时），甚至需要极其强大的手指。对于初学者来说，将所有这些协调成一首以可识别的节奏播放的歌曲几乎是不可能的。前二十或三十次我尝试“在风中飘扬”时，我错过了所有其他和弦，并且无法以常规节奏演奏。

Music, as it turns out, requires all three. Music shares with virtually all sports the need for carefully coordinated muscle control. Like chess (and many team sports), music demands rapid pattern recognition (especially when improvising live with an ensemble), and it even requires insanely strong fingers. For a beginner, coordinating all that into a song played at a recognizable tempo is close to impossible. The first twenty or thirty times I tried “Blowin’ in the Wind,” I missed every other chord and couldn’t play in anything like a regular rhythm.

 

记忆力、感知力、协调性、力量：吉他实在是太难了。

Memory, perception, coordination, strength: guitar is just plain hard.

 

 

在感知方面，吉他手需要经过严格训练的耳朵，并且始终能够很好地感知手指的位置。最好的吉他手也利用他们从手指获得的触觉，根据情况需要减轻或施加更大的压力。在听觉方面，完美（绝对）音高不是必需的，但对所谓相对音高的敏锐感觉至关重要，其本质上包括能够可靠地识别称为音程的音乐步骤的精确幅度。*

On the perceptual side, guitarists need exquisitely trained ears and a good sense of where their fingers are at all times. The best guitarists also exploit the tactile sensations they get from their fingers, easing up or placing more pressure as circumstances require. On the auditory side, perfect (absolute) pitch is not a requirement, but a keen sense of so-called relative pitch, which essentially consists of being able to reliably recognize the precise magnitude of the musical steps known as intervals, is essential.*

考虑一下歌曲“Yankee Doodle”（“Yankee Doodle 进城”）的开头短语。不同的人可能会用不同的音域来唱这首歌；孩子可能更喜欢以 G 开头，最终结果是歌曲的开头短语现在不会呈现为 C、C、D、E、C、E、D，而是呈现为 G、G、A、B 、G、B、A——一组完全不同的音符。但它会立即被识别为同一首歌。

Consider the opening phrase to the song “Yankee Doodle” (“Yankee Doodle went to town”). Different people might sing the song in different registers; a child might prefer to start with a G, with the net result being that the opening phrase of the song would now be rendered not as C, C, D, E, C, E, D but as G, G, A, B, G, B, A— a completely different set of notes. Yet it would be immediately recognizable as the same song.

 

为什么？因为在两种情况下音符之间的间隔是相同的。对于训练有素的音乐家来说，“Yankee Doodle”的旋律由一系列特定的音程或精确幅度的步骤组成。

Why? Because the intervals between the notes are the same in both cases. To a trained musician, the melody of “Yankee Doodle” consists of a particular series of intervals, or steps of precise magnitude.

 

 

“Yankee Doodle”的开头音符用两种不同的调来演唱

The opening notes of “Yankee Doodle,” sung in two different keys

这种音程语言为任何给定歌曲的旋律提供了蓝图，并且它以独立于歌曲调的方式提供蓝图，以便具有不同音高范围的不同歌手都可以以可识别的方式演唱同一首歌。只有当音乐家能够可靠地识别音程的确切大小时，才可以“用耳朵”演奏。

This language of intervals provides the blueprint for the melody of any given song, and it does so in a way that is independent of the key of the song— so that different singers with different pitch ranges can all sing the same song in a recognizable way. It is only when a musician can reliably recognize the exact size of musical intervals that it becomes possible to play “by ear.”

 

对于许多人（除了那些拥有完美音高的人）来说，音程的识别最初是相当具有挑战性的。儿童和未经训练的成年人对于音乐从一个音符到下一个音符的跳跃幅度只有粗略的感觉。如果没有经过训练，大多数听众只能辨别一些更模糊的东西，例如旋律的大致方向（例如，向上与向下），也许还可以区分大跳跃和小跳跃之间的差异，而没有任何特别的精确性。这种程度的模糊性对于演讲来说已经足够了，我们只需要注意到广泛的差异，比如问题中音调的上升与陈述性陈述中音调的下降之间的对比，但对于音乐来说就太不精确了。

For many people (except those with perfect pitch), the recognition of intervals is initially quite challenging. Both children and untrained adults have only a rough sense of the size of the musical leaps from one note to the next. Absent training, most listeners can only discern something fuzzier, such as the general direction a melody is going (for example, up versus down) and maybe the difference between big leaps and smaller leaps, without any particular precision. That level of vagueness suffices for speech, where we need only notice broad differences like the contrast between rise in pitch in a question versus the fall in a declarative statement, but it is far too imprecise for music.

 

我很快了解到，精确区分音程的挑战是人类日常执行的最困难的快速分类问题之一。使用 iPhone 上的“耳朵训练”程序，我花了几个小时试图区分纯四度和纯五度等音程，咒骂我的耳朵太糟糕了，而且很少能得到超过 60% 的正确率——这是我玩过的最不愉快的视频游戏之一玩过。一直以来，我意识到听力训练器让事情变得更容易：每个音程都是单独演奏的，而在真正的音乐中，每个新音符都会形成一个新的音程，与它前面的音符并置数百次一首典型歌曲的过程。一个熟练的音乐家可能需要每秒识别几个音程；如果我能自己识别出一个，我就很幸运了。我打算做的事情就像一个孩子第一次学习识别书页上的字母时必须做的事情一样，早在面临阅读单词和句子的更大挑战之前。还有我的在耳朵里，这些差异就像早期困扰许多孩子的b与d差异一样难以理解。

As I soon learned, the challenge of precisely distinguishing musical intervals is among the hardest of rapid categorization problems that hu man beings routinely perform. Using an “ear training” program that I got for my iPhone, I spent hours trying to distinguish between intervals like perfect fourths and perfect fifths, cursing my lousy ears and rarely getting much above 60 percent correct—among the least pleasant video games I ever played. And all the while, I realized that the ear trainer was making things easier for me: each interval was played in isolation, whereas in real music every new note forms a new interval, in juxtaposition with the note that precedes it, several hundred times over the course of a typical song. A skilled musician might need to recognize several intervals every second; I was lucky if I could identify one on its own. What I was setting out to do was comparable to what a child must do when he or she first learns to recognize letters on a page, long before facing the greater challenge of reading words and sentences. And to my ears the differences were as inscrutable as the b-versus-d difference that plagues many children early on.

 

我采访过的一位音乐家，一位教堂管风琴师的儿子，他说他不仅通过聆听来学习音程，还通过感觉来学习音程，坐在教堂风琴的鼓声中，听他父亲的演奏，大量的空气掠过。一个更常见的技巧（对于已经具有良好音调感的人）是将特定音程与特定歌曲的开头音符相关联。但没有人天生就能给它们贴上标签，而且许多人从未掌握它们。有些人甚至从未注意到“Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star”和“The Alphabet Song”遵循相同的旋律（因此由相同的音程序列组成）。

One musician I interviewed, the son of a church organist, said he learned intervals not just by hearing them but by feeling them, sitting in the swell of a church organ as his father played and huge volumes of air swept by. A more common trick (for people who already have a decent sense of pitch) is to associate specific intervals with the opening notes of specific songs. But nobody is born being able to label them, and many people never master them. Some people never even notice that “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star” and “The Alphabet Song” follow the same melody (and hence consist of the same sequence of intervals).

 

“耳朵训练”——精炼听觉皮层以便能够精确识别特定音乐元素的过程——是大多数音乐家的基本需求，需要认真的努力和大量的大脑重组。

“Ear training”—the process of refining one’s auditory cortex so as to be able to precisely identify specific musical elements— is a fundamental need for most musicians that takes serious effort and considerable brain reorganization.

 

 

我们的耳朵以及评估通过耳朵的内容的脑组织只是等式的一部分。另一个是纯粹的身体灵活性，比如吉他手弹奏吉他时控制手腕；歌手嘴唇、舌头和声带的精确位置；或者像打击乐手及时协调四个肢体一样控制手臂和小腿的力量和动态。

Our ears— and the brain tissue that evaluates what passes through the ears— are only one part of the equation. Another is sheer physical dexterity, be it in controlling the wrists as a guitarist strums a guitar; in the exact placement of the lips, tongue, and vocal cords in a vocalist; or in controlling the force and dynamics of arms and calves as a percussionist coordinates four limbs in time.

对于初学者吉他手来说，第一个也是最明显的挑战——我每天都会面临的挑战——是将按动的手（右手吉他手的左手）扭曲成形成和弦所需的精确形状。没有一种手形一开始看起来是自然的，但每一种手形最终都必须以极高的精度和速度制作出来。而且，正如我一次又一次注意到的那样，靠近还不够好：一根手指即使错位一毫米也会导致嗡嗡声或音符跑调。作为初学者，当我能够形成和弦时，我很高兴，但最终，吉他手必须能够创建并移动每个形状，基本上没有误差范围。

For the beginning guitarist, the first and most evident challenge— one I faced every single day— is contorting one’s fretting hand (left for a right-handed guitarist) into the precise shapes required for forming chords. Not one of the hand shapes initially seems natural, yet every one must eventually be made with great precision and speed. And, as I noticed over and over again, close isn’t good enough: a finger that is misplaced by even a millimeter can lead to a buzzy noise or a note out of tune. As a beginner, I was happy when I could form a chord at all, but ultimately, the guitarist must be able to create— and move— each shape with essentially no margin of error.

 

例如，最简单的 F 大调和弦版本要求演奏者用食指同时按住前两根弦的第一根弦，而中指必须夹住第二根弦上的第三根弦，而环手指必须保持对第四弦第三品的压力。为了正确地发出最低的低音音符，人们还必须将拇指完全缠绕在吉他的琴颈上，以夹住第六弦上的第一个品格。其他更复杂的和弦也需要小指参与。培养这种灵活性是一项艰巨的任务。我很快就长出了老茧，肩膀紧张，手指疼痛。最终，我在网上订购了握力增强器。

The simplest version of the F major chord, for example, requires the player to simultaneously hold down the first fret of the first two strings with the index finger, while the middle finger must clamp down the third string on the second fret, and the ring finger must maintain pressure on the third fret of the fourth string. To properly sound the lowest bass note, one must also wrap one’s thumb completely around the guitar’s neck in order to clamp down the first fret on the sixth string. Other chords, even more complex, require the pinkie to get involved as well. Developing this dexterity is taxing; I soon developed calluses, my shoulder tensed, and my fingers ached. Eventually, I ordered a grip strengthener online.

 

不过，手指力量只是等式的一部分。由于手指不能自然地独立移动，因此形成和弦的过程变得更加复杂。（例如，尝试将所有手指并拢，手掌朝下，然后慢慢地前后移动小指；您的无名指，可能还有拇指，都会忍不住跟着一起走。）

Finger strength is only one part of the equation, though. The process of forming chords is further complicated by the fact that one’s fingers don’t naturally move independently. (Try, for example, to bring all of your fingers together, with your palm facing down, and then slowly move your pinkie back and forth; your ring finger, and possibly your thumb, will be tempted to go along for the ride.)

 

钢琴家也必须立即形成极其复杂的手形，歌手和管乐器演奏者也需要用嘴唇、牙齿和舌头做类似的事情。

Pianists, too, must form enormously complicated hand shapes at an instant’s notice, and singers and players of wind instruments need to do similar things with their lips, teeth, and tongues.

 

要求如此精确的学习技能的最大问题之一是计算机科学家有时所说的“归咎分配”问题：当出现问题时，有时很难找出确切的原因。罚球不中的篮球运动员一定想知道问题出在肘部还是手腕上；吉他手一定想知道是肘部、手腕还是指尖下方的关节。世界级音乐家和运动员人们之所以经常聘请教练，是因为即使是表现最好的人有时也无法诊断自己的局限性。吉他手可能不需要大块的肌肉，但弹吉他确实是一项运动，对高效、准确的演奏有着同样严格的要求。

One of the biggest problems with learning skills that demand such precision is what computer scientists sometimes call the problem of “blame assignment”: when something goes wrong, it’s sometimes difficult to figure out exactly why. The basketball player who misses a free throw must wonder whether the problem lies with the elbow or the wrist; the guitarist must wonder whether it is the elbow, the wrist, or the joint just below the fingertip. World-class musicians and athletes so often hire coaches because even the best performers sometimes can’t diagnose their own limitations. Guitarists may not need big muscles, but playing the guitar is truly an athletic endeavor with the same rigorous demands for efficient and accurate performance.

 

 

几乎在音乐的每个方面，纯粹的物理速度都是至关重要的。在这里，有抱负的国际象棋大师摆脱了困境——除了闪电象棋之外，移动后的物理速度并不是真正的问题——但有抱负的音乐家却不然。吉他手必须像外科医生一样精确地移动他或她的手，并在完美的时间里这样做，频繁地重塑他或她的手，通常是每秒多次，每次在正确的时间落在正确的琴弦上，将施加适量的压力，然后尽可能高效地移动到下一个位置。

In virtually every aspect of music, sheer physical speed is crucial. Here the aspiring chess master gets off the hook— except possibly in lightning chess, the physical speed at which one moves one’s queen is not really an issue— but the aspiring musician does not. The guitarist must move his or her hands with the precision of a surgeon and do so in perfect time, reshaping his or her hands frequently, often many times a second, each time landing on exactly the right strings, at exactly the right time, placing just the right amount of pressure, and then moving on to the next position as efficiently as possible.

更糟糕的是，音乐家不仅需要速度快，还需要速度快。他们还必须在准确的时间执行每个动作——这是人类大脑没有自然准备的另一项壮举。计算机和微波炉出厂时的时钟都精确到毫秒，而这种精确度的计时是人类一生的追求。如果你，一个人而不是一个数字时钟，尝试精确地数出十二秒，你会发现相当大的滑动；一次你可能做得对，下一次你可能太快，第三次又太慢。我们天生具有昼夜节律，使我们能够跟踪一天中的大致时间，但以毫秒为单位跟踪时间却带来了严峻的挑战。

Worse than that, musicians don’t just have to be quick; they also have to perform each movement at precisely the right time— another feat that the human brain is not naturally prepared for. Whereas computers and microwave ovens all come from the factory with clocks that are accurate to the millisecond, timing at that level of precision is for human beings a lifelong pursuit. If you, a human being rather than a digital clock, try to count out exactly twelve seconds, you will find considerable slippage; one time you may get it right, the next you may be too fast, the third too slow. We are naturally endowed with circadian rhythms that allow us to keep track of the general time of day, but tracking time in milliseconds poses serious challenges.

 

为了达到这种精确度，有抱负的音乐家经常花费数百或数千小时随着节拍器稳定的滴答声进行演奏。他们的目标不仅仅是能够在节拍器响起时准确地演奏每个节拍，而是掌握时间在节拍器的节拍之间——例如，在节拍器的四分音符之间精确地演奏八分音符（或者更难，将四分音符之间的周期划分为更小的部分，如三连音或十六分音符）；在许多音乐传统中，音乐家会做一些更具挑战性的事情，那就是故意在节拍之前或之后演奏（每种都会产生不同的节奏感）。瞬间计时对于计算机来说是很自然的事情，但人类的大脑永远无法完全掌握它。即使是训练有素的音乐家有时也会陷入听觉错觉。举一个例子，充满细分（例如，可听的十六分音符）的时间间隔在主观上听起来比没有填充类似细分的时间间隔更长。

To develop that level of precision, aspiring musicians often spend hundreds or thousands of hours playing along to the steady tick-tock-tick-tock of a metronome. Their goal is not just to be able to play each beat exactly when the metronome clicks but to master the time in between the metronome’s beats—to play, for example, eighth notes exactly in between the metronome’s quarter notes (or, harder still, to divide the period between quarter notes into smaller divisions like triplets or sixteenth notes); in many musical traditions, musicians do something even more challenging, which is to deliberately play ahead of or behind the beat (each of which creates a different rhythmic feel). Split-second timing comes naturally to computers, but human brains never fully master it. Even trained musicians sometimes fall prey to auditory illusions. To take one example, temporal intervals that are filled with subdivisions (for instance, audible sixteenth notes) sound subjectively longer than temporal intervals that aren’t filled with comparable subdivisions.

 

掌握时间实际上可能需要数年时间。我认识的一位职业音乐家朋友讲述了一个故事，在他职业生涯的十年里，他如何与一位著名的爵士音乐家一起参加大师班，希望获得对即兴创作的深入了解。“当然，”他的老师在第一次采访后看着我朋友打球时说道。“我们可以解决你的问题。” 但对于即兴创作却只字未提。相反，这位伟大的大师说：“聆听[计时传奇]阿特·布莱基的任何作品，并按照节奏进行演奏。这会修正你的时间观念。”

Mastering time can literally take years. One professional musician friend I know tells a story of how, a decade into his career, he went to a master class with a famous jazz musician, hoping to gain great insight into improvisation. “Sure,” his teacher said, after a first interview, watching my friend play. “We can fix your problems.” But not a word was said about improvisation; instead, the great master said, “Listen to anything by [the timekeeping legend] Art Blakey and play along to the groove. That’ll fix your sense of time.”

 

 

对于普通人来说，更困难的是同时计算两个或更多的东西，这是除了最简单的音乐之外的所有音乐中都需要的。我手机上的一个廉价应用程序让我可以使用十几个倒计时器，所有计时器都非常精确，每个计时器都独立于下一个计时器。当我们必须保持至少两个时间序列连续时，人类的思维就会紧张。例如，尝试用左手数出三拍，用右手数出两拍的循环节奏，首先以慢速开始，然后逐渐加快节奏。大多数非音乐家觉得这很难，至少一开始是这样。即使你掌握了它的窍门，无论你是否是一位训练有素的音乐家，你几乎肯定会发现，随着你的速度越来越快，你很快就会达到节奏崩溃的速度。三拍二拍最终“演变”（使用专业术语）为二拍一拍，而且一拍更快；最终演变成一对一。

Even harder for ordinary mortals is counting two or more things at once, something that is required in all but the simplest music. A cheap app on my phone gives me access to a dozen countdown timers, all perfectly precise, each one independent of the next. The human mind strains when we have to keep as few as two time sequences straight. Try, for example, to count out a cyclical rhythm of three beats with your left hand against two with your right, starting first at a slow speed and gradually increasing the tempo. Most nonmusicians find this hard, at least at first. And even once you get the hang of it, whether or not you are a trained musician, you will almost surely find that as you go faster and faster, you soon reach a speed at which the rhythm breaks down. Three beats against two eventually “devolves” (to use the technical term) into two beats against one, and one goes faster still; it eventually devolves into one against one.

作为另一项练习，尝试交替使用左手和右手，首先每秒一次，然后逐渐加快速度。会发生什么？（尝试一下！）最终，大多数未经训练的音乐家的手会从异相（左手向上，右手向下，反之亦然）变为同相（双手同时举起，与说明直接矛盾）。更复杂的比例，比如 7:5（远远超出了像我这样的初学者可以应对的范围），就更难了；人类的思维认为 1:1 很容易，但几乎其他一切都很困难，特别是当我们试图以快节奏演奏时。

As another exercise, try alternating between your left hand and your right, first once per second and then gradually increasing the speed. What happens? (Try it!) Eventually, the hands of most people who are not trained musicians go from being out of phase (left hand up while right hand is down, and vice versa) to being in phase (both hands up at the same time, in direct contradiction to the instructions). More complicated ratios, like 7:5 (way outside the range of what a beginner like me could cope with), are even harder; the human mind finds 1:1 easy, but almost everything else is hard, particularly as we try to play at a rapid tempo.

 

音乐的本质要求表演者在不同的时间安排上执行许多不同的动作，但我们的大脑中似乎只有一个主时钟。当我们尝试产生复杂的比率时，我们经常使时钟负担过重。每个鼓手的目标都是实现四肢之间的“独立”——这是一个崇高的目标，但却与我们的自然倾向背道而驰。

The nature of music requires performers to execute many different actions on different time schedules, but we appear to have only one master clock in the head. As we try to produce complex ratios, we often overburden that clock. The goal of every drummer is to achieve “independence” between his or her limbs—a noble goal, but one that runs directly counter to our natural tendencies.

 

事实上，我们在生命早期就存在独立协调四肢的自然挑战。婴儿经常犯一些所谓的“溢出错误”，即他们毫无意义地移动一只手与另一只手对称，例如，当他们试图用左手抓住东西时，他们会举起右手。目前的证据表明，大脑根本无法实现真正​​的独立，而是学习越来越复杂的方式将两只手（或两只手和两只脚）的单独动作分组（或“分块”）在一起，从而产生一种独立的幻觉，其中实际上没有一个存在。我们走得越快，这种幻想就越有可能被打破。

In fact, our natural challenges with coordinating our limbs independently are present early in life. Babies frequently make something called overflow errors, in which they pointlessly move one hand in symmetry with the other, lifting their right, for example, when they try to grab something with the left. Current evidence suggests that the brain never achieves true independence at all, but rather learns increasingly intricate ways of grouping (or “chunking”) the separate actions of the two hands (or two hands and two feet) together, yielding an illusion of independence where none actually exists. The faster we go, the more likely that illusion is to break.

 

 

最终，有抱负的音乐家表演的各个方面都必须变得自动，以尽可能少的努力实现，就像经验丰富的驾驶员在转弯时协调方向盘和刹车的过程一样。音乐也是如此。最初，每个元素都需要高度集中。当我在可怕的F和弦上挣扎时，我的牙齿会咬紧，而且当我试图进行复杂的和弦变化时，我不止一次会忘记完全保持节拍。

Ultimately, every aspect of an aspiring musician’s performance must become automatic, achieved with as little effort as possible, like the process of an experienced driver coordinating the steering wheel and the brakes in turning a corner. The same happens with music; initially, each element takes immense concentration. My teeth would clench as I struggled with the dreaded F chord, and more than once I would forget to keep the beat altogether when I tried to make a complicated chord change.

然而另一个挑战源于这样一个事实：大脑通常受到所谓的速度与准确性权衡的束缚：几乎对于我们所做的任何事情，我们走得越快，我们就越有可能犯错误。欲速则不达，确实容易造成浪费。为了有效地发挥作用，音乐家必须规避这一定律，演奏得又快又准。（初学者可能会以每分钟四十拍的速度在 E 小调和弦和 A 小调和弦之间交替，但是摇滚歌曲可能需要三倍的节奏，没有错误，完美的节奏，而朋克歌曲或重金属歌曲可能需要所有的节奏）速度超过每分钟两百次。）

Yet another challenge stems from the fact that the brain is ordinarily bound by what is known as the speed-accuracy trade-off: for virtually anything we do, the faster we go, the more likely we are to make errors. Haste really does tend to make waste. In order to be effective, musicians must circumvent this law, playing both quickly and accurately. (A beginner might alternate between the E minor chord and the A minor chord at forty beats per minute, but a rock song could require triple that, with no mistakes, in perfect tempo, and a punk song or heavy metal song could require all of that at speeds of over two hundred beats per minute.)

 

唉，唯一已知的克服速度与准确性权衡的方法是通过练习，使用大脑可以运用的唯一技术，这个过程被称为自动化或程序化，在这个过程中，大脑从显式或“原则上可以口头表达的“陈述性”知识（尽管很慢），而可以快速执行的隐性或“程序性”知识。随着知识变得程序化，我们有时会感觉好像我们的手指或肌肉知道一些东西，但失去了明确解释正在发生的事情的能力。

Alas, the only known way to defy the speed-accuracy trade-off is through practice, using the only technique that the brain can bring to bear, a process known as automatization or proceduralization, in which the brain makes a transition from explicit or “declarative” knowledge, which can in principle be verbally articulated (albeit slowly), to implicit or “procedural” knowledge, which can be executed rapidly. As knowledge becomes proceduralized, we sometimes feel as if we know something in our fingers or muscles but lose the capacity to explicitly explain what is going on.

 

在此过程中，简单的步骤被组合或“分解”成更高效、更大的单元。比如说，当我第一次学开车时，我知道左转由几个不同的单独铰接的元素组成（“施加制动压力”、“使用转向灯”、“转动方向盘”、“向两边看”、“恢复油门”、“监控汽车保持在原位”）车道”），但很难协调所有这些。在急于同时控制转向和刹车的过程中，我有时会忘记打开转向灯，或者更糟糕的是，忘记看两边。幸运的是，我的大脑最终成功地将整个复杂的动作集重新编码为一个可以毫不费力地执行的整体或“程序”（“向左转”）。对于任何技能来说，情况都是一样的。最终，一些最初需要付出巨大努力的技能变得如此自动，以至于减少了有意识的注意力，并为其他任务留出了空间。

During this process, simple steps get combined or “chunked” into more efficient, larger units. For instance, when I first learned to drive, I knew that taking a left turn consisted of several different individually articulated elements (“apply brake pressure,” “use turn signal,” “turn steering wheel,” “look both ways,” “resume gas,” “monitor car to stay in lane”), but it was hard to coordinate them all. In the rush to simultaneously control the steering and the brakes, I’d sometimes forget to flip on the turn signal or, worse, forget to look both ways. Fortunately, my brain eventually managed to re-encode the whole complex set of actions into a single ensemble or “procedure” (“make a left”) that could be executed effortlessly. Much the same happens for any skill; eventually, some of the skills that initially required a great deal of effort become so automatic they take up less conscious focus and leave room for other tasks.

 

通过确保程序化的是正确的习惯，刻意练习大概可以使这种情况更快地发生。如果不仔细选择练习制度，学习者可能会自动养成坏习惯，从而形成草率或不充分的程序，从而阻碍未来的进步。

Deliberate practice can presumably make this happen faster, by ensuring that what gets proceduralized is the right set of habits. When practice regimes aren’t selected with care, the learner may wind up automatizing bad habits and thus enshrine sloppy or inadequate procedures, in a way that impedes future progress.

 

在神经层面，程序化由一系列精心协调的过程组成，包括灰质（神经细胞体）和白质（连接神经元之间的轴突和树突）的变化。现有的神经连接（突触）必须变得更加有效，新的树突棘可能会形成，并且蛋白质必须被合成。通常，最初存储在前额叶皮层（我们将其与意识认知联系起来）中的心理表征会转移到大脑的新部分，例如与记忆相关的海马体、负责记忆的运动皮层和基底神经节。更直接地控制我们的肌肉。

At the neural level, proceduralization consists of a wide array of carefully coordinated processes, including changes to both gray matter (neural cell bodies) and white matter (axons and dendrites that connect between neurons). Existing neural connections (synapses) must be made more efficient, new dendritic spines may be formed, and proteins must be synthesized. Often, mental representations that are initially stored in the prefrontal cortex (which we associate with conscious cognition) shift to new parts of the brain such as the hippocampus, associated with memory, and the motor cortex and the basal ganglia, which are in charge of the more immediate control of our muscles.

 

在所有这些练习刺激的大脑发育开始发生之前，你也许能够享受音乐，但你肯定无法演奏它。当我努力形成我的和弦并在它们之间顺利变化时，每次我坐下来演奏时，我都会想起这一点。

Until all that practice-spurred brain growth starts to happen, you might be able to enjoy music, but you certainly won’t be able to play it. As I struggled to form my chords and change smoothly between them, I was reminded of this, every time I sat down to play.

 

*古典传统中的高级学生必须面对更大的复杂性，例如在某些情况下 D 也可以被称为 C##，或者在哪些情况下可以引用上面的注释E 为 E#，而不是更传统的 F。

* Advanced students in the classical tradition have to confront even greater complications, such as the way in which D can also be referred to as C## in certain contexts, or the precise set of circumstances under which it is okay to refer to the note above E as E# rather than the more conventional F.

*在某种程度上，大多数人，甚至是未经训练的听众，实际上都兼有两者：一种用音符之间的抽象关系（相对音高）来表示歌曲的心理系统，以及一种类似于绝对音高的虚拟磁带录音，这使我们能够以接近录制音调的方式演唱非常熟悉的歌曲。然而，后者与技术上所谓的绝对音高不同，因为绝大多数人实际上无法说出他们正在聆听或回忆的各个音符。

* To some extent, most people, even untrained listeners, actually have a bit of both: a mental system that represents songs in terms of abstract relations between notes (relative pitch), and a kind of virtual tape-recording, akin to absolute pitch, that allows us to sing highly familiar songs at close to their recorded pitch. The latter differs from what is technically known as absolute pitch, however, in that the vast majority of people can’t actually name the individual notes they are listening to or recalling.

 

说话的头像

TALKING HEADS

 

音乐与语言有何不同

How Music Is— and Isn’ t— Like Language

 

语言和音乐有很多共同点，而我这个终生学习语言的人，现在沉浸在音乐中，我不禁不断反思两者之间的关系。

Language and music have a lot in common, and as I, a lifelong student of language, now immersed myself in music, I couldn’t help but constantly reflect upon the relation between the two.

用我的行业术语来说，语言和音乐都是“形式系统”。语言是由单词排列成句子组成的；歌曲由排列成旋律的音符组成。在这两种情况下，排列都不能只是随机的。音乐有管理的规则，就像语言有管理的规则一样。两者都是具有无限可能性的“有限系统”；英语字母表只有二十六个字母（有限），从莎士比亚到杰基·柯林斯以及未来几代作家可能写出的任何其他作品都源自这些字母（无限）。同样，从莫扎特到布兰妮·斯皮尔斯，西方音乐都以新的组合一遍又一遍地依赖相同的十二个音符。*

Both language and music are, in the terminology of my trade, “formal systems.” Languages are made up of words arranged into sentences; songs are made up of notes arranged into melodies. In neither case can the arrangement simply be random. There are rules that govern music, just as there are rules that govern language. Both are “finite systems” with infinite possibilities; the English alphabet has just twenty-six letters (finite), from which spring everything from Shakespeare to Jackie Collins and whatever else future generations of authors may write (infinite). Likewise, to a first approximation, Western music relies on the same twelve notes, over and over again, in new combinations, in everything from Mozart to Britney Spears.*

 

音乐和语言都在生命早期出现。孩子们在五个月大的时候就开始练习音节，许多人在一岁半的时候就开始唱歌。新生儿可以区分母亲的母语和其他语言，而且，正如我们之前所见，他们可以区分辅音和不协和和弦。但这不仅是音乐和语言似乎并行不悖，而且也是如此。对于一些学者来说，语言和音乐实际上是孪生反射，由不同的元素组成，但以相同的方式组合。

Both music and language emerge early in life; children start practicing syllables by the time they are five months old, and many start singing by the time they are a year and a half. Newborns can tell the difference between their mother’s native language and a different language, and, as we saw earlier, they can discriminate between consonant and dissonant chords. But it’s not just that music and language appear to lead parallel lives; to some scholars, language and music are actually twin reflexes, composed of different elements but assembled in the same way.

 

最具音乐性的生物——人类、鸣禽、鲸鱼和海豚——也是拥有最丰富的交流系统的生物，这难道是巧合吗？或者说，唯一能够及时跳舞的生物——人类、鸣禽和至少一只大象——都是声音模仿者？音乐是一种语言形式吗？或者语言是音乐的一种形式？又或者两人只是同路人？由于语言和音乐之间存在惊人的相似之处，理清两者之间的关系是理解音乐起源的重要第一步。

Is it coincidence that the most musical creatures— humans, songbirds, whales, and dolphins— are among the creatures with the richest systems for communication? Or that the only creatures that can dance in time— humans, songbirds, and at least one elephant— are all vocal mimics? Is music a form of language? Or is language a form of music? Or are the two just fellow travelers? Because of the striking parallels between language and music, sorting out the relation between the two is a vital first step in understanding where music came from.

 

 

几乎所有你能想象到的语言和音乐之间可能的关系都得到了支持。有些人将音乐视为一种特殊的语言形式；有些人则将音乐视为一种特殊的语言形式。其他人则将音乐视为自成一格，有其独立于语言的独立实体，所有明显的相似之处纯属巧合。

Just about every possible relation between language and music that you could imagine has been championed. Some have seen music as a special form of language; others have seen music as sui generis, its own independent entity separate from language, all apparent resemblance merely coincidental.

不需要天才就能意识到音乐和语言实际上不可能完全相同。例如，一个人不会通过学习说话而自动变得有音乐天赋（反之亦然）。大多数人都能流利地说母语，但很少有人（除了训练有素的音乐家）能够完全掌握相对音高。即使说话有声调语言——如普通话（其中一个词的含义部分由其音调轮廓定义，例如，当用高平声发音表示“喝”的词时，表示“河”）语气上升）——并不能保证。有很多受过音乐学院训练的音乐家，他们会说声调语言，但仍然无法获得完美的音调。尽管音乐很可能借鉴语言，但它显然也有自己的独立元素。例如，音调的整个概念似乎在语言中缺乏任何直接的对应物。

It doesn’t take a genius to realize that music and language can’t literally be identical. One doesn’t automatically become musical by learning to talk, for instance (nor the other way around). Most people speak a native language fluently, but few (aside from trained musicians) manage to fully master relative pitch. Even speaking a tonal language—like Mandarin Chinese (in which the meaning of a word is defined in part by its pitch contour, such that, for example, the word that means “to drink” when uttered with a high flat tone means “river” when it is said with a rising tone)—is no guarantee. There are plenty of conservatory-trained musicians who speak tonal languages yet still fail to acquire perfect pitch. Although music may well draw on language, it clearly has its own independent elements, too; the whole notion of musical key, for instance, seems to lack any direct counterpart in language.

 

这些考虑导致一些人主张相反的极端，即语言和音乐可能是身体和心理上不同的“模块”。支持这种观点的第一个论点来自弗朗茨·约瑟夫·加尔 (Franz Joseph Gall)，他在 1825 年描述了一位患有脑损伤的患者，他的音乐能力受损，但其他方面似乎正常，这表明音乐能力可以与其他能力分开。与语言有关。从那时起，我们又发现了更多有趣的患者，其中一些患者除了语言能力正常外，还存在音乐障碍（例如失语症，一种严重的音调障碍，通常包括无法识别旋律之间的差异），还有一些患者的语言能力受损（失语症）。很大程度上保留了音乐能力。患有阿尔茨海默氏症等疾病晚期的人有时会表现出明显的语言功能受损，但仍然能够识别很久以前学过的歌曲。奥利弗·萨克斯（Oliver Sacks）在他的《音乐爱好》一书中描述了一位相反方向的病人，一位整形外科医生，在被闪电击中后开始沉迷于钢琴，但他的语言能力没有明显变化。

Such considerations have led some to argue for the opposite extreme, for a view in which language and music might be physically and psychologically distinct “modules.” One of the first arguments for this sort of view came nearly two hundred years ago, from Franz Joseph Gall, who in 1825 described a patient with brain damage who had impaired musical abilities but otherwise seemed normal, suggesting that musical faculties could be separated from those pertaining to language. Since then, many more intriguing patients have been found— some with musical impairments (such as amusia, a profound impairment in pitch that often includes the inability to recognize differences between melodies) alongside normal linguistic abilities, another with impaired language abilities (aphasia) yet largely preserved musical abilities. People in the late stages of diseases like Alzheimer’s sometimes show markedly impaired linguistic function yet still manage to recognize songs learned long ago. In his book Musicophilia, Oliver Sacks described a patient who went in something of the opposite direction, an orthopedic surgeon who became obsessed with piano after being struck by lightning, with no apparent changes to his linguistic abilities.

 

 

正如我们之前所看到的，还没有人在大脑中找到一个专门针对音乐而不是其他东西的位置。布罗卡区受牵连在语言和音乐中，前额叶皮层也是如此，它与从讽刺到音调感知、性高潮和爵士乐即兴创作等一切事物有关。音乐与语言一样，是一种需要广泛利用大脑资源的活动。其中许多资源由这两种技能共享。正如神经科学家阿尼鲁德·帕特尔 (Aniruddh Patel) 最近的一篇评论所显示的那样，数十项研究都指出，有助于语言的大脑机制和有助于音乐的大脑机制之间存在一定程度的重叠。

As we saw earlier, nobody has yet found a spot in the brain that is tuned exclusively to music and nothing else. Broca’s area is implicated in both language and music, and the same can be said for the prefrontal cortex, which has been implicated in everything from sarcasm to pitch perception, orgasm, and jazz improvisation. Music— like language— is an activity that draws on a wide range of the brain’s resources. Many of those resources are shared by the two skills. As a recent review by the neuroscientist Aniruddh Patel shows, literally dozens of studies have pointed to some degree of overlap between the brain mechanisms that contribute to language and those that contribute to music.

同样，一些脑损伤患者表现出对语言或音乐的选择性损伤，但许多对其中一种表现出损伤的患者也对另一种表现出损伤。在我能找到的最系统的脑损伤研究回顾中，近三分之一有音乐障碍的患者也有语言障碍。

Similarly, some patients with brain damage show selective impairments for language or music, but many patients who show impairments for one also show impairments for the other. In the most systematic review of brain damage studies that I could find, nearly a third of all patients with musical impairments also had impairments with language.

 

音乐和语言之间的神经重叠在越来越多的心理学文献中得到了呼应，这些文献显示了音乐和语言能力之间的相关性。一组研究表明，讲普通话等声调语言的人能够更好地辨别音高。另一项针对学习英语的日本人的研究发现，能够更好地唱出旋律并说出和弦中有多少个音符的人更容易识别声音 l 和 r 之间的语言差异，这进一步证明了语言和音乐正在利用一些相同的电路。

The neural overlap between music and language is echoed in a growing psychological literature that shows correlations between musical and linguistic abilities. One set of studies shows that people who speak tonal languages like Mandarin are better able to discriminate musical pitch. Another, a study of Japanese speakers learning English, found that people who were better able to sing back melodies and tell how many notes were in a chord were better at recognizing the linguistic difference between the sounds l and r— further evidence that language and music are tapping into some of the same circuitry.

 

另一组研究要求以英语为母语的人听诸如“间谍遇到的警察写了一本关于此案的书”之类的句子，并用包含或不包含走调音符的旋律来演唱，结果发现，在更多的情况下，当语言和音乐是由完全独立的大脑机制处理时，这种结果将很难解释。另一项调查表明，训练儿童音调的过程有助于他们更好地识别言语中的情绪。

Another set of studies required native English speakers to listen to sentences like “The cop that the spy met wrote a book about the case,” sung to melodies that did or did not contain an out-of-key note, and found that in more difficult sentences, the out-of-key notes interfered with people’s sentence comprehension— a result that would be hard to explain if language and music were processed by entirely separate brain mechanisms. Still another line of inquiry has shown that the process of training children in musical pitch helps them to better identify the emotions in speech.

 

 

大脑的不同部分是专门化的，但并不像我们预期的那样。每种心理能力不是为每个内容区域分配一个不同的区域（例如，语言、音乐、运动控制），而是利用广泛的大脑区域，并可能以独特的组合使用。例如，每当大脑需要将较小的单位组合成较大的单位时，就可以使用布罗卡区，无论是将语言的声音组合成单词，将音乐的音符组合成短语，还是在规划运动动作时使我们能够使用工具。同样，海马体作为记忆引擎反复发挥着作用，不仅在电话号码或历史日期等细节的记忆中，而且在几乎任何需要发展所谓肌肉记忆的技能中以微妙的方式发挥作用。语言可能使用与音乐不同的大脑区域群，但两者都不依赖于完全独特的神经区域。

Different parts of the brain are specialized, but not in the way we anticipated. Rather than allocating a distinct region for each content area (say, language versus music versus motor control), each mental ability draws upon a broad range of brain areas, perhaps used in unique combinations. Broca’s area, for instance, may be used whenever the brain needs to combine smaller units into larger units, whether it be in combining the sounds of language into words, in combining the notes of music into a phrase, or in the planning of motor actions that allow us to use tools. Similarly, the hippocampus plays a recurring role as an engine for memory, not just in the memory for details like phone numbers or historical dates, but also in subtle ways in virtually any skill that demands the development of so-called muscle memory. Language might use a different constellation of brain areas than music does, but neither depends on entirely unique neural real estate.

我发现有用的一个比喻是工具包。例如，如果一个人建造一张桌子或一把椅子，往往会重复使用一套特定的工具，例如锤子、螺丝刀、锯子和扳手。尽管人们可能偶尔需要特殊用途的工具（例如自行车商店中的辐条扳手），但许多工具会反复用于各种任务。这并不是说应该使用锤子来执行螺丝刀的功能，或者螺丝刀可以代替锤子，而是说最终产品通常会利用广泛的工具，这些工具以特定的方式使用特定项目。

One metaphor I find helpful is that of a tool kit. If one builds, say, a table or a chair, a certain set of tools tends to get used repeatedly, such as hammers, screwdrivers, saws, and wrenches. Although one might need the occasional special-purpose tool (like the spoke wrench in a bicycle shop), many tools get used over and over for a wide variety of tasks. This is to say not that a hammer should be used to perform the function of a screwdriver, or that a screwdriver may substitute for a hammer, but rather that the end products often draw upon a broad collection of tools that get used in particular ways for particular projects.

 

语言在很多方面与音乐相似，因为两者都是从相同的大脑工具基本集合中产生的产物。例如，两者都大量利用我们的记忆神经资源，无论是存储和识别特定的单词或短语，还是存储和检索特定的旋律或主题。虽然到了一定尽管我们对单词和旋律的长期记忆可能存储在物理上不同的地方，但两组记忆回路很可能是由相同的遗传密码构建的。因此，在这两种情况下，记忆都会以类似的方式崩溃。像“People people left left”这样的句子很难解析，就像菲利普·格拉斯（Philip Glass）的极简主义作品中大量重复大体相似的主题但略有变化一样，很难记住。正如我在《克鲁格》一书中讨论的那样，我们的记忆缺乏计算机所具有的整洁的表格形式的记忆，而我们想要记住的两件事越相似，我们就越有可能将它们混淆。听众会迷失在“People [whom] people left left”中，因为他们对名词“people”的哪个实例与动词“left”的哪个实例对应感到困惑；学习菲利普·格拉斯作品的音乐家同样会迷失在给定主题的变奏顺序中。

Language is similar in many ways to music because both are products that emerge from the same fundamental collection of brain tools. Both, for instance, draw heavily on our neural resources for memory, whether for storing and recognizing specific words or phrases, or for storing and retrieving specific melodies or motifs. Although to a certain extent our long-term memories for words and melodies may be stored in physically separate places, both sets of memory circuits are likely built by the same genetic code. As a consequence, memory breaks down in comparable ways in both cases. A sentence like “People people left left” is hard to parse for the same reason that a minimalist composition by Philip Glass with numerous repetitions of generally similar motifs with slight variations can be hard to memorize. As I discussed in my book Kluge, our memories lack the neat tabular form of memory that computers have, and the more similar two things we aim to remember are, the more likely we are to confuse them. Listeners get lost in “People [whom] people left left” because they get confused about which instance of the noun “people” goes with which instance of the verb “left”; musicians learning Philip Glass pieces can equally get lost in sequencing which variation on a given motif goes where.

 

 

随着人们重新认识到音乐和语言之间存在一些重要的重叠，达尔文的一个古老假设又重新流行起来。在发表了开创性的《物种起源》之后， 达尔文 意识到音乐和语言提出了类似的难题：如果所有现代物种都是从其祖先的进化而来，那么为什么语言和音乐在动物世界中几乎没有明显的对应物？他们的出现有联系吗？达尔文在《人类的由来》中提出，音乐“原始语言”可能首先出现，语言是从音乐中产生的。

As the pendulum swings back toward the view that there is some important overlap between music and language, an old hypothesis of Darwin’s has come back into vogue. After his seminal On the Origin of Species, Darwin realized that music and language posed similar puzzles: If all modern species descended with modification from their predecessors, why was it that language and music had so few obvious counterparts in the animal world? Could their emergence be linked? Darwin proposed in The Descent of Man that a musical “protolanguage” might have come first, with language emerging from music.

考古学家史蒂文·米森（Steven Mithen）是这一假说最乐观的支持者之一，他是经常被引用的《歌唱的尼安德特人》一书的作者。在米森看来，音乐早在语言出现之前就进入了原始人类谱系，而语言（或语言的某种原始语言学先驱）是从音乐中出现的。

One of this hypothesis’s most cheerful exponents is the archaeologist Steven Mithen, author of the often-cited The Singing Neanderthals. In Mithen’s view, music entered the hominid lineage long before language did, and language (or some protolinguistic precursor of language) emerged from music.

 

为了捍卫音乐可能以某种方式领先的主张对于语言，米森指出了母亲语的假定普遍性，这是一种由长元音、高音调和夸张的音高轮廓组成的音乐音域，是成人与婴儿交谈的特征。但即使它是普遍的（这是一个有争议的问题），母亲语也可能不是真正与生俱来的。个别父母可能会想出这个想法（或从长辈那里借用），只是因为婴儿更注意它，也许是因为婴儿更容易听到，或者因为母亲的高音本质上听起来很快乐或接近听觉甜蜜点。

In defense of the proposition that music might somehow precede language, Mithen points to the putative universality of motherese, a musical register of long vowels, high pitches, and exaggerated pitch contours that characterize how adults talk to babies. But even if it is universal (a matter that is in dispute), motherese may not be truly innate. Individual parents might work out the idea (or borrow it from their elders) simply because infants pay more attention to it, perhaps because it is easier for the infants to hear or because the high pitches of motherese intrinsically sound happy or fall close to an auditory sweet spot.

 

米森关于音乐原始语言这一想法的另一个论点源自他自己的个人经历。米森指出，作为一个成年人，他（第一次）能够发展一些歌唱技巧——在音乐闲置了三十五年之后，他参加了一年的歌唱课程——并且功能性核磁共振（fMRI）显示，结果他的大脑发生了变化。米森由此得出结论：“实际上，我开始释放潜在的音乐性，这种音乐性是在数百万年的进化中被放置在那里的，[迄今为止]被忽视并且……处于休眠状态。” 也许。但只要我们做任何事，大脑就会发生变化。最近的一项研究表明，大脑的变化与高尔夫技能的发展有关，另一项研究则与学习探戈有关，但人们很难从这一事实中推断出高尔夫是我们休眠的进化遗产的直接反映。

Another of Mithen’s arguments for the idea of a musical protolanguage derives from his own personal experience. Mithen notes that as an adult he was able (for the first time) to develop some skill at singing— taking a year’s worth of singing lessons after being musically idle for thirty-five years— and a functional MRI (fMRI) revealed that there were changes in his brain as a consequence. From this Mithen concludes, “In effect, I began to release potential musicality that has been placed there by millions of years of evolution, [heretofore] neglected and … dormant.” Well, maybe. But the brain changes anytime we do anything; one recent study showed changes in the brain associated with developing skill at golf, another at learning the tango, but one would hardly want to infer from that fact that golf was a direct reflection of our dormant evolutionary heritage.

 

归根结底，据我所知，除了音乐（可以说）在动物世界中比语言更普遍这一真实但令人困扰的直觉之外，确实没有任何充分的理由认为音乐先于语言。例如，鸟类和鲸鱼拥有“音乐”交流系统，这些系统依赖于具有不同时间持续时间的有序音调集，但只有人类利用我们称之为单词和句子的有序音素集。尽管如此，单纯的流行率并不能告诉我们什么。生理学的许多方面，从循环系统到生育后代的哺乳动物特征，都比音乐普遍得多，但显然与语言没有什么直接关系。值得注意的是，音乐几乎完全没有出现在队列中我们最直接衍生的生物。尽管大猩猩确实有节奏地拍打胸部，就像原版《金刚》中一样，但绝大多数非人类灵长类动物对音乐几乎不感兴趣。如果某些早期脊椎动物是有音乐性的，从而产生了鸣禽和鲸鱼，那么这种音乐性在产生灵长类动物的祖先分支中早已消失了——这意味着我们仍然需要重新发展音乐。鸟类和鲸鱼的通讯系统很可能在很大程度上独立于我们的进化，也许共享一些听觉的一般特性，这些特性可以进一步追溯到一些共同的祖先，但仍然让人类进行了大量的改造。

In the final analysis, as far as I can tell, there really isn’t any good reason to think that music preceded language, beyond the true but troubled intuition that music is (arguably) more prevalent than language in the animal world. Birds and whales, for example, have “musical” communicative systems that depend on ordered sets of pitches with varying temporal durations, but only humans exploit the ordered sets of phonemes that we call words and sentences. Still, sheer prevalence tells us little; many aspects of physiology, ranging from circulatory systems to the defining mammalian characteristic of bearing live young, are far more prevalent than music, yet obviously of little direct relevance to language. Tellingly, music is almost entirely absent in the line of creatures from which we most directly derive. Although gorillas do beat their chests rhythmically, just like in the original King Kong, the vast majority of nonhuman primates show almost no interest in music. If some early vertebrate creature was musical, giving rise to songbirds and whales, that musicality was long lost in the ancestral branch that gave rise to primates— which means we still had to have developed music anew. In all likelihood, the communication systems of birds and whales evolved largely independently of ours, perhaps sharing some general properties of audition that trace further back to some common ancestor, but still leaving humans to do a lot of reinvention.

 

与此同时，语言无处不在，几乎每个正常人都会习得，但近 5% 的人是音盲，许多人无法可靠地唱歌。当人们考虑到儿童和未经训练的成年人在提取简单的音程时所面临的麻烦，而不是幼儿将音节串在一起的天赋时，音乐作为语言直接先驱的故事似乎非常难以置信。

Meanwhile, language is ubiquitous, acquired by essentially every normal human being, yet nearly 5 percent of the population is tone-deaf, and many people can’t reliably sing on pitch. When one considers the trouble that children— and untrained adults— face in extracting even simple musical intervals as opposed to the gifts that toddlers have in stringing syllables together, the story in which music served as a direct precursor to language seems deeply implausible.

 

此外，已知最早的乐器——在德国的一个洞穴中发现的象牙笛——只有大约三万六千年的历史，大多数学者认为语言的出现要早得多：至少五万年前（有些人将语言视为可以追溯到几百万年前）。当然，我们的祖先可能在制造乐器之前就已经唱歌了，但考古记录中并没有特别的理由这么认为。事实上，我们的祖先很早就开始制造其他类型的工具，至少有一百万年了，这表明我们的早期祖先缺乏音乐工具并不是因为缺乏工具制造能力。

Furthermore, the earliest known musical instrument— an ivory flute found in a cave in Germany— is only about thirty-six thousand years old, and most scholars place the advent of language considerably earlier: at least fifty thousand years ago (some place language as far back as a few million years). Of course, our ancestors may have sung before they made instruments, but there is no particular reason in the archaeological record to think so. In fact, our ancestors were making other kinds of tools far earlier, for at least a million years, suggesting that the lack of musical tools by our early ancestors wasn’t due to a lack of toolmaking ability.

 

事实上，正如我们稍后将看到的，尽管大多数学者都同意语言可能是自然选择的直接产物，但有充分的理由认为音乐不是，而是更类似于一种文化获得的活动（如阅读或悬挂式滑翔）比任何通过进化直接连接到大脑的东西都要重要。

Indeed, as we will later see, although most scholars would agree that language is likely a direct product of natural selection, there is good reason to think music is not, but is more akin to a culturally acquired activity (like reading or hang gliding) than anything directly wired into the brain through evolution.

 

与此同时，每当旋律和歌词发生冲突时，歌词往往会获胜。正如我们之前所看到的，如果有选择的话，婴儿更喜欢听语音而不是器乐，而且一些研究表明，对于没有受过音乐训练的人来说，歌词比旋律更容易记住。另一项研究表明，如果两首歌有相同的歌词（即使旋律发生变化），四岁的孩子就会认为两首歌是相同的，但如果两首歌有相同的旋律（如果歌词不同），那么四岁的孩子就会认为两首歌是相同的。最近的一项研究表明，十一个月大的婴儿也会出现同样的现象。音乐和语言可能在某种程度上利用了大脑的相同部分，但很可能它们共享的大脑部分首先是为语言服务而出现的，后来才被招募来为音乐服务的。

Meanwhile, whenever melody and lyrics clash, lyrics tend to win. As we saw earlier, infants would prefer to hear speech to instrumental music, given the choice, and several studies have shown that for people without musical training, lyrics are more easily remembered than melodies. Another shows that four-year-olds consider two songs to be the same if they have the same lyrics (even if the melodies change), but not if two songs have the same melody (if the lyrics differ). A more recent study has shown a precursor of the same phenomenon with eleven-month-olds. Music and language may draw to some extent on the same parts of the brain, but it is very likely that the parts of the brain they share first arose in the service of language and only later became recruited in the service of music.

 

 

如果语言先行（似乎更有可能），这是否意味着音乐只不过是一种特殊的语言形式？完全不是：两者可能有很多共同之处，但各自仍然独立。迄今为止，我所见过的关于这场辩论的最清醒和最有资格的观点来自雷·杰肯多夫（Ray Jackendoff），他是一位受人尊敬的语言学家（由诺姆·乔姆斯基训练），一位卓有成就的单簧管演奏家，也是世界上对音乐理论的科学理解的主要贡献者之一（与作曲家 Fred Lerdahl 合着了影响巨大的书《音调音乐的生成理论》）。

If language came first, as seems more likely, does that mean music is nothing more than a special form of language? Not at all: the two may share a lot, but each still stands on its own. By far the most sober and qualified perspective on this debate that I have seen comes from Ray Jackendoff, a well-respected linguist (trained by Noam Chomsky), an accomplished clarinetist, and one of the world’s leading contributors to the scientific understanding of music theory (co-author, with the composer Fred Lerdahl, of the enormously influential book A Generative Theory of Tonal Music).

杰肯多夫在参观他位于波士顿郊区的家时向我提出，语言与音乐并不相似，而与制作一杯咖啡所涉及的复杂的层次规划过程并不相似。起初我以为他是在开玩笑，但事实上他说的很有道理。在一篇学术文章中，Jackendoff 将制作一杯咖啡的过程分解为由 23 个事件和子事件组成的层次结构，例如“将壶放在水龙头下”（一个较低级别的子事件，可能类似于一个单词或音乐剧）主题）和“将水放入机器”（一个更高级别的子事件，可能类似于句子或句子的一部分）歌曲），设置为与语言学家用于描述语言（以及杰肯道夫本人用于分析音乐）相同的技术机制。在杰肯多夫看来，这种所谓的组合性对于音乐和语言来说都是至关重要的，但它并不是这两个领域所独有的。语言确实与音乐有很多共同点，但问题不应该是“语言和音乐有什么共同点？” “语言和音乐有什么共同点，而没有其他共同点？”

Language, Jackendoff suggested to me during a visit to his suburban Boston home, is no more similar to music than it is to the sorts of complex hierarchical planning processes involved in making a cup of coffee. At first I thought he was kidding, but in fact he had a very good point to make. In an academic article, Jackendoff broke down the process of making a cup of coffee into a hierarchy of twenty-three events and subevents, such as “put pot under faucet” (a lower-level subevent, perhaps akin to a word or a musical motif) and “put water into machine” (a higher-level subevent, perhaps akin to a sentence or a section of a song), set into the same sort of technical machinery that linguists use for describing language (and that Jackendoff himself used for analyzing music). In Jackendoff’s view, this so-called compositionality is essential for music and for language, but it is hardly unique to either domain. Language really does share a lot with music, but the question should be not so much “What do language and music share?” as “What do lan guage and music share exclusively with each other but with nothing else?”

 

杰克多夫的观点（这与我们之前看到的布罗卡区在语言和音乐中被重用的观点相吻合）是，实际上语言和音乐所共享的认知结构的每个方面也与心灵的其他方面共享；两者都只是从广泛的重要认知资源中汲取灵感。例如，组合性——将较小的元素组合成大元素，形成更大的单元——是语言的标志，同样也是音乐的标志。但是，当我们将各个场景放在一起制作更大的故事或计划去购物中心时，我们也会利用组合性。实验证据表明，即使是整理床铺或洗碗等平凡的活动也可以分解为子事件的层次结构，这些子事件在心理上以类似的方式从一个人到另一个人进行表征。

Jackendoff’s point (which fits with what we saw earlier about Broca’s area being reused in both language and music) is that virtually every aspect of cognitive architecture that is shared by language and music is also shared with other aspects of the mind; both simply draw from a wide range of important cognitive resources. Compositionality, for instance— the putting together of smaller elements into big elements that form still larger units— is a hallmark of language and equally a hallmark of music. But we also exploit compositionality when we put together individual scenes to make larger stories, or plan a trip to the shopping mall. Experimental evidence shows that even mundane activities like making the bed or doing the dishes can be broken down into hierarchies of subevents that are mentally represented in similar ways from one individual to the next.

 

同样，语言和音乐都代表了普遍性和文化习得性的有趣混合，但这种混合本身并不是独一无二的。你可以在宗教中看到同样的并置，这种并置几乎是普遍存在的，但在不同的文化中以不同的方式体现出来，在饮食偏好中（每种文化都有一些，但正如寿司和蚱蜢等食物所表明的那样，一种文化的禁忌可能是另一种文化的禁忌）美味）。

Likewise, both language and music represent an interesting mix of the universal and the culturally acquired, but that mixture itself is not unique. You can see the same sort of juxtaposition in religion, which is also nearly universal yet instantiated in different ways in different cultures, and in dietary preferences (every culture has some, but as foods like sushi and grasshoppers show, one culture’s taboo may be another’s delicacy).

 

音乐就像语言，但又不是语言；这只是一个经过适当激励的人类大脑可以获得的又一项奇妙的技能。

Music is like language, but it isn’t language; it’s just one more wondrous skill that a suitably motivated human brain can acquire.

 

喜剧演员马丁·马尔曾经说过：“写音乐就像跳舞建筑一样。” 尽管人们当然可以使用语言来描述音乐，但令人痛苦的是，语言充其量只能为了解音乐的真实本质提供一个明显有限的窗口，类似于“干燥”、“坚硬”、“青草”、“如果要求葡萄酒商用口头语言描述他们的产品，他们会选择“有嚼劲”和“圆润”。即使是我们认为理所当然的词语也不是普遍适用的。我们描述为“高”和“低”的音调在挪威语中被描述为“亮”和“暗”。

The comedian Martin Mull once said, “Writing about music is like dancing about architecture.” Although one can certainly use language to describe music, it is painfully obvious that words at best offer only a distinctly limited window into the true nature of music, akin to the underpowered adjectives like “dry,” “flinty,” “grassy,” “chewy,” and “rounded” that vintners settle for if asked to describe their wares in verbal terms. Even words that we take for granted aren’t universal; pitches that we describe as “high” and “low” are described as “light” and “dark” in Norwegian.

也许我读过的对器乐作品最生动的描述是亚历克斯·罗斯对乔治·格什温的《蓝色狂想曲》的优雅描述，这部作品本身曾被描述为“所有美国音乐会作品中最受欢迎的作品”。用罗斯的话说，狂想曲

Perhaps the single most vivid description I have ever read of a piece of instrumental music is Alex Ross’s elegant description of George Gershwin’s Rhapsody in Blue, a piece that was itself once described as “the most popular of all American concert works.” In Ross’s words, Rhapsody

 

以单簧管上的慵懒颤音开始，然后变成同样慵懒的向上音阶，然后变成超级优雅且一点也不沙哑的滑音。在到达最上面的降B调后，单簧管慢慢地演奏出一段轻微切分音的旋律，严重依赖于音阶的降低的第七个音符。曲调沿着开场音阶摆动的同一个楼梯舞动，以乐曲开头的 F 结尾——这是典型的格什温对称。

begins with a languid trill on the clarinet, which turns into an equally languid upward scale, which then becomes a super-elegant and not at all raucous glissando. Having reached the topmost B-flat, the clarinet then saunters through a lightly syncopated melody, leaning heavily on the lowered seventh note of the scale. The tune dances down the same staircase that the opening scale shimmied up, ending on the F with which the piece began— a typical Gershwin symmetry.

 

......狂想曲以一系列令人眼花缭乱的转调形式呈现；作品中心的拉赫玛尼诺爱情主题最终以 E 调为主，这是一个与降 B 调不同的三全音。

… The Rhapsody plays out as a dizzying sequence of modulations; the Rachmaninovian love theme at the center of the work ends up being in the key of E, a tritone away from the home B-flat.

当我阅读罗斯的描述时，很容易想起格什温的作品，但它需要相当多的音乐背景知识（关于转调、切分音、音阶和三全音）。即便如此，这种语言仍然远远无法真正传达音乐的真实含义。对于以前没有听过《蓝色狂想曲》的人来说，会失去很多东西。

As I read Ross’s description, it is easy to bring the Gershwin piece to mind, but it requires a fair bit of musical background knowledge (about modulations, syncopation, scales, and tritones). And even so, the language still falls far short of genuinely conveying what music really sounds like. To someone who had not heard Rhapsody in Blue before, much would be lost.

 

你甚至不能作弊。即使你用乐谱的逐个音符逐字阅读来取代罗斯技术性而又诗意的描述，你仍然无法捕捉到开头两个半八度幻灯片的美感。事实上，实际上定义这首曲子的滑奏甚至不在原始乐谱中。相反，在印刷品中，一个完整的音符后面跟着十七个简短的单独音符，按音阶递增。定义这首歌的流畅滑音并非源自乐谱本身，而是源自单簧管演奏家罗斯·戈尔曼（Ross Gorman）的诠释和想象（有人说他在这首曲子的早期排练中演奏了这首曲子，有人说是开玩笑）。捕捉其中的细微差别非常具有挑战性，以至于三位物理学家写了整篇文章来介绍专业人士如何发挥它。

You can’t even cheat. Even if you were to replace Ross’s technical-yet-poetic description with a note-by-note verbatim reading of the sheet music, you still wouldn’t capture the beauty of the opening two-and-a-half-octave slide. In fact, the glissando that practically defines the piece isn’t even in the original sheet music. Instead, in print, a single whole note is followed by seventeen brief individual notes, ascending a scale. The smooth slide that defines the song developed not out of that notation per se but out of the interpretation and imagination of the clarinetist Ross Gorman (who played it, some say as a joke, in one of the piece’s early rehearsals). Capturing the nuance there is so challenging that three physicists wrote an entire article about how professionals play it.

 

正如作曲家亚伦·科普兰（Aaron Copland）在他著名的《音乐中该听什么》一书中所说：

As the composer Aaron Copland put it, in his justly famous book What to Listen for in Music:

 

音乐在不同的时刻表达平静或繁荣、遗憾或胜利、愤怒或喜悦。它以无数微妙的阴影和差异表达了这些情绪中的每一种以及许多其他情绪。它甚至可能表达一种在任何语言中都没有适当的词语来表达的意义状态。

Music expresses, at different moments, serenity or exuberance, regret or triumph, fury or delight. It expresses each of these moods, and many others, in a numberless variety of subtle shadings and differences. It may even express a state of meaning for which there exists no adequate word in any language.

 

阿门。

Amen.

 

* “同样的十二个音符”其实有点夸张。尽管钢琴键盘仅限于相同的十二个音符（C、C#、D 等，以高八度和低八度重复出现），但许多其他乐器，包括吉他和人声，都具有产生中间可能性的能力。在吉他上，这种“音符之间”可以通过物理弯曲琴弦来演奏，最著名的是用于创建所谓的蓝色音符，例如布鲁斯中常见的稍微扁平的三分之一。

* “The same twelve notes” is actually a bit of an exaggeration. Although the piano keyboard is limited to the same twelve notes (C, C#, D, and so on, recurring in higher and lower octaves), many other instruments, including the guitar and the human voice, have the capacity to generate intermediate possibilities. On the guitar, such “between notes” can be played by physically bending the strings, most famously in the service of creating so-called blue notes, such as the slightly flattened third that is common in the blues.

 

回到学校

BACK TO SCHOOL

 

老师变成学生

The Teacher Becomes a Student

 

到了二月，经过六个月的断断续续的练习，我的努力开始得到回报。我不是摇滚明星，我知道我不会很快成为大卫莱特曼乐队的主唱，但我很高兴终于能够按节奏演奏一些基本和弦。A大调和D大调和弦开始流畅，甚至令人讨厌的F大调也终于变得触手可及。天生运动技能和节奏技能完美结合的人可能会更早到达这里——我花了六个月的时间才完成了一些人可能在一周内完成的事情——但我非常欣喜若狂。

By February, after six months of on- and-off practice, my labors begin to pay off. I’m no rock star, and I can see that I won’t be fronting David Letterman’s band anytime soon, but I’m thrilled to finally be able to play some basic chords in tempo. The A major and D major chords have started to come fluently, and even the pesky F major finally seems within reach. People born with the right combination of innate motor and rhythmic skills might have gotten here a lot sooner— it’s taken me six months to do what some people might have done in a week— but I’m positively ecstatic.

尽管如此，我仍然能够尽可能多地从事音乐工作，只是因为我有一年没有教书。当我意识到再过六个月，我的休假就要结束时，我开始恐慌。我突然意识到，是时候找老师了。如果我要抓住时机，我需要帮助！

Still, I’ve been able to work on music as much as I have only because I had the year off from teaching. I start to panic when I realize that in another six months, my sabbatical will be over. I suddenly realize that the time has come to get a teacher. If I am to seize the moment, I need help!

 

我前往附近的吉他商店寻求推荐。那里的人向我介绍了一位名叫唐的老师。通过谷歌，我发现唐显然知道他在做什么；他知道自己在做什么。他从事吉他教学已有三十年，并撰写了多本有关吉他的书籍。更重要的是，他有一个“经济衰退特别”活动，并且只收费每小时五十美元，对于纽约市来说非常合理。为了避免重蹈童年竖笛课的创伤，我打开钱包，重新审视音乐教育的世界。

I head to my neighborhood guitar store and ask for a recommendation. The people there point me to a teacher named Don. Through Google, I discover that Don definitely seems to know what he’s doing; he’s been teaching for thirty years and has written several books about guitar. What’s more, he has a “recession special” going and charges only fifty dollars an hour, eminently reasonable for New York City. Hoping not to reprise the trauma of my childhood recorder lessons, I open my wallet and revisit the world of music education.

 

 

为什么我们需要老师？最明显的答案是，老师知道学生不知道的事情，无论是贝多芬第九交响曲中一系列音符的最有效指法，还是减和弦与增和弦之间的区别。当然，另一个原因是教师可以充当激励者，可以通过胡萝卜（金星和贴纸），也可以通过大棒（羞辱、羞耻或成绩不佳）。对于成人学习者来说，老师也可能会提供激励：我们大多数人可能练习得比我们应该练习的少，然后在下一课即将到来时竞相赶上。好的老师还可以强加结构，帮助我们知道练习什么以及何时练习。仅仅说“回家练习”是不够的；一位好老师会说要练习什么以及如何练习：最熟练的老师旨在帮助学生有效地练习。但除此之外，老师最重要的作用可能是帮助学生找出错误、针对薄弱环节；尤其是初学者，往往忙于创作音乐。他们并没有真正听到自己在演奏什么。正如一位音乐教学圣人所说，“[通常，学生的太多]注意力都集中在音乐的制作上，而不是[足够]监控声音的结果。” 教师在这方面可以很出色。

Why do we need teachers at all? The most obvious answer is that teachers know things that their students don’t, be it the most efficient fingering for a sequence of notes in Beethoven’s Ninth or the difference between a diminished chord and an augmented chord. Another reason, of course, is that teachers can serve as motivators, either through carrots (gold stars and stickers) or through sticks (mortification, shame, or bad grades). For an adult learner, teachers also likely provide incentive: most of us probably practice less than we should, and then race to catch up when our next lesson is coming up. Good teachers can also impose structure, helping us to know what to practice and when. It is not enough to say, “Go home and practice”; a good teacher says what to practice, and how: the most skilled teachers aim to help their students practice efficiently. But beyond all this, the most important role of a teacher may be to help the students pinpoint their errors and target their weaknesses; beginning students, especially, are often too busy trying to make music. They don’t really hear what they are playing. As one sage academic of music teaching put it, “[Often, too much of a student’s] attention is devoted to the production of the music, not [enough] to monitoring the result of the sound.” Teachers can be brilliant in this regard.

 

当我第一次和 Don 交谈时，我可以看到他显然知道自己的东西，并且他分享了我的理念，即理解音乐的工具，歌曲是如何创作和演奏的，而不是仅仅专注于简单的音乐创作。记住特定的歌曲。死记硬背的知识往往非常脆弱，从一开始我就试图获得概念性的理解，而不是仅仅背诵这么多歌曲。正如唐所说，他作为一名教师的方法是“让人们演奏，表达自己，并理解他们正在演奏的内容，以便最终自己取得进步，而不是仅仅‘鹦鹉学舌’别人的音乐理念”——确切地说我在寻找什么。

When I first speak to Don, I can see he obviously knows his stuff, and he shares my philosophy, which is to understand the tools of music, how songs are written and played, rather than concentrating on simply memorizing particular songs. Rote knowledge is often very brittle, and from the outset I have tried to gain a conceptual understanding, rather than just learn so many songs by heart. As Don puts it, his approach as a teacher has been “to get people to play, express themselves, and understand what they are playing in order to eventually progress on their own, rather than just ‘parrot’ someone else’s musical ideas”—exactly what I am looking for.

不过，唐补充道，有些歌曲确实具有教学价值。他说，“像滚石一样”是和弦变化的良好练习，并且可以用开放和弦（没有那些令人讨厌的巴利和弦，你的食指必须同时按住几根弦）以简单的调来演奏。 C. 适合初学者。

Still, Don adds, some songs do have pedagogical value. “Like a Rolling Stone,” he says, is good practice for chord changes, and it can be played with open chords (none of those nasty barre chords, where your index finger has to hold down several strings simultaneously) in the straightforward key of C. Good for beginners.

 

我答应在我们见面之前练习一下，当我挂断电话时，他说，“当然，吉米·亨德里克斯用所有的小节和弦演奏了这首曲子，但那是另一天的故事了。” 我对即将获得的知识感到兴奋。他只要求我带一本横线螺旋装订笔记本；吉他可选。

I promise to practice that before we meet, and as I hang up the phone, he says, “Of course Jimi Hendrix played it with all barre chords, but that’s a story for a different day.” I thrill at the knowledge I may soon acquire. All he wants me to bring is a lined spiral-bound notebook; guitar optional.

 

 

上第一节课的那天，当我离开公寓，担心自己是否花了足够的时间做作业时，我在电梯里看到一个银发女人——我妈妈的年龄，也许比我妈妈大一点——带着什么她背上看起来像一个吉他盒，和我一样。如此巧合，我打破了电梯安静的密码。“你是音乐家，还是去上课？” 我问。事实证明，是后者。她携带的乐器——不是吉他，而是中提琴——对我来说是个谜。但很高兴知道我不是唯一一个在星期四下午去上音乐课的二十岁以上的人。

On the day of my first lesson, as I’m leaving my apartment, worrying about whether I have spent enough time doing my homework, I see a silver-haired woman in the elevator—my mom’s age, maybe a little older—with what looks like a guitar case on her back, same as me. Struck by the coincidence, I break the code of elevator silence. “Are you a musician, or going to a lesson?” I ask. The latter, it turns out. The instrument she’s toting— it’s not a guitar but a viola da gamba— is a mystery to me. But it’s nice to know that I’m not the only person over the age of twenty going for music lessons on a Thursday afternoon.

在我的课上，唐和我立即开始讨论“Like a Rolling Stone”的乐谱。我在音乐探索中已经发现的一件事是，似乎没有两本歌集会注明以一致的方式播放任何一首歌曲。我带来了家里的两个版本，唐看了看，摇了摇头。“我只是在这个[转录]中没有听到D小调第七音。我听到的是 D 小调，但没有听到七度。” 我想知道我的耳朵是否会那么精确。

At my lesson, Don and I immediately get into a discussion of the sheet music for “Like a Rolling Stone.” One of the things I’ve already discovered in my musical quest is that no two songbooks seem to notate any one song in a consistent way. I’ve brought along the two versions I have at home, and Don looks them over, shaking his head. “I just don’t hear the D minor seventh in this [transcription]. I hear a D minor, but not a seventh.” I wonder to myself whether my ears will ever be that precise.

 

然后唐警告我，他希望我玩一个他认为是很好练习的简化版本。他说，有时，在教授初学者时，他会为了教学的利益而“采取自由行动”。在录制的版本中，整个乐队都在演奏——键盘、贝斯、鼓、吉他等等。唐在教导初学者时，目的不是再现吉他手的特定部分，而是以一种可以用单一乐器捕捉的方式传达他所谓的“综合声音”，即整体声音。我看过足够多的歌曲集，知道有些人想要听起来与原始录音一模一样的精确转录，但我知道我还没有准备好，而且我并不渴望成为一个精确的模仿者：如果我想的话听迪伦的话，我会放一张CD。唐演奏了他想让我学习的版本，听起来很棒。

Don then warns me that he’ll want me to play a simplified version he thinks will be good practice. Sometimes, when teaching beginners, he says, he “takes liberties” in the interest of pedagogy. In the recorded version, there’s a whole band playing—keyboard, bass, drums, guitar, and so forth. Don’s aim, in teaching a beginner, is not to reproduce the guitarist’s particular part but to convey what he calls the “conglomerate,” the overall sound, in a way that can be captured by just a single instrument. I’ve looked at enough songbooks to know that some people want exact transcriptions that sound precisely like the original recordings, but I know I’m not ready for that, and I’m not aspiring to be an exact mimic: if I want to hear Dylan, I’ll put on a CD. Don plays the version he wants me to learn, and it sounds great.

 

令我震惊的是，我发现唐对我的演奏的整体看法非常积极。他告诉我，我“看起来很放松”（这对我来说是个新闻），而且我打球时手感很轻。我向他展示了我演奏巴利和弦的原始努力，甚至尝试了可怕的B小调，不知怎的，结果是正确的，每个音符都很干净，没有一丝音品嗡嗡声。我鼓起勇气，向唐展示了我一直在练习的另一项主要技能：演奏音阶。

I discover, to my shock, that Don’s overall view of my playing is remarkably positive. He tells me that I “look relaxed” (news to me) and that I play with a light touch. I show him my primitive efforts at playing barre chords, even attempting a dreaded B minor, and somehow it comes out right, each note clean, not a hint of fret buzz. Emboldened, I show Don the other main skill I’ve been working on: playing scales.

 

总而言之，唐喜欢他所听到的。他认为我的时间观念——我一直认为是我最大的弱点——听起来还不错；但我的时间观念却很糟糕。我怀疑我的心律失常是否已经完全消失，但练习肯定对一些人有帮助。唐还认为我的双手配合得很好（我什至没有想到这一点），并说我握住镐的位置很好。他希望我更多地使用我的小指——在小调五声音阶上弹奏一些遥远的音符时，我有点用无名指作弊——但总的来说，这个消息是好的，比我预期的成绩单更好。

All in all, Don likes what he hears. He thinks my sense of time— what I have been thinking of as my biggest weakness— sounds okay; I doubt my arrhythmia has completely vanished, but practice is definitely helping some. Don also thinks that my hands work together well (something I hadn’t even thought about) and says that the position in which I hold my pick is good. He wants me to use my pinkie more— I kind of cheat with my ring finger when playing some distant notes on the minor pentatonic— but overall the news is good, a better report card than I was expecting.

 

 

对于某些人来说，音乐课完全是可选的。当我向近年来最好的吉他手之一汤姆·莫雷洛（Tom Morello）询问此事时，他告诉我他正好拿了两把。这两件事都是他十三岁时的事。第一次，他的老师教他给吉他调音（“真是浪费了五美元，”年轻的汤姆心里想）；接下来，汤姆急切地报告练习，“很高兴”他学会了吉他调音，并准备学习“底特律摇滚城”和“黑狗”。相反，老师教他弹奏C大调音阶（“do re mi”等，但用吉他演奏）。年轻的汤姆也觉得这完全是浪费时间，与对他有意义的音乐毫无关系（至少看起来如此）。事实上，汤姆想弹的歌曲和课程之间的差距是如此之大，他完全放弃了，把吉他塞进了衣柜里，在接下来的四年里，它在那里积满了灰尘。从那时起，他基本上是自学成才。我采访过的其他一些非常有成就的音乐家也基本上是自学成才的。例如，斯特林·坎贝尔 (Sterling Campbell) 是一位鼓手，曾与大卫·鲍伊 (David Bowie)、B-52s、辛迪·劳珀 (Cyndi Lauper) 和杜兰·杜兰 (Duran Duran) 一起演奏。他将自己的技能主要归功于从唱片专辑中通过耳朵学习演奏，而不是任何正式的课程。

For some people, music lessons are entirely optional. When I asked Tom Morello, one of the best guitarists in recent memory, about this, he told me that he had taken exactly two. Both were when he was thirteen years old. In the first, his teacher taught him to tune his guitar (“What a waste of five dollars,” young Tom thought to himself); in the next, Tom eagerly reported to practice, “all chuffed” that he’d learned to tune the guitar and ready to learn “Detroit Rock City” and “Black Dog.” Instead, the teacher taught him to play the C major scale (“do re mi” and so on, but on guitar). This, too, struck young Tom as a complete waste of time, having nothing (or so it seemed) to do with the music that was meaningful to him. Indeed the gap between lessons and the songs Tom wanted to play was so great he gave up entirely, stuffing his guitar in the closet, where it collected dust for the next four years. Since then, he has been largely self-taught. Some of the other highly accomplished musicians I spoke to are also largely self-taught. Sterling Campbell, for example, is a drummer who has played with David Bowie, the B-52s, Cyndi Lauper, and Duran Duran; he credits his skills mainly to learning to play by ear from record albums, not any formal lessons.

其他人则对他们的老师给予很大的信任。布鲁斯·霍恩斯比 (Bruce Hornsby) 的主音吉他手道格·德里贝里 (Doug Derryberry)（也是电视节目《芝麻街》的官方吉他手）深情地回忆起他小时候在田纳西州一个小镇上的钢琴老师菲利斯·戴 (Phyllis Dye)。“这不仅仅是‘学习你的作品，演奏你的作品，好，金星，继续前进。’” 就像是，“学习你的作品，按照节奏弹奏你的作品等等”，但每周我们都会有一本包含理论课的练习册。所以这就像是，“这是一个理论概念[也许是关于特定类型的和弦变化序列的逻辑]，这是一个小测验，”我喜欢这些东西。我把它吃掉了。我真的很信任她的教学方法为我提供了第一个工具，帮助我解码我在音乐中设法解码的任何其他内容。”

Others give a great deal of credit to their teachers. Doug Derryberry, lead guitarist for Bruce Hornsby (and official guitarist for the television program Sesame Street), fondly recalls Phyllis Dye, the piano teacher he had in a small town in Tennessee as a child. “It wasn’t just like, ‘Learn your piece, play your piece, good, gold star, move on.’ It was like, ‘Learn your piece, play your piece to tempo and whatever,’ but also every week we had a workbook with a theory lesson. So it was like, ‘This is a theory concept [perhaps something about the logic of a particular type of sequence of chord changes], and here is a little quiz,’ and I loved those things. I ate it up. I really credit her teaching method as giving me the first tools that helped me decode whatever else I have managed to decode in music.”

 

 

是什么造就了一个好老师，或者一堂好课？音乐教育（或音乐教育学）的科学非常薄弱。尽管超过 40% 的富裕美国父母送孩子去上音乐课，但人们对于如何使音乐教学有效却知之甚少。

What makes a good teacher, or a good lesson? The science of music education (or music pedagogy) is surprisingly thin. Although over 40 percent of affluent American parents send their children to music lessons, comparatively little is known about what makes music teaching effective.

许多教师，尤其是成人教师，接受的教师培训相对较少：许多音乐教师是从未成名且需要钱的音乐家；不需要许可证。任何会弹钢琴或吉他的人都可以在 Craigslist 或走廊公告板上张贴广告。然而，一个有抱负的学生，尤其是年轻的学生，可能无法选择一位好老师。据我所知，我三年级的竖笛老师可能是巴尔的摩最伟大的竖笛演奏家，但事后看来，她不知道如何教初学者。她缺乏任何老师都应具备的两个最重要的特质：耐心和诊断问题的能力。没过多久，她就发现我没有取得进步，但她没有意愿坚持我，也没有洞察力看到我没有得到什么。回想起来——这是丹·莱维汀（Dan Levitin）多年后立即认识到的——我根本不理解节奏的本质。我知道《玛丽有一只小羔羊》的音符按特定顺序排列，但我没有意识到这些音符的持续时间应该有系统地变化。一位熟练的老师会看到这一点，敦促我把“小羔羊”放在一边一两周，并想出一些简单的游戏来增加我对节奏的敏感度——所有这些都不会让我真正无能。如果有支持和正确的诊断，我可能会取得进步，而不是绝望地放弃。

Many teachers, especially of adults, have relatively little training as teachers: many music teachers are musicians who never quite got famous and who need the money; no license is required. Anyone who knows how to play a piano or a guitar can put up an ad on Craigslist or a hallway bulletin board. An aspiring student, especially a young student, may however not be in a position to pick a good teacher. For all I know, my third-grade recorder teacher may have been the greatest recorder player in Baltimore, but in hindsight she had no clue how to teach beginners. She lacked two of the most important traits that any teacher could have: patience and the ability to diagnose problems. It didn’t take her long to see that I wasn’t making progress, but she didn’t have the inclination to stick with me, nor the perspicacity to see what it was that I didn’t get. In retrospect— and this was what Dan Levitin immediately recognized, years later— I simply didn’t understand the nature of rhythm. I knew that “Mary Had a Little Lamb” had notes that were sequenced in a particular order, but I didn’t realize that the notes were supposed to vary systematically in duration. A skilled teacher would have seen that, urged me to set “Little Lamb” aside for a week or two, and come up with some simple games to increase my sensitivity to rhythm— all without letting on how inept I really was. With support and a proper diagnosis, I might have made progress, rather than giving up in despair.

 

当然，一个好的老师不仅仅是一个好的诊断师，而且还是一个好的激励者。如果我的老师催促我回家简单地交替练习短音符和长音符，我无疑会感到无聊，就像汤姆·莫雷洛（Tom Morello）对C大调音阶的练习一样恼火。真正有才华的老师会诊断问题，然后提出既有趣又有益的治疗方法。在有关教学和培训的大量文献中（不仅在音乐领域，而且在任何领域），研究一致指出教师有能力激励学生，了解他们的特殊需求，并提出不太容易的练习也不太难（我之前提到的最近发展原则的阴影）。
