A good teacher is not just a good diagnostician, of course, but also a good motivator. Had my teacher urged me to go home and simply practice alternating short notes and long notes, I would no doubt have been bored out of my mind, as annoyed with that exercise as Tom Morello was with the C major scale. The truly talented teacher diagnoses the problem and then proposes a treatment that is both fun and rewarding. In the larger literature on teaching and training (not just in music, but in any domain), studies consistently point to the abilities of teachers to motivate their students, to understand their particular needs, and to come up with exercises that are neither too easy nor too hard (shades of the principle of proximal development that I mentioned earlier).

 

当我开始沉浸在音乐中时，我旁听了各种课程，有些是作为学生（从吉他到唱歌到歌曲创作），另一些是作为旁观者，许多课程针对的是儿童（所有年龄段，小至十二个月大） ）。老师们的方法和能力的差异令人难以置信。我见过一些伟大的老师，也看到或至少听说过一些糟糕的老师。最糟糕的是一个超级大男子主义类型的人，他告诉朋友“变调夹[临时缩短吉他琴弦以改变音调的夹子状工具]是为娘娘腔准备的”——没有完全意识到变调夹不仅可以改变调，还可以改变音调。为原本需要以不太共鸣的方式演奏的音符添加额外的共鸣，事实证明这种方式对从迪伦到老鹰乐队、约翰尼·卡什和披头士乐队的每个人都很有用。

As I began immersing myself in music, I sat in on all kinds of lessons, some as student (in everything from guitar to singing to songwriting), others as spectator, many aimed at children (of all ages, as young as twelve months old). The differences in the approaches and capacities of the teachers were mind-boggling. I saw some great teachers and saw, or at least heard about, some terrible ones. The worst was an über-macho type who told a friend that “capos [ clamp-like tools that temporarily shorten a guitar’s strings in order to change musical key] are for sissies”—not quite realizing that capos can not only change key but also add extra resonance to notes that would otherwise need to be played in a less resonant fashion, in ways that have proven useful for everyone from Dylan to the Eagles, Johnny Cash, and the Beatles.

 

 

我遇到的最有天赋的老师是布鲁克林一位名叫米歇尔·霍纳（Michele Horner）的快乐女士，她在两岁时得到了第一把吉他。米歇尔是著名的铃木方法的拥护者，该方法强调（除其他外）通过耳朵学习而不是从乐谱中学习。米歇尔本人享誉世界，经常受邀在全球各地的研讨会上授课。当我第一次见到米歇尔时，她正在给予为两个孩子上的小型私人课程，其中一个名叫希洛，是朋友的朋友的六岁女儿。铃木最出名的可能是小提琴教学技术，但实际上铃木有针对一系列弦乐器的课程，不仅包括管弦乐器（大提琴、中提琴等），还包括我选择的乐器，吉他。当年轻的希洛专注地坐着时，米歇尔巧妙地让她的学生关注他们的姿势，告诉他们，“你的任务是保持你的拇指[向上]，让每个人都能看到它有多么伟大。好的？”

The single most gifted teacher I encountered was a jovial woman in Brooklyn named Michele Horner, who got her first guitar at the age of two. Michele is a devotee of the famous Suzuki method, which emphasizes (among other things) learning by ear rather than learning from sheet music. Michele herself is world renowned, often invited to teach workshops around the globe. When I first saw Michele, she was giving a small private lesson to two kids, one of whom was named Shiloh, the six-year-old daughter of a friend of a friend. Suzuki is probably best known as a technique for teaching violin, but there are in fact Suzuki curricula for a range of string instruments, including not just orchestral instruments (cello, viola, and so on) but also my instrument of choice, the guitar. As young Shiloh sat attentively, Michele subtly got her students to focus on their posture, by telling them, “Your mission is to keep your thumb [up] where everyone can see how great it is. Okay?”

当天歌曲的不同部分都有有趣的标签，例如“面包”（歌曲的第一部分）和“奶酪”（第二部分），因此形式为 aba 的歌曲将是“面包奶酪面包”三明治。节奏变化是用有趣的音节来教授的：草莓代表一组三连音，果冻代表一对八分音符，西瓜代表四个十六分音符，等等。希洛试探性地演奏了一段短乐段，但几乎完美。米歇尔滔滔不绝地说：“你做了面包，你做了奶酪，你做了奶酪，你做了面包——你得到了四枚邮票！” 夏洛很兴奋。当米歇尔转向我说：“我们努力让一切变得有趣。因为如果这不有趣，谁愿意去做呢？连我也不行。”我知道我面对的是一位名师。

Different sections of the day’s song had fun labels like “bread” (for the first section of a song) and “cheese” (for the second section), hence a song with the form aba would be a “bread cheese bread” sandwich. Rhythmic variations were taught with entertaining syllables: straw-ber-ry for a set of triplets, Jell-O for a pair of eighth notes, wa- ter-mel-on for four sixteenth notes, and so on. Shiloh played a short passage, tentatively but almost perfectly. Michele gushed, “You did a bread, you did a cheese, you did a cheese, you did a bread—you get four stamps for that!” Shiloh was thrilled. By the time Michele turned to me and said, “We try to make everything fun. ’Cause if it’s not fun, who wants to do it? Not even me,” I knew I was in the presence of a master teacher.

 

至少有四个特征使米歇尔成为一位伟大的老师。首先，她有一双鹰眼：米歇尔注意到，当学生将手指从完美位置倾斜、弯腰驼背或以其他方式偏离理想的古典吉他姿势时，她就会注意到。其次，无论孩子做什么，米歇尔所说的几乎每一句话即使不是完全热情洋溢，也是积极的。米歇尔始终保持乐观态度，而且从不显得带有任何批判性，她帮助灌输了心理学家卡罗尔·德韦克（Carol Dweck）所说的“成长”心态。米歇尔并没有让一些学生觉得自己天生能力不够，而是帮助他们所有人觉得只要每天努力学习和练习，任何事情都是可以实现的。第三，米歇尔是维持学生的高手。注意力。多年来，她已经了解了关于这个六岁女孩的思想的一切。从贴纸到她发音“挑战”一词的方式（就好像这是法语，如“你准备好迎接……挑战了吗？”），米歇尔确切地知道如何在四十年的时间里保持她的负责人的积极性和专注力。五分钟的课程（即使对于大学生来说也很长，据我所知）。

At least four characteristics made Michele a great teacher. First, she had the eyes of a hawk: the instant a student tilted a finger from a perfect position, or slouched, or otherwise deviated from ideal classical guitar posture, Michele noticed. Second, no matter what a child did, virtually every utterance Michele made was positive, if not downright ebullient. By being perpetually upbeat and never sounding remotely judgmental, Michele helped instill what the psychologist Carol Dweck would call a “growth” mind-set. Instead of making some students feel as if they might not have enough natural ability, Michele helped them all feel as if anything was achievable, so long as they worked hard and practiced every day. Third, Michele was a master at maintaining her students’ attention. Over the years, she’s learned all there is to know about the currency of the six-year-old girl’s mind. From stickers to the way in which she pronounced the word “challenge” (as if it were French, as in “Are you ready for a … shallenge?”), Michele knew exactly how to keep her charges motivated and focused through a forty-five-minute lesson (long even for college students, as I know only too well).

 

第四，也许也是最重要的一点，米歇尔知道课堂外的生活比课堂内的生活要严肃得多。和所有铃木老师一样，她知道每周弹一两个小时是学不来吉他的；为了提高效率，学生的大部分学习需要在家里练习时进行，她知道孩子们只有在感到愉快的情况下才会在家练习。米歇尔给我印象最深的是，她付出了巨大的努力来确保学生的家长得到良好的指导，尤其是在让练习成为每天例行公事中快乐和规律的一部分方面。米歇尔最坚持的一点是，父母何时应该纠正孩子的错误：永远、永远，除非孩子犯了至少三次错误。米歇尔明智地意识到，她作为老师的角色就是引导孩子们养成正确的习惯；纠正孩子的父母很容易最终摧毁孩子的积极性。如果和爸爸妈妈一起练习很麻烦，那么整场比赛就输了。米歇尔确保这种情况永远不会发生，她每周都会在仅限家长参加的夜间课程中加入一些合理的技巧，帮助家长如何应对希望孩子立即出类拔萃和保持足够耐心以营造快乐学习环境之间的紧张关系。

Fourth, and perhaps most important, Michele knew that life outside the classroom was far more serious than life inside the classroom. Like all Suzuki teachers, she knew that you couldn’t learn guitar by playing for an hour or two a week; to be effective, most of a student’s learning needs to take place during practice at home, and she knew that kids would only practice at home if doing so was pleasurable. What most impressed me about Michele was the immense pains she took to make sure her students’ parents were well instructed, especially in the art of making practice a happy and regular part of every day’s routine. The single point that Michele was most adamant about was a rule for when parents should correct a child’s mistake: never, ever, until the child had made that error at least three times. Wisely, Michele saw that her role as teacher was to guide children into developing proper habits; parents who corrected their children could easily wind up destroying their kids’ motivation. If practice with Mom or Dad got to be a drag, the whole game was lost. Michele made sure that never happened, sprinkling her weekly parents-only night classes with sound techniques for how parents could navigate the tension between wanting their children to excel right away and being patient enough to foster a happy learning environment.

 

在我第一次看到 Shiloh 上课六个月后，我参加了她的年终独奏会，她（现在七岁）演奏的精确度让我大吃一惊。她从“一闪一闪亮晶晶”到“草地小步舞曲”。据她父亲说，此时希洛已经连续练习了 126 天。她的根基坚如磐石，姿势完美，每一个音符在完美的时间、以完美的音调演奏。很多学习都是为了改掉坏习惯，而夏伊洛却没有。

Six months after I first saw Shiloh take a class, I sat in on her end-of-year recital and was absolutely floored by the precision with which she (now age seven) played; she had graduated from “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star” to the “Meadow Minuet.” According to her dad, Shiloh had by this point practiced for 126 consecutive days. Her foundation was rock solid, her posture was perfect, and each and every note was played with perfect tone, in perfect time. A lot of learning is about breaking bad habits, and Shiloh had none.

 

 

尽管米歇尔显然是一位才华横溢的老师，但铃木的方法本身也并非没有缺点。它适用于许多孩子——许多著名的管弦乐演奏家从小就接受过铃木的训练——但它也有失去那些不沉浸在古典传统中的孩子的风险。十卷的基本曲目（九卷吉他），从《Twinkle》到维瓦尔第、巴赫和莫扎特，非常严格，基本上与铃木新一在 1950 年代中期开发它时相同，并且完全专注于音乐来自早期时代的音乐可能对许多现代孩子来说并不陌生。一个新人可能会花一年的时间学习演奏“Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star”（有许多节奏变化），我可以看到，一个真正想跟着披头士乐队或麦莉赛勒斯摇滚的孩子可能会放弃并感觉（就像汤姆·莫雷洛（Tom Morello）确实如此）他或她想学的东西和课堂上发生的事情之间的差距太大了。

Although Michele is clearly a gifted teacher, the Suzuki approach itself is not without its drawbacks. It works for many children— any number of famous orchestral players had Suzuki training from an early age— but it also risks losing kids who aren’t steeped in the classical tradition. The basic repertoire of ten volumes (nine for guitar), progressing from “Twinkle” to Vivaldi, Bach, and Mozart, is incredibly rigid, essentially the same now as when Shinichi Suzuki developed it in the mid-1950s, and focused entirely on music from an earlier era, music that may not speak to many modern children. A newcomer might spend a year learning to play “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star” (in many rhythmic variations), and I could see that a kid who really wanted to rock out to the Beatles or Miley Cyrus might give up and feel (as Tom Morello did) that the gap between what he or she wanted to learn and what was going on in class was too great.

同样，铃木方法对完美形式的崇高强调（米歇尔有一句座右铭：“复习比学习新东西更好”）可能对许多孩子来说是不重要的。特殊的孩子（比如希洛）需要有耐心专注于完美，通过一系列几乎看不见的小步骤来实现。（这就是为什么天才教师对于这种方法如此不可或缺的部分原因。在米歇尔能干的手中，这种方法有效；在缺乏耐心的人手中，脾气可能会爆发。）

Likewise, the Suzuki method’s noble emphasis on perfect form (Michele has a motto: “It’s better to review than to learn something new”) might be lost on many kids. It takes a special child (like Shiloh) to have the patience to focus on perfection, achieved through a series of almost invisibly small steps. (This is part of why a gifted teacher is so indispensable to the approach. In Michele’s capable hands, the method works; in the hands of someone less patient, tempers might fray.)

 

铃木教学的另一个缺点是，它通常很少或根本不教孩子们即兴创作。就像古典音乐学院的传统一样，重点主要是像伟大的音乐家一样演奏伟大的作品，而不是发展学生自己的想法，虽然这无疑具有价值，但每个学生也有相当大的价值得知他或她可以创作自己的音乐。就我个人而言，发现即兴创作的乐趣几乎比其他一切都重要，但许多接受过古典风格训练的音乐家（无论是通过铃木音乐还是在茱莉亚学院学习）都觉得自己从未学会过即兴创作。我不禁觉得他们错过了音乐所能带来的一些最大的快乐。关于铃木的另一个常见抱怨是，用这种方法训练的孩子通常不会学会读乐谱，这让我不那么担心。确实如此，但在我看来并不是那么重要（我将在稍后解释）。

Another drawback of Suzuki instruction is that it typically tends to teach children little or nothing about improvisation. Much as in the classical conservatory tradition, the emphasis is largely on playing the great works as the great musicians played them, rather than developing a student’s own ideas, and while there is indubitably value in that, there is also considerable value in each individual student learning that he or she can make his or her own music. In my own case, the discovery of the joys of improvisation have outweighed virtually all else, yet many musicians trained in the classical style (be it through Suzuki or lessons at Juilliard) feel that they have never learned to improvise. I can’t help but feel that they are missing out on some of the greatest joy that music can bring. Another common complaint about Suzuki, which worries me less, is that children trained in that method often don’t learn to read music; true, but to my mind not as essential (as I will explain later).

 

在这方面，我非常喜欢另一种音乐教学方法，这种方法在美国不太出名（尽管在欧洲更为人所知）：埃米尔·雅克-达尔克罗兹方法。在纽约斯卡斯代尔，霍夫-巴塞尔森音乐学院院长露丝·阿尔珀森 (Ruth Alperson) 是当代达尔克罗兹方法的主要弟子之一，她很友善地允许我旁听几门课程，其中包括两门专门为学生设计的课程。对于还穿着（或刚刚脱掉）尿布的幼儿，一个班级里有两岁的孩子，另一个班级里只有一岁的孩子。这里的重点不是以完美的姿势弹奏吉他，这可能远远超出了大多数学生的运动协调能力，而是简单地培养音乐感，尤其是节奏感。

In this respect, I am a big fan of another music-teaching approach that is less well-known in the United States (though somewhat better known in Europe): the Émile Jaques-Dalcroze method. In Scarsdale, New York, Ruth Alperson, dean of the Hoff-Barthelson Music School, is one of the leading contemporary disciples of the Dalcroze method, and she was kind enough to allow me to sit in on several classes, including two that were geared toward toddlers still in (or barely out of) diapers, one class filled with two-year-olds, the other with children as young as one. Here the emphasis was not on playing a guitar with perfect posture, which would presumably be well out of the motor coordination capacities of most of the students, but on simply developing a sense of music, especially rhythm.

 

与幼儿坐在一起，我立即证实了一个事实，即对于许多人来说，音乐并不一定是自然而然的：大多数年幼的孩子只是模模糊糊地掌握了正式称为“夹带”的概念，也就是说，随着音乐的发展音乐与节拍同步。事实上，所有人都明白节奏的概念——如果音乐较快，则移动得更快；如果音乐较慢，则移动得较慢。但在八到十个孩子的年轻群体中，只有一个——她恰好是在学校工作的一位专业钢琴家的女儿——能够真正与音乐同步摇摆和行走。

Sitting in with the toddlers immediately confirmed for me the fact that for many human beings music doesn’t necessarily come all that naturally: most of the younger kids only dimly grasped the notion formally known as “entrainment,” which is to say moving along to music in synchrony with a beat. Virtually all got the idea of tempo— move faster if the music is faster, move slower if the music is slower. But in the younger group of eight or ten kids, only one— who happened to be the daughter of a professional pianist who worked at the school— could really sway and walk in genuine synchrony with the music.

 

达尔克罗兹方法的一个巧妙见解是，对于幼儿来说，老师来到学生身边可能比相反更好。在年龄较大的群体中，老师可能会设置节拍器并要求学生及时玩耍；在我看到的幼儿课程中，阿尔帕森通常让学生们设定时间。孩子们可以单独或在父母或祖父母牵着手的帮助下在房间里走动或慢跑，阿尔帕森与他们一起及时演奏，即兴创作旋律和节奏来配合孩子们的动作。达尔克罗兹方法有时也被称为 eurhythmics，源自希腊词根eu（和谐）和韵律（运动），原因很容易理解。主要重点是温和地鼓励孩子们将音乐和动作联系起来。对于一般两岁的孩子来说，随着音乐敲击鼓可能太具有挑战性，但音乐首先来自身体，甚至在孩子们能够演奏乐器之前，达尔克罗兹方法似乎能有效地帮助他们展现这一点。联系。安妮·伦诺克斯 (Annie Lennox)，Eurythmics 乐队（拼写略有不同）的创始人，最著名的是他们的歌曲“Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)”，她小时候就参加了达尔克罗兹课程；我只希望我也有。

One clever insight of the Dalcroze method was that with toddlers it might be better for the teacher to come to the student than the other way around. In older age groups, a teacher might set a metronome and ask the student to play in time with it; in the classes I saw with toddlers, Alperson generally let the students set the time. Kids, either individually or with the aid of a hand-holding parent or grandparent, walked or loped around the room, and Alperson played in time with them, improvising a melody and rhythm to match the children’s movements. The Dalcroze method is also sometimes known as eurhythmics, from the Greek roots eu (harmonious) and rhythm (motion), and it was easy to see why. The chief emphasis was on gently encouraging children to connect music and motion. For your average two-year-old, banging on a drum in time with music may be too challenging, but music comes from the body first, even before children can play instruments, and the Dalcroze method seemed to be effective in helping bring out that connection. Annie Lennox, founder of the (slightly differently spelled) band the Eurythmics— most famous for their song “Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)”—took Dalcroze lessons as a child; I only wish that I had, too.

 

 

另一位给我留下深刻印象的音乐老师（根本没有教过乐器）是西尔特·吉尔（Cirt Gill），他是北卡罗来纳州格林斯博罗表演艺术学校韦弗学院（Weaver Academy）的一名公立高中教师。吉尔曾经是一名职业小号手，曾在电影《紫色》中扮演“点唱机联合音乐家” 。自2003年以来，他一直在教授音乐制作课程，即使用录音设备和计算机软件来编排、录制和开发音乐的艺术和科学。当吉尔开始上课时，他的制作班可能是全国唯一一所针对高中生的此类课程。吉尔只得到了一间教室和少量的录音设备预算，并让他自己决定应该教什么以及如何教。

Another music teacher who impressed me— without teaching a musical instrument at all— was Cirt Gill, a public high school teacher at Weaver Academy, a school for the performing arts in Greensboro, North Carolina. At one time, Gill was a professional trumpeter who had played as “juke joint musician” in the film The Color Purple. Since 2003, he has been teaching a class in music production, which is to say in the art and science of using recording equipment and computer software to arrange, record, and develop music. When he began, Gill’s production class may have been the only one of its kind for high school students in the country. Gill was given little more than a classroom and a modest budget for recording equipment and left to his own devices to figure out what should be taught and how he should teach it.

在吉尔的课堂上，孩子们为他们的儿童读物创作配乐自己的设计），创建播客，并了解现场录音会话中麦克风的放置位置。在我上课的那天，我看到了一些与我在高中记忆中完全不同的东西：原创性、灵感和真正自我激励的学生。没有讲师站在房间的前面，而是更像作家或艺术家的工作室。学生们单独或成对地创作作品，而吉尔在房间里走动，批评他们的作品，并就他们的作品提出音乐和技术方面的建议：在这里添加一些打击乐，或者鼓励学生尝试一种新工具，Melodyne，等等类似于自动调音（一种流行的计算机程序，可以纠正跑调的歌唱音调），但在某些方面更灵活。

In Gill’s class, kids compose soundtracks (to children’s books of their own devising), create podcasts, and learn about microphone placement in live recording sessions. On the day I sat in, I saw something that looked completely different from anything I remember from my high school: originality, inspiration, and students who were genuinely self-motivated. No lecturer standing at the front of the room, but something more akin to a writers’ or artists’ workshop. Students worked individually or in pairs on compositions while Gill circulated throughout the room, critiquing their compositions and making suggestions, both musical and technical, about their work: adding some percussion here, or encouraging the student to try out a new tool, Melodyne, sort of like Auto-Tune (a popular computer program that corrects the pitch of out-of-key singing) but in certain ways more flexible.

 

在我的高中，我们迫不及待地想放学，这样我们就可以出去玩终极飞盘；在吉尔的课堂上，许多学生在下课时显得明显失望。吉尔班上的孩子们没有被要求在期末考试中复述一些已经记住的事实，而是建立了自己的项目。他们不是竞争，而是合作。最熟练的学生是一名有着可爱歌声的三年级学生，她正忙着将自己的歌曲与西班牙歌词和巴西节奏混合在一起。如果她有一天成为明星，我不会感到惊讶——而且不是那种被动地坐在那里被告知要做什么的歌手，而是那种拥有专业知识作为自己的制作人的完全音乐家。

In my high school, we couldn’t wait for classes to end so that we could go outside and play Ultimate Frisbee; in Gill’s class, many students seemed manifestly disappointed when class ended. Instead of being asked to regurgitate some set of memorized facts for a final exam, the kids in Gill’s class build their own projects. And instead of competing, they were collaborating. The most skilled student, a junior with a lovely singing voice, was busy mixing her own track with Spanish lyrics and Brazilian rhythms. I wouldn’t be surprised if she became a star someday— and not the sort of singer who would sit around passively being told what to do, but the sort of total musician who would have the know-how to serve as her own producer.

 

随着计算机的出现，传统乐器被机器取代（在某些情况下）或至少被机器补充，很难确切地知道二十五年后音乐教育将采取什么形式，但吉尔的课堂给我留下了深刻的印象，因为他的课堂非常出色。模型。

With computers on the scene, and traditional instruments being replaced (in some instances) or at least supplemented by machines, it is hard to know exactly what shape music education will take twenty-five years from now, but Gill’s classroom struck me as an excellent model.

 

 

另一位给我留下深刻印象且采取截然不同方法的老师是杰米·安德烈亚斯 (Jamie Andreas)，他是一位受过古典音乐训练的吉他手，住在纽约州伍德斯托克，以在线授课为生（主要通过视频 Skype）。我第一次认识她是通过大学同学迈克尔·多夫曼（Michael Dorfman），他住在挪威。多夫曼从小就弹吉他，手腕发生了意外，那次意外让他对弹吉他的身体方面产生了兴趣；他知道音符和他想弹奏的内容，但由于受伤，他的双手无法再做他的大脑想要他们做的事情。杰米是少数几个对此类问题、肌肉和大脑之间的关系以及如何有效利用身体感兴趣的老师之一。游泳教练和高尔夫老师一直在考虑这样的问题，但在音乐教学领域这绝对是罕见的。

Another teacher who impressed me immensely, and who takes a very different approach, was Jamie Andreas, a classically trained guitarist who lives in Woodstock, New York, and makes her living giving lessons online (mainly via video Skype). I first discovered her through a classmate from college, Michael Dorfman, who was living in Norway. Dorf man, who had played guitar since childhood, had an accident with his wrist, and that accident had led him to develop an interest in the physical side of playing guitar; he knew the notes and what he wanted to play, but because of the injury his hands could no longer do what his brain wanted them to do. Jamie is one of the few teachers who seems interested in that sort of question, the relationship between muscle and brain, and how to use one’s body efficiently. Swim coaches and golf teachers consider such questions all the time, but it’s decidedly rare in the field of music instruction.

后来，我亲自见到了杰米，我们聊得越多，我印象就越深刻。杰米的学生通常是成年人，他们来找她是因为他们陷入了一个他们想要跨越的高原。她的主要重点不是即兴演奏、音阶、琶音、歌曲或任何你在标准吉他书或普通吉他课程中可以找到的其他东西。相反，她的重点几乎完全集中在正确运动控制的机制上——让一个人的肌肉尽可能高效、尽可能少地做自己想做的事情（对于那些知道这一点的人来说，这让人想起亚历山大技术，但适用于吉他）；一切都以完美的姿势和流畅的动作为中心。尽管杰米从未上过认知心理学的正式课程，但她几年前就读过一本关于人类运动控制的教科书，并对大脑如何接收信息有了很好的理解，并将其融入到她的方法中。她还花了数年时间仔细研究学生容易陷入困境的地方。她看待吉他手的方式就像汽车修理工看待汽车一样：她认识到许多常见问题，拥有一套诊断工具，并拥有一套匹配的技巧来纠正问题。

Later, I got to meet Jamie in person, and the more we talked, the more impressed I became. Jamie’s students are often adults who come to her because they get stuck at a plateau that they’d like to move past. Her main emphasis wasn’t on riffs or scales or arpeggios or songs or any of the other things you’d find in a standard guitar book or your average guitar lesson. Instead, her emphasis was almost entirely on the mechanics of proper motor control— on getting one’s muscles to do what one wants, as efficiently as possible, with as little tension as possible (reminiscent, for those who know it, of the Alexander technique, but applied to guitar); everything centers around perfect posture and smooth motion. Although Jamie had never taken a formal class in cognitive psychology, she had devoured a textbook on human motor control some years earlier and developed an excellent understanding of how the brain takes in information, incorporating it into her approach. She’d also spent years closely examining where students tended to get stuck. She viewed guitarists the way auto mechanics look at cars: she recognized a host of common problems, had a set of tools for diagnosis, and had a matching set of tricks for making things right.

 

杰米并没有声称她可以教授真正的灵感；她只是说她能传授真正的灵感。比如说，她的目标不是教授歌曲创作，而且她相对不太重视异国情调的技术。她的目标只是把基础知识教得非常非常好。任何想成为一名真正的艺术家的人都需要从扎实的基础开始，杰米的课程（或她的经典著作《吉他正确练习原则》）将是一个很好的起点，也许是成年人最接近发展的地方铃木训练中灌输的习惯。

Jamie didn’t claim she could teach true inspiration; her goal wasn’t, say, to teach songwriting, and she placed relatively little emphasis on exotic techniques. Her aim was only to teach the basics really, really well. Anyone who wants to be a true artist needs to start with sound fundamentals, and Jamie’s lessons (or her cult-classic book The Principles of Correct Practice for Guitar) would be a fine place to start, maybe the closest an adult could come to developing the kinds of habits that are instilled in Suzuki training.

 

 

最后一位以不同方式给我留下深刻印象的老师是特雷·罗什 (Terre Roche)，她是颇具影响力的罗切斯三人组中的二姐。他们的同名首张专辑被《纽约时报》评选为 1979 年年度专辑。特雷也没有接受过认知心理学方面的正式培训，但她认真对待自己的教学职责，并深入思考她的学生可能会在哪里陷入困境以及如何帮助他们。她自己主要是通过玩耍来学习，而不是通过正式课程（在她成为职业选手几年后才接受正式培训）。Terre 已经打了很长时间的球，并且和很多超级巨星（Paul Simon、Laurie Anderson、Philip Glass、Robert Fripp 等）一起打球，她有很多技巧可以传授，特别是对于高级球员，但给我印象最深的是她的教学风格是她创建的一套闪存卡，称为“指板维生素”。

A final teacher who impressed me in yet a different way was Terre Roche, middle sister in an influential trio known as the Roches; their self-titled debut was the New York Times’ 1979 Album of the Year. Terre, too, had no formal training in cognitive psychology, but she took her teaching responsibilities seriously and thought deeply about where her students might get stuck and how to help them. She herself had learned mainly through playing, rather than through formal lessons (only taking formal training years after she had become a professional). Terre has been playing for so long and with so many superstars (Paul Simon, Laurie Anderson, Philip Glass, Robert Fripp, and so on) that she has loads of techniques to impart, especially for advanced players, but what impressed me the most about her teaching style was a set of flash cards— dubbed Fretboard Vitamins— that she created.

当然，闪存卡本身并不是什么新鲜事，但特雷重新思考了它们的使用方式和原因。她向我展示的卡片旨在向学生介绍可怕的指板，并具有两项创新。首先，卡片本身的装饰方式最初看起来很愚蠢，但实际上是经过仔细考虑的。每张卡片大约五乘七英寸，包含一个指板，突出显示特定的音乐关系（例如纯五度的音程），周围是有趣的（并且隐秘的信息）边缘，由疯狂而多彩的塔罗牌般的图画组成。鼓励学生看一张给定的卡片三分钟，但也允许让他或她的眼睛在卡片的范围内自由地四处走动，无论是在指板图上还是在周围。这些卡片可以让学生自己调整节奏，不会陷入饱和状态，但也不会完全走神。适当的研究还没有完成，但我的想法是基于最近关于记忆随着时间的推移而固化的过程的动态研究，这些卡片可能非常有效，因为它们允许一段时间的巩固，在记忆与学习交织在一起，更加牢固。

Flash cards themselves, of course, aren’t remotely new, but Terre rethought how and why they were used. The cards she showed me were aimed at teaching students about the dreaded fretboard and featured two innovations. The first was that the cards themselves were decorated in a way that initially seems goofy but is actually carefully considered. Each card, about five by seven inches, contains a fretboard that highlights a particular musical relationship (for example, the interval of a perfect fifth), surrounded by a fun (and slyly informative) fringe of crazy and colorful tarot-card-like drawings. The student is encouraged to look at a given card for three minutes but also permitted to let his or her eyes wander around freely, within the confines of the card, both on the fretboard diagram and at the surround. The cards allow students to pace themselves without getting saturated, but without zoning out altogether. Proper studies haven’t been done yet, but my thinking, which is based on recent studies about the dynamics of processes by which memories solidify over time, is that the cards may be quite effective, because they allow for a period of consolidation, in which memories firm up, interleaved with study.

 

罗氏闪存卡的第二个创新是，每张卡片都专注于一个特定的音程，而不是要求学生将音阶作为未分析的整体来记忆（类似于著名的 do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-do）在音阶上（例如，小三度、纯五度），说明在指板上可以找到该音程的几何位置（例如，可以找到相对于某个起始音符的大三度的所有位置）。这些卡片有助于在学生职业生涯的早期灌输良好的相对音高感，也使学生能够轻松地开始即兴创作新鲜的旋律，只需分发随机的卡片组（大三度、小二度、纯四度）并在其中进行选择即可立即可见的选项。由于每张卡片都说明了单个音程的几何形状（或者，更专业地说，“音阶程度”），因此学生可以专注于音乐，而不是难以记住的几何形状。这些卡片尚未上市，但当我看到它们的那一刻，我就想要一套。

The second innovation in Roche’s deck of flash cards is that rather than requiring students to memorize scales as unanalyzed wholes (à la the famous do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-ti-do), each card focuses on a specific interval on the scale (for example, minor third, perfect fifth), illustrating the geometry of where that interval can be found on the fretboard (for example, all the places where one can find a major third relative to some starting note). The cards help instill a good sense of relative pitch early in a student’s career and also make it easy for students to begin to improvise fresh melodies, simply by dealing out random sets of cards (major third, minor second, perfect fourth) and choosing among the options that become immediately visible. Because each card illustrates the geometry of a single interval (or, more technically, “scale degree”), students can focus on the music rather than on the difficult-to-remember geometry. The cards aren’t yet commercially available, but the minute I saw them, I wanted a set.

 

像 Jamie 和 Terre 这样的老师很棒，因为他们不仅花时间找出学生需要学习的技能，而且还预测学生可能遇到的障碍并帮助他们避免它们。

Teachers like Jamie and Terre are great because they take the time not just to figure out the sets of skills their students need to learn but also to anticipate their students’ likely stumbling blocks and help them to avoid them.

 

 

在音乐成就的研究中（通常在古典音乐而不是摇滚音乐的背景下进行），除了数量之外的一个因素持续预测成就的实践不是你是否去铃木学校，或者是否采用其他方法学习，而是父母的支持，大概是因为大多数幼儿在没有外部激励的情况下无法充分发挥自己的作用。

In studies of musical achievement (typically done in the context of classical music rather than rock music), the one factor besides amount of practice that consistently predicts achievement is not whether you go to Suzuki school, or study under some other method, but parental support, presumably because most young children can’t apply themselves sufficiently without external motivation.

最终，动机可以来自外部或内部——来自父母或老师的鼓励，或者来自控制、甚至主宰乐器的内在愿望。帕特·马蒂诺（Pat Martino）被许多人认为是他这一代最伟大的爵士吉他手，他学习吉他是为了给父母留下深刻的印象。汤姆·莫雷洛从十七岁开始，纯粹是为了自己，作为获得掌控自己生活的一种方式。他的父母可能对重金属球拍不太感兴趣，而且他也不是为了老师——他没有老师。当我问汤姆他是否学会了为女孩们演奏时，他立即回答说“天哪，没有！” 然后他停顿了一分钟，更轻柔地补充道：“嗯，也许吧，但不是你想象的那样。一头扎进这种痴迷的吉他练习是弥补社交失误的一种方式。作为伊利诺伊州利伯蒂维尔唯一的黑人孩子，约会是令人痛苦的……超出了我的控制范围。练习吉他的世界完全在我的掌控之中。” 莫雷洛转向吉他并不是因为它能让他找到女孩，而是因为它让他摆脱了与女孩互动的挑战，以及追求女孩时经常带来的社交尴尬和拒绝。吉米·亨德里克斯的一位传记作者对亨德里克斯写了类似的内容：“在他的吉他到达后不久，他就发现 [亨德里克斯] 一生中真正想做的就是弹吉他。这是他的妹妹，他的女人，他的缪斯，他的释放。” 亨德里克斯在青少年时期害羞又笨拙，他花了很多时间在吉他上，以至于他几乎把它带到了床上。莫雷洛也同样着迷，他说：“我没有选择弹吉他；我选择了弹吉他。” 它选择了我。”

Ultimately, motivation can come from without or within— from parents or teachers offering encouragement or from an internal desire to control, even dominate, an instrument. Pat Martino, considered by many to be the greatest jazz guitarist of his generation, took up guitar as a way to impress his parents. Tom Morello, starting at seventeen, did it purely for himself, as a way of gaining power over his own life. His parents probably weren’t too thrilled by the heavy metal racket, and he wasn’t doing it for a teacher, either— he didn’t have one. When I asked Tom whether he had instead learned to play for the girls, his immediate answer was “Hell, no!” He then paused for a minute and added, more softly, “Well, maybe, but not in the way you might think. Diving headlong into this obsessive guitar practice was a way of compensating for social lapses. Dating, as the only black kid in Libertyville, Illinois, was harrowing … out of my control. The world of practicing guitar was all completely in my control.” Morello had turned to guitar not because it would lead him to girls but because it led him away from the challenges of interacting with girls, and the social awkwardness and rejection that often came from pursuing them. One of Jimi Hendrix’s biographers writes something similar about Hendrix: “It had not taken him long after his guitar arrived that all [Hendrix] really wanted to do in life was to play guitar. It was his sister, his woman, his muse, his release.” Hendrix, shy and awkward in his teenage years, spent so much time with his guitar that he literally brought it to bed with him. Morello, similarly obsessed, said, “I didn’t choose playing guitar; it chose me.”

 

在他的职业生涯后期，当莫雷洛参加了被称为“撕碎赛”的比赛时，他开始将著名的赛马秘书处视为榜样。到大学结束时，我们的目标不仅仅是获胜，而是让其他参赛者放弃并回家。如果他要实现他意识到，这个巨大的目标需要他去弥补。莫雷洛十七岁时才开始接触吉他，他的起步时间几乎比他所有的吉他偶像（以及他的大多数竞争对手）都要晚。为了弥补失去的时间，他开始每天练习一个小时。然后是两个，然后是四个，六个，最后是八个。在哈佛大学本科四年（他同时完成了政治学荣誉学位）期间，莫雷洛估计他错过了大约三天的训练。“如果我发烧 102 度并在早上进行检查，我还有六个小时的时间。”

Later in his career, as Morello went to competitions known as shred-offs, he began to see the famous racehorse Secretariat as a role model. By the end of college, the goal was not just to win, but to make the other competitors give up and go home. If he was going to achieve this outsize goal, he realized, he had enormous ground to make up. Taking up guitar only at the age of seventeen, Morello had started later than virtually all of his guitar idols (and most of his competitors). To make up for lost time, he began by practicing an hour every day. Then two, then four, six, and eventually eight. In his four years as a Harvard undergraduate (where he simultaneously completed an honors degree in political science), Morello estimates that he missed practice on maybe three days. “If I had a fever of 102 and an exam in the morning, I still got in my six hours.”

 

我不确定任何老师或家长都能向学生灌输这种程度的动力——它很可能必须来自内部——但很难想象还有什么比这更有价值的了。

I’m not sure any teacher or parent can instill that level of drive in a student— it most likely must come from within— but it is hard to imagine anything of more value.

 

 

在音乐教育领域，最鼓舞人心的人物之一是 Marienne Uszler，她是广受好评的《平均律键盘老师》一书的合著者。

In the world of music education, one of the most inspiring figures is Marienne Uszler, co-author of the widely regarded The Well-Tempered Keyboard Teacher.

当乌斯勒第一次接受训练时——作为一名钢琴家，而不是一名教育家——音乐教育学领域几乎不存在；人们可以研究像让·皮亚杰（Jean Piaget）和杰罗姆·布鲁纳（Jerome Bruner）这样的认知发展先驱，但很少有研究人员专门研究音乐教育。

When Uszler was first trained— as a pianist, not an educator— the field of music pedagogy scarcely existed; one could study pioneers in cognitive development like Jean Piaget and Jerome Bruner, but few researchers specialized in music education.

 

直到二十世纪中叶，大多数方法书籍“在书的前面都有一个你必须记住的东西清单”，它们确实适合那些已经在某种程度上知道如何演奏的人；他们是我们现在所谓的中级学生的指南，而不是新手；像我这样的人就完全不走运了。正如乌斯勒所说，“在[卡尔]菲利普·伊曼纽尔·巴赫的时代，街区里的普通孩子不会上音乐课”，并且没有太多思考如何让新手轻松融入音乐生活。在过去，这是一种师徒模式，几乎所有的东西都是死记硬背的，无论是音乐还是其他教育领域。现存的书籍主要集中在音阶等方面，最后是练习曲和练习；演奏起来很有趣的作品可能会更好地激励学生，这一观念显然还没有在这个领域（或者实际上是在整个教育工作者中）出现。

Until the mid-twentieth century, most method books “had a list of things that you had to memorize at the front of the book,” and they were really geared to people who already knew how to play to some degree; they were guides for what we might now call intermediate students, not novices; someone like me would have been entirely out of luck. As Uszler put it, “In the days of [Carl] Philipp Emanuel Bach, the ordinary kid down the block didn’t take music lessons,” and there wasn’t much thought as to how to ease a novice into a life of music. In the old days, it was a master-and-apprentice model, with virtually everything learned by rote, for music as for so much else in education. What books did exist focused mainly on things like scales, and eventually études and exercises; the notion that a student might be better motivated by compositions that were fun to play apparently hadn’t dawned on the field yet (or indeed on educators at large).

 

直到 20 年代或 1930 年代，教师和作家才开始超越死记硬背，转向更广泛的音乐机制背景，转向和声（多种声音或乐器的结合）、和弦和理论等方面。

It also took until the 1920s or 1930s before teachers and writers began to move beyond rote memorization to a broader background in the mechanics of music, toward aspects such as harmony (the coming together of multiple voices or instruments), chords, and theory.

 

另一项创新可能是由心理学研究结果推动的，它是认识到强化先前学到的概念很重要。在一本著名的书《教小手指玩》（仍在使用）中，广告吹嘘每一页都有新的东西，而没有考虑到人类的大脑需要一定程度的重复才能完全编码所学到的东西。“每一页都有新东西”抽象地听起来不错，但如果要学习的内容变化太快，巩固可能永远不会发生，而且可能坚持的东西太少（因此米歇尔的“复习比学习新东西更好”）。理想的老师必须平衡新旧：足够的旧的可以强化良好的习惯，足够的新的可以防止课程变得乏味。乌斯勒是新一代音乐教育家的先驱，这一代人既关心音乐本身，也关心学习的潜在心理。

Another innovation, driven perhaps by findings in psychology, was the realization that reinforcement of previously learned concepts was important. In one famous book, Teaching Little Fingers to Play (still in use), advertisements vaunted the fact that there was something new on every page— without considering that the human mind needs some degree of repetition in order to fully encode what is learned. “Something new on every page” sounds good in the abstract, but if what is to be learned shifts too rapidly, consolidation may never occur, and too little may stick (hence Michele’s “It’s better to review than to learn something new”). The ideal teacher must balance the old and the new: enough of the old to reinforce good habits, enough of the new to keep lessons from becoming tedious. Uszler is a pioneer in a new generation of music educators, a generation as concerned with the underlying psychology of learning as with the music itself.

 

 

二十世纪音乐教育先驱埃德温·戈登（Edwin E. Gordon）特别强调他所谓的“听感”，或“吸收和理解（不仅仅是排练）音乐的过程”。随意的听众只是听到音乐，而对音乐的构成方式没有任何明确的理解，即使对于许多表演者来说，同样的情况也会发生，他们只是通过例行公事而不是更深层次的学习。正如戈登所说，“记住音乐乐器[通常]主要与手指和其他技术问题有关，”而不是与更抽象的理解有关。戈登的目的是训练学生更积极地参与，用音阶、和弦进行等组成部分以及更复杂的概念（如调调的转调）来解释他们听到的内容，以便他们能够轻松地唱一首曲子——或者在内心听到它——就像他们用自己的乐器演奏一样。用戈登的话来说，“就像计算器成为不会乘法或除法的学生的拐杖一样，乐器也可以成为不会听力的学生的拐杖。”

The pioneering twentieth-century music educator Edwin E. Gordon has placed particular emphasis on what he calls audiation, or “the process of assimilating and comprehending (not simply rehearsing) music.” The casual listener merely hears music, without any explicit understanding of how that music is constructed, and the same can happen even for many performers, who learn simply by routine, rather than at a deeper level. As Gordon puts it, “Memorizing music on an instrument is [ordinarily] primarily related to fingers and other technical matters,” and not to a more abstract understanding. Gordon’s intention has been to train students to engage more actively, to interpret what they hear in terms of constituent parts like musical scales, chord progressions, and more sophisticated notions such as modulations in musical key, so that they are as comfortable singing a piece— or hearing it on the inside— as they are playing it on their own instruments. In Gordon’s words, “Just as a calculator becomes a crutch for students who cannot multiply or divide, so music instruments [can] become a crutch for students who cannot audiate.”

在努力帮助有抱负的音乐家超越单纯的死记硬背知识的过程中，戈登建议学生按照严格的步骤顺序培养试听技能，从简单地听熟悉和不熟悉的音乐，到学习阅读音乐、写乐谱、回忆音乐。从记忆中，最终到创作和即兴音乐。我对细节有一些疑问——在我看来，戈登过分强调了阶段的逻辑进展；例如，许多早期的爵士音乐家在没有学习过读或写音乐的情况下就成为熟练的即兴演奏家。但戈登的总体观点——从音乐的内部结构而不是仅仅从一系列音符的角度来理解一首音乐具有相当大的价值——是深刻的。一个只能死记硬背所学知识的音乐家永远无法与从内部理解音乐逻辑的音乐家相媲美。

In striving to help aspiring musicians move beyond mere rote knowledge, Gordon has recommended that students develop audiation skills in a strict sequence of steps that progress from simply listening to familiar and unfamiliar music, to learning to read music, to writing it, to recalling music from memory, and ultimately to creating and improvising music. I have some issues with the de tails— in my view, Gordon overemphasizes the logical progression in the stages; many early jazz musicians managed, for instance, to become skilled improvisers without ever learning to read or write music. But Gordon’s general point— that there is considerable value in understanding a piece of music in terms of its inner structures rather than just as a sequence of notes— is profound. A musician who can merely reproduce what he or she has learned by rote will never match one who understands the logic of music from the inside.

 

 

归根结底，教师是否接受过铃木方法、达尔克罗兹方法或其他我没有讨论过的方法（例如奥尔夫或柯达伊方法）的培训可能并不那么重要；重要的是，教师是否接受过铃木方法、达尔克罗兹方法或其他我没有讨论过的方法（例如奥尔夫或柯达伊方法）的培训。相反，更重要的是他们是否有能力倾听并提供建设性且热情的反馈。这与技术无关；而是与技术有关。这是关于老师的。

In the final analysis, it may not matter so much whether teachers are trained in the Suzuki method, the Dalcroze method, or others I haven’t discussed, such as Orff or Kodaly; instead, what may be more important is whether they are equipped to listen well and give feedback that is simultaneously constructive and enthusiastic. It’s not about the technique; it’s about the teacher.

 

摇滚学院

SCHOOL OF ROCK

 

男人与青少年

Man Versus Teen

 

六月底，也就是我的音乐追求大约十个月后，我收到了一份我无法拒绝的邀请：有机会参观 DayJams，这是一个夏令营，八岁到十五岁的孩子们可以在这里学习摇滚乐的演奏和作曲。当我与训练营主任托拜厄斯·赫维茨 (Tobias Hurwitz) 交谈时，赌注立即增加了，他在一次预采访中告诉我，“我们欢迎你旁听课程，但为了获得完整的体验，你需要想加入乐队。” （当然，我心想，一半兴奋，一半恐惧。）“如果你想加入乐队，最好弹低音吉他，因为贝斯手永远不够。”

Toward the end of June, about ten months into my musical quest, I got an offer I couldn’t possibly refuse: a chance to visit DayJams, a summer camp where kids ages eight to fifteen learn to play and compose rock and roll. The stakes were immediately raised when I spoke to the camp’s director, Tobias Hurwitz, who told me, in a kind of pre-interview, “You’re welcome to sit in on the classes, but to get the full experience, you’ll want to be in a band.” (Definitely, I thought to myself, half-excited, half-terrified.) “And if you want to be in a band, it’s probably best if you play bass guitar, because there are never enough bass players.”

嗯，贝斯？我从来没有弹过贝斯。我没有，事实上，我唯一一次碰过它是在大学一年级，当时我的朋友亚历克斯（Alex）慷慨地尝试（无论如何没有运气）教我九个音符的开场连复段。 Talking Heads 的歌曲“Psycho Killer”。

Um, bass? I’d never played bass. I didn’t own one, and in fact the only time I’d ever even touched one was my freshman year in college, when my friend Alex graciously tried (with no luck whatsoever) to teach me the nine-note opening riff to the Talking Heads song “Psycho Killer.”

 

这一次，我决心要有更好的态度。我在大学时可能对音乐一无所知，但我在吉他方面取得了巨大的进步；贝斯有多难？

This time, I was determined to have a better attitude. I may have been musically clueless in college, but I’d made huge strides on guitar; how hard could bass be?

我熬了半夜在网上阅读有关如何为自己购买贝斯的信息。赫尔维茨慷慨地表示，营地有“贷款人”，但贷款人给我的印象是一个糟糕的主意：我需要立即开始。如果我要说服一些青少年让我加入他们的乐队，我就必须在训练营的第一个小时内做到这一点。如果我不能演奏至少一些像样的乐段，那么即使是最蹩脚、最绝望的初学者乐队也很难让他们父母这个年龄的人加入。我在网上找到了一把紫色的 Ibanez，并支付了隔夜运送可赚大钱。

I stayed up half the night reading online about how to choose a bass to buy for my very own. Hurwitz generously offered that the camp has “loaners,” but a loaner struck me as a terrible idea: I needed to start immediately. If I was to persuade some of the teenagers to let me be in their band, I would have to do it in the first hour of the camp. If I couldn’t play at least a few decent licks coming in, it was hard to see how even the lamest, most desperate band of beginners would let someone of their parents’ age join in. I found a purple Ibanez online and paid the big bucks for overnight shipping.

 

在接下来的三周里，贝斯成了我的生活。其他一切，甚至吉他本身，都被抛在了一边。我学会了“Another One Bites the Dust”的开场舔，记住了贝斯的指板——事实证明这比吉他的指板更容易、更符合逻辑，基本上相当于吉他上遵循一致模式的四根弦，没有这两件事令人困惑——并祈祷我能找到加入乐队的方法。

For the next three weeks, bass became my life; everything else, even guitar itself, got pushed aside. I learned the opening lick to “Another One Bites the Dust,” memorized the bass’s fretboard— which turns out to be a lot easier and more logical than a guitar’s, essentially equivalent to the four strings on the guitar that follow a consistent pattern, without the bother of the two that confuse— and prayed that I could find my way into a band.

 

 

在第一天去营地的路上，我在旅途中并不是第一次感到焦虑。我必须上台试镜吗？我会好吗？

On the way over to camp the first day, I am, not for the first time in my journey, anxious. Will I have to audition onstage? Will I be any good?

我到达的时间比我多年来到达任何地方的时间都要早，并且找到了去赫尔维茨的路。有着凸出的二头肌和齐肩的卷发，他看起来更像是摇滚明星而不是营地主管。幸运的是，他很谦虚，并且立即尽力让我感到舒服。他告诉我，他将在开幕式上介绍我，但又赶紧补充说，是否让我加入他们的乐队将由营员们决定。

I arrive earlier than I’ve arrived at anything in years and find my way to Hurwitz. With bulging biceps and curly shoulder-length hair, he looks more like a rock star than a camp director. Luckily, he is unpretentious, and right away he does his best to make me feel comfortable. He tells me that he’ll introduce me at the opening assembly but hastens to add that it is up to the campers to decide whether to include me in their band.

 

简短的交谈后，有人给了我一个包，里面装着初学者的东西贝斯教科书，由营地教练之一格伦·莱利（Glenn Riley）编写，还有一些贝斯弦，然后托比亚斯把我送到一个小教室/围栏，营员们正在里面收集。我主要和本交谈，他是一个善于交际的 12 岁孩子，他从七岁起就参加 DayJams，显然他知道的事情比我多得多。

After a brief chat, someone gives me a bag containing a beginner’s bass textbook, written by Glenn Riley, one of the camp’s instructors, and some bass strings, and then Tobias sends me off to a small classroom/holding pen in which the campers are collecting. Mostly I talk to Ben, a sociable twelve-year-old who’s been coming to DayJams since he was seven and who clearly knows far more than I ever will.

 

上午9:00刚过，营地正式开营；大约五十名营员、几名流浪家长和辅导员被带到一个巨大的礼堂，教官们正在演奏警察的“瓶中信”。之后还有另一首歌，然后赫尔维茨发布了六条公告，其中我最喜欢的是“禁止在任何不是鼓的东西上打鼓”。

Just after 9:00 a.m., the camp officially opens; the fifty or so campers, a few stray parents, and the counselors are led to a huge auditorium, where the instructors are playing “Message in a Bottle” by the Police. There’s another song after that, and then Hurwitz makes half a dozen announcements, my favorite of which is “No drumming on anything that isn’t a drum.”

 

托拜厄斯最终把我叫到台上，介绍我作为一名教授和作家，并告诉观众我是来参加露营并写下来的。他说我想加入乐队（而不仅仅是坐在旁边观看），并提到一些露营者的名字可能会在一本书中提到，这让我的兴趣更加浓厚。不过，这取决于他们，我能做的就是等待；根据双方同意，托比亚斯将开始喊出各个教练的名字以及各自乐队的成员的名字，只有当所有的孩子都已经组织好之后，我们才能看看是否有我的空间。在等待的过程中，我满脑子都是三年级、四年级学生的日子，希望能被踢球，拼命祈祷：选我，选我，选我！

Tobias eventually calls me up onstage, introduces me as a professor and an author, and tells the audience that I’m there to be a camper and write about it. He says I’d like to be in a band (and not just sit around and watch) and sweetens the pot by mentioning that some of the campers might have their names mentioned in a book. Still, it’s up to them, and all I can do is wait; by mutual agreement Tobias will start calling out the names of various instructors and who will be in their respective bands, and it’s only once all the kids have already been organized that we’ll get to see if there is room for me. While I wait, all I can think of is my days as a third and fourth grader, hoping to get picked for kickball, praying desperately: Pick me, pick me, pick me!

 

 

最后，其他一切都安排好了，托比亚斯带我去了最年轻的乐队之一，碰巧该乐队的指挥是迈克尔·雷齐克(Michael Raitzyk)，他是我母亲的邻居之一，也是我家朋友的儿子。他也是马里兰州顶尖的爵士吉他手之一，并且恰好是第一个告诉我关于这个营地的人。六个孩子，大约十岁或十一岁，正在玩吉他和鼓，其中一个在键盘上，他们很少注意到我。

Finally, everything else is organized, and Tobias brings me to one of the youngest bands, which, as it happens, is directed by Michael Raitzyk, who is one of my mother’s neighbors and the son of a family friend. He’s also one of Maryland’s leading jazz guitarists, and happens to be the person who told me about the camp in the first place. Half a dozen kids, all around ten or eleven years old, are fooling around with guitars and drums, one on a keyboard, and they take little notice of me.

托比亚斯问他们是否愿意让我加入他们的乐队。迈克尔说了一句好话：“加里是个好人，拥有一名贝斯手对乐队真的很有帮助。” 三个孩子耸耸肩说当然；没有人提出异议。就这样，我加入了一支乐队，这是我作为贝斯手的第一次演出。

Tobias asks if they’d like to have me in their band. Michael puts in a good word: “Gary’s a nice guy, and it’ll really help the band to have a bass player.” Three of the kids shrug and say sure; nobody demurs. With that, I’m in a band, my first gig as a bass player.

 

 

我的三位乐队成员，Ryan（主音吉他手）、Riley（鼓手）和 Greer（键盘手），显然以前都演奏过；还有两个完全新手，莎拉和彼得，吉他手。当我到达课堂时，瑞安已经在演奏他在家创作的朗朗上口的即兴演奏。上课的前四十五分钟大部分时间都花在学习他的即兴演奏上；我尝试在贝斯上与他匹配，但舔音太快，我真的跟不上。

Three of my bandmates, Ryan (lead guitarist), Riley (drummer), and Greer (keyboardist), have clearly played before; there are also two complete novices, Sarah and Peter, on guitar. By the time I arrive in class, Ryan’s already playing a catchy riff that he made up at home. Most of the first forty-five minutes of class time is spent learning his riff; I try to match him on bass, but the lick is too fast and I can’t really keep up.

从那里开始，进入低音课程；这次我们大约有八个人（吉他手、键盘手和打击乐手都去了其他地方）和一位有点不高兴的老师，名叫杰米。杰米立即注意到我用右手用拇指（而不是惯用的食指和中指）弹奏音符。在他看来，这是一个坏主意。“你不一定要用手指来玩。。”。他吟诵着，但还没把话说完。他的言外之意是——如果我一直用拇指玩游戏，我就是个白痴——是很清楚的。（仅仅几个月后，我才意识到他的推理——右手有两个活跃的手指而不是一个，可以更轻松地弹得更快。）

From there, it’s off to bass class; this time there are about eight of us (guitarists, keyboard players, and percussionists have all gone elsewhere) and a slightly grouchy teacher named Jamie. Right away Jamie notices that with my right hand I am picking notes with my thumb (rather than the customary index and middle fingers). In his view, this is a bad idea. “It’s not imperative that you play with your fingers . . .” he intones, without ever quite finishing his sentence. His implication— that I’d be an idiot if I kept playing with my thumb— is clear enough. (Only months later do I realize his reasoning— with two active fingers on your right hand instead of one, it’s a lot easier to play faster.)

 

杰米的首席助理乔纳森只有十三岁，是一位明显的神童。尽管杰米是一位职业音乐家，早在乔纳森出生之前就开始演奏，但他的演奏已经几乎和杰米一样好。

Jamie’s chief assistant, Jonathan, is only thirteen and an obvious prodigy; he can already play nearly as well as Jamie can, even though Jamie is a professional musician who started playing long before Jonathan was born.

 

我们从简单的开始，使用我在前几周的贝斯速成课程中或多或少掌握的信息，例如贝斯吉他四弦上每个音符的名称。我很快发现，这种书本学习是我唯一知道而我的同学不知道的事情（我什至注意到黑板上的一个错误）。但当它说到实际演奏，我比其他大多数学生落后了好几英里，但我无法判断这是我的年龄还是他们的经验——除了一个人之外，所有人都曾经参加过训练营，而且许多人已经演奏了多年。我成年人的悟性对缩小差距有帮助吗？还是我会越来越落后？

We start easy, with information I’ve already more or less mastered in the previous weeks, during my crash course on bass, such as the name of each note on the bass guitar’s four strings. As I soon discover, this sort of book learning is about the only thing I know that my classmates don’t (I even notice an error on the blackboard). But when it comes to actual playing, I’m miles behind most of the other students, but I can’t tell whether that’s my age or their experience— all but one have been to the camp before, and many have been playing for years. Will my adult savvy be of any help in trying to close the gap? Or will I fall further and further behind?

 

 

杰米教我们一个相对简单的舔音——第一弦上两个音符，第二弦上一个，第三弦上两个。一个更有经验的孩子立即演奏它，并且演奏得很好。五分钟后，杰米把我叫到教室中央，让我弹奏那首乐曲。我已经设法了解了音符的顺序，但绝对没有掌握它们的时间安排。我试探性地玩，太尴尬了，无法与全班同学进行眼神交流。

Jamie teaches us a relatively simple lick—two notes on the first string, one on the second, two on the third. One of the more experienced kids immediately plays it, and plays it well. Five minutes later Jamie calls me to the center of the classroom and asks me to play the lick. I’ve managed to learn the order of the notes, sort of, but definitely haven’t mastered their timing. I play tentatively, too embarrassed to make eye contact with the class.

当天的亮点出现在最后阶段，在我们的日程安排中被列为“阶段”。我们乐队中的六人，加上我们的教练迈克尔，站上舞台，将我们的乐器插入专业级放大器（比我的乐队成员高），然后开始创作我们的歌曲。没有观众——老实说，我们不配拥有观众——但这并不重要。这是我第二次与类似乐队的东西一起演奏（另一次是与一位老朋友一起演奏，他来到城里给我上了一堂课），而且我以前从未与现场鼓组一起演奏过——那种发自内心的感觉底鼓和军鼓的近距离接触令人兴奋。

The highlight of the day comes during the final period, listed on our schedules as “Stage.” The six of us in my band, plus our instructor, Michael, get up on the stage, plug our instruments into professional-grade amplifiers— which are taller than my bandmates— and begin to work out our song. There’s no audience—and, to be honest, we wouldn’t deserve one—but it doesn’t matter. This is only the second time I’ve ever played with anything resembling a band (the other was with an old friend who came to town and gave me a lesson), and never before have I played alongside a live drum kit— the visceral feel of the kick and snare up close is thrilling.

 

我们从瑞安的舔开始，或多或少地记下来。这些音符很简单——G、A、B，再一次是A，都在最低的E弦上——但我不断收到关于每个音符敲击多少次的不同报告。瑞安（Ryan）弹得如此之快，以至于我和两位新手吉他手都很难跟上（尽管键盘手和鼓手似乎非常满意）。

We start with Ryan’s lick, and more or less get it down. The notes are easy— G, A, B, and A again, all on the lowest E string— but I keep getting varying reports on how many times to hit each note. Ryan plays so fast that the two novice guitarists and I have trouble keeping up (though the keyboardist and drummer seem perfectly content).

 

然后迈克尔征求建议，我建议一个简单的低音乐句，它是主吉他乐句的回声（尽管以更高的音调演奏）音高，在 G 弦而不是 E 弦上）。突然间，我发现自己被困在歌曲中间演奏一段短的独奏，两小节长，我几乎被随之而来的计时责任压垮了，特别是因为我不太明白如何让我的五个音符的舔音整齐地融入两个小节，每个小节四个节拍。我试图退出，或者至少建议我的贝斯独奏放在歌曲的结尾（没有其他人会依赖我），但迈克尔不同意。我被自己造成的负担所困。

Michael then calls for suggestions, and I suggest a simple bass lick that’s kind of an echo of the main guitar lick (though played in a higher pitch, on the G string rather than the E). Suddenly I find myself stuck with the responsibility of playing a short solo, two bars long, in the middle of the song, and I feel almost overwhelmed by the timekeeping responsibilities I’ve consequently acquired, especially since I can’t quite figure out how to make my five-note lick fit neatly into two bars of four beats each. I try to back out, or at least suggest that my bass solo go at the end of the song (where nobody else would rely on me), but Michael’s having none of it. I’m stuck with a burden of my own making.

 

到目前为止，我们练习了我们的作曲：吉他乐段，演奏了四次，然后是我的两个小节，然后是整个连复段的四次重复。大多数时候，总会出现一些问题：有人开始得太早，有人来得太晚，有人（通常是我，因为我跟不上）完全迷失了方向。我是一个相对较新的人，莎拉（和最终离开乐队的彼得）以前几乎从未演奏过；似乎只有 Ryan、Greer 和 Riley 真正知道他们在做什么，但即使他们也不太习惯作为一个乐队一起演奏。如果一支完美的乐队、一支演奏同步的乐队被称为“紧”，那么我们就处于“松”和“游荡”之间。可怕的是，到周五下午，我们必须齐心协力：我们将在所有营员及其父母（包括我的父母）面前在舞台上表演。我们能把它放在一起吗？

We practice our composition so far: guitar lick, played four times through, then my two bars, then four more repeats of the whole riff. And most of the time, something or other goes wrong: somebody starts too soon, somebody comes in too late, somebody (often me, because I can’t keep up) gets lost altogether. I’m a relative newcomer, and Sarah (and Peter, who would end up leaving the band) literally never played before; only Ryan, Greer, and Riley really seem to know what they are doing, but even they aren’t entirely used to playing together as a band. If a perfect band, a band that plays in synchrony, is called “tight,” we’re somewhere between “loose” and “wandering.” The scary part is that by Friday afternoon, we’d have to pull it together: we would be performing onstage in front of all the campers and their parents— including mine. Would we be able to pull it together?

 

 

接下来几天我们要做的大部分工作是结构和时间安排——何时从歌曲的一个部分切换到下一个部分，每个连复段重复多少次。这一切对我来说都不是一件容易的事，尤其是在我的乐队演奏的速度下——更像是雷蒙斯的歌曲而不是缓慢的民谣。最难的部分——就在我进入之前——是当我必须数出十六个连续的 G 音符时，所有这些音符（由我和其他人）全速演奏，就在我自己的简短独奏之前。我不知道如何在演出当晚把这件事做好。

Much of what we work on over the next few days is structure and timing— when to change from one section of the song to the next, how many times to repeat each riff. None of this comes easily for me, especially at the speed at which my band is playing— more like a Ramones song than a slow ballad. The hardest section— just before my entrance— is when I have to count sixteen consecutive notes of G, all played (by me and everyone else) at full speed, just before my own brief solo. I have no idea how I am going to get this right on the night of the show.

另一方面，瑞安本能地知道一个小节有多长。我不知道他的这种本能是自然而然还是经验丰富（他至少从去年夏天就开始打球，也许更久），但下午晚些时候我目瞪口呆地看着。迈克尔教瑞安 G 大调音阶的音符，并要求他用这些音符构建独奏，并按照他喜欢的顺序排列它们。关键是 Ryan 正好有 16 个节拍需要填充，不知怎的，孩子却做得恰到好处，事后大声惊叹道：“我不知道我是怎么做到的；我不知道我是怎么做到的；我不知道我是怎么做到的。” 我才知道。” 我可能了解代数、微积分和统计学，但当涉及到计算节拍的简单算术时，这些孩子比我领先光年。

Ryan, on the other hand, knows instinctively just how long a measure is. I don’t know whether he’s come by that instinct naturally or from experience (he’s been playing at least since last summer, maybe longer), but I watch agape later in the afternoon. Michael teaches Ryan the notes in the scale of G major and asks him to construct a solo out of those notes, arranging them in whatever sequence he likes. The key is that Ryan has exactly sixteen beats to fill, and somehow the kid gets it just right, marveling out loud afterward, “I don’t know how I did that; I just knew.” I may know about algebra, calculus, and statistics, but when it comes to the simple arithmetic of counting beats, these kids are light-years ahead of me.

 

 

在某种程度上，如何学习一件事取决于材料本身，与学习者无关。例如，无论是儿童还是成人，如果不首先学习音乐字母表，就不可能学习演奏旋律：旋律是由有序的、有节奏的音符组组成的；和声由多组音符组成，这些音符组合在一起形成优雅的整体。任何学习吉他的人，无论年龄大小，都必须习惯指板及其所需的奇怪形状。同样重要的是节奏感和时间感（一直是我的致命弱点）；如果不流畅、不规律，那么一切听起来都不好。

To a certain degree, how a thing is learned depends on the material itself, independent of who is doing the learning. Neither children nor adults, for instance, could have any hope of learning to play melody without learning the alphabet of music first: melodies are composed of ordered, rhythmical sets of notes; harmonies are composed of sets of notes that combine to form elegant wholes. Anyone learning guitar, whatever his or her age, must become accustomed to the fretboard and the strange shapes it requires. Equally essential is a sense of rhythm and time (ever my Achilles’ heel); nothing sounds good if it is not fluid and regular.

但大量研究表明，儿童和成人的大脑是不同的，大脑结构的差异原则上可能会导致学习方式的差异。从生理上来说，灰质（主要由神经细胞体组成）的密度在青春期增加，然后逐渐开始下降。大约在同一时间，白质（主要由形成神经元之间连接的轴突和树突组成）开始增加，这可能是所有正在发生的学习的产物。从行为上来说，至少在学习第二语言时，这也许是一种晚习音乐的模式在生活中，成年人的平均适应能力肯定不如孩子。许多研究都表明，在生命早期学习一门语言显然胜过在生命晚期学习一门语言，即使这种衰退并不像人们普遍认为的那样突然。

But lots of studies suggest that the brains of children and adults are different, and differences in brain structure could in principle lead to differences in learning style. Physiologically, gray matter (consisting mainly of neural cell bodies) increases in density through adolescence, and then gradually begins to decline. At roughly the same time, white matter (consisting mainly of the axons and dendrites that form connections between neurons) begins to increase, presumably a product of all the learning that is taking place. Behaviorally, at least when it comes to learning a second language, perhaps a model for acquiring music late in life, adults are certainly on average less apt than kids. Any number of studies have shown that learning a language early in life clearly beats learning one late in life, even if the decay is not nearly as abrupt as once widely believed.

 

 

没有人真正知道为什么。成年人是否因为记忆力较弱而处于劣势？因为某些大脑模块在青春期左右关闭了？或者仅仅因为他们不像年轻的同龄人那样努力？令人惊讶的是，科学文献五花八门。没有确凿的证据表明认知机会之窗在明确定义的时刻关闭。最近一项针对超过 200 万受试者的研究发现，随着年龄的增长呈线性下降——五十岁开始英语的人比四十岁开始英语的人表现更差，四十岁开始英语的人比三十岁开始英语的人表现更差，依此类推——但没有确切的说法曲线上的突破，没有一个决定性的时刻，超过了就不能学习第二语言。事实上，最近的一些研究发现，一些成年人能够完全掌握晚年习得的第二（或第三）语言。

Nobody really knows why. Are adults at a disadvantage because their memories are weaker? Because some brain module shuts down around the time of puberty? Or simply because they don’t try as hard as their younger counterparts? The scientific literature is surprisingly mixed. There is no solid evidence that windows of cognitive opportunity close at clearly defined moments. One recent study of over two million subjects found a linear decline with age— people starting English at the age of fifty did worse than those starting at age forty, who did worse than those who started at age thirty, and so on— but no firm break in the curve, no decisive moment beyond which a second language could not be learned. Indeed, some recent studies have found that some adults are able to fully master second (or third) languages acquired later in life.

我自己对文献的解读是，我们的记忆力从二十多岁开始慢慢下降，但也存在一个严重的干扰和习惯问题：你的母语习惯越强，做不同的事情就越困难用第二语言。当然，您使用母语的时间越长，它就会变得越根深蒂固和习惯。如果你习惯把动词放在中间，那么在德语中就很难学会把它放在最后。

My own reading of the literature is that our memory skills slowly decline from the mid-twenties onward but that there is also a serious issue of interference and habits: the stronger your habits are with your native language, the harder it is to do something different in a second language. And of course the longer you’ve been speaking your first language, the more ingrained and habitual it has become; if you are used to putting the verb in the middle, it’s hard to learn to put it at the end in German.

 

孩子们在学习许多东西时可能具有更大的优势，因为他们如何分配时间和注意力，常常要忍受成年人会觉得乏味的无休止的重复。成年人往往急于了解全局，部分原因是他们通常背负着其他责任。孩子们愿意练习一个元素——单词甚至音节——一遍又一遍，直到他们弄清细节。用心理学家艾丽莎·纽波特（Elissa Newport）的话来说，有时可能是“少即是多”。例如，众所周知，保加利亚孩子学习演奏复杂的民歌时，会密切关注表演的细节——学习所有的装饰音和旋律，而不是首先学习旋律。成年人可能首先关注整体旋律，然后再添加更精细的细节。

Kids are likely at a further advantage in learning many things because of how they allocate their time and attention, often enduring endless repetition that adults would find tedious. Partly because they are typically saddled with other responsibilities, adults are often in a rush to get the big picture; kids are willing to practice a single element— a word or even a syllable— over and over until they get that detail right. In the words of the psychologist Elissa Newport, it may be that sometimes “less is more.” Bulgarian kids learning to play complex folk songs, for example, have been known to focus closely on the details of a performance— learning all the ornaments along with the melody instead of just learning the melody first. Adults might focus first on the overall melody and add the finer details later.

 

正如 Marienne Uszler 向我指出的那样，适用于所有技能习得的另一个区别是“一般来说，学习者越年轻，体验未知事物的意愿就越大。” 十五岁时比五十岁时更容易冒险。

Another difference that applies to all skill acquisition is, as Marienne Uszler pointed out to me, that “generally speaking, the younger the learner, the greater the willingness to experience something unknown.” It is easier to take risks at fifteen than at fifty.

 

 

许多人可能认为孩子只是学得更快，但实验室研究表明事实并非如此。在对儿童和大学生“程序性”学习的少数直接比较中，成年人实际上往往比儿童学习得更快。在我能发现的最近、最仔细的研究中，六岁的孩子、八岁的孩子、十岁的孩子和成年人都做了类似的按下按钮的任务，有点像钢琴的简化版， （为了平衡竞争环境）每个人都必须学习不熟悉的新模式。令人惊讶的是，对于那些认为孩子能够快速学习的人来说，尤其是在可能感觉有点像电子游戏的按下按钮的任务上，成年人在系统上表现得更好，在比孩子少得多的尝试中获得了新的模式。

Many people probably imagine that kids are simply quicker learners, but laboratory research suggests otherwise. In the few direct comparisons of “procedural” learning in children and college-aged adults, adults actually tend to be quicker learners than children. In the most recent, most careful study I could find, six-year-olds, eight-year-olds, ten-year-olds, and adults all did a similar button-pressing task, kind of a simplified version of piano, in which (to balance the playing field) everyone had to learn new patterns that were unfamiliar. Surprisingly, for anyone who imagined kids to be quick studies, especially on a button-pressing task that might feel a bit like a video game, adults were systematically better, acquiring the new patterns in significantly fewer trials than children.

如果孩子比成年人表现出色，可能不是因为他们学得更快，而是因为他们更坚持；同样的动力可以让他们连续五天观看电视节目的同一集而没有任何失去兴趣的迹象，也可以让一个渴望演奏乐器的孩子一遍又一遍地练习相同的即兴演奏。尽管成年人最初学习这些模式的速度更快，但有足够的练习的孩子最终能够达到同样水平的准确性。十岁的孩子比八岁的孩子更早到达那里，八岁的孩子比六岁的孩子更善于学习，但他们最终都会到达那里，从长远来看，如果孩子们练习的话更重要的是，他们可能会超越他们的长辈。但除了识别音调上细微的声学差异等情况外，没有证据表明学习晚绝对会破坏交易。

If kids outshine adults, it’s probably not because they are quicker to learn but simply because they are more persistent; the same drive that can lead them to watch the same episode of a TV show five days in a row without any signs of losing interest can lead a child who aspires to play an instrument to practice the same riff over and over again. Although adults initially learn the patterns more quickly, with enough practice kids are ultimately able to achieve the same level of accuracy. The ten-year-olds get there sooner than the eight-year-olds, who are more adept learners than the six-year-olds, but they all manage to get there in the end, and in the long run, if kids practice more, they may just overtake their elders. But except in contexts like recognizing fine acoustic differences in pitch, there’s no evidence that learning late is an absolute deal breaker.

 

 

真正决定学习速度的可能不是年龄，而是经验。考虑到我完全缺乏天生的天赋，在任何年龄都能产生影响的唯一因素就是纯粹的练习。总的来说，学习最快的孩子是那些练习时间最长的孩子。十五岁的孩子比十三岁的孩子好，十三岁的孩子比十一岁的孩子好。罕见的十三岁巫师（比如乔纳森）通常很早就开始了（对他来说是四岁）。另一个十三岁的孩子以前从未打过球，他和我一样挣扎。

What really governs the speed of learning is probably not so much age as experience. Factoring out my complete lack of native talent, the single element that seemed to make the difference at any age was sheer practice. The kids who were the quickest studies were, by and large, those who had spent the most years practicing. Fifteen-year-olds were better than thirteen-year-olds, and thirteen-year-olds were better than eleven-year-olds. The rare thirteen-year-old wizards (like Jonathan) had generally started very early (at four, in his case). Another thirteen-year-old had never played before, and he was struggling just as much as I was.

为什么练习如此重要？正如我们之前所看到的，当我们掌握任何领域时，无论是吉他、代数还是壁球，我们的大脑在两件事上会变得更好：识别片段是什么（称为分块）和知道在哪里看（称为注意力）。

Why does practice matter as much as it does? As we saw earlier, when we master any domain, be it guitar or algebra or squash, our brains get better at two things: recognizing what the pieces are (known as chunking) and knowing where to look (known as attention).

 

对于初学者来说，任何歌曲（或即兴重复段）或多或少都只是随机的音符集合。对于专家来说，这些相同的音符会立即变得熟悉：“这个小节就像降 D 大调音阶，只是跳过了升 F 音符！” 突然间，七个音符变成了一个易于记忆的区块；我们识别的方块越多，我们就能玩得越快、越高效。当吉他手掌握了连复段和音阶的词汇时，所有新的东西都比旧的东西更容易记住。一旦棋手能够突破局面，他们就可以进一步思考伦敦出租车司机一旦了解了各个社区的来龙去脉，就能更有效地规划路线。（所有这些都会在大脑中反映出来：正如我们之前所看到的，当我们学习新事物时，我们的灰质往往会变得更加密集。）同样，专业音乐家一旦开始编码更大的内容，就可以更好地理解整个音乐以及更抽象的音乐块。

To a beginner, any song (or riff) is more or less just a random collection of notes. To an expert, those same notes will be instantly familiar: “That measure is just like a descending D major scale, except that the F-sharp note is skipped!” Suddenly seven notes become one easy-to-remember block; the more blocks we recognize, the faster and more efficiently we can play. As the guitarist acquires a vocabulary of riffs and scales, everything new becomes easier to remember in relation to the old. Chess players can think further ahead once they can break positions down into familiar chunks, and aspiring London taxi drivers plan their routes more efficiently once they learn the ins and outs of individual neighborhoods. (All of which has a reflection in the brain: as we saw earlier, our gray matter tends to get denser as we learn new things.) In the same way, expert musicians can better understand music as a whole once they begin to encode bigger and more abstract musical chunks.

 

 

作为乐队的一员，我无法保持年轻得多的乐队成员的狂躁能量，但我确实可以贡献一件事：对歌曲整体的动态感。我一生都在与心律失常作斗争，但这并没有阻止我成为一名积极的倾听者，现在我多年的倾听开始派上用场。此外，几个月来，我一直在积极思考歌曲的制作和编曲，通过苹果GarageBand（一个允许用户创作自己音乐的程序）的实验，以及对美学科学的阅读和思考；相对于我的年轻乐队成员，我的整体作曲感更强。在 Ryan 介绍了两个基本的连复段之后，实际组装我们的歌曲的大部分工作都落在了我的手中。我最终建议了我们开始这首歌的方式（本质上是一个笑话，格里尔演奏了一段复杂的古典前奏曲——被莱利猛击鼓突然打断，此时情绪从温和的钢琴独奏变成了激烈的演奏） -摇摆混乱）。我还制定了结局，并在歌曲的后半部分提出了一个组织方案，其中每个更有经验的成员都可以进行独奏（或接近独奏，除了鼓手之外的所有人都退出）。我对此并不咄咄逼人——我尽可能温和地提出每一个建议，从不坚持（特别是因为我总是感觉自己像个客人）——但我的乐队成员很高兴收到他们的建议；根本没有考虑到构图的高层次因素孩子们的想法。孩子们宁愿完善他们的即兴演奏，也不愿考虑整个合奏。这给我这个老一辈的代表留下了一个难得的发光发热的地方。

As a member of the band, I couldn’t maintain the manic energy of my much younger bandmates, but I did have one thing I could contribute: a sense of the dynamics of songs as a whole. My lifelong struggles with arrhythmia hadn’t kept me from being an active listener, and now my years of listening started to come in handy. Moreover, for months, I’d been actively thinking about song production and arrangement, through experiments with Apple’s GarageBand (a program that allows users to compose their own music), and reading and thinking on the science of aesthetics; relative to my young bandmates, I had a stronger sense of composition as a whole. After Ryan introduced two basic riffs, much of the effort in actually assembling our song wound up in my hands. I ended up suggesting a way for us to begin the song (essentially a joke, with Greer playing the intro of a complex classical prelude— interrupted abruptly by Riley slamming on the drums, at which point the mood changes from a gentle piano recital to hard-rocking mayhem). I also worked out the ending and suggested an organizational scheme in the latter part of the song wherein each of the more experienced members might take solos (or near solos, with everyone but the drummer dropping out). I wasn’t pushy about it—I made each suggestion as gently as possible, and never with insistence (especially since I always felt like a guest)—but my bandmates were glad to have them; high-level considerations about composition simply weren’t on the kids’ minds. The kids would rather polish their riffs than think about the ensemble as a whole. Which left me, as representative of an older generation, a rare place in which to shine.

几个月后，我发现自己和一位好朋友的三个非常有才华的年轻吉他演奏儿子一起参加了一个假日聚会。每个孩子都能比我更华丽地演奏一系列单独的连复段，但两个弟弟还没有捕捉到音乐中需要一起演奏的部分。相反，每个人都沉浸在自己的世界中，练习自己的即兴演奏，而不考虑其他人在演奏什么。凭借我对音乐理论不断加深的理解，我能够担任指挥，并设法让孩子们齐声即兴演奏——这是他们以前从未真正做过的事情。

A few months later, I found myself at a holiday party with three incredibly talented young guitar-playing sons of a good friend. Each child could play a fleet of individual riffs with vastly more panache than I could, but the two younger brothers hadn’t yet captured the part of music that is about playing together. Instead, each was in his own world, practicing his own riff without regard to what the others were playing. Drawing on my growing understanding of music theory, I was able to act as conductor and managed to get the kids to jam together in unison— something they had never really done before.

 

如果我的经验有任何指导意义的话——而且它与贫乏的科学文献非常吻合——儿童和成人之间的比较并不是简单地说一个人比另一个人好；而是简单地说一个人比另一个人好。相反，孩子和成人都有自己的优势和劣势。孩子们在餐桌上带来了巨大的耐心和敏捷的手指；成年人拥有大量的隐性知识，这些知识是通过多年的倾听而培养起来的，并且更容易进行抽象。

If my experience is any guide— and it fits pretty well with the meager scientific literature— the comparison between kids and adults isn’t a simple matter of saying one is better than the other; rather, kids and adults have their own strengths and liabilities. Children bring to the table enormous patience and fast fingers; adults have a vast reservoir of implicit knowledge, cultivated through years of listening, and far more facility with abstractions.

 

年迈的棒球投手有时会在职业生涯后期设法从蛮力（除了热力之外什么也不投球）转变为狡猾的方式，通过投出各种较慢的投球来使击球手失去平衡。我从来没有热情，但也许在三十九岁的时候我可以利用我的经验（以及美学科学的知识）至少为音乐桌上带来一些东西。

Aging baseball pitchers sometimes manage, late in their careers, to shift from brute force— throwing nothing but heat— to cunning, keeping batters off balance by throwing a wide variety of slower pitches. I never had the heat, but maybe at thirty-nine I could use my experience (and knowledge of the science of aesthetics) to bring at least a little something to the musical table.

 

 

真正的人才

TRUE TALENT

 

努力工作并不是一切

Hard Work Isn’t Everything

 

当我坐在营地试图掌握贝斯时，我当然没有忽视练习的重要性。但实践是唯一重要的因素吗？最近的流行心理学畅销书十分之九似乎都表明天赋并不存在，或者至少（借用一个标题）天赋被高估了。心理学家安德斯·埃里克森甚至写道：“新的研究表明，出色的表现是多年刻意练习和指导的结果，而不是任何天生的天赋或技能。”

As I sat at camp trying to master the bass, the importance of practice was certainly not lost on me. But is practice the only factor that matters? Nine out of ten recent pop-psychology bestsellers seem to suggest that talent doesn’t exist or at least that (to borrow the title of one) talent is overrated. The psychologist Anders Ericsson went so far as to write, “New research shows that outstanding performance is the product of years of deliberate practice and coaching, not of any innate talent or skill.”

我多么希望这是真的。臭名昭著的行为主义者约翰·沃森 (John Watson) 在 20 年代也曾说过类似的话，当时他写道：

How I wish it were true. The notorious behaviorist John Watson said something similar back in the 1920s when he famously wrote:

 

给我一打健康的婴儿，发育良好，在我自己指定的世界里抚养他们，我保证随机挑选任何一个，训练他成为我可能选择的任何类型的专家——医生、律师、艺术家、商人首领，是的，甚至是乞丐和小偷，无论他的天赋、嗜好、倾向和能力如何。

Give me a dozen healthy infants, well-formed, and my own specified world to bring them up in and I’ll guarantee to take any one at random and train him to become any type of specialist I might select— doctor, lawyer, artist, merchant-chief and, yes, even beggar-man and thief, regardless of his talents, penchants, tendencies, [and] abilities.

 

实践确实很重要——很多——而且以令人惊讶的方式。但从实践的重要性推断出：天赋在某种程度上是无关紧要的，就好像两者是相互对立的。打个比方，长得最高的树不仅是吸收水分最多的树，而且是吸收水分最多的树。他们也是拥有最好基因的人，能够最有效地通过代谢阳光和光来构建新结构的人。伟大的音乐家就像最高的植物一样，需要最佳的条件：理想的基因和理想的环境。

Practice does indeed matter— a lot— and in surprising ways. But it would be a logical error to infer from the importance of practice that talent is somehow irrelevant, as if the two were in mutual opposition. To use an analogy, the trees that grow the tallest aren’t just the ones that get the most water; they are also the ones with the best genes, the ones that can most efficiently build new structure by metabolizing sun and light. Great musicians, like the tallest plants, need optimal conditions: ideal genes and ideal environments.

 

 

夏令营结束后的一天晚上，我带着夏令营的负责人托拜厄斯出去吃晚饭，在简短地聊了一些关于巴尔的摩难以忍受的炎热天气之后，谈话很快转向了他、我和所有有抱负的音乐家想要了解的中心问题：关系在天赋、实践和成功之间。我们从简单的部分开始：练习是否必要？当然好。只要你高效、有效地练习，专注于克服自己的弱点并学习新事物（而不仅仅是排练你已经知道的东西），练习越多越好。

One night after camp ends, I take the camp’s director, Tobias, out to dinner, and after some brief chitchat about the unbearable Baltimore heat the conversation quickly turns to the central issue he, I, and all aspiring musicians want to understand: the relation between talent, practice, and success. We start with the easy part: Is practice essential? Hell, yes. So long as you practice efficiently and effectively, focusing on fixing your weaknesses and learning new things (not just rehearsing what you already know), the more practice, the better.

托比亚斯认识巴尔的摩的每一位重要音乐家，并且可以立即说出他们作为音乐家的优点和缺点（这位鼓手演奏得很好，并且有知道添加什么声音来补充任何歌曲的天赋，但有时他很匆忙，无意中加快了节奏；那位吉他手有一种天赋，可以将他听到的声音直接转化为手指的动作）。托比亚斯还知道每个人的练习制度是什么样的：每个人在什么年龄开始练习，以及他现在作为一名活跃的职业音乐家在练习上投入了多少时间。他发现技能和实践之间存在很强的关联性，但并不完美。事实上，托比亚斯最大的遗憾之一是，他觉得作为一名职业音乐家，他练习的时间比他喜欢的要少，因为他需要花时间进行自我营销。他说，他的一个好朋友不太擅长自我推销，因此变得不那么富有，赞助协议也更少，但他也是一个更好的音乐家：更少的营销时间留下了更多的练习时间。

Tobias knows every significant musician in Baltimore and can in stantly rattle off both their strengths and weaknesses as musicians (this drummer plays well and has a gift for knowing what sounds to add to complement any song, but sometimes he rushes, inadvertently accelerating the beat; that guitarist has a gift for transforming what he hears directly into actions with his fingers). Tobias also knows what each individual’s practice regime is like: at what age each person started practicing and how much time he invests in practice nowadays as an active professional musician. And he sees a strong— but not perfect— correlation between skill and practice. Indeed one of Tobias’s big regrets is that he feels that as a working musician he has less time for practice than he likes because he needs to spend time on self-marketing. A good friend of his, he says, is less savvy about self-promotion— and as a result less wealthy, with fewer sponsorship deals— but also the better musician: less time marketing leaves more time for practicing.

 

但当谈到“天赋不存在，练习超越所有”这一观点时，托比亚斯不会咬人。他接着说，在私人课程中，他教了成千上万的新手“Wild Thing”的和弦（G、C、D）；他向他们展示了如何握住每个音节的手（这是你的 G），并按节奏和节奏演奏该序列，并要求学生也这样做。几乎每个人一开始都会遇到困难，即使是后来成为伟大吉他手的学生也不例外。但也有少数人以前从未接触过吉他，很快就掌握了。他说，有些学生，你教一个小时，他们就学到了“这么多”，他的双手张开，而“其他人则少得多”，他的双手几乎合拢。

But when it comes to the notion that talent doesn’t exist, practice über alles, Tobias won’t bite. He goes on to say that in private lessons he’s taught literally thousands of novices the chords to “Wild Thing” (G, C, D); he shows them how to hold their hands for each one (this is your G), and plays the sequence in rhythm and tempo, and asks the students to do the same. Almost everyone struggles at first, even any number of students who have gone on to become great guitarists; yet a handful get it instantly, never having touched a guitar before. Some students, he says, you teach for an hour, and they learn “this much,” extending his hands wide, and “others much less,” his hands nearly closed.

 

托比亚斯和我晚上剩下的大部分时间都在讨论一个我称之为理查德的青少年，在托比亚斯看来，他无疑是他见过或见过的最好的学生。比我在训练营见过的最好的孩子还要好？我问。“在一个不同的联盟，”托比亚斯毫不犹豫地说。

Tobias and I spend much of the rest of the evening discussing a teenager I’ll call Richard, who in Tobias’s opinion is far and away the best student he’s ever had or seen. Better than the best kid I’ve seen at the camp? I ask. “In a different league,” says Tobias, without hesitation.

 

事实证明，理查德是先天性失明，而且（我从托比亚斯的描述中推断出）患有自闭症。由于视力障碍，理查德将吉他放在腿上弹奏，他仅靠感觉就能完美地熟悉指板。自闭症可能有所帮助，因为它可以让孩子的注意力集中到许多其他孩子无法比拟的程度。伴随着这种专注而来的是一种非凡的音调和节奏感：作为一种派对技巧，理查德学会了通过发动机发出的声音来识别不同的汽车，他可以如此仔细地记录时间，以至于他可以估计汽车的速度随着轮胎撞击板条的节奏越过一座木桥。

Richard, it turns out, is congenitally blind and also (I infer from Tobias’s description) autistic. Because of his visual impairment, Richard plays with the guitar in his lap, and he knows the fretboard perfectly, by feel alone. The autism likely helped, by allowing for a level of concentration that many other children wouldn’t be able to match; along with that concentration came an extraordinary sense of pitch and rhythm: as a sort of party trick, Richard had learned to identify different cars by the sounds their engines made, and he could keep such careful track of time that he could estimate a car’s velocity over a certain wood bridge by the tempo of the tires thumping against the slats.

 

托拜厄斯讲述了一次事件，他为理查德演奏了一首史蒂夫·瓦伊的歌曲，名为“为了上帝的爱”，这是一首极其复杂的七分钟歌曲，充满了缓慢的旋律线和疯狂的快速撕裂之间的交替。这是迄今为止 Vai 最著名的作品，托比亚斯花了几个月的时间才掌握。理查德？他所要做的就是听一次。他放慢了一些较快的部分，几乎就像他正在将它们翻译成自己的语言一样，但除此之外，他在第一次聆听时几乎完美地再现了整个作品。“我永远无法世界上最伟大的碎纸机之一托拜厄斯说，“无论我练习多少，都要做到这一点。”

Tobias recounted an incident in which he played for Richard a Steve Vai song called “For the Love of God,” a ridiculously complex seven-minute song that is filled with alternations between slow melodic lines and insanely fast shredding. It’s by far Vai’s most famous piece, and it took Tobias months to master. Richard? All he had to do was listen once. He slowed down a few of the faster bits, almost as if he were translating them into his own language, but otherwise reproduced the entire piece on his first listen, almost flawlessly. “I will never be able to do that,” said Tobias, one of the world’s great shredders, “no matter how much I practice.”

 

 

“我是马尔科姆·格拉德威尔的超级粉丝，”一位著名的音乐业内人士告诉我。“我喜欢《眨眼》和《引爆点》。但我认为《离群者》（他关于天赋、实践和成功的书）的表述过于圆滑。这并不是说任何经过十年[练习]的人都会成为披头士乐队。” 也许任何人都可以通过练习成为一名像样的音乐家，但要成为真正伟大的音乐家，需要的不仅仅是努力。对于每个人来说，音乐技能都是必须培养的东西，但是人们学习的速度以及最终能够达到的水平存在差异。披头士乐队自己在工作中几乎学到了所有知识，但他们投入的时间大约是两千个小时，而不是一万个小时，甚至算上洞穴俱乐部和汉堡每天一次和两次的演出。与此同时，成千上万的音乐家投入了一万个小时，却没有成为明星或创作出任何持久的音乐；只注重实践就是不公平地解雇人才。例如，吉米·亨德里克斯和吉米·佩奇；两人都是在青少年时期才开始演奏的（以音乐家的标准来看，年龄相对较晚），但两人在开始演奏后一年左右的时间里就开始了职业演奏。他们显然比大多数同龄人学得更快，并且（不言而喻）最终达到了几乎无人能及的高度。

“I’m a huge fan of Malcolm Gladwell,” one well-known music industry insider told me. “I loved Blink and The Tipping Point. But I think Outliers [his book on talent, practice, and success] is just too glib a formulation. It’s not that anybody with ten years [of practice] is going to be the Beatles.” Maybe anybody could learn to be a decent musician from practice alone, but to be truly great, a musician needs more than hard work. Musical skill is, for everybody, something that must be cultivated, but there are differences in how fast people learn, and perhaps in the levels they can ultimately attain. The Beatles themselves learned almost everything they knew on the job, but they put in more like two thousand hours, not ten thousand, even counting all the once-and twice-a-day shows at the Cavern Club and in Hamburg. Meanwhile, thousands of musicians have put in their ten thousand hours without becoming stars or producing any music of lasting note; to focus solely on practice is to unfairly dismiss talent. Consider, for example, Jimi Hendrix and Jimmy Page; neither started until he was an adolescent (relatively late in life by musicians’ standards), but both were playing professionally within a year or so of when they started. They clearly learned faster than most of their peers and (it goes without saying) eventually attained heights that almost nobody else ever did.

尽管“一切都是练习”的说法很流行，但我们应该持怀疑态度的原因有很多。首先，考虑一下来自有音乐倾向的家庭的数量惊人的顶级音乐家。保罗·麦卡特尼的父亲是一名职业贝斯手（吉姆·麦克爵士乐队的队长），保罗·西蒙的父亲也是职业贝斯手，经常出现在电视上。Ziggy 和 Damian Marley、Dweezil Zappa、Jakob Dylan、Rosanne Cash、Sean 和 Julian 等人列侬都继承了他们的家族传统，杰森·博纳姆 (Jason Bonham) 也是如此，他是已故齐柏林飞艇鼓手约翰·博纳姆 (John Bonham) 的儿子。贝贝尔·吉尔伯托 (Bebel Gilberto)，若昂·吉尔伯托 (João Gilberto) 的女儿；以及明星萨克斯管演奏家约书亚·雷德曼（杜威的儿子）。Fela Kuti（已故）有两个儿子 Femi 和 Seun。还有曾经的 R&B 演奏家约瑟夫·沃尔特·杰克逊 (Joseph Walter Jackson)，他有九个孩子：兰迪、马龙、蒂托、杰梅因、杰基、雷比、珍妮特、拉托亚和已故的迈克尔，其中八个孩子获得了金唱片。其中有温赖特一家——劳登三世、他的妹妹斯隆、已故的妻子凯特·麦加里格尔，以及劳登和凯特的两个孩子鲁弗斯和玛莎——还有罗氏家族（罗氏家族的玛吉、特雷和苏西，以及他们的女儿）。卢登三世 (Loudon III) 与苏兹·罗奇 (Suzzy Roche) 联手，诞生了歌手兼作曲家露西·温赖特·罗奇 (Lucy Wainwright Roche)。我还可以提到才华横溢的马萨利斯兄弟，温顿、布兰福德、德尔菲约和杰森，他们都是专业钢琴家小埃利斯·马萨利斯的后代。古典音乐迷会知道施特劳斯家族（约瑟夫、爱德华、约翰一世和约翰二世） ）、莫扎特和巴赫家族（约翰·塞巴斯蒂安、卡尔·菲利普·伊曼纽尔、约翰·克里斯蒂安），更不用说当代排行榜上名列前茅的安姐妹玛丽亚、露西亚和安吉拉了。尽管一些第二代或第三代音乐家的演奏风格与他们的父母大致相同，但其他人，例如西塔琴演奏家拉维香卡的女儿歌手诺拉·琼斯，听起来一点也不像他们的父母。还有已故歌手杰夫·巴克利，他的声音听起来怪异地像他的亲生父亲蒂姆·巴克利，尽管两人只见过一次。甚至在现代遗传技术出现之前，音乐的遗传成分就已经很清楚了。

As popular as the “it’s all practice” meme is, there are many reasons why we should be skeptical. To begin with, consider the strikingly large number of top musicians who come from musically inclined families. Paul McCartney’s father was a professional bass player (leader of Jim Mac’s Jazz Band), and Paul Simon’s father played bass professionally, too, often appearing on television. Folks like Ziggy and Damian Marley, Dweezil Zappa, Jakob Dylan, Rosanne Cash, and Sean and Julian Lennon all carry on their family traditions, as do Jason Bonham, son of the late Led Zeppelin drummer, John Bonham; Bebel Gilberto, daugh ter of João Gilberto; and the star saxophonist Joshua Redman, son of Dewey. Fela Kuti (deceased) has his sons Femi and Seun. And then there is the onetime R&B player Joseph Walter Jackson, who had nine children: Randy, Marlon, Tito, Jermaine, Jackie, Rebbie, Janet, La Toya, and the late Michael— eight of whom earned gold records. There are the Wainwrights—Loudon III, his sister Sloan, and his late wife, Kate McGarrigle, and Loudon and Kate’s two children, Rufus and Martha—along with the Roche family (Maggie, Terre, and Suzzy, of the Roches, and their brother, David), who joined forces when Loudon III got together with Suzzy Roche, giving rise to the ascending singer-songwriter Lucy Wainwright Roche. I could also mention the absurdly talented Marsalis brothers, Wynton, Branford, Delfeayo, and Jason, all offspring of the professional pianist Ellis Marsalis Jr. Fans of classical music will know about the Strauss family (Josef, Eduard, and Johann I and Johann II), the Mozarts, and the Bach family (Johann Sebastian, Carl Philipp Emanuel, Johann Christian), not to mention the contemporary chart-topping Ahn sisters, Maria, Lucia, and Angella. And although some second-or third-generation musicians play in much the same style as their parents, others, like the singer Norah Jones, daughter of the sitarist Ravi Shankar, sound nothing at all like their parents. And then there’s the late singer Jeff Buckley, who sounds eerily like his biological father, Tim Buckley, even though the two met only once. Even before modern genetic techniques were available, the heritable component of music was already clear.

 

当然，音乐在这方面并没有什么特别之处。在我的成长过程中，我最喜欢的棒球运动员是小卡尔·瑞普肯（Cal Ripken Jr）。他的父亲是一名职业棒球运动员，最终成为巴尔的摩金莺队的经理，他的兄弟比利也很出色，在美国大联盟打了几年内野。 。科比·布莱恩特的父亲是一名职业篮球运动员；小肯·格里菲 (Ken Griffey Jr.) 和巴里·邦兹 (Barry Bonds)，过去几年中最伟大的两位棒球运动员几十年来，都是大联盟球员的儿子。NFL 四分卫佩顿和伊莱·曼宁也是如此，他们都是阿奇·曼宁的儿子，阿奇·曼宁本人也是一名 NFL 四分卫。

Of course there’s nothing special about music in this regard. When I was growing up, my favorite baseball player was Cal Ripken Jr. His father was a professional baseball player who eventually became the manager of the Baltimore Orioles, and his brother Billy was also good enough to play infield for several years in the major leagues.
