Kobe Bryant’s father was a professional basketball player; Ken Griffey Jr. and Barry Bonds, two of the greatest baseball players in the last couple of decades, were sons of major leaguers. Ditto for the NFL quarterbacks Peyton and Eli Manning, both sons of Archie Manning, himself an NFL quarterback.

 

我毫不怀疑小卡尔·瑞普肯在他父亲的膝下学到了很多关于棒球的知识，并且可能拥有大多数孩子没有的机会。但所有这些家庭集群也不可能都是环境的简单产物。相反，对同卵双胞胎的仔细研究一次又一次表明，对于任何人试图测量的几乎任何人类行为指标来说，遗传学都是比生活在同一个家庭中更好的预测因素。有充分的科学理由认为，从体育到国际象棋，从写作到音乐，天赋在各个领域都很重要。认知活动是心灵的产物，而心灵是基因与环境共同作用的产物。否定人才就是忽视所有生物学证据。

I have no doubt that Cal Ripken Jr. learned a lot about baseball at his father’s knee— and probably had opportunities that most kids do not. But it is also unlikely that all these family clusters are a simple product of the environment. Instead, careful studies of identical twins show time and again that— on virtually any indicator of human behavior that anyone has tried to measure— genetics is a better predictor than living in the same family. There is good scientific reason to think that talent matters in a wide variety of domains, from sports to chess to writing to music. Cognitive activities are a product of the mind, and the mind is a product of genes working together with the environment. To dismiss talent is to ignore all evidence from biology.

 

 

尽管如此，这并不意味着人类基因组包含专门针对音乐（或者就此而言，美国职业棒球大联盟）的基因。个体基因构建蛋白质，而不是行为。从基因到蛋白质、神经元再到行为的因果链是巨大且极其复杂的。我们不太可能找到专门用于记忆大调音阶或演奏颤音的基因。但并不需要如此：基因不必如此具体才能产生巨大的影响。例如，FOXP2 基因是人类语言的先决条件，但它的存在并不仅仅是为了这个目的。它还支持肺部的某些功能，事实上，它存在于所有脊椎动物中，从鱼到猴子再到人。新功能通常是由旧基因拼凑而成的。

Still, that doesn’t mean the human genome contains genes specifically tailored to music (or, for that matter, major-league baseball). Individual genes build proteins, not behaviors. The chain of causality from gene to protein to neuron to behavior is vast and immensely complicated; we are not likely to find a gene specifically dedicated to remembering major scales or playing trills. But there doesn’t need to be: genes need not be so specific to have a dramatic impact. The gene FOXP2, for example, is a prerequisite of human language, but it does not exist solely for that purpose; it also underwrites some function in the lungs and in fact can be found in all vertebrates, from fish to monkeys to people. New functions are often cobbled together out of old genes.

我们获得音乐的能力不是来自一组特定于音乐的基因，而是来自对人格、认知和感知等更广泛方面有不同影响的一系列基因。例如，有充分的证据表明基因的个体差异会影响记忆效率（显然，对于学习歌曲至关重要）。其他基因的变异可以调节好奇心（这可以调节人们在学习音乐上投入的努力），还有第三个基因可以调节对绝对音高的敏感度。最近的另一项研究表明，另一个特定基因的变异与人们在音乐创作和即兴创作测试中的得分相关。该基因并非专门致力于音乐——它在人类以及其他物种的社交互动中发挥着重要作用——但基因具有深远影响的事实并不意味着它对音乐不是必不可少的。音乐是一种建立在多种大脑回路基础上的技能，这与这一观点相一致，它也是一种利用许多不同基因的技能——每一种基因都可能以某种方式促进个人的音乐天赋。

Our capacity to acquire music comes not from a set of genes that are specific to music but from a host of genes that have differing effects on broader aspects of personality, cognition, and perception. There is ample evidence, for example, that individual variation in genes affects memory efficiency (vital, obviously, in learning songs). Variation in other genes can modulate curiosity (which can mediate how much effort people put into learning music), and still a third modulates sensitivity to absolute pitch. Another recent study shows that variation in another particular gene correlates with people’s scores on tests of musical composition and improvisation. This gene isn’t uniquely dedicated to music— it plays an important role in social interaction in humans as well as other species— but the fact that a gene has far-reaching consequences doesn’t mean it isn’t essential for music, too. In keeping with the idea that music is a skill that builds on a multiplicity of brain circuits, it is also a skill that draws on many different genes— each of which may contribute in some way or another to an individual’s talents for music.

 

练习——即使是刻意练习，努力克服自己的弱点，而不仅仅是闲逛——本身并不能完全预测音乐成就。其他因素，包括一般智力、听觉能力和工作记忆能力，也显然很重要，即使在统计上控制了练习的效果之后。毫不奇怪，最高水平的表演者很可能是将最伟大的才华与最多的实践相结合的人。（而且，如果你想从技术上讲，实践本身并不完全独立于生物学。我们对经验的反应，甚至我们寻求什么类型的经验，本身在一定程度上是我们与生俱来的基因的功能。这不是先天与后天的对抗；而是先天与后天的共同作用。）

Practice— even deliberate practice, working hard at one’s weaknesses and not just noodling around having fun— can’t by itself fully predict musical achievement. Other factors, including general intelligence, auditory aptitude, and working memory capacity, are also demonstrably critical, even after the effects of practice are statistically controlled for. Not surprisingly, the highest-level performers are likely to be people who combine the greatest talent with the most practice. (And, if you want to be technical about it, practice itself isn’t entirely independent of biology. How we respond to experience, and even what type of experience we seek, are themselves in part functions of the genes we are born with. It’s not nature versus nurture; it’s nature working together with nurture.)

 

事后看来，不祥之兆已经存在：尽管实践很重要，但“人才被高估”的热潮从未真正有意义。一项早期对同卵双胞胎的研究表明，某些遗传因素一定发挥了作用。如果你看看爱立信和其他人的原始研究，很多人最近写了书，你会发现存在大量的个体差异，无法通过一个人投入的时间来预测。例如，许多严肃的小提琴家练习了二十年，却没有达到像其他只演奏了八年的人一样好的水平。当人们仔细研究有关实践和成功的科学文献时，就会发现，平均而言，人们练习的次数越多，他们的表现就越好。这些研究绝不表明实践是唯一重要的因素。与此同时，每个人似乎都忽视了一项关于音乐才能的极其全面的研究，这项研究于 20 世纪 60 年代进行，至今仍是同类研究中最全面的：一项为期三年的纵向研究，几乎涵盖了四所学校的每一个五年级和六年级学生。该团队的领导者埃德温·戈登（Edwin Gordon）发现，学童演奏乐器的能力的近一半变化可以提前三年预测，仅根据天赋（通过音乐能力测试来衡量，该测试检查音调和节奏等因素）图像）。天赋重要，实践重要；两者都不可忽视。如果我投入一万个小时，我可能会成为一名优秀的吉他手，甚至可能是一名非常优秀的吉他手，但这并不意味着我在练习了一半后就能达到亨德里克斯的水平。

In hindsight, the writing was already on the wall: as important as practice is, the “talent is overrated” craze never really made sense. An earlier study with identical twins had suggested that some genetic factors must play a role. And if you look at the original study by Ericsson and others that so many people have recently written books about, you’ll find that there was a substantial amount of individual variation that couldn’t be predicted by how many hours a person put in. Plenty of serious violinists, for example, had practiced for twenty years without becoming as good as others who had played for only eight. When one looks carefully at the science literature on practice and success, all it shows is that on average the more people practice, the better they perform. In no way do such studies show that practice is the only important factor. Meanwhile, everyone seems to have overlooked an incredibly comprehensive study of musical aptitude, conducted in the 1960s and to this day by far the most comprehensive of its kind: a three-year longitudinal study with virtually every fifth and sixth grader in four schools. The team’s leader, Edwin Gordon, discovered that nearly half of the variation in how well schoolchildren played musical instruments could be predicted three years in advance, on the basis of talent alone (as measured by musical aptitude tests that examined factors such as tonal and rhythmic imagery). Talent matters, and practice matters; neither can be ignored. If I put in my ten thousand hours, I might become a good guitarist, maybe even a very good one, but that doesn’t mean I’d be anywhere near as good as Hendrix was after half as much practice.

 

当然，人才的另一面是缺乏人才。在我的吉他演奏冒险大约十八个月后，我发现了音乐对我来说一直如此困难的原因之一：节奏与平衡跟踪前庭系统密切相关。从小我的前庭系统就很糟糕。我永远无法忍受乘坐秋千，讨厌被上下弹跳，坐在汽车后座时经常感到恶心，并选择完全不坐过山车。一项新的研究表明，前庭系统的电刺激可以直接影响节律感知，回想起来，很容易看出为什么节律一直对我构成挑战。可以肯定的是，吉米·亨德里克斯小时候比我更喜欢被弹跳。

The flip side to talent, of course, is the lack of talent. Eighteen months or so into my guitar-playing adventures, I figured out one of the reasons why music had always been such a struggle for me: rhythm turns out to be deeply tied to the balance-tracking vestibular system. Since I was a child, my vestibular system has been lousy. I could never bear to ride on a swing, despised being bounced up and down, routinely became nauseated when sitting in the back of the car, and opted out of roller coasters altogether. A new study showed that electrical stimulation of the vestibular system can directly affect rhythmic perception, and in retrospect it is easy to see why rhythm has always posed a challenge for me. It’s a pretty safe bet that Jimi Hendrix enjoyed being bounced as a baby a lot more than I did.

 

 

同年夏天，我参加了帕特·麦瑟尼（Pat Metheny）的问答环节，他是世界领先的爵士吉他手之一。麦西尼显然是一位才华横溢的人，清晰、清晰，而且常常很有趣；他也毫不怀疑他是业内最勤奋的音乐家之一。他每年演出超过150场，当他不演出时，他几乎一直在创作，试图为新节目和新专辑开发新材料。（奇怪的是，他的大部分作曲都是在钢琴上完成的；Metheny 在音乐会上弹吉他，因为这是他出名的地方，但像我遇到的其他几位吉他手一样，他发现在钢琴上作曲更容易。）

That same summer I sat in on a Q&A session with Pat Metheny, one of the world’s leading jazz guitarists. Metheny, obviously a brilliant man, was clear, lucid, and frequently funny; he also left no doubt that he is one of the hardest-working musicians in the business. He performs over 150 times a year, and when he is not performing, he is almost constantly working on composition, trying to develop new material for new shows and new albums. (Curiously, he does most of his composing on piano; Metheny plays guitar in concert because that’s what he’s known for, but like several other guitarists I met, he finds composition easier on the piano.)

有一次，一位观众站起来宣称麦西尼是熟能生巧论的完美例子。但提问者似乎错过了梅西尼刚才告诉我们的一半内容。梅瑟尼不仅努力练习，而且还努力练习。他来自一个令人难以置信的音乐家庭。他的兄弟、父亲和祖父都吹小号，而且演奏得非常好。他的祖父与约翰·菲利普·苏萨（最著名的军事进行曲作曲家）一起演奏，他的兄弟十岁时就在堪萨斯城管弦乐团演奏。帕特有一段时间是家里的懒鬼，嫉妒他哥哥受到的关注。帕特直到十二岁时才开始学习吉他（部分原因是为了反抗他的铜管乐器家庭）。但是——这就是关键点——他并没有花费近一万个小时就可以熟练掌握它；三年之内，年轻的帕特已经足够优秀，可以在堪萨斯城最好的爵士俱乐部演出。

At one point, a member of the audience got up and declared that Metheny was a perfect example of the practice-makes-perfect thesis. But it was almost as if the questioner had missed half of what Metheny had just told us. Metheny didn’t just practice hard; he came from an incredibly musical family. His brother, father, and grandfather all played trumpet, and did so extremely well. His grandfather played with John Philip Sousa (the most famous composer of military marches), and his brother was playing with the Kansas City Orchestra by the time he was ten. Pat was, for a little while, the slacker in the family, jealous of the attention his brother was getting. It was only at age twelve (in part as a rebellion against his brass-playing family) that Pat picked up the guitar. But— and here’s the key point— it didn’t take him anywhere near ten thousand hours to get good at it; within three years, young Pat was already good enough to get gigs at the best jazz clubs in Kansas City.

 

后来，我有机会与帕特进行了深入交谈，他解释说他将音乐天赋视为一种网格。他说，有些音乐家的手指就像在看不见的指板上移动一样，他们拥有灵巧的身体，而另一些音乐家则拥有异常敏感的耳朵。（亨德里克斯可能两者兼而有之。）麦西尼认为自己的身体灵活性有限，更多地是通过残酷的练习而不是自然本能而发展起来的，但他也知道自己从很小的时候起就是一位熟练的倾听者。小时候，他在音乐能力测试中获得了满分，从那以后，他以其他音乐家无法企及的方式磨练了自己的耳朵。麦西尼对事物有着惊人的敏感度其他音乐家风格的细节，不仅仅是谁好谁坏的粗略水平，而是他们最擅长的音乐元素，以及任何特定音乐家如何融入前辈的万神殿。麦西尼可以将他听到的每一个音符分解成一节迷你历史课。例如，关于温顿·马萨利斯的问题引发了一篇关于温顿的呼吸技巧如何借鉴迈尔斯·戴维斯和一位曾经与马萨利斯的父亲一起演奏的不太知名的小号手的专题论文。与梅瑟尼交谈就像与一位棒球球探交谈，他知道每个年轻天才投球动作的确切机制，哪个小联盟球员以有趣的方式抬起肩膀，以及哪些球员过早地投球。显然，麦西尼生来就有金耳朵。

Later, I got a chance to talk with Pat in great depth, and he explained that he saw musical talent as a sort of grid. Some musicians, he said, moving his fingers as if on an invisible fretboard, are blessed with physical dexterity, others with exceptionally sensitive ears. (Hendrix probably had both.) Metheny saw his own physical dexterity as limited, developed more by brute practice than natural instinct, but he also knew that he himself had been an adept listener since his earliest days. As a child, he’d gotten a perfect score on a musical aptitude test, and in the time since, he’d honed his ears in ways that few other musicians could ever hope to match. Metheny has an astonishing sensitivity to the details of other musicians’ styles, not just at the coarse level of who was good or bad, but exactly which elements of music they were most proficient at, and exactly how any given musician fit into the pantheon of predecessors. Metheny could decompose every note he heard into a mini history lesson. A question about Wynton Marsalis, for instance, led to a disquisition on how Wynton’s breathing techniques drew on both Miles Davis and a lesser-known trumpeter who had once played with Marsalis’s father. Talking to Metheny was like talking to a baseball scout who knew the exact mechanics of every young phenom’s pitching motion, which minor leaguer lifted his shoulder in a funny way, and which ones released a pitch a moment too soon. Metheny, it was clear, was born with golden ears.

 

 

当然，弹吉他只是成为音乐家的一个要素；另一个写歌。我能想到的关于纯粹音乐天赋迅速爆发的最令人惊奇的例证之一就是鲍勃·迪伦作为词曲作者的崛起的故事。在迪伦接受训练的民间传统中，创作原创曲子根本就不是一件容易的事。直到二十岁左右，他才开始认真写歌。迪伦的第一张专辑主要由翻唱组成。十三首歌曲中，只有两首是他自己创作的。但当迪伦开始认真写歌的那一刻，一股洪流就被释放了。三年之内，他写出了《风中飘》（在彼得、保罗和玛丽手中立即大受欢迎）、《玛吉的农场》、《地下乡愁布鲁斯》和《他们的时代》 A-改变。” 在另外两本书中，他写了《积极地第四​​街》、《没关系，妈妈（我只是在流血）》、《现在一切都结束了，淡蓝色》和《像滚石一样》。只有少数词曲作者，无论他们投入了多少年的时间，能够与迪伦最初几年的所作所为相媲美。

Of course, playing guitar is only one element of becoming a musician; writing songs another. One of the most amazing illustrations of the rapid eruption of sheer musical talent that I can think of is the story of Bob Dylan’s emergence as a songwriter. In the folk tradition, in which Dylan was trained, writing original tunes simply wasn’t done; and it wasn’t until he was about twenty that he started seriously writing songs. Dylan’s first album consisted mainly of covers; out of thirteen songs, only two were his own compositions. But the minute Dylan started writing songs in earnest, a torrent was unleashed. Within three years, he’d written “Blowin’ in the Wind” (which became an immediate hit in the hands of Peter, Paul, and Mary), “Maggie’s Farm,” “Subterranean Homesick Blues,” and “The Times They Are A-Changin’.” Within another two he’d written “Positively 4th Street,” “It’s Alright, Ma (I’m Only Bleeding),” “It’s All Over Now, Baby Blue,” and “Like a Rolling Stone.” Only a handful of songwriters, no matter how many decades they’ve put in, have ever matched what Dylan did in those first few years.

 

进入凹槽

INTO THE GROOVE

 

音乐是如何演变的

How Music Really Evolved

 

周三和周四的训练营就这样模糊地过去了：无休止的排练、很多错误、很多焦虑。但渐渐地，情况会好起来。星期五，DayJams 的最后一个早上，我们有最后一次排练的机会。

Wednesday and Thursday at the camp pass by in a blur: endless rehearsals, many mistakes, much anxiety. But little by little, things get better. On Friday, the final morning of DayJams, we get a last chance to rehearse.

经过似乎数小时的声音检查后，我们的第一次运行非常不稳定。幸运的是，我们乐队的教练迈克尔很快就推断出我们问题的根源。这并不是说乐队忘记了我们所学到的一切；而是说他们忘记了我们所学到的一切。问题是我们的鼓手坐在巨大的有机玻璃屏幕后面（以免我们耳聋），听不到乐队其他人的声音。原则上，鼓手应该从“舞台监听器”获得反馈——一个扬声器，其位置可以将乐队其他成员的一些声音发送回有机玻璃屏幕后面。但鼓手的监听器被关闭了，莱利之前只上过台一次，他甚至没有意识到他应该能够听到我们的声音；他只是在没有显示器的情况下继续前进，快乐地扮演自己的角色，却没有意识到我们其他人不同步。迈克尔解决了这个问题后，我们第二次演奏，现在乐队听起来就像一支真正的乐队。我们进行了第三次拍摄，营地工作人员将其录制成 MP3。我们的第一次现场录音！

Our first run-through— after what seems like hours of sound checks— is quite shaky. Fortunately, our band’s instructor, Michael, quickly de duces the source of our problems. It’s not that the band has forgotten everything we’ve learned; it’s that our drummer, who sits behind a giant Plexiglas screen (to spare us from deafness), can’t hear the rest of the band. In principle, a drummer is supposed to get feedback from a “stage monitor”—a speaker positioned so that it sends a bit of the sound from the rest of the band back behind the Plexiglas screen. But the drummer’s monitor was switched off, and Riley, who’s only been onstage once before, doesn’t even realize he’s supposed to be able to hear us; he just soldiers on without a monitor, happily playing his part without realizing that the rest of us are out of sync. After Michael sorts that out, we play through a second time, and now the band sounds like a real band. We do a third take, and the camp staff gets it down on MP3. Our first live recording!

 

之后，迈克尔决定做一些不同的事情，试图让我们放松——而当他这样做的那一刻，事情就发生了。他没有强迫我们再次排练我们的歌曲，而是转向键盘（我们只见过他弹吉他，甚至没有意识到他知道如何弹键盘）并告诉我们所有人开始即兴演奏。 G. Riley 的调子定下了他一直在练习的节拍，而我们其他人则演奏我们喜欢的任何东西，只要它在时间上并且在那个调上。我们一起创作真正的音乐。然后迈克尔转向鼓，要求我们在两个和弦之间交替演奏 F 和 G。从数七的挑战中解脱出来，从必须达到完美的责任中解脱出来，我感到解放了，显然整个乐队也有同样的感觉。作为一名听众，我从来没有特别喜欢像 Grateful Dead 和 Phish 这样的“即兴演奏”乐队，但对于表演者来说，一场协调良好的即兴演奏，其中每个人都组成一个部分，并结合在一起形成一个自发生成的整体，这绝对是一个完美的选择。比欣快。

Afterward, Michael decides to do something different, to try to keep us loose— and the minute he does, something clicks. Rather than forcing us to rehearse our song yet again, he moves over to the keyboard (we’ve only ever seen him play guitar, and didn’t even realize he knew how to play keyboard) and tells us all to start jamming in the key of G. Riley lays down a beat he’s been working on, and the rest of us play whatever we like, as long as it’s in time and in that key. And together we produce real music. Michael then moves over to drums and asks us to jam in F and G, alternating between the two chords. Freed from the challenges of counting sevens, and freed from the responsibility of having to achieve perfection, I feel liberated, and it’s obvious that the whole band feels the same way. As a listener, I never especially liked “jam” bands like the Grateful Dead and Phish, but for a performer, a well-coordinated jam, in which each person makes up a part that fits together into a spontaneously generated whole, is nothing less than euphoric.

 

但真正打动人心的不是音乐，而是音乐。这是我对音乐起源的理解。一瞬间，我突然以一种全新的方式理解了音乐的起源。

But what really clicks is not the music; it’s my understanding of the origins of music. In a single moment, I suddenly understand the origins of music in a whole new way.

 

 

音乐进化的主导理论——由达尔文提出，由杰弗里·米勒发展，并得到丹尼尔·莱维汀的认可——是音乐完全与性选择有关：男人演奏音乐是因为女孩喜欢音乐，而男人喜欢女孩。演奏音乐对吉米·亨德里克斯的基因有好处，而且，故事是这样的，我们对音乐的热爱演变成了让原始人上床的一种方式。米勒告诉我们，亨德里克斯

The dominant theory of music evolution— introduced by Darwin, developed by Geoffrey Miller, and endorsed by Daniel Levitin— is that music is all about sexual selection: guys play music because girls like music, and guys like girls. Playing music was good for Jimi Hendrix’s genes, and, so the story goes, our love of music evolved as a way of getting primeval men laid. Hendrix, Miller tells us, had

与数百名追星族发生性关系，与至少两名女性保持平行的长期关系，并在美国、德国和瑞典生下了至少三个孩子。在节育之前的祖先条件下，他会生育更多的孩子。

sexual liaisons with hundreds of groupies, maintained parallel long-term relationships with at least two women, and fathered at least three children in the United States, Germany, and Sweden. Under ancestral conditions before birth control, he would have fathered many more.

 

米克·贾格尔 (Mick Jagger) 有七个孩子，吉米·佩奇 (Jimmy Page) 有五个孩子。正如达尔文所写，“音符和节奏……最初是为了吸引异性而获得的”？米勒提供了大量证据，例如，报告称，在 6000 张近期爵士乐、摇滚和古典专辑的样本中，90% 是由男性制作的。

Mick Jagger has had seven children, Jimmy Page five. Were “musical notes and rhythm … first acquired … for the sake of charming the opposite sex,” as Darwin wrote? Miller piles on the evidence, reporting, for example, that in a sample of six thousand recent jazz, rock, and classical albums, 90 percent were produced by men.

 

但我并不相信，不仅仅是因为贝多芬似乎没有孩子。尽管性选择理论听起来很聪明，但它有很多严重的缺陷。

But I’m not convinced, and not just because Beethoven appears to have been childless. Although the sexual selection theory sounds very clever, it has a slew of serious flaws.

 

首先，在由性选择塑造的生理学的大多数方面，我们通常看到显着的二态性，也就是说男性和女性之间存在明显的差异。孔雀有羽毛，而雌性孔雀则没有；雄性鸣禽唱歌，雌性鸣禽一般不唱歌。在人类历史的某个时刻，人们可能会以同样的方式构想人类音乐——仅是男性的产物，而米勒的录音数据最初似乎与此一致。但事后看来，这种明显的二态性很可能更多地与机会和社会学有关，而不是人类生物学的必然事实。我们现在确信，女性可以成为与男性一样有能力的音乐家。例如，考虑一下近几十年来古典世界发生的事情。在盲选出现之前（有抱负的音乐家在屏幕后演奏），大多数管弦乐团中男性的数量远远多于女性；现在大多数交响曲都接近平价。我家乡的交响乐团最近成为首批聘请女指挥（马林·阿尔索普）的主要交响乐团之一，而且肯定会有更多的乐团效仿。词曲作者名人堂里充满了女性，比如卡罗尔·金（《你有一个朋友》）、玛丽莲·伯格曼（《往日情怀》）、贝蒂·科姆登（《雨中曲》）、多莉·帕顿（《雨中曲》） “我将永远爱你”）和乔尼·米切尔（“现在双方”）。在当代摇滚世界中，托里·阿莫斯 (Tori Amos)、西尼德·奥康纳 (Sinead O'Connor) 和艾丽西亚·凯斯 (Alicia Keys) 等表演者与男性同行一样才华横溢、富有原创性。玛丽亚·凯莉 (Mariah Carey) 获得第一名的次数比埃尔维斯 (Elvis) 还要多。与此同时，艾莉森·克劳斯 (Alison Krauss)、玛丽·J·布莱姬 (Mary J. Blige)、琳达·佩里 (Linda Perry) 和米西·艾略特 (Missy Elliott) 等女性最终帮助打破了这一局面。音乐制作界的玻璃天花板。没有理由相信人类在听音乐或创作音乐方面存在真正的性别二态性。

First, in most aspects of physiology that are shaped by sexual selection, we generally see a significant dimorphism, which is to say noticeable variation between males and females. Peacocks have plumage, their female counterparts don’t; male songbirds sing, females generally don’t. At one point in human history, one might have conceived of human music in the same way— as the product of males alone, and Miller’s data on recordings initially seem consistent with that. But in hindsight, that apparent dimorphism is most likely more about opportunity and sociology than a necessary fact about human biology. We now know with certainty that women can be just as capable musicians as men. Consider, for example, what has happened in the classical world in recent decades. Before the advent of blind auditions (in which aspiring musicians play behind a screen), men drastically outnumbered women in most orchestras; now most symphonies are near parity. My hometown orchestra recently became one of the first major symphonies to hire a female conductor (Marin Alsop), and many more are sure to follow. The Songwriters Hall of Fame is filled with women, like Carole King (“You’ve Got a Friend”), Marilyn Bergman (“The Way We Were”), Betty Comden (“Singin’ in the Rain”), Dolly Parton (“I Will Always Love You”), and Joni Mitchell (“Both Sides Now”). In the contemporary rock world, performers like Tori Amos, Sinead O’Connor, and Alicia Keys are every bit as talented and original as their male counterparts; Mariah Carey has had more No. 1 hits than Elvis. Meanwhile, women like Alison Krauss, Mary J. Blige, Linda Perry, and Missy Elliott helped finally break the glass ceiling in the world of music production. There’s no reason to believe that in humans there is a bona fide sexual dimorphism in either the listening to or the creation of music.

 

其次，吉米·亨德里克斯理论将一位才华横溢的吉他手的强大形象与大多数音乐家的现实混为一谈。有些音乐家可能确实这样做是为了吸引女孩，但例如，只有大约一半的大学学位音乐家能够以音乐事业为生；少数人以演奏交响乐为生，但大多数人以教授音乐课为生，或者干脆离开这个领域。即使在茱莉亚学院毕业后，四分之一的毕业生也无法以音乐家的身份维持收支平衡。大多数音乐家追求音乐是因为他们对音乐充满热情，而不是因为音乐使他们变得富有或受欢迎。“我在死亡金属乐队中主唱”可能是一种挑衅，但“我教四年级学生长号”可能不是。正如一位音乐历史学家对我所说，即使在莫扎特和海顿时代，音乐家也没有受到特别好的尊重，他们通常穿着制服，像仆人一样，不像现代摇滚皇室那样生活。亨德里克斯理论只有在事实证明，平均而言，那些在音乐专业知识上投入大量时间的人比那些在其他方面花费时间的人拥有更多的后代时才有效，而且据我所知，没有数据支持这一猜想。

Second, the Jimi Hendrix theory conflates the powerful image of a single exceptionally talented guitarist with the realities of most musicians. Some musicians probably do indeed do it to get girls, but only about half of college-degreed musicians, for instance, are even able to make a living in a musical career; a handful make a living soloing with symphonies, but most make a living giving music lessons or leave the field altogether. Even after Juilliard, one out of four graduates can’t make ends meet as a musician. Most musicians pursue music because they are passionate about music, not because it makes them rich or popular. “I sing lead vocals in a death metal band” may be a come-on, but “I teach trombone to fourth graders” probably isn’t. Even in the time of Mozart and Haydn, as one historian of music put it to me, musicians were not particularly well regarded, typically dressing in livery, like servants, not living like modern-day rock royalty. The Hendrix theory only works if it turns out that on average people who invest the many hours required for musical expertise have more offspring than people who spend that time in other ways, and I know of no data to support that conjecture.

 

第三，亨德里克斯理论的前提是对现在的看法与我们进化的过去几乎没有相似之处。亨德里克斯生活在一个音乐家有可能赚到数百万美元并成为国际知名的时代，但任何对音乐有贡献的基因早在广播电台或唱片交易出现之前就已经进化了。宫廷小丑也创作音乐，但他们的地位很难与当代摇滚明星相比。在 1760 年代的莫扎特和 19 世纪早期的帕格尼尼崛起之前，很少有表演者能够在国际上享有盛誉，而且大笔资金只是在录音时代才到来（而现在，在下载时代又再次消失了）。

Third, the Hendrix theory is premised on a view of the present that hardly resembles the past in which we evolved. Hendrix lived in a time in which it was possible for musicians to make millions of dollars and become internationally famous, but whatever genes contribute to music evolved long before there were radio stations or record deals. Court jesters made music, too, but their status was hardly that of contemporary rock stars. Before Mozart in the 1760s and Paganini’s rise in the early nineteenth century, few performers became internationally renowned, and the big money arrived only in the age of recording (and is disappearing again, now, in the download era).

 

第四，亨德里克斯理论听起来好像存在一个特定的大脑中的音乐模块在某种程度上是进化的目标，但正如我们之前看到的，大脑中没有明显的“音乐中心”，而是神经组织的联盟，几乎所有这些都早于音乐 - 这表明亨德里克斯理论是在寻找错误的采石场。

Fourth, the Hendrix theory makes it sound as if there were a specific music module in the brain that was somehow targeted by evolution, but as we saw earlier, there is no distinct “music center” in the brain, but rather a coalition of neural tissue, virtually all of which predates music— suggesting that the Hendrix theory is after the wrong quarry.

 

最后，亨德里克斯理论——以及我遇到过的几乎所有其他音乐进化理论——在音乐上是幼稚的，因为它听起来好像所有音乐都是平等的。播放任何老歌，找朋友，故事结束。要是事情这么容易该多好啊！任何曾经制作过唱片的人都意识到，我们人类是善变的。没有一种流派能让所有人满意，也没有一首歌能让所有人满意。创作好的音乐是一项艰苦的工作，而且往往是不可预测的。亨德里克斯的理论听起来好像我们对音乐的热爱是不加区别的，就好像我们听众是耍蛇人桶里无助的生物。事实上，我们对音乐的热爱更加个性化和独特。有些音符的安排让我们感动；有些则让我们感动。其他人则不然。

Finally, the Hendrix theory— as well as just about every other theory of music evolution I have ever encountered— is musically naive, because it makes it sound as if all music were equal. Play any old song, get mate, end of story. Would that it were so easy! As anyone who has ever produced a record realizes, we humans are a fickle lot. No one genre pleases everybody, and no one song pleases everybody. Making good music is hard work, and often unpredictable. The Hendrix theory makes it sound as if our love for music were undiscriminating, as if we listeners were helpless creatures in a snake charmer’s bucket. In reality, our love for music is far more individual and idiosyncratic. Some arrangements of notes move us; others don’t.

 

另一个常见的说法是音乐之所以进化是因为它能促进社会联系。没有人会争辩说音乐不能将人们聚集在一起，但这些理论至少在两个不同的方面错过了要点：他们没有说明为什么随着时间的推移组织起来的声音模式应该在联系中发挥任何特殊的作用，而且他们错过了事实上，许多其他不属于我们适应性遗产的事物——比如相对现代的啤酒发明——也能产生社会凝聚力。

Another common claim is that music evolved because it leads to social bonding. No one would argue that music can’t bring people together, but such theories miss the point in at least two different ways: they don’t say why patterns of sound organized over time should play any special role in bonding, and they miss the fact that many other things that weren’t part of our adaptive heritage— like the relatively modern invention of drinking beer— also induce social cohesion.

 

 

所有艺术领域都出现了完全相同的问题。我们为什么热爱诗歌？雕塑？绘画？四十八分钟的犯罪剧？对于每一种艺术，都有一个进化理论。但它们都没有特别有说服力。对进化中几乎所有事物的标准解释是，我们从事某种行为是因为它符合我们基因的利益。但大多数艺术，无论我们是观众还是参与者，都不符合我们自私基因的利益。

Precisely parallel issues arise in all the arts. Why do we love poetry? Sculpture? Painting? Forty-eight-minute crime dramas? For every art, there’s an evolutionary theory. But none of them is particularly persuasive. The standard explanation for just about everything in evolution is that we engage in a certain behavior because it’s in the interest of our genes. But most art, whether we are spectators or participants, isn’t in the interest of our selfish genes.

对于毕加索或达利来说，数学可能是正确的。支撑他们创造性工作的基因使他们成为传奇，随着名气的增加，他们也有机会接触性伴侣。因此，按照进化的标准——生殖适应性——来判断，他们是赢家。但对于每一位毕加索或亨德里克斯来说，都有成百上千的无名英雄、诗人和画家，他们在默默无闻中辛勤劳作，也许在死后变得出名（像梵高），但为时已晚，无法传播他们的基因，或者永远得不到任何认可根本不。对于绝大多数人来说，从严格的基因角度来看，对艺术的投资是薄弱的赌注。花在艺术上的时间——尤其是作为观众，但即使作为参与者——也远离了收集食物、建造住所、发展新技能或生孩子的时间。人们沉迷于艺术并不是因为它对他们的基因有好处；而是因为它对他们的基因有好处。尽管他们有基因，但他们还是这样做。

For a Picasso or a Dalí, the math may work out. The genes that underwrote their creative work made them legends, and with fame came considerable access to sexual partners; hence, as judged by the yardstick of evolution—reproductive fitness— they were winners. But for every Picasso or Hendrix there are hundreds or thousands of unsung heroes, poets, and painters who toil in obscurity, perhaps becoming famous after death (like van Gogh), when it is too late to spread their genes, or never getting any recognition at all. For the vast majority of people, investments in the arts are, from a strictly genetic perspective, weak bets. Time spent on art— especially as a spectator, but even as a participant— is time away from gathering food, building shelter, developing new skills, or making babies. People don’t indulge in the arts because it’s good for their genes; they do it despite their genes.

 

 

用伟大哲学家韦伦·詹宁斯的话来说，科学家们一直在错误的地方寻找创造力的解释。大脑并没有进化出一种特殊用途的音乐本能或艺术本能，就像它没有进化出一种渴望小型便携式电子产品的特殊本能一样。仅仅因为我们喜欢某样东西并不意味着我们对它产生了特定的品味。

To paraphrase the great philosopher Waylon Jennings, scientists have been looking for explanations of creativity in all the wrong places. The brain has not evolved a special-purpose music instinct or art instinct, any more than it evolved a special instinct for craving small portable electronic gadgets. Just because we like something doesn’t mean we evolved a specific taste for it.

相反，考虑音乐和艺术演变的科学家经常犯下我所认为的“历史现实的错误”：人们倾向于自动假设现在正确的事情永远都是正确的；我们看到一座山，并认为它永远在那里。当代音乐和现代艺术对当代人的大脑来说非常有吸引力，但第一个问题是我们祖先的艺术作品是否同样具有吸引力。我们可能会因为观看洞穴壁画而感到高兴，但这并不意味着普通的洞穴壁画会引起人类大脑的注意程度与《阿凡达》中计算机生成的 3D 渲染图一样。如今，捕捉我们想象力的艺术媒体远远超过了我们祖先所能拥有的任何媒体。

Instead, scientists who have considered the evolution of music and art have often made what I think of as “the error of the historical present”: people tend to automatically assume that what’s true now was always true; we see a mountain and think it’s been there forever. Contemporary music and modern arts are incredibly compelling to contemporary brains, but the first question is whether the artistic productions of our ancestors would be equally compelling. We may get a kick out of seeing cave paintings, but that doesn’t mean your average cave painting would capture a human brain’s attention to the same extent as the 3-D computer-generated renderings in Avatar. The artistic media that capture our imagination now far exceed anything available to our ancestors.

 

这是因为多年来，艺术家，尤其是商业艺术家，在理解人类运转的动力方面变得越来越精明。以米老鼠的形象为例。正如已故的斯蒂芬·杰伊·古尔德曾经指出的那样，几十年来，迪士尼每隔几年就会缓慢但坚定地重新调整米奇的形象，其方式最初可能会被忽视。然而变化的方向始终是一样的，朝着越来越可爱的方向发展：不那么成熟，不那么具有威胁性，更加幼稚，更加可爱。

And that’s because over the years, artists, especially commercial artists, have gotten savvier and savvier at understanding what makes human beings tick. Take, for instance, the image of Mickey Mouse. As the late Stephen Jay Gould once pointed out, over the decades Disney has slowly but surely retooled Mickey’s image every few years, in ways that might initially escape the eye. Yet the direction of change has always been the same, toward cuter and cuter: less adult, less threatening, more juvenile, more adorable.

 

我的观点是，音乐就像米奇：根本不是进化的直接产物，而是艺术家进化他们的技艺以以特定方式刺激大脑的产物。音乐、艺术和 iPhone 的传播并不是因为我们天生就有时髦舞蹈节拍或电子玩具的电路，而是因为音乐家、艺术家和发明家往往在对人类心灵进行逆向工程方面具有非凡的天赋。

My contention is that music is like Mickey: not the direct product of evolution at all, but the product of artists evolving their craft in order to tickle the brain in particular ways. Music, art, and iPhones spread not because we have innate circuitry for funky dance beats or electronic toys but because musicians, artists, and inventors are often uncommonly talented at reverse-engineering the human psyche.

 

 

那天早上我和乐队成员一起即兴演奏时，我所感受到的正是许多音乐家一直在努力追求的东西：不是性选择或任何线性的东西，而是一种快乐的沉浸状态，其中一个人失去了所有时间流逝的感觉——心理学家 Mihály Csíkszentmihályi（发音为“chick-SENT-me-high-ee”）称之为“心流”的奇妙状态。

What clicked the morning I was jamming with my bandmates was exactly the thing that so many of those musicians have been striving for: not sexual selection or anything quite so linear, but a state of joyous immersion, wherein one loses all sense of time passing— the wondrous state that the psychologist Mihály Csíkszentmihályi (pronounced “ chick-SENT-me-high-ee”) has called “flow.”

根据 Csíkszentmihályi 的说法，心流是一种全身心投入一项具有挑战性的活动的状态，需要技巧、行动与意识的融合。其特点是对手头任务的专注感和控制感、自我意识的丧失以及时间观念的改变。

Flow, according to Csíkszentmihályi, is a state of being fully engaged in a challenging activity requiring skill, a merging of action and awareness. It is characterized by a sense of concentration on the task at hand and a sense of control, a loss of self-consciousness, and an altered sense of time.

 

这几乎完美地定义了即兴演奏，而且我相信，它也为了解真正的音乐史前史提供了重要线索。音乐并不是一种特殊的、天生的模块化心理机制；它是一种特殊的、与生俱来的模块化心理机制。这是一项在过去五万年里不断完善和发展的技术，在很大程度上是为了最大限度地提高流量。

This defines jamming almost perfectly, and it also, I believe, gives a big clue into the true prehistory of music. Music isn’t a special inborn modular mental mechanism; it’s a technology, refined and developed over the last fifty thousand years, in no small part to maximize flow.

 

每一代新一代的艺术家都渴望用新的方式来拓宽调色板，从而寻求更好的方式来让听众和表演者都着迷，处于一种流动的状态。音乐的技术基础在物理乐器的演变中最为明显。例如，钢琴比它的前身大键琴取得了巨大进步。这两种乐器都使用键盘来跨越很大的音调范围，但羽管键琴没有动态，也就是说每个音符要么大声演奏，要么根本不演奏。钢琴由巴托洛梅奥·克里斯托福里 (Bartolomeo Cristofori) 于 1700 年左右发明，基本上为每个音符添加了音量控制，用可以大声或轻柔地敲击特定音符的软垫音锤系统取代了一组通常由鸟羽毛制成的拨片或拨片。 ，或介于两者之间。一旦克里斯托福里的技术得到完善，钢琴（piano forte的缩写，来自意大利语“安静”和“大声”的术语）几乎完全取代了羽管键琴，就像一个新物种取代了旧物种一样，因为钢琴的动态变化更大。钢琴为音乐家提供了一个全新的表达世界。新的演奏技术也得到了发展，音乐家们学会了利用改变音符响度的可能性，后来又发现了增加左手演奏部分复杂性的方法；正如心理学家安德烈亚斯·莱曼（Andreas Lehmann）和安德斯·埃里克森（Anders Ericsson）所说，随着新技术的开发和传播，钢琴演奏者的熟练程度随着历史的推移而稳步提高。

Each new generation of artists craves new ways to broaden the palette, and hence better ways of keeping both listeners and performers entranced, in a state of flow. The technological underpinnings of music are most immediately obvious in the evolution of physical instruments. The piano, for instance, represented a huge advance over its immediate predecessor, the harpsichord. Both instruments used keyboards to span a vast pitch range, but the harpsichord had no dynamics, which is to say that each note could be played either loudly or not at all. The piano, invented by Bartolomeo Cristofori in about 1700, basically added a volume control for each individual note, replacing a set of picks or plectra, often made of bird quills, with a system of padded hammers that could strike a given note loudly, softly, or somewhere in between. Once Cristofori’s technology became refined, the piano (short for piano forte, from the Italian terms for “quiet” and “loud”) almost entirely replaced the harpsichord, much like a new species displacing an old one, because the more variable dynamics of the piano offered the musician a whole new world of expression. New playing techniques developed as well, as musicians learned to exploit the possibilities in varying the loudness of notes and later discovered ways of adding complexity to the parts they played with their left hand; as the psychologists Andreas Lehmann and Anders Ericsson have argued, the level of sophistication of piano players has steadily increased over historical time as new techniques have been developed and disseminated.

 

合成器和电吉他（特别是与增加吉他固有声音复杂性的踏板结合使用）同样增加了音乐家的选择范围，麦克风为歌手打开了同样引人注目的新世界，让低语像尖叫一样清晰可闻。毫不奇怪，所有这些创新发展后迅速传播；它们在音乐上相当于新物种，开辟了新的领域，并且在某些方面比许多前辈更能适应环境。多轨录音的出现也是如此：一旦秘密曝光，每个音乐家都想尝试分层和配音等技术所带来的新可能性。

Synthesizers and electric guitars (especially in combination with pedals that add complexity to the guitar’s intrinsic sound) similarly multiplied the range of options available to musicians, and the microphone opened equally compelling new worlds for vocalists, allowing whispers to be as audible as screams. It is no wonder that all these innovations spread rapidly once developed; they are the musical equivalent of new species, which open new niches and are in some ways better adapted to the environment than many of their predecessors. Ditto for the advent of multitrack recording: once the cat was out of the bag, every musician wanted to experiment with the new possibilities that techniques like layering and overdubs opened up.

 

 

不太明显但同样重要的是，一些最具创新性的音乐技术是智力而非物理技术。直到大约公元900 年，几乎所有音乐都是单音的，也就是说，它仅由单一旋律组成，可能由多个歌手齐声演唱，就像格里高利圣歌一样；像对位法（用多个声音唱不同的台词）这样的想法还没有发明：没有理发店四重奏，也没有精致的西蒙和加芬克尔和声。大约在公元900 年，或者可能更早一些，一些音乐家或一群音乐家开始意识到，两个歌手不必总是同时唱同一个音符才能听起来很好。一位音乐家可以唱 C 音符，另一位音乐家可以唱 G（形成纯五度音程），两者一起听起来会很不错。这一观察结果催生了一种称为“奥尔加农”的音乐形式，其中两位不同的音乐家演唱独立（但相关）的旋律线。尽管如此，作曲家还是倾向于只坚持一小部分可能的音程（纯五度和纯四度）；这样的和声对于现代人来说常常听起来生硬。大三度和小三度的概念还没有被发明——直到十二世纪左右，作曲家们开始尝试包含三种不同的声音，包括大三度和小三度，这些音程有助于定义大三度和小三度和弦，分别。那时，也只有到那时，我们才可能将其视为现代西方和声的发明。

Something that is less obvious— but no less important— is that some of the most innovative technologies of music have been intellectual rather than physical. Until roughly A. D. 900, virtually all music was monophonic, which is to say it consisted of only a single melody, perhaps sung in unison by multiple singers, as in Gregorian chant; ideas like counterpoint (with multiple voices singing distinct lines) had not yet been invented: no barbershop quartets, and no delicate Simon and Garfunkel harmonies. Around A. D. 900, or perhaps a bit earlier, some musician or set of musicians came to realize that two singers didn’t have to always sing the same note at the same time to sound good together. One musician could sing the note C, another could sing G (forming the interval known as the perfect fifth), and the two would sound good together. This observation gave rise to a form of music known as organum, in which two different musicians sing separate (but related) melodic lines. Even then, though, composers tended to stick to only a small subset of possible musical intervals (the perfect fifth and the perfect fourth); such harmonies often sound stilted to modern ears. The notion of a major or minor chord had not yet been invented— that wasn’t until around the twelfth century, when composers began to toy with including three distinct voices, including major thirds and minor thirds, the intervals that help define major and minor chords, respectively. Then, and only then, was something we might recognize as modern Western harmony invented.

最终，这些作曲家最初为歌手创作的内容被映射到键盘和其他乐器上。作曲家和键盘演奏者制定了严格的规则，规定哪些音符（和弦）组合在一起听起来不错，哪些听起来不和谐，他们还制定了哪些规则，哪些和弦在顺序组合中听起来不错，哪些则不然，从而产生了技术比如三部和声和理发店四重奏；事实上，所有现代音乐都依赖于对和声及其伴随单位、和弦进行、功能的发现。这种知识（一种技术创新）一旦开发出来，就会迅速传播到全世界。

Eventually, what these composers initially worked out for singers was mapped onto keyboards and other musical instruments. Composers and keyboard players figured out strict rules for which sets of notes (chords) sounded good together and which sounded dissonant, and they figured out rules for which sets of chords sounded good in sequential combination and which ones didn’t, giving rise to techniques like three-part harmony and barbershop quartets; virtually all modern music depends on this discovery of how harmony and its attendant units, chord progressions, function. Once that knowledge, a kind of technological innovation, was developed, it spread rapidly throughout the world.

 

当稳定的打击乐节拍的概念从非洲传入西方时，这种青睐得到了回报。事实上，现在你在广播中听到的每一首歌都结合了这两种音乐技巧——和声和稳定的打击乐——这两种技巧本质上都必须被发明出来。

The favor was returned when the notion of a steady percussive beat was imported from Africa into the West. Virtually every song you hear on the radio nowadays combines these two musical techniques— harmony and steady percussion— both of which in essence had to be invented.

 

再举一个智力而非物理技术的例子，考虑一下被称为十二小节布鲁斯的音乐形式，这是一组以特定顺序演奏的特定和弦，在和声概念出现之前，它实际上是不可能被发明的。发展了。十二小节结构出现在无数布鲁斯歌曲中，更广泛地存在于现代音乐中，从 Clash 的“Should I Stay or Should I Go?” 甲壳虫乐队的“我们为什么不在路上做呢？” 以及查克·贝里 (Chuck Berry) 和埃里克·克莱普顿 (Eric Clapton) 的数十首歌曲。

To take another example of a technology that is more intellectual than physical, consider the musical form known as the twelve-bar blues, a particular set of chords played in a particular order, which literally couldn’t have been invented before the idea of harmony was developed. The twelve-bar structure is found in countless blues songs and more broadly throughout modern music, ranging from the Clash’s “Should I Stay or Should I Go?” to the Beatles’ “Why Don’t We Do It in the Road?” and dozens of tunes by Chuck Berry and Eric Clapton.

 

它的流行部分只是历史的偶然：任何广为人知的惯例都对音乐家有用，因为惯例为以前可能没有一起演奏过的音乐家群体提供了直接的共同点。但十二小节布鲁斯的流行很大程度上与这种形式本身与人类心理的契合有关。十二小节布鲁斯——二十世纪初的一项发明——看起来几乎是完美设计的最大限度地结合两种心理奖励：熟悉性和新颖性（我将在稍后进一步讨论）。*

Part of its popularity is merely historical accident: any convention that is widely known can be useful for musicians, because convention gives immediate common ground for groups of musicians who may not have previously played together. But a considerable part of the popularity of the twelve-bar blues has to do with the way in which the form itself fits in with human psychology. The twelve-bar blues— an invention of the early twentieth century— seems almost perfectly designed to maximize the combination of two psychological rewards: familiarity and novelty (which I will discuss further later).*

 

这些现代创新都不是绝对必要的。简单朴实的旋律仍然可以引人注目。但总体而言，缺乏和谐的早期音乐形式——比如格里高利圣歌——对现代观察者来说往往感觉平淡，就像发现透视之前的绘画一样：值得一看，但不是大多数现代人审美体验的核心。例如，圣歌很少会出现大量的播放列表轮换，部分原因是它们没有利用和声的流动诱导特性。结果，我们更快地习惯了它们，因为它们的新奇而短暂地享受它们，但很快就厌倦了它们。（最后一首以格里高利圣歌为特色的流行歌曲——Enigma 1990 年的圣歌“Mea Culpa”——并没有停留在未经修饰的圣歌上，只为听众提供一致的声音。相反，它通过各种现代制作技术增强了潜在的单音圣歌，从近距离录音、性感的法语配音到鼓机、音效和电吉他独奏。）

None of these modern innovations are strictly necessary; a simple unadorned melody can still be compelling. But on the whole, earlier forms of music that lack harmony— like Gregorian chants— often feel flat to modern observers, like paintings from before the discovery of perspective: worth a look, but not central to most modern people’s aesthetic experience. Chants, for instance, rarely get heavy playlist rotation, in part because they don’t exploit the flow-inducing properties of harmony. As a result we habituate faster, enjoying them briefly because of their novelty but soon growing tired of them. (The last pop tune to feature Gregorian chant— Enigma’s 1990 anthem “Mea Culpa”—didn’t rest on chant unadorned, offering its listeners nothing but voices in unison. Instead, it enhanced the underlying monophonic chant with all sorts of modern production techniques, ranging from close-miked, sexy French-language overdubs to drum machines, sound effects, and electric guitar solos.)

 

多年来，音乐在艺术意义上可能并没有进步——这是有争议的，也是品味问题。但音乐的工艺和技术储备不断改进，就像任何其他技术一样，这为音乐家提供了越来越多的选择，这意味着更容易让听众保持心流状态。

Music may not be improving over the ages in an artistic sense— that’s up for debate and a matter of taste. But the craft and the reservoir of techniques constantly improves, in music as in any other technology, and that gives musicians more and more options, which means it is easier to keep listeners in a state of flow.

 

不可避免的是，一些新的音乐发明最终会成为时尚，技术只会在舞台上停留很短一段时间。但其他人——比如西方和声、打击乐节拍、麦克风、钢琴和电吉他——在发明后迅速传播并流传下来，这是有充分理由的：它们非常适合人类的心理。主张音乐是一种进化本能的人经常忘记的是，我们现在看到的音乐——这对我们来说似乎很有吸引力——至少是文化选择的产物，也是自然选择的产物。新的工具和想法催生了新的音乐技巧，而那些更好的（或者至少更有效地吸引听众的注意力）会被保留下来。

Inevitably, some new musical inventions turn out to be fads, techniques that remain on the scene for but a brief period of time. But others— like Western harmony, percussive beats, the microphone, the piano, and the electric guitar— spread rapidly and stick around when invented, and for good reason: they fit well with the psychology of the human mind. What advocates of music as an evolved instinct often forget is that the music we see now— and that seems so compelling to us— is at least as much a production of cultural selection as it is of natural selection. New tools and ideas lead to new musical techniques, and the ones that are better (or at least more effective in holding listeners’ attention) stick around.

 

现代制作人可以使用所有的技术——从智力（如和声和常规打击乐）到技术（如均衡器、限制器和压缩器，有助于澄清和放大每种乐器的独特声音）到从后勤（如节拍音轨，让音乐家在时间上保持紧密而愉快的节奏）到声音（如合成声音、失真踏板以及回声、延迟和混响等技术）——我们情不自禁地进入了最佳状态。

With all of the techniques at the disposal of the modern producer— ranging from the intellectual (like harmony and regular percussion) to the technical (like equalizers, limiters, and compressors, which help clarify and amplify the distinctive sounds of each instrument) to the logistical (like click tracks, which keep musicians tightly and pleasurably in time) to the sonic (like synthesized sounds, distortion pedals, and techniques like echo, delay, and reverb)—we can’t help but get into the groove.

 

*人们可能会对常见的歌曲结构做出类似的评论，例如aaba形式（格什温的“I Got Rhythm”、杰里·李·刘易斯的“Great Balls of Fire”、海滩男孩的“Surfer Girl”以及经过修改的甲壳虫乐队的“Surfer Girl”）。 “我想握住你的手”）或一种较旧的形式，通常是马尼拉麻，称为回旋曲，其中主题不断回归。（莫扎特的《费加罗的婚礼》第一幕的结尾就是一个例子。）没有一种结构形式可以锁定所有音乐，部分原因是我们喜欢从一首歌曲到下一首歌曲的变化本身。但诗句和副歌的交替，无论是陌生的还是熟悉的，都能让听众沉浸在游戏中，并让多巴胺——可能是心流神经基础的关键角色——在我们的大脑中流动。

* One might make similar remarks about common song structures like the aaba form (Gershwin’s “I Got Rhythm,” Jerry Lee Lewis’s “Great Balls of Fire,” the Beach Boys’ “Surfer Girl,” and, in modified form, the Beatles’ “I Want to Hold Your Hand”) or an older form, typically abaca, known as the rondo, in which a main theme keeps returning. (The end of the first act of Mozart’s The Marriage of Figaro is one example.) No one structural form has a lock on all music, in part because we like variation itself, from one song to the next. But alternations of verse and chorus, unfamiliar and familiar, keep listeners in the game and keep dopamine—likely a key player in the neural basis of flow—coursing through our brains.

 

在舞台上

ONSTAGE

 

面对我的恐惧

Face-to-Face with My Fears

 

不知不觉间，就到了最后集会的时间，训练营的负责人托比亚斯 (Tobias) 教我们一些现场表演的规则。使用 Fender 吉他的人应该将拾音器设置为 2 或 4 级，这样就不会产生太多嗡嗡声；不要使用你的打击棒，否则你可能会跑调。欢迎您在舞台上跳来跳去，但前提是这不会扰乱您的演奏。（我打算一动不动地站着，以免失去时机。） *

Before we know it, it’s time for Final Assembly, wherein the camp’s director, Tobias, teaches us some rules of live performance. People with Fender guitars should set their pickups to notch two or four so there won’t be lots of buzz; don’t use your whammy bars, or you might go out of tune. You’re welcome to jump around onstage, but only if it won’t mess up your playing. (I planned to stand rock still, lest I lose my timing.)*

当瑞安告诉我“我等待的时间越长，我就越紧张”时，我确切地知道他的意思。

When Ryan tells me “The longer I wait, the nervouser I get,” I know exactly what he means.

 

 

对于一些音乐家来说，怯场可以定义整个职业生涯。斯蒂利·丹饰演的唐纳德·费根就患有此病（他的母亲也是如此）表明可能存在遗传联系），芭芭拉·史翠珊 (Barbra Streisand)、卡莉·西蒙 (Carly Simon) 和 XTC 的安迪·帕特里奇 (Andy Partridge) 也都曾与怯场作过斗争。像《音乐的内在游戏》这样的整本书都讲述了如何应对它，以便音乐家在舞台上和在舞台下练习时都能演奏得一样好。我从十几岁起就知道，当我还是一个相对认真的业余杂耍演员时，我永远无法在人群面前表演出最好的戏法；即使只有几个朋友的一小群观众也会让人伤脑筋。

For some musicians, stage fright can come to define an entire career. Steely Dan’s Donald Fagen suffered from it famously (as did his mother, suggesting a possible genetic connection), and Barbra Streisand, Carly Simon, and XTC’s Andy Partridge have all battled stage fright as well. Whole books, such as The Inner Game of Music, have been written about how to cope with it, so that musicians can play as well onstage as they can offstage in practice. I knew from my teenage years, when I was a relatively serious amateur juggler, that I could never do my best tricks in front of a crowd; even a tiny audience of a few friends can be nerve-racking.

最小的孩子通常不会感到恐惧。我的一个朋友在三岁半的时候举行了她的第一次独奏会，尽管她搞砸了这首曲子，但她一直微笑着。当她坐下来时，她的母亲问她为什么微笑，而对于两人来说，很明显，表演并没有达到应有的效果。我朋友的反应是？“我的老师告诉我，‘如果你只是微笑，没有人会知道。’ 直到后来，到了青春期，恐惧和羞辱的感觉才开始出现。

The youngest children often feel no fear. One friend of mine had her first recital at the age of three and a half and smiled the whole time, even as she bungled the piece. When she sat down, her mother asked why she was smiling, when it was pretty obvious to both that the performance was not as good as it could have been. My friend’s response? “My teacher told me, ‘If you just smile, no one will know.’ ” It’s only later, toward adolescence, that the sense of fear and mortification sets in.

 

怯场（或表演焦虑）源于生理和心理等不同因素的综合作用。一方面，为表演做准备往往会提高心率；另一方面，为表演做准备往往会提高心率。另一方面，不同的人以不同的方式解释心率。不太容易怯场的表演者似乎会利用心率升高来刺激他们获得更好的表现。对于更容易怯场的表演者来说，兴奋的生理状态有时会被解释为恐惧（“如果我在这场独奏会上失败了，我的职业生涯就毁了”）。

Stage fright (or performance anxiety) stems from a mix of different factors, physiological and psychological. On the one hand, getting ready for a performance tends to elevate heart rate; on the other hand, different people interpret that heart rate in different ways. Performers who are less prone to stage fright seem to use that elevated heart rate as a spur to better performance. In performers who are more prone to stage fright, the physiological state of arousal sometimes gets interpreted as fear (“If I blow this recital, my career is ruined”).

 

如今，职业音乐家服用被称为β受体阻滞剂的心脏药物并不罕见，这种药物最初是为了对抗高血压而设计的。这些药物可以减轻生理症状，而心理症状可能会随着觉醒的降低而减轻。最好的长期解决方案可能是练习：一个人上台的次数越多，一切就越可预测，一个人的恐惧看起来就越不现实。

Nowadays, it’s not uncommon for professional musicians to take cardiac medications known as beta-blockers, which were originally designed to combat high blood pressure. These drugs reduce the physiological symptoms, and the psychological symptoms may diminish along with the decreased arousal. The best long-term solution is likely practice: the more often one is onstage, the more predictable everything is, and the less one’s fears seem realistic.

 

具体来说，怯场是一个问题，不仅仅是因为它令人不愉快但因为它会抑制性能。当身体紧张时，保持流畅的节奏变得更加困难，也更难回忆起记忆中的音乐片段。就我自己而言，没有什么真正的危险——我不可能毁掉作为一名职业音乐家的一生——但二十分钟的等待肯定足以让我尝到专业人士所面临的挑战。

Concretely, stage fright is a problem not just because it is unpleasant but because it can inhibit performance. As the body tenses, it becomes more difficult to maintain fluid rhythms and harder to recall memorized sections of music. In my own case, nothing was really at stake— no chance that I was about to ruin a lifetime as a professional musician— but twenty minutes of waiting in the wings was certainly enough to give me a taste of what professionals are up against.

 

 

终于，观众就座，声音检查完成，托比亚斯走上舞台，介绍自己是营地主管，并对营地本身做了一些仁慈的简短评论。

At long last, the audience was seated, sound checks were complete, and Tobias took the stage, introducing himself as camp director and making some mercifully brief remarks about the camp itself.

接下来他宣布了我们的乐队“Rush Hour”，然后帷幕拉开了。

Next he announced our band, Rush Hour, and the curtains opened.

 

作为我们乐队中唯一有在人群面前演讲经验的人，我有权利和责任介绍乐队。“女士们先生们，”我用我最好的 PT Barnum 声音喊道，“如果你们检查一下手表，就会发现现在是下午 5:00，这意味着……高峰时间到了！”

As the only person in our band with experience speaking in front of crowds, I earned the right and responsibility of introducing the band. “Ladies and gentlemen,” I shouted, in my best P. T. Barnum voice, “if you check your watches, you will see that it is 5:00 p.m., and that means it’s time for…RUSH HOUR!”

 

这就是格里尔的暗示。下线！他演奏了他优雅的古典乐曲的几个小节，然后（一切都按照计划）莱利突然以八个响亮的鼓点敲响了。九拍来了，莱利的铙钹准时响起，我们其他人也加入了进来。唱了两遍主歌，然后其他人都退出了，轮到我演奏我的小低音填充了。还有两节经文，然后是我们险恶的副歌。接下来是格里尔的钢琴独奏（仅由莱利用轻柔的铙钹伴奏）；然后瑞安加入了一首诗。在下一节的开头，莎拉和我一起回来。主歌又重复了两次，副歌又重复了两次，还有莱利的鼓独奏，莱利最后高举鼓棒，标志着我们的大结束：每个人都敲响了一个响亮的 G 和弦，我们就完成了！

And that was Greer’s cue. We’re off! He plays a few measures of his elegant classical piece, and then (all according to plan) Riley bursts in with eight loud beats on his drums. Beat nine comes, Riley’s cymbal is right on time, and the rest of us join in. Twice through the verses, and then everybody else drops out, and it’s my turn to play my little bass fill. Two more verses, and then it’s on to our menacing chorus. Greer’s piano solo (accompanied only by Riley on softly hit cymbals) is next; then Ryan joins in for a verse. At the start of the next verse Sarah and I return together. Twice more through the verse, twice more through the chorus, and a drum solo for Riley, who winds up and holds his sticks high to signal our big finish: everyone hits a loud G chord, and we’re done!

 

一切都按计划进行，我们得到了雷鸣般的掌声。我们现在是一支真正的摇滚乐队了！

Everything has gone according to plan, and we get a thundering round of applause. We’re a real rock band now!

 

 

音乐会结束后，我找到我的乐队成员，并摆好姿势拍乐队照片。在出去的路上，我感到一种特别的喜悦和悲伤的混合体，这是我大学毕业以来从未有过的感觉。我经常是最先离开社交活动的人之一，但今天我是最后一个。当我向我所认识的最伟大的十一岁孩子们告别时，我让自己的父母久等了。

When the concert ends, I hunt out my bandmates, and we pose for band pictures. On the way out I feel a particular mixture of elation and sadness that I haven’t felt since college graduation. I’m often among the first people to leave social events, but today I’m the last. I keep my own parents waiting as I say good-bye to the greatest bunch of eleven-year-olds I’ve ever known.

*事后看来，保持静止可能是一个错误。许多音乐家最好随着音乐的节奏用脚敲击，而不是站着不动。但敲击本身需要练习，特别是对于那些先天节奏受损的人来说，就像我一样，在当时，敲击似乎又是一件需要注意的事情，对已经超负荷的大脑提出了另一项要求。

* In hindsight, keeping still may have been a mistake. Many musicians are better off tapping a foot in rhythm with the music, rather than standing still. But tapping itself requires practice, especially for those who are congenitally rhythmically impaired, as I am, and at the time, tapping just seemed like one more thing to have to keep track of, another demand on an already overloaded brain.

 

世界上最糟糕的歌曲

THE WORST SONG IN THE WORLD

 

是什么造就了一首好歌？

What Makes a Good Song?

 

在经历了一周的营地以及我们自己原创作品的创作、练习和表演之后，我开始思考歌曲的本质。我还没准备好完全自己写一篇文章，但我开始研究一些最好的例子——以及一些最糟糕的例子。

Having survived the week at camp and the creation, practice, and performance of our own original piece, I was starting to think about the nature of songs. I wasn’t ready to write a piece entirely on my own, but I began to study some of the best examples— and some of the worst.

制作一首歌需要什么？为什么有些人比其他人工作得更好？我一直是一个被动的倾听者，只知道自己喜欢什么，却不知道为什么；在我的旅程一年后，我想加深我的理解。我开始向我的音乐老师提问，并开始阅读有关快乐心理学和美学的文章。

What goes into making a song? And why do some work better than others? I’d always been a kind of passive listener, knowing what I liked without knowing why; a year into my journey I wanted to go deeper in my understanding. I had started asking my music teachers questions and started reading articles on the psychology of pleasure and aesthetics.

 

大约在同一时间，微软推出了一款新的计算机程序 Songsmith，据称可以帮助任何人写自己的歌曲。Songsmith 背后的想法很简单：用户唱歌，程序创建背景音轨。很快，瞧。流行音乐已制作完成。

At around the same time, Microsoft introduced a new computer program, Songsmith, that would allegedly help anyone write his or her own songs. The idea behind Songsmith was simple: user sings, program creates backing track. Presto, voilà. Pop tunes are made.

 

或者至少该程序应该是这样工作的。

Or at least that’s how the program was supposed to work.

 

事实上，《宋史密斯》彻底失败了，从《娱乐周刊》到《纽约时报》，所有人都将其撕成碎片。YouTube 上充斥着歌曲史密斯制造的灾难：重拍的《Roxanne》斯汀 (Sting) 的歌声、钢鼓和平淡、有点夏威夷风格的节奏（超过 571,000 次观看，并且还在增加）；奥兹·奥斯本 (Ozzy Osbourne) 的“疯狂火车”被重做为一首真正难以听的波尔卡舞曲（观看次数超过 150,000 次）。

In reality, Songsmith turned out to be a total flop, ripped to shreds by everyone from Entertainment Weekly to the New York Times. YouTube is crawling with Songsmith-created disasters: “Roxanne” remade with Sting’s vocals, steel drums, and an insipid, vaguely Hawaiian-sounding backbeat (over 571,000 views and counting); Ozzy Osbourne’s “Crazy Train” redone as a truly unlistenable polka (over 150,000 views).

 

从技术角度来看，Songsmith 的歌曲非常有意义。复杂的算法得出用户声音的音高轮廓，并在一组和弦和节奏之上分层，这些和弦和节奏在音乐上与用户的输入一致。根据任何一年级音乐理论学生都会认识到的原则，选择和弦和低音线与旋律和谐。按理说，Songsmith 的歌应该很好听。但他们经常不这样做，我很快就开始想知道为什么。一首好歌的要素是什么？Songsmith 缺少什么？

From a technical standpoint, Songsmith’s songs make perfect sense. A sophisticated algorithm derives the pitch contour of a user’s vocals and layers on top a set of chords and rhythms that are musically consistent with the user’s inputs. Chords and bass lines are chosen to be harmonious with the melody, according to principles that any first-year music theory student would recognize. By rights, Songsmith’s songs ought to sound good. But they frequently don’t, and I soon began to wonder why. What makes a good song, and what was Songsmith missing?

 

 

公平地说，Songsmith 的作品听起来并不是真正糟糕，只是糟糕得令人遗憾。

In fairness, Songsmith’s compositions don’t sound truly awful, just regrettably bad.

本章的标题（世界上最糟糕的歌曲）并非来自 Songsmith，而是来自观念艺术家 Vitaly Komar 和 Alexander Melamid 以及小提琴家兼作曲家 Dave Soldier（碰巧是他在哥伦比亚大学担任神经科学家）。科马尔和梅拉米德在 20 世纪 90 年代中期受到了大量关注，当时他们利用调查数据创作了他们毫不掩饰地描述为“最想要的”和“最不想要的”画作。例如，美国“最受欢迎”的画作包括一幅点缀着野生动物的秋季风景、一个享受户外的家庭、乔治·华盛顿和蓝色（几乎在每个接受调查的国家中都是反复出现的主题）。

The title of this chapter (The Worst Song in the World) comes not from Songsmith but from an allusion to an art project of a slightly different title by the conceptual artists Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid and the violinist and composer Dave Soldier (who happens to spend his days as a neuroscientist at Columbia University). Komar and Melamid had received a ton of attention in the mid-1990s when they used survey data to create what they described, tongue lodged firmly in cheek, as the “most wanted” and “least wanted” paintings. America’s “most wanted” painting, for instance, consisted of an autumnal landscape dotted with wild animals, a family enjoying the outdoors, George Washington, and the color blue (a recurrent theme in virtually every country surveyed).

 

采用类似的调查方法，士兵开始寻找“最不受欢迎的音乐”，并根据一系列调查问卷确定这将是一首最不受欢迎的音乐。

Following a similar survey method, Soldier set out to find “the most unwanted music,” determining based on a series of questionnaires that it would be a composition that is

 

长度超过25分钟，在喧闹和安静的部分、快节奏和慢节奏之间剧烈转变，并以极高和极低的音色为特色，每种二分法都以突然的过渡呈现。最不受欢迎的管弦乐队被确定为大型乐团，其中包括手风琴和风笛（与最不受欢迎的乐器并列 13%）、班卓琴、长笛、大号、竖琴、风琴、合成器（唯一出现在最不受欢迎的乐器中的乐器）。想要的和最不需要的合奏）。歌剧女高音说唱并演唱无调性音乐、广告歌曲、政治口号和“电梯”音乐，儿童合唱团则演唱歌曲和节日歌曲。最不受欢迎的歌词主题是牛仔和假期，最不受欢迎的聆听环境是不自觉地接触广告和电梯音乐。

over 25 minutes long, veers wildly between loud and quiet sections, between fast and slow tempos, and features timbres of extremely high and low pitch, with each dichotomy presented in abrupt transition. The most unwanted orchestra was determined to be large, and features the accordion and bagpipe (which tie at 13% as the most unwanted instrument), banjo, flute, tuba, harp, organ, synthesizer (the only instrument that appears in both the most wanted and most unwanted ensembles). An operatic soprano raps and sings atonal music, advertising jingles, political slogans, and “elevator” music, and a children’s choir sings jingles and holiday songs. The most unwanted subjects for lyrics are cowboys and holidays, and the most unwanted listening circumstances are involuntary exposure to commercials and elevator music.

 

然后，他开始招募一支由专业音乐家组成的精干团队，与他们一起创作了一首令人痛苦但又奇怪地可以忍受的作品，正是按照这些思路（你可以在他的网站上听到并在 NPR 上播出）。

He then proceeded to recruit a crack team of professional musicians with whom he composed an excruciating— yet strangely bearable— piece along exactly these lines (which you can hear on his Web site and which aired on NPR).

 

与此同时，“最想要的”属性包括“中等持续时间（大约 5 分钟）的音乐、适中的音高范围、适中的节奏以及适中到响亮的音量”——我们对流行音乐的一切期望。士兵的舌头可能紧紧地贴在脸颊上，但他的结果——以及它们与流行音乐特征的奇特相似——确实提出了一个问题：我们的审美体验是否可以用科学定律来捕捉。

The “most wanted” properties, meanwhile, consisted of “music of moderate duration (approximately 5 minutes), moderate pitch range, moderate tempo, and moderate to loud volume”— everything we have come to expect from pop music. Soldier’s tongue may have been lodged firmly in cheek, but his results—and their curious resemblance to the hallmarks of pop music—do raise a question about whether our aesthetic experience can be captured with scientific laws.

 

 

在剧本创作领域，也许没有一本书比罗伯特·麦基的《故事》更臭名昭著了，这本书表明，剧本创作艺术的很大一部分可以简化为一组简单的原则。我认识的作家要么喜欢它，要么讨厌它：我的一位剧作家朋友很喜欢《故事》，另一个则全心全意地鄙视它。电影制片人和编剧查理·考夫曼（《成为约翰·马尔科维奇》、《 美丽心灵的永恒阳光》）发现整个概念非常荒谬，他将麦基和他的原则作为一个 114 分钟笑话的笑柄（也称为电影改编）。

In the field of screenwriting, perhaps no book is more notorious than Robert McKee’s Story, which suggests that a surprisingly large part of the art of screenwriting can be reduced to a simple set of principles. Writers I know either love it or hate it: one playwright friend of mine adores Story, another despises it with all her heart. The filmmaker and screenwriter Charlie Kaufman (Being John Malkovich, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind) found the whole notion so ridiculous he made McKee and his principles the butt of a 114-minute joke (otherwise known as the film Adaptation).

麦基认为，情节应该分为“节拍”、命运逆转、假结局、煽动事件等手段。麦基在他的书籍和参加人数众多的研讨会中讨论了十几种这样的技术，每一种技术都是为了小心地保持观众的兴趣而设计的。

According to McKee, plots should be divided into devices known as “beats,” reversals of fortune, fake endings, inciting incidents, and so forth. In his books and well-attended seminars, McKee discusses a dozen or so such techniques, each designed to carefully maintain the viewer’s interest.

 

也许他的所有技巧都不是必要的（例如，《Koyaanisqatsi》就违反了所有技巧），而且它们当然还不够（麦基自己的剧本中只有一个被拍成电影，而且是用于电视，而不是大银幕））。他们不会告诉任何人如何想出各种巧妙的情节曲折，使《第六感》、《记忆碎片》和《非常嫌疑犯》等电影如此令人难忘。正如麦基本人所指出的，他的策略更多地面向商业而不是艺术。但他的言论有一定道理。

Perhaps none of his techniques are necessary (Koyaanisqatsi, for example, violates them all), and they certainly aren’t sufficient (only one of McKee’s own screenplays was ever made into a movie, and that one was for TV, not the big screen). And they aren’t going to tell anybody how to come up with the sorts of clever plot twists that make movies like The Sixth Sense, Memento, and The Usual Suspects so memorable. And as McKee himself would point out, his strategies are geared more toward commerce than art. Yet his remarks have an element of truth.

 

音乐也能被类似地解构吗？真的有原则可以解释我们喜欢什么音乐、不喜欢什么音乐吗？

Can music be similarly deconstructed? Are there really principles that can explain what music we like and don’t like?

 

 

关于这个问题首先要说的是，我们喜欢的东西始于给定歌曲的固有属性（例如它的旋律、节奏和歌词），但许多其他因素也很重要。

The first thing to say about this question is that what we like starts with inherent properties of a given song (such as its melodies, its rhythms, and its lyrics), but many other factors matter, too.

最大的因素之一是单纯的曝光。在其他条件相同的情况下，仅仅听一首歌就会让我们更喜欢它，这说明了一种更广泛的现象，即“喜欢熟悉的感觉”。记录这一现象的首批研究之一让受试者非常简短地查看一组人造汉字——每个汉字仅两秒钟——然后要求受试者判断一组更大的表意文字的美感，其中一些是他们见过的简而言之，其中其他的是新的。短暂的接触被证明是有效的。受试者以前见过的角色系统地获得了更高的评分。从那时起，数百个实验复制并扩展了这些原始结果，几乎使用了你能想象到的各种刺激，包括音乐。在 20 世纪 50 年代，人们常常拿着装满现金的纸袋付钱给 DJ，让他们播放他们的歌曲。这可能是非法的，但几乎可以肯定，这笔钱花得值。歌曲只有被人们听到才能成为热门歌曲，而且听得越多，他们就越喜欢它们。

One of the biggest factors is mere exposure. Simply listening to a song has a tendency, other things being equal, to make us like it more, an illustration of a broader phenomenon known as “liking for familiarity.” One of the first studies to document this phenomenon had subjects look very briefly at a set of faux Chinese characters— just two seconds each— and later asked the subjects to judge the beauty of a larger set of ideographs, some of which they’d seen briefly, others of which were new. Brief encounters proved potent; characters that subjects had seen before systematically got higher ratings. Since then, hundreds of experiments have replicated and extended these original results, with virtually every kind of stimulus you could imagine, including music. In the 1950s, guys with paper bags full of cash used to pay off DJs to play their songs; it might have been illegal, but it was almost certainly money well spent. Songs can become hits only if people hear them, and the more they hear them, the more they tend to like them.

 

另一个重要因素可能是我们第一次听到一首歌的时间。我们中的许多人往往更喜欢青少年时期听到的音乐。正如罗伯特·萨波尔斯基 (Robert Sapolsky) 所说，“没有多少 17 岁的年轻人会收听安德鲁斯姐妹 (Andrews Sisters) 节目，也没有多少《愤怒的机器》(Rage Against the Machine) 在退休社区上演，而最大的粉丝却是不间断地观看 60 分钟詹姆斯·泰勒 (James Taylor) 开始穿休闲牛仔裤。”

Another important factor may be when we first hear a song. Many of us tend to like the music we hear as teenagers more than anything else. As Robert Sapolsky put it, “Not a whole lot of seventeen-year-olds are tuning in to the Andrews Sisters, not a lot of Rage Against the Machine is being played in retirement communities, and the biggest fans of sixty non-stop minutes of James Taylor are starting to wear relaxed jeans.”

 

叛逆是一个关键因素吗？经济学家泰勒·考恩（Tyler Cowen）曾经打趣道：“旧音乐的问题很简单。已经有人喜欢了。” 但在写这本书的过程中，我见过不少 12 岁的孩子随着齐柏林飞艇乐队的音乐摇摆起来，如今，在布鲁斯·斯普林斯汀和 U2 等巨星的演出中看到全家人一起观看的情况并不少见。巴赫和贝多芬的音乐流行了数百年（并且在世界某些地区仍然流行，特别是在摇滚乐作为替代品不太容易获得以及音乐教育仍然很发达的地方）。事实上，今天的孩子经常听与父母不同的音乐，这可能更多地源于替代品的增多——现在有比以往任何时候都多的音乐——而且一个简单的事实是，孩子们通常比成年人有更多的时间来听新的音乐。今天的孩子（尤其是我在摇滚训练营遇到的那种）经常吸收他们父母时代最好的歌曲和当下最热门的歌曲。并不是孩子叛逆，而是孩子叛逆。它们是海绵：它是 U2 和本月风味，而不是非此即彼。

Is rebellion a key factor? The economist Tyler Cowen once quipped, “The problem with old music is simple. Somebody else already liked it.” But in the course of writing this book, I have seen any number of twelve-year-olds rocking out to tunes by Led Zeppelin, and nowadays it’s not uncommon to see whole families at the shows of megastars like Bruce Springsteen and U2. Music by Bach and Beethoven stayed in vogue for hundreds of years (and remains popular in some parts of the world, especially where rock and roll is less accessible as an alternative and where music education is still robust). The fact that today’s children so often listen to different music than their parents do may stem more from a blossoming of alternatives— more music is available now than ever before—and the simple fact that kids typically have a lot more time than adults to listen to new music. Today’s kids (especially the kind I met at rock-and-roll camp) frequently soak up both the best songs from their parents’ era and whatever is hot at the moment. It’s not that kids are rebellious; it’s that they are sponges: it’s U2 and the Flavor of the Month, not either-or.

 

在更广泛的范围内，背景起着至关重要的作用。一首特定的歌曲可能非常适合电影，但单独听时却听起来过于甜美。没有古典音乐背景的人可能很难理解是什么让一首奏鸣曲比下一首奏鸣曲更好，而有些专辑，比如卢·里德的《金属机器音乐》，在发行时就受到了鄙视，但几十年后却被誉为具有巨大影响力。作者贾森·哈特利 (Jason Hartley) 反复指出，有些艺术家对于听众来说过于“先进”。他的“核心前提是，像鲍勃·迪伦 (Bob Dylan) 和卢·里德 (Lou Reed) 这样的艺术家并没有在 20 世纪 80 年代突然开始臭名昭著，而是超越了大多数人的理解范围。如果像里德这样的艺术家在 20 世纪 60 年代领先于他的时代，理论上来说，他在 1980 年代仍然领先于他的时代，当时大多数人错误地认为他“失去了它”。无论人们如何评价 80 年代中期的 Dylan 和 Reed，毫无疑问，一首歌的商业成功潜力在一定程度上与潜在听众的音乐背景有关。

On a broader scale, context plays a critical role. A given song may fit perfectly into a movie yet sound overly sweet when heard on its own. Someone with no background in classical music may have trouble grasping what makes one sonata better than the next, and some albums, like Lou Reed’s Metal Machine Music, are despised at their release and only decades later hailed as enormously influential. The author Jason Hartley has riffed about how some artists are too “advanced” for their listeners; his “central premise is that artists like Bob Dylan and Lou Reed didn’t suddenly start to stink in the 1980s but had, instead, advanced beyond most people’s comprehension. If an artist like Reed was ahead of his time in the 1960s, the theory goes, it is plausible that he was still ahead of his time in the 1980s, when most people mistakenly thought he ‘lost it.’ ” Whatever one makes of mid-80s Dylan and Reed, there’s little doubt that a song’s potential for commercial success relates in part to the musical background of potential listeners.

 

 

更复杂的是，没有一首歌可以满足所有听众，因为不同类型的人听音乐的原因不同。最近的一项研究发现，个人音乐品味之间的很大一部分差异可以通过他们的性格来预测，“五大”性格特征（外向性、宜人性、尽责性、情绪稳定性和开放性）都发挥着重要作用。例如，在开放性方面得分高的人倾向于喜欢具有反思性和复杂性的音乐，而外向的人比内向的人更倾向于喜欢充满活力和节奏的音乐。这样，一首歌的价值部分来源于听者的气质。与此同时，新手可能更多地被歌曲的情感内容所驱动，而专家可能会更多地分析性地聆听。我们是在聆听一个简单的节奏来跳舞，还是在理解一个抽象概念时获得的稀有乐趣？创新？一首歌如何打动我们，部分取决于我们所听的内容。

To make things even more complicated, no one song can satisfy every listener, because different types of people listen to music for different reasons. One recent study found that a considerable amount of the differences between individuals’ musical taste could be predicted by their personalities, with each of the “Big Five” personality traits (extroversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, emotional stability, and openness) playing an important role. People who score high on openness, for example, tend to like music that is reflective and complex, while extroverts have a greater tendency than introverts to like music that is energetic and rhythmic. In this way, the value of a song derives partly from the temperament of the listener. Novices, meanwhile, may be driven more by the emotional content of a song, whereas experts may listen more analytically. Are we listening for a simple groove to dance along with or the rarefied pleasure of understanding an abstract conceptual innovation? How a song strikes us is in part a function of what we are listening for.

这也与我们的朋友所听的内容有关。几年前，社会学家邓肯·瓦茨（Duncan Watts）设法为网络上的参与者提供聆听和下载原创音乐的机会，其实验设计操纵了参与者对其他人正在听的音乐的了解。这项研究最酷的部分是通过翻转对照组特定歌曲的收听频率排名来欺骗一组网站访问者。Parker Theory 的第 1 首歌曲“She Said”实际上总共听了 128 次，被描述为第 48 首歌曲，到目前为止有 9 次聆听，而 Post 的第 48 首歌曲“Florence” 《Break Tragedy》实际上听了 9 次，被列为排名第一的歌曲，据称有 128 次听。听众不再相信自己的耳朵，而是蜂拥而至那些人为夸大流行分数的歌曲。

It’s also a function of what our friends listen to. A couple years ago the sociologist Duncan Watts contrived to give participants on the Web the opportunity to listen to and download original music, in an experimental design that manipulated what the participants knew about what other people were listening to. The coolest part of the study faked out one group of Web site visitors by flipping a control group’s rankings for how often particular songs were heard. Song No. 1, “She Said,” by the Parker Theory, actually listened to a total of 128 times, was portrayed as song No. 48, with 9 listens so far, while song No. 48, “Florence,” by Post Break Tragedy, actually listened to 9 times, became listed as the No. 1 song, with an alleged 128 listens. Instead of trusting their own ears, listeners flocked to the songs with artificially inflated popularity scores.

 

这是坏消息。好消息是，随着时间的推移，至少有一首歌——被独立团体评为第一名的《她说》——开始恢复。社会压力是强大的，但不是绝对的。如果一首歌确实非常出色，那么无论如何它都可能登上榜首。

That’s the bad news. The good news is that over time, at least one song—“She Said,” the song judged No. 1 by the independent group— started to recover. Social pressure is powerful, but not absolute. If a song is really truly exceptional, it just might make it to the top no matter what.

 

 

想到那项研究，我不禁想起了《天国的阶梯》。正如主音吉他手吉米·佩奇（Jimmy Page）所观察到的那样，早在听众听到《天堂的阶梯》的录音之前，他们就在音乐会上起立鼓掌——他们不喜欢熟悉感，也没有社会压力，因为歌迷认识他们的朋友喜欢它。这首歌刚刚奏效了。相反的极端是一个残酷的事实，即大多数歌曲——即使是那些由大唱片公司发行的歌曲——都失败了。抛开营销和社会因素不谈，火鸡永远是火鸡。一首歌进入我们耳朵和大脑的方式是金钱买不到的。归根结底，在个性之后，营销和文化背景都被排除在外，音乐本身仍然存在一些东西。为什么我们这么喜欢音乐？是什么让一首歌比另一首歌效果更好？

Thinking about that study, I can’t help but think of “Stairway to Heaven.” As the lead guitarist, Jimmy Page, has observed, audiences were giving “Stairway to Heaven” a standing ovation in concert long before they had ever heard a recording of it— there was no liking for familiarity, no social pressure because fans knew their friends liked it. The song just worked. At the opposite extreme of the spectrum is the brute fact that most songs— even those released by major labels— flop. Marketing and social factors aside, a turkey will always remain a turkey. The way in which a song falls upon our ears and brains is something that money just can’t buy. At the end of the day, after personality, marketing, and cultural context are all factored out, there is still something about the music itself that remains. Why do we like music so much? And what makes one song work better than the next?

 

我们从音乐中获得的一些乐趣可以来自单个音符，例如敲击金属锣时产生的长时间回响；在适当的情况下，这种共振可以带来一种崇高的、几乎超凡脱俗的与宇宙的联系感。相反，即使是在廉价合成器上演奏的单个音符也可能听起来令人不快、粗糙，甚至是彻头彻尾的磨砂。我们通常更喜欢充满共鸣的丰富音符，而不是老式合成器产生的简单正弦波，可能是因为乐器上的音符听起来更像大自然的声音。心理学家、音乐作家、前摇滚制作人丹·莱维汀 (Dan Levitin) 告诉我，他曾经花了整个夏天的时间，除了用萨克斯管演奏整个音符之外什么也没做，因为他和许多其他音乐家都意识到，作品作为一种艺术形式的美感。整体必须从其元素之美开始。

Some of the pleasure we get from music can derive from a single note, like the long reverberations of a single bang on a metallic gong; in the right circumstance, that resonance can bring a sublime, almost unearthly sense of connectedness to the universe. Conversely, even a single note played on a cheap synthesizer may sound unpleasant, unpolished, or even downright abrasive. We generally prefer lush notes filled with resonance to simple sine waves produced by old-fashioned synthesizers, possibly because notes on musical instruments sound more like the sounds of nature. The psychologist, music writer, and former rock producer Dan Levitin told me that he once spent an entire summer working on nothing but playing whole notes on his saxophone, because as he, and many other musicians, realized, the beauty of a work as a whole must begin with the beauty of its elements.

正如列维京所指出的，在当代音乐中，制作的重点通常与古典元素（例如主旋律及其伴奏和声）一样关注音色（单个音符和乐器集合，通常是合成的）。为什么？也许是因为如今创造真正听起来新颖的声音比创造真正开辟新天地的旋律或和声更容易，而脱颖而出的歌曲是最有可能被记住（和购买）的歌曲。如果您能找到新的声音，那么您就已经向热门唱片迈出了一大步。想想披头士乐队的《Hard Day's Night》开头的轰鸣和弦，《Day in the Life》结尾的四十秒 E 大调和弦，迈克尔·杰克逊歌曲《Thriller》开头的嘎吱嘎吱的棺材声。 ，”或者莫比的歌曲“Extreme Ways”（杰森·伯恩电影的主题曲）开头的类似地铁的尖叫声。

As Levitin has noted, in contemporary music, the focus of production is often as much on timbre (of individual notes and of collections of instruments, often synthetic) as on classical elements such as the main melody and its accompanying harmony. Why? Perhaps because nowadays it is easier to create sounds that truly sound new than to create melodies or harmonies that break genuinely new ground, and the songs that stand out are the ones most likely to be remembered (and purchased). If you can find a new sound, you’ve already taken a giant step toward a hit record. Just think of the crashing chord at the beginning of the Beatles’ “Hard Day’s Night,” the forty-second E major chord at the end of their “Day in the Life,” the creaky-coffin sound that opens Michael Jackson’s song “Thriller,” or the subway-like screeches that open Moby’s song “Extreme Ways” (theme to the Jason Bourne movies).

 

 

然而，单个音符和和弦只能让艺术家到目前为止。响亮的锣声可能会让人兴奋一两分钟，但没有任何一个音符能够无限期地吸引任何人的注意力。无论单个音符或和弦多么迷人，听众迟早都会渴望更多。最终，音乐与其说是关于单个音符，不如说是关于组织成更大整体的音符流。

Single notes and chords can only get an artist so far, though. A resonant gong may thrill for a moment or two, but no one note could ever sustain anyone’s attention indefinitely. No matter how captivating any individual note or chord might be, sooner or later the listener yearns for more. Ultimately, music is not so much about single notes as about streams of notes, organized into larger wholes.

当我们从一个音符转到两个音符时——无论它们是同时（和声）还是按顺序（旋律）演奏——听众都会寻找两者之间的关系。例如，即使是未经训练的听众也会开始（无意识地）弄清楚一首曲子的调。

The minute we move from one note to two— whether they are played at the same time (harmonically) or in sequence (melodically)—the listener searches for a relation between the two. Even untrained listeners, for example, begin to try to figure out (unconsciously) what key a piece is in.

 

对来自十种不同文化的数百首歌曲旋律的数据库进行分析表明，旋律不是随机的，任何一首都与其他任何一首一样合理；相反，某些倾向似乎很普遍，从一种文化到另一种文化。例如，大多数歌曲中的大多数旋律步长在大多数情况下都很小。小跳跃——钢琴键盘上的一两个音符——远远多于大跳跃。诚然，也有例外——比如瑞士约德尔调和莫扎特《魔笛》中夜后独奏“Der Hölle Rache”中令人眩晕的上下跳跃——但这样的例外相对较少。

An analysis of a database of hundreds of song melodies taken from ten different cultures shows that melodies aren’t random, with any one just as plausible as any other; instead, certain tendencies seem widespread, from one culture to the next. Most melodic steps in most songs most of the time, for example, are small. Small jumps— those of just a note or two on the piano keyboard— vastly outnumber larger leaps. There are exceptions, to be sure— like Swiss yodeling and the vertiginous jumps up and down in the Queen of the Night’s solo “Der Hölle Rache” in Mozart’s Magic Flute— but such exceptions are relatively rare.

 

同样，大多数旋律中的大多数音符在大多数情况下都倾向于“调”；C大调的歌曲主要由钢琴键盘上的白音符组成，黑音符的停顿相对较少，通常只持续很短的时间。

Likewise, most notes in most melodies most of the time tend to be “in key”; a song in C major will consist mainly of the white notes on a piano keyboard, with stops on black notes relatively infrequent and typically only for brief periods.

 

如果我随意敲击钢琴，引起相当大的不和谐音，你可能会因为听到我违反规则而获得一种稀有的智力愉悦，但最终你可能不会那么投入。音乐有很多子流派，比如“噪音核心”，我开玩笑地称之为“吸尘器音乐”，其中最著名的是 Merzbow 乐队，但 Merzbow 的销量相对不太可能超过旋律更优美、但可能不那么原创的 Kenny G。

If I were to whack randomly on the piano, eliciting considerable dissonance, you might get a kind of rarefied intellectual pleasure from hearing me break the rules, but at the end of the day you probably wouldn’t be all that into it. There are subgenres of music like “noisecore” and what I jokingly refer to as “vacuum cleaner music,” made most prominent by the band Merzbow, but it is relatively unlikely that Merzbow will ever outsell the more melodic if arguably less original Kenny G.

 

尽管如此，一点不和谐音还是可以的（就像布鲁斯歌曲中的蓝色音符），而且随着历史的推移，人们对不和谐音的兴趣也在增加。熟悉不仅会产生对特定歌曲的喜爱，还会产生对风格和音乐惯例的喜爱。例如，中世纪的作曲家极力避免被称为三全音的听起来不协和的音程，但如今，数以百万计的孩子每天都会听到三全音，因为《辛普森一家》的片头字幕从 A 到升 D 跨越了两个音节“辛普森一家”这个词。《西区故事》中“玛丽亚”的前两个音节代表了另一个例子，欧洲警笛的oo-ee 声和老式 Macintosh II 上的启动声也是如此。（个体之间对不和谐音的敏感性也不同，音乐家的差异比非音乐家的差异更明显。）

Still, a little bit of dissonance is fine (like blue notes in the midst of a blues song), and appetites for dissonance have increased over historical time. Familiarity breeds affection not just for particular songs, but for styles and musical conventions. Composers in the Middle Ages, for example, strenuously avoided the dissonant-sounding interval known as the tritone, but nowadays millions of kids hear tritones every day, as the opening credits to The Simpsons leap from A to D-sharp across the two syllables of the word “Simpsons.” The first two syllables in “Maria,” in West Side Story, represent another example, as do the oo-ee of a European police siren and the start-up sound on the old Macintosh II. (There’s also differing sensitivity to dissonance between individuals, with the differences sharper for musicians than for nonmusicians.)

 

 

为什么未经训练的人类思维更喜欢和谐而不是不和谐？最初和最常见的理论可以追溯到毕达哥拉斯，他注意到任何给定音符对的频率之间的比率在辅音音程（例如纯五度）中比在不和谐音符对中更为优雅。作为一个粗略的问题，人们可以将音程从最辅音（例如纯四度和五度）到最不辅音（小二度和三全音）进行排序，并且与比率简单性的相关性似乎很强。

Why does the untutored human mind prefer consonance to dissonance? The original and most common theory goes back to Pythagoras, who noticed that the ratio between the frequencies of any given pair of notes was more elegant in consonant intervals such as perfect fifths than in dissonant pairs of notes. As a rough matter, one can order the intervals from most consonant (perfect fourths and fifths, for example) to least consonant (minor seconds and tritones), and the correlation with the simplicity of the ratios seems strong.

但毕达哥拉斯是一位比心理学家更好的数学家，他没有意识到完美的五度听起来仍然相当不错，即使它稍微跑调，在这种情况下，比率开始变得相当毛茸茸。这告诉我们什么？

But Pythagoras was a better mathematician than he was a psychologist, and he didn’t realize a perfect fifth can still sound pretty good even when it is slightly out of tune, in which case the ratio starts to become rather hairy. What does this tell us?

 

毕达哥拉斯走在正确的道路上，但出于错误的原因。他想象出一种完美比例所固有的神秘之美，但是什么实际上，使和声听起来很好听的并不是振动本身的某种物理特性。相反，听众倾向于将稍微跑调的音符归入他们最了解的类别中。但这种计算本身取决于听众所掌握的音乐元素词汇，这可能是经验丰富的音乐家比非音乐家对协和音更敏感的部分原因。

Pythagoras was on the right track, but for the wrong reasons. He imagined a kind of mystical beauty inherent in perfect ratios, but what actually makes harmonic notes sound good together is not some physical property of vibrations per se. Instead, listeners tend to assimilate slightly out-of-tune notes into the categories they know best. But that calculation itself depends on the vocabulary of musical elements that a listener has developed, which is presumably part of why experienced musicians are more sensitive to consonance than nonmusicians.

 

正如音乐学者大卫·休伦（David Huron）所说，走调的音符或不和谐的和弦就像一张失焦的图片：大脑很难理解潜在的场景。一个人可以学会喜欢不和谐，就像一个人可以学会喜欢印象派绘画的模糊性一样，但在其他条件相同的情况下，大脑的自然偏好是最容易理解的。

As the music scholar David Huron put it, an out-of-tune note, or a dissonant chord, is like an out-of-focus picture: the brain struggles to make sense of the underlying scene. One can learn to love dissonance, much as one can learn to love the fuzziness of Impressionist paintings, but other things being equal, the brain’s natural preference is for that which it can most easily make sense of.

 

20 年代，作曲家阿诺德·勋伯格（Arnold Schoenberg）试图挑战这一点，他故意创造了由“音行”组成的不和谐音乐，这些“音行”是由十二个音符组成的序列，其中每个音符，无论黑白，都同样频繁地使用，目的是打破听者对音调中心的依赖。在我看来，勋伯格的实验是崇高的，但并不成功，因此，对于心灵的耳朵到底有多灵活（或不灵活）具有启发性。许多学者认为勋伯格是二十世纪的关键作曲家，但事实上很少有普通人喜欢他的作品。最近一次参观维也纳音乐之家博物馆时，我看到一个又一个房间专门陈列着维也纳最著名的作曲家——海顿、莫扎特、施特劳斯、贝多芬和马勒——每个人都自豪地演奏着这座城市的本土儿子的音乐。可怜的勋伯格只得到了合住的宿舍，一个小房间的三分之一。他的房间与其他房间不同，很安静，大概是因为博物馆馆长认为音调排列会吓跑游客。

In the 1920s, the composer Arnold Schoenberg tried to challenge that, creating deliberately dissonant music consisting of “tone rows,” which were sequences of twelve notes in which every note, black and white, was used equally often, with the intention of breaking the listener’s reliance on tonal center. In my view, Schoenberg’s experiments were noble but unsuccessful, and, as such, instructive about just how flexible (or not) the mind’s ear can be. Many academics see Schoenberg as the pivotal composer of the twentieth century, but in truth few ordinary people enjoy his work. On a recent trip to the Haus der Musik museum in Vienna, I saw room after room devoted to some of Vienna’s most famous composers— Haydn, Mozart, Strauss, Beethoven, and Mahler— each one proudly playing the music of the city’s native sons. Poor Schoenberg got only shared quarters, a third of a tiny room. And his room, unlike the others, was silent, presumably because the museum’s curators thought that tone rows would scare away the tourists.

 

这并不是说不和谐的音乐，比如勋伯格和他同时代人创作的音乐，没有价值，但也许更好地认为它是一种后天的品味，而不是人耳自然产生的东西。已故的米尔顿·巴比特（Milton Babbitt）是追随勋伯格的二十世纪作曲家之一，他的著作《一份名为“如果你听谁在乎？”的宣言 （据称是由他的编辑命名的），其中他游说一种只有少数专家才能欣赏的专业音乐，大概是基于一套只能通过努力学习才能学到的技能。巴比特的观点并没有什么问题——在任何艺术中，某些作品更容易被内部人士理解，专家也有权享受他们的乐趣——但任何音乐心理学的努力都必须从对最自然欣赏的事物的理解开始。

This is not to say that dissonant music, such as that composed by Schoenberg and his contemporaries, is without value, but it is perhaps better considered an acquired taste than something that comes naturally to the human ear. One of the twentieth-century composers who followed Schoenberg, the late Milton Babbitt, notoriously wrote a manifesto called “Who Cares If You Listen?” (allegedly titled by his editor) in which he lobbied for a kind of specialist music that might be appreciated only by a tiny community of experts, presumably on the basis of a set of skills that could be learned only through hard work.
