Nothing is wrong with Babbitt’s notion— in any art, certain works are better understood by insiders, and specialists are entitled to their fun— but any efforts at a psychology of music have to start with an understanding of that which is most naturally appreciated.

 

 

和谐与不和谐只是调色板中的颜色，真正关心的是整个艺术品的形状。法国作曲家埃德加·瓦雷兹（Edgard Varèse）曾将音乐定义为“有组织的声音”，这个定义可能既太宽泛（缝纫机的反复敲击算不算？）又太窄（约翰·凯奇作品中的随机音符怎么样？） 。凯奇还挑战了我们的定义，创作了像4 33这样的作品，其中包括四分三十三秒的沉默。4 33或 Cage 的随机作品是否真正算作音乐（或只是概念艺术）可能取决于您自己的个人定义；很少有人会觉得其中任何一个特别令人愉快。如果你的定义足够自由的话，从技术上讲它们可能都被认为是音乐，但《4 33》和凯奇的随机作品都不包含音乐引人注目的本质：两种表面上矛盾的力量的并置，新颖性和熟悉性。

Consonance and dissonance are only colors in a palette, where the real concern is the shape of the artwork as a whole. The French composer Edgard Varèse once defined music as “organized sound,” a definition that may be both too broad (does the repeated tapping of a sewing machine count?) and too narrow (how about the random notes of a John Cage composition?). Cage also challenged our definitions by creating pieces like 433, which consisted of four minutes and thirty-three seconds of silence. Whether or not 433 or Cage’s random pieces should really count as music (or just conceptual art) may depend on your own personal definition; few people would find either to be especially pleasing. They might both be technically considered to be music, if your definitions are liberal enough, but neither 433 nor Cage’s random pieces contain the essence of what makes music compelling: the juxtaposition of two ostensibly contradictory forces, novelty and familiarity.

例如，凯奇随机生成的棋子就具有一定的新颖性；根据定义，每个新音符都独立于上一个音符，因此无法预测接下来会发生什么。但它们完全缺乏重复，这种技术在几乎所有其他音乐中都非常常见。在一首又一首的歌曲中，无论是流行音乐还是古典音乐，小元素和大元素都会一遍又一遍地重复，以至于乐谱本身就充满了变化。竖线（表示何时应该重复某些部分）和符号 DC（表示从头开始重复，源自短语da capo，意大利语“从头开始”）等符号。音乐理论史上最重要的人物之一海因里希·申克（Heinrich Schenker）曾写道：“如果有人问：音乐是在哪里、何时以及如何首次发展出其最引人注目和最引人注目的特征，我们对音乐技巧的理解就会更进一步。”独特的特征——重复？”

Cage’s randomly generated pieces, for example, have a certain kind of novelty; by definition, each new note is independent from the last, hence there is no way to predict what comes next. But they altogether lack repetition, a technique that is startlingly common in almost all other music. In song after song, in both popular music and classical pieces, small elements and larger ones get repeated over and over, so much so that music notation is itself filled with a whole slew of symbols like vertical bars (which indicate when sections should be repeated) and the notation DC (which means repeat from the beginning, derived from the phrase da capo, Italian for “from the head”). One of the most important figures in the history of music theory, Heinrich Schenker, once wrote, “Our understanding of musical technique would have advanced much further if only someone had asked: Where, when, and how did music first develop its most striking and distinct characteristic— repetition?”

 

事实上，与其他艺术相比，音乐的重复程度令人震惊。诚然，诗人有时会包含重复的短语，但在散文中很少看到重复，电影也很少重复场景。非小说类作家重复一句话很可能会受到编辑的责骂；重复对话的剧作家要么是大卫·马梅特（形成了独特的风格），要么是个傻瓜。很少有人花钱听演员把同一句话说两遍，更不用说逐字逐句地重复了。*但是您最后一次听到一首不重复副歌的流行歌曲是什么时候？

It is in fact startling the extent to which music, relative to other arts, overflows with repetition. To be sure, poets sometimes include repeated phrases, but it is rare to see repetition in prose, and movies repeat scenes sparingly if at all. A nonfiction author who repeats a sentence is likely to be scolded by his editor; a playwright who repeats his dialogue is either David Mamet (forging a distinctive style) or a fool. Few people pay to hear actors say the same line twice, much less if it’s literally repeated word for word.* But when is the last time you heard a pop song that didn’t repeat its chorus?

 

一个罕见的例子违反了这一规则，歌词从不重复——没有副歌，没有副歌，什么都没有——可能是迪伦的《西班牙皮革靴子》，但即使在那里，旋律和和弦进行（和弦序列）也会重复；比莉·哈乐黛的强力版《奇怪的水果》也是如此。摇滚和流行歌曲通常具有每八或十二小节重复一次的和弦进行，并且通常在这些小节内有相当多的重复。没有立即重复的歌曲和和弦进行被称为“完整创作”——披头士乐队的“幸福是一把温暖的枪”是一个罕见的例子——但人们几乎不需要重复歌曲的列表。重复，无论是在歌曲结构还是在聆听中，都是音乐的核心部分。

A rare example that violates that rule, in which the lyrics never repeat— no chorus, no refrain, no nothing— might be Dylan’s “Boots of Spanish Leather,” but even there the melody and chord progression (sequence of chords) do repeat; the same can be said for Billie Holiday’s powerful version of “Strange Fruit.” Rock and pop songs typically have chord progressions that repeat every eight or twelve measures, often with considerable repetition within those measures. Songs and chord progressions in which there isn’t some immediate repetition are called through-composed— the Beatles’ “Happiness Is a Warm Gun” is a rare example— but one hardly needs a list for songs with repetition. Repetition, both in song structure and in listening, is a central part of music.

 

 

尽管如此，重复本身还是很乏味的，必须通过其他元素来平衡。聆听雷蒙斯乐队 (Ramones) 的“I Wanna Be Sedated”（没有人声）的音乐，您可能会想要犯下 hari-kari 的错误。随着歌词的质感和变化的增加，这首歌变得引人入胜，即使对于像我这样不太想喜欢它的人来说也是如此。最近，我有幸观看了乔伊·雷蒙 (Joey Ramone) 的弟弟米奇·李 (Mickey Leigh) 的演唱会，场地很小，出席人数不超过三十或四十人。大多数歌曲都是翻唱的，以纪念利已故的兄弟。尽管我试着讨厌歌词（“我想要镇静剂/我想要镇静剂”），但我还是忍不住被带走了。同样，《Blitzkrieg Bop》也兑现了它的承诺，让听众几乎无法抑制地想要跳舞。坐下来听歌毫无意义，站起来也没有抵抗力。“Blitzkrieg Bop”的主要工具是压倒性的重复——简单的吉他连复段以令人头脑麻木的速度传递，节奏部分是稳定的八分音符，完全是下划线，形成了一种重复的无上划线模式，任何民谣吉他手都不会被卡死演奏时，优雅换成了坚持。但它确实有效。歌词——三段歌词和三遍重复的“嘿，我们走”副歌——几乎没有什么吸引力（“他们在后座堆积/他们在产生蒸汽热”），但设法传达了足够的对位，使整个事情都有效。

Still, repetition on its own would be dull and has to be balanced by some other element. Listen to the music to the Ramones’ “I Wanna Be Sedated” without the vocals and you might be tempted to commit hari-kari. With the added texture and variation of the lyrics, the song becomes engaging, even for folks like me who don’t particularly want to like it. I recently had the pleasure of seeing Joey Ramone’s younger brother— Mickey Leigh— in concert, in a tiny venue, with not more than thirty or forty people present. Most of the songs were covers, in tribute to Leigh’s late brother. Try as I did to hate the lyrics (“I wanna be sedated / I wanna be sedated”), I couldn’t help but be carried along. Likewise, “Blitzkrieg Bop” delivers what it promises, driving the listener headlong into an almost overwhelming compulsion to dance. There’s no point in listening to the song while sitting down and no ability to resist when you’re standing up. The primary tool of “Blitzkrieg Bop” is overwhelming repetition— simple guitar riffs delivered at mind-numbing speed, the rhythm part a steady diet of eighth notes, entirely downstrokes, forming a repetitive upstroke-free pattern that no folk guitarist would be caught dead playing, elegance traded for insistence. Yet it works. The lyrics— three verses and three repetitions of the “Hey ho, let’s go” refrain— are hardly compelling (“They’re piling in the back seat / They’re generating steam heat”) but manage to convey just enough counterpoint to make the whole thing work.

交响乐以通过调和乐章调制的主题开始，流行歌曲则以副歌和副歌点缀诗句。有时吉他连复段会一遍又一遍地重复（音乐家的行话是“vamping”），但通常会有一位独奏者提供高于背景的变奏，以免歌曲听起来单调。菲利普·格拉斯 (Philip Glass) 的极简主义作品（例如《Koyaanisqatsi》的配乐）与之前的许多古典音乐不同，与他的作品似乎所反抗的浪漫主义时代的作品相比，运动性要小得多，但他的作品不仅包含大量的重复，而且包含不断的（尽管微妙的）变化。事实上，你听过的每一首歌都由这样的内容组成：一遍又一遍地重复的主题，并覆盖着变奏。

Symphonies begin with themes that modulate through keys and movements, pop songs pepper verses with choruses and refrains. Sometimes guitar riffs get repeated over and over (“vamping,” in the lingo of musicians), but generally there is a soloist providing variation that runs above that background, lest the song sound monotonous. Philip Glass’s minimalist compositions (such as the soundtrack to Koyaanisqatsi) deviate from much of the classical music that preceded them, with much less obvious movement than, say, the Romantic-era compositions that his work seems to rebel against, yet his works, too, consist not only of extensive repetition but also of constant (though subtle) variation. Virtually every song you’ve ever heard consists of exactly that: themes that recur over and over, overlaid with variations.

 

声乐往往比器乐（无论是流行音乐还是古典音乐）更受欢迎，部分原因是歌词的直接性，部分原因是人声的表现力，还有部分原因是人声（即使在流行音乐和古典音乐中）一门外语）增加了重复和变化的新维度，一种在覆盖变化（歌词）的同时保持事物不变（旋律）的新方式——新颖性传达了它自己单独的奖励。出于类似的原因，合成器和鼓采样器可能已经变得普遍。通过丰富声音调色板，新技术扩展了将本质上重复的主题与色彩和新颖性进行分层的方式，使大脑能够同时收集两种奖励——新颖性和熟悉性。如果我必须用一个简洁的短语来概括星际旅行者的人类音乐，可能会是这样：“重复，有变化。”

Vocal music tends to be more popular than instrumental music (in both the pop and the classical worlds) in part because of the immediacy of lyrics and in part because of the expressiveness of the human voice— but also in part because vocals (even when in a foreign language) add a new dimension of repetition and variation, a new way of keeping one thing constant (melody) while overlaying variation (lyrics)—and novelty conveys its own separate reward. Synthesizers and drum samplers may have become widespread for a similar reason. By enriching the sonic palette, new technologies expand the ways in which an intrinsically repetitive theme can be layered with color and novelty, allowing the brain to collect two rewards— novelty and familiarity— at the very same time. If I had to sum up human music for intergalactic travelers in a single concise phrase, it might be this: “Repetition, with variation.”

 

 

如果我们的记忆力更好的话，所有这些重复（带有变化或其他）可能会更加烦人。如果听众第一次就能记住歌曲的每个细节，他们可能不想听到它重复八次。但我们大多数人在第一次听时都记不住旋律的具体细节，只能记住轮廓，最近的一项研究发现，许多听众无法识别重复，即使被要求明确地听它们。当我们第一次听到一首歌时，我们的脑海里就好像已经形成了一幅模糊的画面；第二次，图像变得不再那么模糊；第三次或第四次，我们可能真的记住了旋律，但仍然陶醉于我们前几次没有注意到的纹理和复杂性通过。实验研究表明（取决于歌曲）我们可能需要听几十遍才会真正感到无聊。

All that repetition (feathered with variation or otherwise) would likely be considerably more annoying if our memories were better. If listeners could commit every detail of a song to memory the first time through, they might not want to hear it repeated eight times. But most of us can’t remember the exact details of a melody on a first hearing, just the outlines, and one recent study found that many listeners don’t recognize repetitions, even when asked to listen for them explicitly. The first time we hear a song, it’s as if we’ve formed a fuzzy picture in our heads; the second time, the picture becomes a little less fuzzy; the third or fourth time through, we might actually remember the melody but still revel in textures and intricacies we didn’t notice the first few times through. Experimental research suggests that (depending on the song) it can take dozens of listens before we become truly bored.

尽管人们常常认为音乐比其他事物更容易记住，但没有真实的数据支持这一说法，至少对于非音乐家来说是这样。在仔细的实验​​室条件下，对于非音乐家来说，音符串比仔细匹配的字母列表（R、C、J、E、L等）更难记住，并且相对于，任意字母本身都很难记住，说，连贯的句子。此外，最近的研究表明，听觉记忆总体上不如视觉记忆强大。正如一位研究人员所说，“音乐作为助记手段的‘特殊’力量可能在于它促进了过度的排练”——而不是我们本质上擅长于此。换句话说，天真的听众往往能很好地记住歌曲，只是因为他们听得很多。具有讽刺意味的是，我们经常听歌曲的原因之一是因为它们很难记住。

Although people often believe that music is easier to remember than other things, there are no real data to support that assertion, at least for nonmusicians. Under careful laboratory conditions, strings of musical notes are harder for nonmusicians to remember than carefully matched lists of letters (R, C, J, E, L, and so on), and arbitrary letters themselves are pretty hard to remember, relative to, say, coherent sentences. Moreover, recent studies suggest that auditory memory in general is significantly less powerful than visual memory. As one researcher put it, “The ‘special’ power of music as a mnemonic device may be that it fosters excessive rehearsal”—and not that we are intrinsically good at it. In other words, naive listeners tend to remember songs well only because they listen to them a lot. And, ironically, one of the reasons that we listen to songs a lot is because they are hard to remember.

 

 

奇怪的是，大多数时候，一种不太重要的音乐成分是整体秩序和凝聚力。对音乐的古典分析充满了对这个或那个作曲家如何完美地组织这个或那个奏鸣曲交响曲的整体结构的赞美讨论。例如，贝多芬经常因认识到奏鸣曲的重心可以放在最后乐章而不是最初乐章中而受到赞扬，从而定义了在作品结尾处达到高潮的叙事结构。“如果一首伟大奏鸣曲的乐章调换过来，”《大英音乐书》热情地说道， “其音乐效果将会较差。”

Oddly, one musical ingredient that doesn’t matter much, most of the time, is overall order and cohesion. Classical analyses of music are replete with laudatory discussions of how this or that composer has beautifully organized the global structure of this or that sonata symphony. Beethoven, for example, is often praised for his realization that the weight in a sonata could be placed in the final movement rather than in the initial movement, so as to define a narrative structure that culminates at the end of the piece. “If the movements of a great sonata are switched around,” enthused the Britannica Book of Music, “the results will be musically inferior.”

这种想法最初可能看起来令人信服，甚至宏伟，但仔细观察后发现，它与经验现实几乎没有关系。许多听众——甚至是训练有素的听众——往往对一首曲子的整体结构漠不关心。甚至一些最受人尊敬的音乐编曲也不能幸免于这种冷漠。一位心理学家拍摄了一系列钢琴奏鸣曲和弦乐四重奏，并重新排列了每个系列的乐章顺序；听众并不关心。受试者都喜欢乱码版本和原始版本——两者之间没有区别。后来的一项研究随机化了巴赫的《哥德堡变奏曲》（通常与格伦·古尔德相关）的顺序，并发现了类似的结果。另一项研究尝试将巴赫、莫扎特和勋伯格的音乐作品雕刻成更精细的片段（每段约六秒），结果再次发现，非音乐家听众并不真正关心这些作品是否被随机排列（尽管他们可以分辨出其中的差异）在更具表现力和更少表现力之间）。另一项研究则更进一步，通过混合肖斯塔科维奇的《梦幻舞曲 3》中三首不同钢琴独奏的片段，创作出新的（古典）作品；经过几次聆听后，受试者（包括一些受过十年音乐训练的大学生）实际上更喜欢混搭的组合，而不是原始的、更有凝聚力的作品。我们对作品的感觉很大程度上取决于我们对各个部分的感受。叙事弧在戏剧中几乎总是必不可少的，但（除非涉及歌词）在音乐中通常不太重要。

That thought may initially seem convincing, or even majestic, but on close inspection it turns out to have little to do with empirical reality. Many listeners— even trained listeners— are often remarkably indifferent to the overall structure of a piece. Even some of the most revered musical arrangements are not immune to this indifference. One psychologist took a series of piano sonatas and string quartets and rearranged the order of the movements of each of the series; listeners didn’t care. The subjects liked both the scrambled versions and the originals— with no difference between the two. A later study randomized the order of Bach’s Goldberg Variations (often associated with Glenn Gould) and found similar results. Yet another study tried carving musical compositions by Bach, Mozart, and Schoenberg into finer slices— about six seconds each— and found, yet again, that nonmusician listeners didn’t really care if the pieces were randomly permuted (although they could tell the difference between more and less expressive performances). Yet another study went a step further and made new (classical) pieces by hybridizing sections of three different piano solos from Shostakovich’s Fantastic Dance 3; after just a few listenings, subjects (including some who were college students with ten years of musical training) actually preferred the bastardized combinations to the original, more cohesive pieces. Our sense of a composition largely inheres in how we feel about the individual parts; narrative arcs are almost always essential in drama but (unless there are lyrics involved) often less essential in music.

 

 

我怀疑，所有这一切都是人类记忆局限性的症状。我们在很大程度上生活在当下；三十秒前发生的事情已经迅速从我们的记忆中消失（或者至少迅速变得难以回忆）。尼古拉斯·库克（Nicholas Cook）相当明确地测试了这一点，他让人们聆听贝多芬和李斯特等作曲家的段落，这些段落经过修改，以与开头不一致的调子结尾。如果关键的变化发生在短时间内，人们会注意到它们，但如果一块在几分钟内逐渐从系泊处移动，几乎没有人注意到。（也许这就是为什么当流行歌曲从主歌切换到音乐上独特的桥段时，似乎没有人介意。）

All of this is, I suspect, again symptomatic of human memory limitations. We live, to a remarkable degree, in the present; what happened thirty seconds ago is already rapidly fading from our memory (or at least rapidly becomes harder for us to retrieve). Nicholas Cook tested this fairly explicitly by having people listen to passages from composers such as Beethoven and Liszt that had been doctored so that they ended in keys that were inconsistent with their beginnings. If the key changes happened within a short window, people noticed them, but if a piece gradually shifted from its moorings over a span of a couple of minutes, hardly anyone noticed. (Perhaps this is why nobody seems to mind when a pop song switches from a verse to a bridge that is musically distinct.)

只要最后几秒钟看起来连贯，那就很重要了。在这方面，我想起了诸如埃舍尔式魔鬼叉之类的视错觉，这张图片乍一看似乎非常普通。

As long as the last few seconds seem coherent, that’s all that matters. In this respect, I am reminded of optical illusions such as the Escher-like devil’s fork, a picture that at first glance appears perfectly ordinary.

 

 

只有全神贯注，观众才会意识到有些不对劲，人物和背景完全混淆了。只要局部看起来还不错，我们就无法意识到整体的不连贯性。（同样的事情也可能发生在语言中，就像我们最初没有注意到“去过俄罗斯的人比我多”这样的句子中的奇怪之处。每对单词单独来看都有意义，但整体则不然。）

Only with focused concentration does the viewer realize that something is amiss, with figure and ground hopelessly confused. As long as the local bits look okay, we fail to realize the incoherence of the whole. (The same thing can happen in language, as when we initially fail to notice the oddness in a sentence like “More people have been to Russia than I have.” Each pair of words makes sense taken individually, but the whole does not.)

我们对音乐的品味，就像生活的其他方面一样，来自我们大脑的组织：我们的大脑如何解释听觉世界，我们的奖励系统如何运作，以及我们能记住什么。

Our tastes in music, as in every other aspect of life, come from the organization of our brains: how our brains interpret the auditory world, how our reward systems work, and what we can remember.

 

 

从一开始，自动歌曲生成程序 Microsoft Songsmith 就注定会失败。作为一个社会问题，唯一比机器生成的音乐更有可能引发我们与他们的反应的是由机器生成的音乐。公司机器。如果节目制作的歌曲被重新包装成青少年乐队的成果，人们可能会有更多的宽容（或者至少是同情）。对于聪明的评论家来说，模仿歌曲史密斯本身很容易。事实上，任何人制作的每一次翻唱都是一场艰苦的战斗，因为一首著名歌曲的原始版本总是具有固有的优势，源于我们对熟悉的固有喜好；闯入者冒着巨大的危险前进。一些封面成功了，但大多数都没有。

From the outset, the automatic song-generating program Microsoft Songsmith was probably destined to fail. As a social matter, the only thing that might be more likely to provoke an us- versus-them reaction than music generated by a machine would be music generated by a corporate machine. If the songs the program produced were repackaged as the fruits of a teen band, people might have rather more tolerance (or at least sympathy). And the Songsmith parodies themselves are easy for a clever critic to make. Virtually every cover that anyone makes is an uphill battle, because the original version of a well-known song always has a built-in advantage of incumbency, born from our inherent liking for familiarity; interlopers proceed at great peril. A few covers succeed, but most don’t.

在技​​术方面，该程序的目的是对旋律与和弦进行的关系进行复杂的分析，并建立一个关于西方音乐中统计上常见内容的详细数据库。但创建它的程序员过于关注音乐的统计数据，而对潜在的心理学关注不够。关于重复、新颖性和变化的更大的结构性问题根本没有提上议程。灾难或许是不可避免的。

On the technical side, what the program has going for it is a sophisticated analysis of how melodies relate to chord progressions and a detailed database of what is statistically common in Western music. But the programmers who created it were focused too much on the statistics of music and not enough on the underlying psychology. Larger structural questions about repetition, novelty, and variation simply weren’t on the agenda. Disaster may have been inevitable.

 

尽管如此，我实际上认为 Songsmith 是一个好主意，尽管执行得不好。事实是，现代音乐家一直在使用计算机化工具，从鼓机到复杂的软件。像乐谱编辑器 Finale 这样的程序可以自动生成四声部和声。流行音乐制作人经常使用 Logic Pro 等程序，该程序在其众多的音乐工具中包括一个所谓的人性化功能，可以以适当的比例向鼓序列添加变化和随机噪音，以保持听众的参与。另一个名为 Band-in-a-Box 的程序多年来一直被用来创建快速而肮脏的编排（之后通常需要手动调整）。

Despite all this, I actually think Songsmith is a good idea, if poorly executed. The truth is that modern musicians use computerized tools all the time, from drum machines to complex software. Programs like the sheet music editor Finale can automatically generate four-part harmonies. Pop music producers routinely use programs like Logic Pro, which includes among its vast array of musical tools a so-called humanizing function that can add variation and random noise to drum sequences in just the right proportion to keep the listener engaged. Another program, called Band-in-a-Box, has been used for years to create quick and dirty orchestrations (which are often hand-tweaked afterward).

 

Songsmith 的问题不在于使用机器作为工具，也不在于其将业余爱好者纳入其中的崇高意图，而在于制造机器的特殊方式。尽管音乐中没有绝对的规则，一首违反大多数惯例（无视可预测性）的歌曲很可能会失败，但一首没有给现有经典添加任何原创内容的歌曲也可能会失败；盲目地坚持在其数据库的统计数据中，Songsmith 忽略了新颖性，因此错过了驱动我们热爱音乐的一半动力。

The problem with Songsmith is not in using machines as tools, nor in its noble intention of bringing rank amateurs into the fold, but rather in the particular way in which the machine was built. Although there are no absolute rules in music, a song that disobeys most conventions (flouting predictability) is likely to fail, but so too is a song that adds nothing original to the existing canon; by sticking slavishly to the statistics of its database, Songsmith ignored novelty and hence missed half of what drives our love of music.

 

 

在关于艺术的科学和哲学论述史上，音乐常常受到不利影响。例如，伟大的德国哲学家伊曼纽尔·康德（Immanuel Kant）可以说是自柏拉图和亚里士多德以来最重要的哲学家，他谈到了艺术的等级制度，并将音乐置于底部附近，因为它“仅与感觉一起演奏”。心理学家史蒂文·平克（Steven Pinker）曾将音乐比作“听觉芝士蛋糕”，这一点颇有名气（也颇具争议）。音乐哲学家彼得·基维将音乐描述为“声音壁纸”。

In the history of scientific and philosophical discourse on the arts, music has often gotten the short end of the stick. For example, the great German philosopher Immanuel Kant, arguably the most significant philosopher since Plato and Aristotle, talked about a hierarchy of arts and placed music near the bottom, since it “plays merely with sensations.” And the psychologist Steven Pinker famously (and controversially) likened music to “auditory cheesecake.” The philosopher of music Peter Kivy has described music as “sonic wallpaper.”

康德的论点是，音乐（特别是器乐）没有内在内容，而小说或寓言可能提供生动的方式来编码替代课程（“小心你的愿望”）。没有歌词的音乐（以任何明显的方式）并不涉及任何特定的事情。对于康德来说，这使得音乐成为一种枯燥的练习，为了装饰而装饰，仅此而已。

Kant’s argument was that music (particularly instrumental music) had no intrinsic content, whereas a novel or a fable might supply vivid ways of encoding vicarious lessons (“Be careful what you wish for”). Music without lyrics isn’t (in any obvious way) about anything in particular. For Kant, this left music as a sterile exercise, decoration for decoration’s sake, and nothing more.

 

平克在他的《心灵如何运作》一书的修订版中写道，他所写的几乎没有什么比他关于音乐可能不是自然选择的直接产物的建议更受批评的了。

In the revised edition of his book How the Mind Works, Pinker writes that hardly anything he has ever written has gotten more flak than his suggestion that music might not be a direct product of natural selection.

 

然而，我们至少已经看到两个充分的理由相信平克是正确的：似乎没有任何专门用于音乐的特定神经模块（正如你可能期望的那样，如果音乐是通过自然选择专门调整的），并且只有一个让我们变得有音乐天赋的一小部分机制似乎首先是与生俱来的。几乎所有人类都可以学会欣赏电子游戏，但这并不意味着我们的祖先进化出了对乒乓球的特定品味。为什么音乐应该有所不同？

Yet we have already seen at least two good reasons to believe that Pinker is right: there doesn’t appear to be any specific neural module devoted to music (as you might expect if music had been specifically tuned by natural selection), and only a small part of the machinery that allows us to become musical seems to be innate in the first place. Virtually all humans can learn to appreciate video games, but that doesn’t mean our ancestors evolved a specific taste for Pong. Why should music be any different?

 

在这一点上我支持平克。但他对音乐的描述确实提出了一个问题：如果音乐是大脑的甜点，为什么它的味道这么好？为什么音乐几乎无处不在，而许多其他艺术在日常生活中的存在却较小？

I’m with Pinker on this one. But his characterization of music does raise a question: If music is dessert for the brain, why does it taste so good? Why is music virtually ubiquitous, when many other arts have a smaller presence in daily life?

 

 

在某些方面，音乐与其他艺术非常相似。例如，在所有艺术中都存在一种附属成分：在其他条件相同的情况下，如果你喜欢我所做的画，我们更有可能成为朋友，雕塑、电影和音乐也是如此。人类的心灵渴望区分我们和他们，每一种艺术都给我们提供了一个新的维度来区分朋友和敌人。

In some respects, music is quite similar to other arts. There is, for example, in all arts an affiliative component: other things being equal, if you like the paintings I do, we’re more likely to be friends, and ditto for sculpture, movies, and music. The human mind longs to divide between us and them, and each art gives us a fresh dimension in which to distinguish friends from foes.

在其他方面，音乐可能被视为领先于其他艺术的一步。正如唱片制作人罗杰·格林纳瓦特（Roger Greenawalt）所说，“许多音乐家没有意识到他们漂浮在数学的海洋中，[但]音乐是所有艺术中最数学化的”，这是一种可重复的主题和模式的演算，可以绣成一种新奇的面料。

In other ways, music might be seen as a step ahead of other arts. As the record producer Roger Greenawalt put it, “Many musicians don’t realize that they are floating in an ocean of math [but] music is the most mathematical of all arts,” a calculus of repeatable motifs and patterns that can be embroidered into a fabric of novelty.

 

正如格林纳瓦特指出的那样，可以有没有旋律或和声的音乐，但几乎没有没有节奏的音乐——节奏是任何艺术中最明显的数学元素之一，因为节拍分为一半和四分之一、八分之一和十六分之一。除了这个分数格之外，还有一个更复杂的换位与和谐代数。

As Greenawalt points out, there can be music without melody or harmony, but there is almost no music without rhythm— one of the most overtly mathematical elements of any art, as beats are divided into halves and quarters, eighths and sixteenths. Beyond this lattice of fractions lies an even more complex algebra of transposition and harmony.

 

音乐也会随着时间的推移而展开。绘画和照片可能会在一瞬间引人注目，但很少有静态艺术能长期保持人们的兴趣。人们愿意为湖泊或海洋的景色支付如此高的价格，部分原因是它们总是在变化。任何静态的观点最终都会失去其吸引力。移动的风景让我们沉浸其中，音乐总是让人感动。

Music also unfolds over time. Paintings and photographs may be compelling for an instant, but few static arts sustain interest over time. People are willing to pay so much for views of lakes or oceans in part because they are always changing; any static view eventually loses its hold. Moving scenery keeps us engaged, and music is always moving.

 

与此同时，正如最近的一项研究所证实的那样，至少有两种不同的神经系统有助于我们听音乐时释放的多巴胺。正如我一直建议的，音乐可以让我们获得奖励在一个包中同时实现新颖性和预测性。重复一段旋律，大脑就会拍拍自己的背：我已经正确地预测了一些事情。现在同时改变歌词：对新颖性的奖励。作曲家拥有几乎无限的工具，可以利用两个最重要但又互补的系统，同时推动人类奖励：一个奖励我们做出成功的预测，另一个奖励我们发现新事物。在任何给定的歌曲中，您都会看到重复的元素，无论是旋律、和声还是歌词，并且您会看到这些元素与同一时间段内发生的变化并列。作为一种世俗艺术，音乐和电影一样，能够很好地提供这两种回报。

Meanwhile, as one recent study has confirmed, at least two distinct neural systems contribute to the dopamine that is released when we listen to music. As I have been suggesting, music allows us to get rewards for both novelty and prediction simultaneously, in a single package. Repeat a melody and the brain pats itself on the back: I’ve predicted something correctly. Now vary the lyrics at the same time: a reward for novelty. Composers have an almost infinite supply of tools for tapping into two of the most important yet complementary systems that drive human reward simultaneously: the one that rewards us for making successful predictions, and the one that rewards us for discovering something new. In any given song, you will see repeated elements, be they melodies or harmonies or lyrics, and you will see those elements juxtaposed against variations occurring over the same expanse of time. As a temporal art, music, like movies, is in good position to deliver both rewards.

 

与此同时，我们在记住音乐的全部细节方面所固有的困难有助于使音乐永远保持新鲜感。尤其是中世纪以来，西方音乐充满了难以一眼理解的丰富和声和复杂的配器，摇滚乐也越来越如此，尤其是在录音室工作中，常常充满了配音。正如音乐作家 Rikky Rooksby 在他富有洞察力的《如何用吉他写歌》中指出的那样：

At the same time, the intrinsic difficulty we have in remembering music in full detail helps keep music perpetually new. Especially since the Middle Ages, Western music has been filled with rich harmonies and complex orchestrations that cannot be apprehended in one glance, and the same has become increasingly true of rock and roll, especially in studio work, which is often filled with overdubs. As the music writer Rikky Rooksby pointed out, in his insightful How to Write Songs on Guitar:

 

制作歌曲广告最强大的手段之一是反旋律。反旋律由第二声音（或伴唱）演唱，有时使用不同的单词。好的副旋律不仅可以使主歌的重复变得活跃起来，还可以给副歌带来毁灭性的力量。

One of the most powerful devices for making a song commercial is counter-melody. A counter-melody is sung by a second voice (or backing vocalists), sometimes using different words. A good counter-melody can not only liven up the repetition of a verse but introduce devastating strength to the chorus.

 

如果只有一条旋律线，对于音乐熟练的听众来说，很容易在他或她的脑海中重播这首歌；添加第二个钩子，听众就会想出去购买唱片，重新创作自己难以重建的东西。（西蒙和加芬克尔经常使用这种技术，也许在《斯卡布罗集市》中最有效；所谓的暴徒之爱二重唱，例如 Method Man 和 Mary J. Blige 合作的“I'll Be There for You/You're All I Need to Get By”，也能引发引人注目的对位效果。）

If there is just a single melodic line, it is easy for a musically adept listener to replay the song in his or her own mind; add a second hook and the listener wants to go out and buy the record, to re-create what is too hard to reconstruct on his own. (Simon and Garfunkel used the technique frequently, perhaps most effectively in “Scarborough Fair”; so-called thug-love duets, like the Method Man/Mary J. Blige collaboration “I’ll Be There for You/You’re All I Need to Get By,” also elicit compelling contrapuntal effects.)

 

最后，音乐和动作之间存在联系：与绘画或摄影不同，音乐吸引听众，使他们想要跳舞或踢踏舞，也许是因为在感官之间架起桥梁的自动趋势，并且因为节奏的感知似乎与参与运动（肌肉）动作排序的神经机制直接相关。这种身体性使音乐特别身临其境。观看体育比赛可以具有类似的品质，但很少有其他艺术可以做到这一点，而且没有任何艺术（除了舞蹈，它与音乐的明显关系）如此一致地将音乐的身体性与其丰富的形式结构和扩展的时间活力结合起来。

Finally, there is a connection between music and motion: music, unlike painting or photography, draws in listeners, making them want to dance or tap along, perhaps because of the automatic tendency to bridge between senses, and because the perception of rhythm appears to be directly tied to neural machinery involved in sequencing motor (muscle) actions. That physicality makes music especially immersive. Watching sports can have a similar quality, but few other arts do, and none (save dance, with its obvious relation to music) so consistently combine music’s physicality with its rich formal structure and extended temporal dynamism.

 

 

最重要的现代美学理论家之一、康德之后的首选学术来源是出生于布拉格的哲学家和音乐评论家爱德华·汉斯利克 (Eduard Hanslick)，他于 1854 年写道：

One of the most important modern theorists of aesthetics, the go-to academic source after Kant, is the Prague-born philosopher and critic of music Eduard Hanslick, who wrote in 1854:

音乐是一种万花筒，尽管它表现在无与伦比的更高的理想水平上。音乐以更加复杂的多样性产生美丽的形式和色彩，温和地溢出，鲜明的对比，始终连贯，但又始终新颖，独立且自我实现。

Music is a kind of kaleidoscope, although it manifests itself on an incomparably higher level of ideality. Music produces beautiful forms and colors in ever more elaborate diversity, gently overflowing, sharply contrasted, always coherent and yet always new, self-contained and self-fulfilled.

 

我还没有看到更好的定义。音乐对于人类心灵来说是一场完美的风暴：形式优美、错综复杂、永远新鲜。

I have yet to see a better definition. Music is a perfect storm for the human mind: beautiful in form, intricate, and eternally new.

 

*重复有时适用于诗歌，但很少适用于散文。音乐煽动家约翰·凯奇曾经写过一篇演讲，其中一页重复了十四次，其中的副歌是“如果有人困了，就让他去睡觉吧”（凯奇，1961）。中途，艺术家让·雷纳尔站起来尖叫道：“约翰，我非常爱你，但我不能再忍受一分钟了。”

* Repetition sometimes works in poetry, but rarely in prose. The musical provocateur John Cage once wrote a lecture in which a single page was repeated fourteen times, with the refrain “If anybody is sleepy let him go to sleep” (Cage, 1961). Midway through, the artist Jean Reynal stood up and screamed, “John, I dearly love you, but I can’t bear another minute.”

 

不知道就知道

KNOWING WITHOUT KNOWING

 

缺乏专业知识时的快乐

Pleasure in the Absence of Expertise

 

在歌曲《(Get Up, I Feel Like Being a) Sex Machine》两分零两秒时，灵魂乐教父詹姆斯·布朗先生向他的管风琴演奏家兼伴唱鲍比·伯德 (Bobby Byrd) 提出了著名的问题：“我应该采取他们到桥上了吗？”

Two minutes and two seconds into the song “(Get Up, I Feel Like Being a) Sex Machine,” the Godfather of Soul, Mr. James Brown, famously asks his organ player and backup vocalist, Bobby Byrd, “Shall I take ’em to the bridge?”

根据我的 iTunes 库，我已经听过这首歌超过两打了，但直到最近我才明白 Brown 的意思。音乐，就像几乎所有的手工艺一样，有其词汇和专业知识，即使我对音乐的机制知之甚少，我也能欣赏这首歌。

According to my iTunes library, I’ve listened to the song over two dozen times, but until recently I had no idea what Brown meant. Music, like virtually all crafts, has its share of vocabulary and specialized knowledge, and I was able to enjoy the song even when I knew vanishingly little about the mechanics of music.

 

我现在意识到，布朗的桥梁是音乐性的，而不是物理性的。他告诉他的乐队成员演奏歌曲的下一部分。桥梁是一种过渡；这是一种新的音乐，与之前的音乐有所不同，但有助于推动歌曲向前发展；例如，一首具有 aaba 结构的歌曲中的b 。它减轻了听众因过多重复而带来的痛苦，但如果做得巧妙，它也为结局奠定了基础。

Brown’s bridge, as I now realize, was musical, not physical; he was telling his bandmates to bring on the next part of the song. A bridge is a kind of transition; it’s a new bit of music that differs from what came before but helps move the song forward; the b, for example, in a song that has an aaba structure. It relieves the listener of the agony that comes from too much repetition, yet, done skillfully, it also sets the stage for the finale.

 

有趣的是，听众不需要知道什么是桥才能欣赏音乐，就像魔术表演的观众不需要知道魔术师如何从他的魔术师中拉出兔子一样。帽子。人们可以在不了解张力、分辨率或高潮的情况下欣赏一部电影或小说，就像人们可以在不了解胶片、对比度或三分法则的情况下欣赏照片一样。我们大多数人只是消费者，而不是生产者，一般来说这没关系：我们理解并欣赏我们所看到和听到的大部分内容，即使我们自己无法生产它们。

The funny thing is, listeners don’t need to know what a bridge is in order to appreciate the music, any more than patrons of a magic show need to know the trick that allows a magician to pull a rabbit out of his hat. One can enjoy a movie or a novel without knowing anything about tension, resolution, or climax, just as one can enjoy a photograph without knowing anything about film, contrast ratios, or the rule of thirds. Most of us are just consumers, not producers, and generally that’s okay: we understand and appreciate much of what we see and hear, even if we can’t produce it ourselves.

 

甲壳虫乐队的《昨天》是另一个很好的例子，说明我们如何在不了解正在发生的事情的情况下欣赏巧妙的作曲。在我开始沉浸在乐理中之前，我已经把这首歌听了几百遍了，却没有意识到它对过去的怀念（“我所有的烦恼似乎都那么遥远”，“我不是我所使用的那个人的一半”） to be”）遵循上升的旋律线，而回到现在的陈述（“现在看起来它们似乎要留下来”）遵循下降的旋律。这种简洁的音乐结构无疑丰富了这首歌，但许多听众从未明确认识到它。

Another great example of how we can appreciate artful composition without recognizing what is going on comes from the Beatles’ “Yesterday.” Before I began immersing myself in music theory, I had listened to the song hundreds of times without once realizing that its statements of yearning for the past (“all my troubles seemed so far away,” “I’m not half the man I used to be”) follow ascending melody lines, while statements that return to the present (“Now it looks as though they’re here to stay”) follow descending melodies. That neat bit of musical architecture undoubtedly enriches the song, yet many listeners never recognize it explicitly.

 

电影观众不需要了解任何有关表演或叙事弧线的内容来欣赏电影，许多音乐听众甚至不知道音符的名称，更不用说古典奏鸣曲倾向于在电影中重复第二主题了。所谓的主调，或者说流行歌曲可以分为桥段和转折等成分。我们如何能够如此彻底地欣赏我们几乎无法表达的东西？

Movie viewers don’t need to know anything about acts or narrative arcs to appreciate film, and many music listeners don’t even know the names of the musical notes, let alone, say, that classical sonatas tend to repeat their second theme in the so-called tonic key, or that popular songs can be divided into components like bridges and turnarounds. How can we so thoroughly appreciate what we can barely articulate?

 

 

不过，这不仅仅是观众。有时，甚至表演者也无法明确阐明他们正在使用的工具。特雷·罗什 (Terre Roche) 向我讲述了她和姐姐玛吉 (Maggie) 第一次录制自己的音乐的经历。特雷当时只有十八岁，尽管她已经是一位颇有成就的音乐家，已经巡演了几年，甚至还为保罗·西蒙的专辑《There Goes Rhymin' Simon》演唱了一些和声，除了与西蒙的一次录音室会议之外，她几乎除了她的妹妹之外，从未与任何人一起表演过。突然，特雷和玛吉发现自己身处阿拉巴马州马斯尔肖尔斯的一间录音室，这里有传奇的马斯尔肖尔斯节奏组，这是一支由顶尖录音室音乐家组成的团队，他们与从珀西·斯莱奇、罗德·斯图尔特、滚石乐队到林纳德·斯金纳德等所有人一起录制了热门歌曲。和橡树岭男孩。有一次，当他们正在创作玛吉的歌曲“证明责任”时，钢琴演奏家巴里·贝克特转向特雷，并使用一种称为罗马数字或纳什维尔编号系统的通用惯例询问她，这首歌是否会转到“ IV 和弦”位于该节第一小节的后半部分。泰雷愣住了；她不知道什么是 IV 和弦。据她回忆：

It’s not just audiences, though. Sometimes even performers can’t explicitly articulate the tools that they are using. Terre Roche told me about the first time she and her older sister, Maggie, went to record their own music. Terre was just eighteen, and although she was already an accomplished musician who had been touring for several years, and had even sung some harmonies for Paul Simon’s album There Goes Rhymin’ Simon, aside from that one studio session with Simon she’d almost never performed with anyone other than her sister. Suddenly Terre and Maggie found themselves in a studio in Muscle Shoals, Alabama, with the legendary Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section, a team of top-notch studio musicians who recorded hits with everyone from Percy Sledge, Rod Stewart, and the Rolling Stones to Lynyrd Skynyrd and the Oak Ridge Boys. At one point, while they were working on Maggie’s song “Burden of Proof,” the piano player Barry Beckett turned to Terre and asked her, using a common convention known as the Roman numeral or Nashville numbering system, if the song went to “the IV chord” in the second half of the first measure of the verse. Terre froze; she had no idea what a IV chord was. As she recalls:

我只知道我正在弹奏 F 和弦。突然我觉得自己是这个房间里最愚蠢的人。我是房间里最年轻的人（只有二十一岁）而且……玛吉[和我]除了彼此之外从未和其他人一起玩过。回听这些曲目，我对我们在没有人告诉我们什么是 IV 和弦的情况下组合在一起的音乐感到惊讶。

All I knew was that I was playing an F chord. Suddenly I felt as if I was the stupidest person in the room. I was the youngest person in the room (just twenty-one) and … Maggie [and I] had never played with anyone else but each other. Listening back to those tracks, I am amazed at the music that we put together without anyone ever telling us what a IV chord was.

 

纳什维尔编号系统的要点是，它允许您独立于其调来描述歌曲。但词汇本身并不像它试图描述的音乐才能那么完整。

The point of the Nashville numbering system is that it allows you to describe a song independently of its key. But the vocabulary itself is not nearly as integral as the musicianship it seeks to describe.

 

大约一两年后，主要通过观看其他人演奏来学习的特雷看到一个女孩演奏一首歌，在歌曲的中间她突然跳到了吉他的第七或第八品格。特雷决定写一篇这样的文章，最终成为“先生”。Sellack”，收录在 Roches 的第一张唱片中（这张唱片被《纽约时报》评选为 1979 年年度专辑）。Terre 回忆道：“我用 D 调，弹奏我所知道的所有和弦，然后跳到更高的音品并尝试不同的形状。几年后，我得知我已经转到了 B 大调和弦，使我脱离了 D 调，而是演奏了导致 E 小调的次要属和弦。整体东西从 D 调走了一小段路，然后在桥的尽头找到了回来的路。当时我什至不知道‘桥梁’这个词是什么意思。”

Perhaps a year or two later, Terre, who had learned mainly by watching other people play, saw a girl play a song in which she suddenly jumped up to the seventh or eighth fret on the guitar in the middle of the song. Terre decided she’d write one like that, which ultimately became “Mr. Sellack,” featured on the first Roches record (the one the New York Times judged 1979 Album of the Year). As Terre recalls, “I was in the key of D, playing all of the chords I knew, then just jumped up to the higher frets and tried different shapes. Years later I learned that I had gone to a B major chord, taking me out of the key of D, but playing a secondary dominant leading to E minor. The whole thing took a little journey out of the key of D and found its way back in by the end of the bridge. At the time I didn’t even know what the term ‘bridge’ meant.”

 

几年后，情况发生了逆转。特雷最终对音乐理论产生了浓厚的兴趣，并且非常精通。她开始教授音乐理论并开始学习复杂的爵士乐和声课程。大约在同一时间，她发现自己和一位好朋友一起工作，这位朋友是一位才华横溢但完全没有受过教育的音乐家，能够在他的家庭工作室中完全通过耳朵复制整个海滩男孩和披头士乐队的唱片。有一天，他和泰雷正在创作他的一首歌，他希望泰雷以一种特殊的方式唱出一首和声，但泰雷不确定她的朋友是否真的想让她按照他的要求去做。“昨天你让我唱[我的音符]三度[高于你的]，”她说，试图澄清，“现在你想让我唱第九度，”在C大调中，九度相距而不是三个。她的朋友有何反应？“你为什么不把你一直在做的所有书本知识都塞进去，然后唱那该死的歌呢！”

Some years later, the tables were turned. Terre eventually became deeply interested— and deeply fluent— in music theory; she began teaching music theory and started taking courses in complex jazz harmonies. At around the same time, she found herself working with a good friend who was a talented yet totally unschooled musician, capable of reproducing entire Beach Boys and Beatles records in his home studio entirely by ear. One day he and Terre were working on one of his songs, and he wanted Terre to sing a harmony in a particular way, but Terre wasn’t sure that her friend had really meant for her to do what he was asking. “Yesterday you told me to sing [my note at a] third [above yours],” she said, attempting to clarify, “and now you want me on the ninth,” which in C major would be nine keys apart rather than three. Her friend’s response? “Why don’t you just shove all that book learning you’ve been doing and just sing the friggin’ song!”

 

正如作曲家兼数学家德米特里·蒂莫茨科 (Dmitri Tymoczko) 所说：

As the composer and mathematician Dmitri Tymoczko has put it:

 

在作曲时，我对和弦、音阶、节奏和乐器做出各种选择，以创造紧张、放松、恐怖和狂喜的感觉，以回忆作品中的早期时刻或预测后来的事件。但我一般不希望听众有意识地跟踪这些选择。这样做的听众（“哦，长号中不和谐的#9和弦，与长笛相对应的复节奏，并反转了乐曲的开头音符！”）就像职业魔术师在观看彼此的表演——充其量只是从事一种不同的表演。欣赏，最坏的情况是，他们太投入智力，无法深入地享受音乐。

When composing, I make various choices about chords, scales, rhythm, and instrumentation to create feelings of tension, relaxation, terror, and ecstasy, to recall earlier moments in the piece or anticipate later events. But I do not in general expect listeners to be consciously tracking these choices. Listeners who do (“ooh, a dissonant #9 chord in the trombones, in polyrhythm against the flutes and inverting the opening notes of the piece!”) are like professional magicians watching each other’s routines— at best, engaged in a different sort of appreciation, and, at worst too intellectually engaged to enjoy the music as deeply as they might.

 

简而言之，音乐理论的形式元素有其用途，但人们当然可以在没有它们的情况下欣赏甚至演奏音乐。

In short, the formal elements of music theory have their uses, but one can certainly appreciate— and even play— music without them.

 

 

20 世纪 90 年代初，法国认知心理学家 Emmanuel Bigand 开始寻找专家和新手听音乐方式的差异。那时已经有大量关于新手和专家对音高和节奏的基本敏感性的文献。简而言之，专家的耳朵对细粒度的细节更敏感；当某些东西稍微跑调时，他们更容易注意到，并且（如前所述）能够更好地准确识别两个音符之间的距离。专家还可以更快地发现节奏中的偏差，并且他们通常可以识别和弦中的各个音符，这是新手很少（如果有的话）可以做到的。

In the early 1990s, a French cognitive psychologist named Emmanuel Bigand set out to find the differences between experts and novices in how they listened to music. There was at that point already a sizable literature on the basic sensitivity of novices and experts to pitch and rhythm. Simply put, experts’ ears are more sensitive to fine-grained details; they are more prone to noticing when something is slightly out of key and (as mentioned earlier) better able to recognize precisely how far apart two notes are. Experts are also quicker to detect deviations in a rhythm, and they can often identify the individual notes in a chord, something that novices can rarely, if ever, do.

但比甘德的很多发现都令人惊讶。他期望能发现音乐家和非音乐家之间的巨大差异，但在许多情况下却发现非音乐家知道的东西远远超出任何人的预期。文献中的常用术语区分了专家和新手，但比甘德最终开始意识到，他的所有成年受试者，无论是否受过训练，都是某种专家：他们都​​是专家听众。

But a lot of what Bigand found was surprising. He went in expecting to find huge differences between musicians and nonmusicians but instead in many cases discovered that nonmusicians knew far more than anyone could ever have anticipated. The usual terminology in this literature distinguishes between experts and novices, but Bigand eventually started to realize that all of his adult subjects, trained or otherwise, were experts of a sort: they were all expert listeners.

 

比甘​​德开始意识到，即使没有接受过音乐训练，普通听众也会隐含地了解音乐形式结构的许多方面。未经训练的听众不一定能够清楚地表达这些知识；专业音乐家通常可以比普通听众更精确地描述歌曲中的内容。专业音乐家显然（根据定义）比非音乐家更有能力创作音乐。用伟大的棒球传奇人物约吉·贝拉的话来说，“只要倾听，你就能听到很多东西。”

Even without musical training, Bigand began to realize, the average listener comes to know implicitly many aspects of the formal structure of music. Untrained listeners won’t necessarily be able to articulate that knowledge; professional musicians can often describe what’s going on in a song with far more precision than mere listeners can. And professional musicians are obviously (by definition) much more capable of producing music than nonmusicians are. To paraphrase the great baseball legend Yogi Berra, “You can hear an awful lot, just by listening.”

 

例如，比甘德的第一个研究集中于雷·杰肯多夫（Ray Jackendoff）和他的合作者弗雷德·勒达尔（Fred Lerdahl）提出的理论，旨在了解成熟的听众如何解读复杂的作品。这个想法是，在任何给定的作品中，一些音符都会出现比其他人更集中；如果你是一位爵士萨克斯管演奏家，即兴改变《Over the Rainbow》中的旋律，一些音符可能会被安全地改变，而对其他音符的​​修改可能会让听众摸不着头脑。比甘​​德对勒达尔和杰肯多夫关于哪些音符至关重要的理论进行了实验测试，发现专业音乐家的行为或多或少与勒达尔和杰肯多夫的预测一致。但非专家也是如此。普通听众似乎与专家有着大致相同的直觉，只是形式不太精确。此后，比甘德进行了数十项其他研究，着眼于音乐的各个方面，例如解析度（乐曲是否返回到基调），并发现了大致相同的模式：专家总是比非专家更好，但非专家专家们的表现总是比单纯的运气要好得多。新手可能无法说出乐曲的具体音调，但缺乏正规训练的经验丰富的听众仍然可以分辨出乐曲何时违反了规则。其他研究表明，非音乐家在从简短摘录中识别作品情感的能力上几乎与受过训练的音乐家一样好，而未经训练的听众通常可以在学习识别新作品方面做得相当可靠。

For instance, one of Bigand’s first studies focused on a theory that had been introduced by Ray Jackendoff and his collaborator Fred Lerdahl, aimed at understanding how sophisticated listeners interpreted complex pieces. The idea was that in any given piece, some notes figure more centrally than others; if you were a jazz saxophonist improvising changes to the melody in “Over the Rainbow,” some notes might be safely changed, whereas modifications to others might leave the listeners scratching their heads. Bigand set up an experimental test of Ler dahl and Jackendoff’s theory about which notes were critical and found that expert musicians more or less behaved as Lerdahl and Jackendoff had predicted. But so did the non-experts; ordinary listeners seemed to have much the same intuitions, if in less precise form, as the experts. After that, Bigand conducted dozens of other studies— looking at aspects of music such as resolution (whether a composition returns to the root of a key)—and found much the same pattern: experts were invariably better than non-experts, but non-experts always did a lot better than mere chance. A novice might not be able to say which particular key a musical piece was in, but experienced listeners who lacked formal training could still tell when a musical composition broke the rules. Other studies showed that nonmusicians were often nearly as good as trained musicians in their capacity to recognize the emotion of a piece from a brief excerpt, and that untrained listeners could often do a fairly credible job of learning to recognize new pieces.

 

从神经角度看待同一问题，比甘德发现了进一步的证据，表明未经训练的听众能够提取出音乐背后的大量结构。正如他所说，虽然受过音乐训练的听众和未经音乐训练的听众之间确实存在差异，但“人类的大脑已经通过日常生活经验对音乐进行了强化训练：在音乐学校增加补充训练可以使获得特定技能（例如阅读表）成为可能。”音乐或命名音程]对于成为专业音乐家来说必不可少，但[正规训练]并不是决定人类音乐能力的因素。”

Looking at the same question from a neural perspective, Bigand found still further evidence that untrained listeners were able to extract a great deal of the structure that underlies music. As he put it, although there are surely differences between musically trained listeners and untrained listeners, “the human brain is already intensively trained to music through everyday life experience: adding supplementary training in music schools makes it possible to acquire specific skills [like reading sheet music or naming musical intervals] indispensable to be professional musicians, but [formal training] is not what determines the musical ability of human beings.”

 

倾听是让我们进入游戏的第一步。

Listening is what first gets us into the game.

 

 

20 世纪 70 年代末，两位认知心理学家理查德·尼斯贝特 (Richard Nisbett) 和蒂莫西·威尔逊 (Timothy Wilson) 写了一篇开创性的论文，名为《讲述超出我们所能知道的》，该论文回顾了数十项研究，表明人类往往不知道他们为什么做他们所做的事情。有时，一个人有可能准确地表达出他或她在做什么以及为什么这样做，但普通人也很可能在没有特别清楚地意识到他们为什么要做他们所做的事情的情况下采取行动，并在事后证明自己的行为是合理的。事实，而不是事先考虑清楚。在一项著名的研究中，数百名购物者被要求查看一系列尼龙丝袜，并决定他们最喜欢哪一款。受试者倾向于从左到右浏览这一系列的袜子，并且，比机会更频繁地选择最右边的一双长袜。没有一个受试者提到职位作为他们做出选择的理由，当职位被提供作为解释时，每个人都否认它发挥了任何作用；事实上，人们往往倾向于选择最后的选择，因为最后的选择最容易记住。

In the late 1970s, two cognitive psychologists, Richard Nisbett and Timothy Wilson, wrote a groundbreaking paper— still worth reading thirty years later— called “Telling More Than We Can Know,” which reviewed dozens of studies showing that human beings often have no idea why they do the things they do. It is possible, occasionally, for a human being to articulate exactly what he or she is doing and exactly why, but it’s also eminently possible for average people to act without any particularly clear awareness of why they do what they do, justifying their actions after the fact, rather than thinking them through beforehand. In one famous study, hundreds of shoppers were asked to look at an array of nylon stockings and decide which they liked the best. Subjects tended to browse the array from left to right and, far more often than chance would allow, chose the pair of stockings farthest to the right. None of the subjects mentioned position as a reason for making their choice, and when position was offered as an explanation, everyone denied it played any role; in reality, people often tend to take the last choice simply because whatever comes last is easiest to remember.

我们对大脑内部运作的缺乏认识同样延伸到了许多体育运动中。例如，在棒球比赛中接住飞球的动作可以通过微积分和切线的复杂组合来计算，但是有成千上万的少年棒球联盟成员尚未参加微积分课程，但仍然设法接住飞球正好。仅仅因为音乐家的行为可以用音乐理论的抽象数学术语来描述，并不意味着音乐家需要明确地意识到这些抽象。

Our lack of awareness of our brain’s internal operations similarly extends to many athletic endeavors. The act of catching a fly ball in baseball, for example, can be calculated in terms of a complex stew of calculus and tangent lines, but there are thousands of Little Leaguers who have yet to take a calculus class and still manage to catch fly balls just fine. Just because the actions of a musician can be described in the abstract mathematical terms of music theory doesn’t mean the musician needs to be explicitly aware of those abstractions.

 

 

哲学家有时会区分“知道如何”和“知道那个”。知道如何做某事（有时称为肌肉记忆（实际上是大脑中的一种记忆））与能够解释自己在做什么之间是有区别的。

Philosophers sometimes distinguish between “knowing how” and “knowing that.” There’s a difference between knowing how to do some thing, sometimes referred to as muscle memory (really a kind of memory in the brain), and being able to explain what you are doing.

大脑使用不同的系统来编码事实和编码行为。存储在陈述性记忆中的事实与大脑中称为内侧颞叶（以海马形状的海马体为中心）的部分以及（在它们固化后）与颞叶和额叶皮质相关联。行动程序（我之前所说的“自动化”并不总是有意识地可访问的产物）在很大程度上与程序性记忆相关，程序性记忆被编码在以小脑和基底神经节等结构为中心的循环中。正式音乐知识和实际音乐技能脱钩的原因之一是大脑处理两者的方式根本不同。陈述性知识已针对意识知识进行了优化；程序性知识已经针对意识不一定能够获得的快速反应进行了优化。

The brain uses distinct systems for encoding facts and for encoding actions. Facts, stored in declarative memory, have been associated with a section of the brain known as the medial temporal lobe (centered on the seahorse-shaped hippocampus) and (after they have firmed up) with the temporal and frontal cortices. Action programs (the not always consciously accessible product of what I referred to earlier as “automatization”) are largely associated with procedural memory, encoded in a loop that centers on structures such as the cerebellum and the basal ganglia. One reason for the decoupling of formal musical knowledge and practical musical skill is that the two are treated by the brain in fundamentally different ways. Declarative knowledge has been optimized for conscious knowledge; procedural knowledge has been optimized for rapid reflexes that aren’t necessarily accessible to consciousness.

 

如果我们有时发现很难有意识地表达我们的肌肉在做什么，那是因为滋养我们有意识思维的记忆在很大程度上与控制我们肌肉的记忆是分开的。只有经过大量有意识的努力和反思，人们才能真正学会在两者之间流畅地来回穿梭。

If we sometimes find it hard to consciously articulate what our muscles are doing, it’s because the memories that feed our conscious thoughts are largely separate from those that control our muscles. It is only with considerable conscious effort and reflection that one can really learn to traffic back and forth fluidly between the two.

 

比尔·埃文斯 (Bill Evans) 是二十世纪最有影响力的钢琴家之一，最著名的也许是他在迈尔斯·戴维斯 (Miles Davis) 的《那又怎样》(So What) 中的钢琴独奏。和弦的发声。埃文斯部分借鉴了德彪西和拉威尔等印象派作曲家的经验，开始尝试对和弦进行更宽松的解释，省略音符，随着时间的推移延长音符，穿插其他音符，同时仍保留整体风味。当时，没有其他人能够弄清楚埃文斯在做什么，埃文斯本人可能也很难完全阐明他的技术。就连埃文斯的弟弟哈利（一位著名的钢琴家）最初也感到困惑。

Bill Evans, one of the most influential pianists of the twentieth century, most famous perhaps for his piano solo on Miles Davis’s “So What,” first made his mark largely by changing the composition of the chords he played, altering what are known as the voicings of a chord. Drawing partly on impressionist composers like Debussy and Ravel, Evans began to experiment with looser interpretations of chords, omitting notes, extending them over time, interspersing others while still retaining the overall flavor. At the time, nobody else could figure out what Evans was doing, and Evans himself might have been hard-pressed to fully articulate his techniques. Even Evans’s own brother Harry, who was a well-known pianist, was initially puzzled.

 

尽管比尔一定对自己在做什么有所了解，但他所做的大部分都是程序性的；他的肌肉和基底神经节知道如何创造这些新颖的和弦发声，但在早期在他的实验阶段，知识尚未转化为陈述性事实。但最终，有人确实弄清楚了埃文斯在做什么，而且事情并没有复杂到其他人无法理解的程度；相反，一旦翻译完成，“比尔·埃文斯的和弦声部”就成为爵士乐课程的标准部分和每个爵士乐钢琴家的工具箱。那个特殊案例中发生的事情并不少见。即兴创作者通过单独的感觉来进行创新，只有在后来这些创新才被编入可以明确编码为陈述性知识的理论中。在这种情况下，音乐理论的真正优点不是开辟新天地，而是提供一种与其他音乐家分享发现的语言。

Although Bill must have had some idea of what he was doing, the bulk of what he was doing was procedural; his muscles and basal ganglia knew how to create these novel chord voicings, but in the early stages of his experimentation that knowledge had yet to be translated into declarative facts. Eventually, though, someone did figure out what Evans was doing, and it wasn’t so complicated that nobody else could understand it; instead, once the translation was made, “Bill Evans’s Chord Voicings” became a standard part of the jazz curriculum and a tool in every jazz pianist’s kit. What happened in that particular case is not uncommon; improvisers work out innovations by feel alone, and only later do those innovations get codified into theory that can be explicitly encoded into declarative knowledge. The real virtue of music theory in a case like that is not to forge new ground but to provide a language for sharing discoveries with other musicians.

 

事实上，很多爵士乐都是将陈述性与程序性相结合。爵士钢琴家玛丽莲·克里斯佩尔（Marilyn Crispell）经常与伟大的塞西尔·泰勒（Cecil Taylor）相提并论，她也是安东尼·布拉克斯顿（Anthony Braxton）乐队的长期成员，她向我解释说，在她的即兴创作中，她经常将一首作品的整体框架或方向的有意识的、明确的知识与一种无意识的知识结合起来。立即演奏。我无意中听到帕特·梅瑟尼也表达过同样的看法。在某种程度上，古典乐曲可以通过纯粹的死记硬背（完全依靠程序性知识）来演奏得相当好，很多摇滚乐也可以，但令人满意的爵士乐几乎总是需要一种混合。一方面，爵士乐演奏者必须高度依赖高度练习的习惯，这些习惯使音乐家能够快速提升音阶或以其他方式演奏闪电般的连复段。另一方面，要真正引人注目，爵士乐音乐家还必须以计划、想法和概念的形式整合陈述性知识——这些模式有助于塑造作品并产生音乐，正如克里斯佩尔所说，感觉“是作曲的，而不是只是即兴创作的。”

A lot of jazz, in fact, is about blending the declarative with the procedural. The jazz pianist Marilyn Crispell, often compared to the great Cecil Taylor, and longtime member of Anthony Braxton’s group, explained to me that in her improvisations she often blends conscious, explicit knowledge of the overall frame or direction of a piece with a kind of unconscious playing in the immediate moment. I’ve overheard Pat Metheny express much the same. To some degree, classical compositions can be played fairly well by sheer rote (drawing entirely on procedural knowledge), and a lot of rock can, too, but satisfying jazz almost always requires a kind of mixture. On the one hand, the jazz player must depend heavily on highly practiced habits that allow the musician to rapidly ascend scales or otherwise play lightning-fast riffs. On the other hand, to be truly compelling, jazz musicians must also integrate declarative knowledge in the form of plans, ideas, and concepts—schemas that help shape a piece and yield music that, as Crispell put it, feels “composed, and not merely improvised.”

 

古典也曾经是这样的。例如，巴赫是一位传奇的即兴演奏家，能够即兴创作四声部赋格曲。直到十九世纪，即兴创作的精神开始消退，取而代之的是对经典伟大作曲家的正统诠释，古典传统的表演者经常即兴创作，尤其是在被称为华彩乐段的部分——现代吉他独奏的先驱，充满了快速、精湛的段落。将整篇文章逐条写下来并用标记进行充分注释的想法是一个相对较新的传统。从全球和历史的角度来看，爵士乐背后的即兴冲动是常态而不是例外。最好的玩家可能总是那些能够将陈述性和有意识与自动和无意识结合起来的人。

Classical used to be this way, too. Bach, for example, was a legendary improviser, capable of creating four-part fugues on the fly. And until the nineteenth century, when the spirit of improvisation began to fade in favor of orthodox interpretations of canonized great composers, performers in the classical tradition improvised frequently, especially in the sections known as cadenzas— forerunners to modern guitar solos, filled with fast, virtuosic passages. The idea of an entire piece being written out note for note, fully annotated with markings, is a relatively recent tradition. In global and historical perspective, the improvisational impulse behind jazz is the norm rather than the exception. And the best players have probably always been those who could mix the declarative and conscious with the automatic and unconscious.

 

 

在现实的吉他世界中，有时音乐家甚至不知道他们正在演奏的和弦的名称。

In the real world of guitar, sometimes musicians don’t even know the names of the chords they are playing.

也许有史以来最容易用吉他弹奏的歌曲是美国的“一匹无名的马”。这首歌只有两个和弦，而且都很容易演奏，只需用两根手指放在按动的手上即可。

Perhaps the easiest song ever to play on guitar is America’s “A Horse with No Name.” There are only two chords in the song, and both are easy to play, requiring just two fingers each on the fretting hand.

 

两个和弦之一是常见的E小调和弦，其中中指和食指按住第四弦和第五弦的第二音品。另一个是晦涩难懂但同样容易玩的；吉他手不再按住第四弦和第五弦的第二个音品，而是改为按住第三弦和第六弦的第二个音品——仍然是两个手指，几乎不涉及任何动作（正如任何吉他手意识到的那样，所需的动作越少） ， 更好）。

One of the two chords is the common E minor chord, in which the middle and index fingers hold down the second frets of the fourth and fifth strings. The other is obscure but equally easy to play; instead of holding down the second frets of the fourth and fifth strings, the guitarist switches to holding down the second frets of the third and sixth string—still two fingers, and hardly any motion involved (and as any guitarist realizes, the less motion required, the better).

 

但是第二和弦叫什么？您不会在前四十个最常见和弦的任何列表中找到它。正如吉他手兼贝斯手 David Hodge 指出的那样，另一个和弦可能有大约五个不同的名称，其中没有一个是普通吉他手所熟悉的。您可以将“无名之马”中的第二和弦称为Dadd6add9、F#dim7（加6）或F#m7（无5）（加4）（加6）；您也可以将其视为 E11 或 Bm11。但这首歌的作者杜威·邦内尔 (Dewey Bunnell) 很可能没有用这些术语来思考和弦；更有可能的是，他只是在指板上闲逛，一旦他偶然发现了Dadd6add9（或者无论你喜欢怎么称呼它），他就明智地相信自己的耳朵，即使他无法用确切的技术术语解释他所创造的东西。

But what is the second chord called? You won’t find it in any list of the top forty most common chords. As the guitarist and bass player David Hodge points out, the other chord could go by about five different names, not one of which would be familiar to the average guitarist. You could call the second chord in “A Horse with No Name” a Dadd6add9, an F#dim7 (add 6), or an F#m7 (no 5)(add 4)(add 6); you could also think of it as E11 or Bm11. But the guy who wrote the song— Dewey Bunnell— quite likely didn’t think of the chord in any of those terms; more likely, he was just fooling around on the fretboard, and once he stumbled onto the Dadd6add9 (or whatever you prefer to call it), he had the good sense to trust his ears, even if he couldn’t explain in exact technical terms what he had created.

 

 

20 世纪 90 年代中期，记者丹尼尔·戈尔曼 (Daniel Goleman) 写了一本颇具影响力的书，名为《情商》( Emotional Intelligence)，该书认为，智力不仅仅只是在智商测试中看到的解决谜题的方式。戈尔曼认为，人们的社交和情感悟性对于职业成功与他们的原始分析智力同样重要。毫无疑问，社会和情感洞察力对音乐也很重要。

In the mid-1990s, the journalist Daniel Goleman wrote an influential book called Emotional Intelligence, which argued that there was more to intelligence than the sort of puzzle solving you’d see in an IQ test; Goleman argued that people’s social and emotional savvy was as important to professional success as their raw analytical intelligence. There can be little doubt that social and emotional insight matters for music, too.

戈尔曼借用了一位朋友的故事来说明情商，而这位朋友恰好是第一批前往日本学习武术的美国人之一。在一个特定的下午，戈尔曼的朋友发现自己在东京的地铁上，一名醉酒且充满敌意的乘客上了车。醉汉开始尖叫，并最终向其他乘客挥拳。最后，戈尔曼的朋友受够了。他站起来，做好战斗准备。但还没等他加入战斗，一名穿着和服的老者就高兴地喊道：“嘿！” 仿佛他遇见了一位老朋友。通过惊吓醉汉，老人推迟了即将发生的暴力事件。

Goleman illustrates emotional intelligence with a story he borrowed from a friend who happened to be one of the first Americans to journey to Japan to study martial arts. On one particular afternoon Goleman’s friend found himself on a subway in Tokyo when a drunk and hostile passenger got on. The drunk started screaming— and eventually taking swings— at the other passengers. Finally, Goleman’s friend had had enough; he stood up and steeled himself for battle. But before he could enter the fray, an old man dressed in a kimono cheerily shouted “Hey!” as if he had spotted an old friend. By startling the drunk, the old man postponed the imminent violence.

 

“我到底为什么要和你说话？” 醉汉问道。

“Why the hell should I talk to you?” the drunk asked.

 

老人没有回答，而是提出了一个问题：“你喝了什么？” 当醉汉说“清酒吧，这不关你的事”时，老人开始扭转局面。“哦，那太棒了，绝对棒极了，”他说。“你看，我也喜欢清酒。每天晚上，我和我的妻子（她已经七十六岁了，你知道），我们都会加热一小瓶清酒，然后把它带到花园里，然后坐在一张旧木凳上。” 画一幅柿子树的画老人在他的院子里思考着清酒的本质，补充道：“是的，我相信你也有一个很棒的妻子”——此时，醉汉剩余的所有攻击性都消失了。

The old man replied not with an answer but with a question, “What’cha been drinking?” When the drunk said “Sake, and it’s none of your business,” the old man began to turn things around. “Oh, that’s wonderful, absolutely wonderful,” he said. “You see, I love sake, too. Every night, me and my wife (she’s seventy-six, you know), we warm up a little bottle of sake and take it out into the garden, and we sit on an old wooden bench.” Painting a picture of the persimmon tree in his yard and pondering the nature of sake, the old man added, “Yes, and I’m sure you have a wonderful wife, too”—at which point all the drunk’s remaining aggression melted away.

 

“不，”醉汉哀嚎道，“我的妻子死了。。。”。很快，醉汉开始抽泣，解释他是如何失去妻子、工作和家庭的。最后，醉汉把头枕在老人的腿上。

“No,” wailed the drunk, “my wife died. . . .” Soon the drunk was sobbing, explaining how he had lost his wife, his job, and his home; by the end, the drunk had cradled his head in the old man’s lap.

 

在化解局势的过程中，老人表现出了惊人的情商掌控能力，即认知科学家通常所说的“直觉心理学”或“心理理论”，即解读（和预测）他人信念、欲望和需求的艺术。真正最重要的是直觉心理学，而不是音乐理论的正式工具：表演者（或作曲家、作曲家或艺术家）预测作品对观众的吸引力并计算出的能力。找出如何让观众分享某种情绪或感受。也许老板布鲁斯·斯普林斯汀说得最好：

In defusing the situation, the old man displayed a spectacular command of emotional intelligence— or what cognitive scientists often call “intuitive psychology” or “theory of mind,” the art of reading (and anticipating) the beliefs and desires and needs of others. And it is that intuitive psychology, more than the formal apparatus of music theory, that really matters most: the ability of a performer (or songwriter or composer or artist) to anticipate the pull that a work will have on its audience, and to figure out how to get that audience to share in some mood or feeling. Perhaps the Boss, Bruce Springsteen, said it best:

 

我写作时总是考虑到观众。如果我感觉到[联系]回到我身边，那么我就会觉得我正在做我的工作。这就是为什么人们听我的音乐——为了某种情感体验或观点，无论是对自己的生活，还是对他们所生活的世界。

I always write with an audience in mind. If I feel that [connection] coming back at me then I feel like I’m doing my job. That’s why people come to my music— for some emotional experience or a perspective, either on their own lives, or on the world that they’re living in.

 

 

我遇到过的关于歌曲创作艺术的一些最好、最深入的讨论是由作家兼词曲作者保罗·佐洛（Paul Zollo）进行的采访。在其中一篇文章中，佐洛采访了詹姆斯·泰勒，在问了一些简单的问题后，开始深入研究音乐理论的高级主题，向泰勒询问一些技术问题，例如减和弦和十二音阶，这些元素可能超出了普通流行歌星的范围。

Some of the best, most in-depth discussions on the art of songwriting I have ever encountered have been interviews conducted by the author and songwriter Paul Zollo. In one, Zollo interviews James Taylor and after some easy questions starts delving deeply into advanced topics in music theory, asking Taylor questions about technicalities such as diminished chords and twelve-tone scales, elements that might lie outside the average pop star’s range.

然而，泰勒并不担心，并且毫不费力地跟上。例如，他解释说，他从保罗·西蒙那里学会了如何使用减和弦是一种“逃离旋律或和声环境并跳入另一个环境”的方式。

Taylor, however, is unfazed and has no trouble keeping up. He explains, for example, that he learned from Paul Simon how to use diminished chords as a way of “escaping from a melody, or from [one] harmonic sort of context and jumping into another one.”

 

从那里泰勒转向他的前导师保罗·麦卡特尼，并讨论了麦卡特尼在“米歇尔”中演奏的不寻常和弦：

From there Taylor moves on to his former mentor Paul McCartney, and a discussion of an unusual chord McCartney played in “Michelle”:

 

保罗说这是[他和约翰]唯一知道的爵士和弦。他们曾经去利物浦的一家唱片店，那里有人弹吉他，他向保罗和约翰展示了这个[不寻常的]和弦。因此，“米歇尔”中“ma belle”下的第二和弦是一个非常不可能的和弦。……你不会想到会看到它。

Paul said that was the only jazz chord [he and John] knew. They used to go down to a record store in Liverpool and there was somebody there who played guitar and he showed Paul and John this [unusual] chord. So the second chord in “Michelle,” under “ma belle,” that second chord is a very unlikely chord. … And you wouldn’t expect to see it.

 

……但是，天哪，他（保罗）把一个球弹到另一个球上的方式。它真的非常像立体主义……它用简单的线条表达了如此多的[情感]。

… But, boy, the way he [Paul] bounces one onto another. It’s really very much like cubism … it represents so much [emotion] in just a simple line.

这就是音乐的意义所在。真正重要的不是你知道多少和弦，而是你如何使用你所知道的和弦。

And that’s what music is all about. What really matters is not how many chords you know, but how you use the ones you do know.

 

 

发挥极限

TAKE IT TO THE LIMIT

 

专家知道而新手不知道的事情

What Experts Know That Novices Don’t

 

帕蒂·史密斯 (Patti Smith) 的长期吉他手莱尼·凯 (Lenny Kaye) 对我说，关于吉他，你“必须让它成为你的朋友”。他这话是什么意思？让它成为你的朋友是否意味着要花成千上万的时间与它相处？这是否意味着了解并庆祝其能力以及它们如何补充您自己的能力？或者这是否意味着在它面前做你自己？什么是专业音乐家知道而新手不知道的？

The thing about guitar, Lenny Kaye, longtime guitarist for Patti Smith, said to me, is that you “have to make it your friend.” What did he mean by that? Did making it your friend mean spending thousands upon thousands of hours with it? Did it mean knowing and celebrating its capabilities and how they complement your own? Or did it mean being yourself in its presence? What do expert musicians know that novices don’t?

当我试图在音乐世界中开辟自己的小角落时，我很快意识到这个问题的答案有多少音乐家就有多少。虽然我遇到的几乎每位专家都知道一些我显然不知道的事情，比如如何保持稳定的节拍，但专家之间以及他们的专业知识之间存在巨大差异。有些人能读懂乐谱，但很多人不能。有些人可以玩得非常快，有些人则不能。有些人对他们之前的音乐历史有百科全书式的了解，另一些人对他们自己想要创作的音乐只有直观的概念。

As I sought to carve out my own tiny corner in the musical world, I soon realized that there are as many answers to this question as there are musicians. While just about every expert I met knew some things that I clearly didn’t, like how to hold a steady beat, there was enormous variation between the experts, and in their expertise. Some could read music, many couldn’t. Some could play blisteringly fast, others not. Some had an encyclopedic knowledge of the history of the music that preceded them, others only an intuitive notion of the music they themselves wanted to create.

 

 

专业知识始于对细节的敏锐鉴赏力。我不止一次看到一屋子的音乐家争论单个音符的持续时间或响度。这种精确和种类的专业知识不仅在于音乐家，还在于音响工程师和制作人，他们帮助音乐家将原始录音转化为成品。在我们对声音的感知中，就像在我们对视觉世界的感知中一样，大脑没有绝对的规则。相反，它常常依赖于上下文，有时会被愚弄。当然，音乐家、工程师和制作人都非常了解这一点。

Expertise begins with a fine appreciation for detail. More than once I’ve seen a roomful of musicians argue about the duration or loudness of a single note. Expertise of this precision and kind lies not just with musicians but with sound engineers and producers, who help musicians transform raw recordings into finished products. In our perceptions of sound, as in our perceptions of the visual world, the brain has no absolute rules; instead, it often relies on context and sometimes gets fooled. Musicians, engineers, and producers, of course, know this all too well.

在一次会议中，我旁听了丽贝卡·切里（Rebecca Cherry）（一位出色的小提琴家，曾与坎耶·韦斯特（Kanye West）一起演奏）、戴夫·索尔迪尔（Dave Soldier）（他除了创作“最想要的”和“最不想要的”歌曲外，还为大卫创作了弦乐部分） Byrne）和 Rory Young（格莱美奖获奖制作人兼工程师）共同制作了一张名为The Complete Victrola Sessions的专辑。该项目的创意在于，整张专辑是最近才出土的，这是一首最初录制于 1914 年的艺术大师钢琴音乐。该项目将作为一部 Winsome Brown 短片的配乐，由 Cherry 女士主演，她扮演一位俄罗斯小提琴家，在纽约市巡演时成为鸦片瘾君子。

In one session I sat in on, Rebecca Cherry (a fantastic violinist who has played with Kanye West), Dave Soldier (who, aside from his work on the “most wanted” and “least wanted” songs, has composed string sections for David Byrne), and Rory Young (a Grammy Award– winning producer and engineer) worked together on an album that was to be called The Complete Victrola Sessions. The conceit of the project was that the whole album was recently unearthed, a piece of virtuoso piano music originally recorded in 1914. The project would serve as a score for a short Winsome Brown film, starring Ms. Cherry, who plays a Russian violinist who becomes an opium addict while touring in New York City.

 

每首歌曲长四、五、六分钟——悲伤的慢歌《Mata Hari，Ballerina de Java》、对布吉伍吉先锋米德·勒克斯·刘易斯(Meade Lux Lewis)的欢快致敬，等等——都被一遍又一遍地播放和仔细审视。对于音乐家们精致的耳朵来说，绝对没有什么是完美的。对我来说听起来绝对不错的段落——甚至令人难以置信——却引起了人们的皱眉。是不是那里呼吸太多了？事实证明，小提琴手的呼吸（消灭这个想法）和麦克风（诅咒他们的愚蠢）很难区分小提琴手的呼气声和轻轻调制的弓的扬声。短语之间有足够的空间吗？或者应该插入歌曲其他部分的休止符？“我可以把它弄黑，”罗里有一次提出，或者“我们可以找到一些我们喜欢的其他沉默。”

Each song, four or five or six minutes long— the sad slow song “Mata Hari, Ballerina de Java,” a bouncy tribute to the boogie-woogie pioneer Meade Lux Lewis, and so forth— was played over and over and scrutinized intensely. To the musicians’ refined ears, absolutely nothing was perfect; passages that sounded absolutely fine to me— even incredible— drew scowls. Was there too much breathing there? Violinists, it turns out, breathe (perish the thought), and microphones (curse their stupidity) have trouble discriminating between the exhalation of a violinist and the exaltations of a gently modulating bow. Was there enough space between the phrases? Or should a rest from another part of the song be inserted? “I could make it dark,” Rory offered at one point, or “we could find some other silence we like.”

 

另一次谈话涉及弓在小提琴上弹起时发出的几乎听不见的撞击声。戴夫此时静静地坐着，读一本关于蓝草发明者比尔·门罗的书时，她似乎很平静，但丽贝卡（她的弓在弹跳）却不太确定。罗里说：“我可以解决这个问题，但听起来可能太完美了。” 最终，罗里的论点占了上风，微妙的反弹依然存在。每个人都同意，我们的目标不是制作完美的录音，而是制作人性化的录音。过了一会儿，在另一点上，丽贝卡被说服了，宣称：“我喜欢这个脏一点的。” 有了现代技术，选择权就在他们手中。

Another conversation concerned a barely audible thud, as the bow bounced against the violin. Dave, who at this point was sitting quietly, reading a book about the bluegrass inventor Bill Monroe, seemed unperturbed, but Rebecca (whose bow was doing the bouncing) wasn’t so sure. Rory said, “I could fix that— but it might sound too perfect.” Ultimately, Rory’s argument held the day, and the subtle bounce remained. The goal, everyone agreed, was to make not a perfect recording but a human one. A moment later, on another point, Rebecca, by then convinced, declared, “I like this bit dirtier.” With modern technology, the choice was theirs.

 

另一个时候，丽贝卡出声问道：“嗯——我很喜欢第一段的声音，但我不太喜欢这（第二段）的声音。” 罗里（Rory）在制作方面和许多表演方面一样都是专家，他立即尖声说道：“有一件事是，背景非常不同。由于[小提琴]本身[在这里]，这显然会产生很大的差异。你必须把它填得更多，让它更加自给自足。而另一件事必须以某种方式与钢琴相适应。另外……一切都是相对的，所以如果钢琴演奏低音音符，那么[小提琴]音符看起来就不那么低音了。因此，您可以使用该钢琴音符以某种方式对其进行基准测试。我认为在上下文中它听起来不会一样。” 简而言之，我们的耳朵被愚弄了，因为所有的感知都是相对的。

At another juncture, Rebecca wondered aloud, “ Hmm— I like the sound of the first passage a lot, but I like the sound of this [second section] less.” Rory, who is as expert at production as many are at performance, immediately piped up: “One thing is, the context is very different. Since it [the violin] is by itself [here], that obviously makes a big difference. You’ve got to fill it out more and make it more self-sufficient. Whereas the other thing somehow has to fit in with the piano. Plus … everything is relative, so if the piano plays a bass-y note, that makes [the violin] note seem less bass-y. So you use that piano note to benchmark it somehow. I don’t think in context it’s ever going to sound the same.” In short, our ears were fooled, because all perception is relative.

 

罗里的观点实际上是旧幻觉的听觉等同物，其中两条相同的线似乎具有不同的跨度，基于它们周围的箭头。

Rory’s point is actually the auditory equivalent of the old illusion in which two identical lines seemingly have different spans, based on the arrowheads that surround them.

 

 

一名优秀的制作人（或音响工程师）必须像了解音乐本身一样了解我们如何听到事物，而且，正如另一位格莱美奖获奖制作人 Russ Titelman 对我所说，充当治疗师、激励者和选角角色导演，找出哪些音乐家能够很好地配合某个特定的项目，并努力让每个成员都能创作出他或她最好的作品。或者有时必须坐下来让艺术家们演奏：蒂特曼作为制作人最成功的专辑之一，埃里克·克莱普顿的《Unplugged》，仅用两次录音录制，并在两次录音之间进行了一次编辑拼接。在真正的天才面前，所有的赌注都会落空。

A good producer (or sound engineer) must know as much about how we hear things as about the music itself—and also, as another Grammy Award– winning producer, Russ Titelman, put it to me, serve as therapist, motivator, and casting director, figuring out which musicians will fit together well on a particular project and trying to get every single member to produce his or her very best work. Or sometimes must just sit back and let the artists play: one of Titelman’s most successful albums as producer, Eric Clapton’s Unplugged, was recorded in just two takes, with a single edit splicing between the two. In the presence of true genius, all bets are off.

 

 

对于流行音乐家来说，最不重要的技能可能就是阅读乐谱的能力。重要的是音乐本身，而不是它是如何（甚至是否）写成的。披头士乐队中没有人会读或写音乐，埃里克·克莱普顿也不会，伟大的锡盘巷作曲家欧文·柏林也不会。事实上，柏林虽然写出了《没有比演艺界更好的生意》、《白色圣诞节》、《上帝保佑美国》和《你能做的任何事情（我能做得更好）》等标准，但他的钢琴演奏能力却非常有限，以至于他只能演奏升F调，但这并没有阻止他创作音乐。最终，他得到了一架特殊的定制钢琴，右侧有一个变速杆，可以让他将自己的作品移调到其他琴键上。

Probably the least important skill among popular musicians is the ability to read sheet music; what matters is the music itself, not how (or even whether) it is written. None of the Beatles could read or write music, and neither can Eric Clapton, nor for that matter could the great Tin Pan Alley composer Irving Berlin. Indeed, Berlin, who wrote standards such as “There’s No Business Like Show Business,” “White Christmas,” “God Bless America,” and “Anything You Can Do (I Can Do Better),” was such a limited piano player that he could only play in the key of F-sharp, but that didn’t stop him from making music. Eventually, he got a special custom piano with a shift lever on the right that would allow him to transpose his work into other keys.

当然，古典音乐家应该会读乐谱，这对任何音乐家来说都是一项方便的技能，但在更广阔的音乐世界中，视奏几乎不是必需的。世界上许多音乐传统完全没有乐谱而存在，并且有许多才华横溢的盲人音乐家，如史蒂夫·旺德和雷·查尔斯，他们从未读过音符。那些会视奏的人可以获得某些非视奏者无法获得的演出机会（例如 Doug Derryberry 与芝麻街的工作室合作），但是对于不会视奏的熟练录音室音乐家来说，有很多工作要做，就像我的新朋友斯莫基·霍梅尔（Smokey Hormel）一样，他是发明垃圾邮件的杰伊·C·霍梅尔（Jay C. Hormel）的孙子。

Classical musicians, of course, are expected to read music, and it is a handy skill to have for any musician, but in the broader musical world sight-reading is hardly essential. Many of the world’s musical traditions exist entirely without musical notation, and there are scores of brilliant blind musicians like Stevie Wonder and Ray Charles who never read a note. Those who can sight-read can get certain gigs (like Doug Derryberry’s studio work with Sesame Street) that nonreaders can’t, but there’s plenty of work for skilled studio musicians who can’t sight-read, like my new acquaintance Smokey Hormel, a grandson of Jay C. Hormel, the man who invented Spam.

 

当我第一次见到斯莫基时，是在我公寓拐角处的一家墨西哥餐厅里，一次偶然的机会，我注意到了他的吉他，并问他弹吉他是为了乐趣还是为了谋生。起初他有点不愿告诉我，但随着时间的推移，我发现他曾与贝克、尼尔·戴蒙德、汤姆·威茨和贾斯汀·汀布莱克一起玩过。他还与 Sia 一起演奏了“Breathe Me”（这首令人难忘的歌曲，伴随着《六尺之下》最后一集的最后一幕），更令人惊奇的是，他还参与了约翰尼·卡什的最后一张唱片，翻唱了《六尺之下》的最后一幕。九寸钉乐队的歌曲《Hurt》是有史以来最感人的翻唱之一。我见到斯莫基后不久，他就在诺拉·琼斯的乐队中得到了定期演出，这是诺拉亲自挑选的，诺拉似乎根本不在乎他不懂乐谱；她凭借声誉聘请了他，并进行了一次演出，并且非常喜欢他，让他成为乐队的正式成员。Smokey 实际上是录音室音乐家中的 Zelig，能够以任何风格与任何人融为一体；有了像他这样的耳朵，就不需要记号了。

When I first met Smokey, by chance, at a divey Mexican restaurant around the corner from my apartment, I noticed his guitar and asked him whether he played for fun or for a living. He was a bit reticent to tell me at first, but over time, I discovered that he’d played with Beck, Neil Diamond, Tom Waits, and Justin Timberlake. He’d also played with Sia on “Breathe Me” (the haunting song that accompanies the final scene of the final episode of Six Feet Under), and, even more amazingly, he’d played on Johnny Cash’s last recording, a cover of the Nine Inch Nails song “Hurt,” one of the most moving covers ever. Not long after I met him, Smokey got a regular gig in Norah Jones’s band, chosen by Norah herself, who didn’t seem to care at all that he couldn’t read music; she’d hired him by reputation for a single session and liked him so much she made him a regular member of the band. Smokey is practically the Zelig of studio musicians, able to blend in with anybody, in any style; with ears like his, notation is not required.

 

正如保罗·麦卡特尼在电视采访中所说，“只要我们两个人（约翰和保罗）知道我们在做什么，我们知道我们在演奏什么和弦，并且我们记住了旋律，我们实际上就没有需要写下来或阅读它。” 谁能与保罗爵士争论呢？

As Paul McCartney said in a television interview, “As long as the two of us [John and Paul] know what we’re doing, we know what chords we are playing, and we remember the melody, we don’t actually have the need to write it down or to read it.” Who could argue with Sir Paul?

 

 

麦卡特尼和我不是酒友，但我能够问斯莫基，他在看不懂乐谱的情况下是如何做到的。他向我解释说，对他来说，一切都是几何的：他记得形状和图案，以及它们与耳朵的关系。例如，所谓的 B 小调五声音阶的第一位置，其弹奏方式与 A 小调五声音阶的第一位置相同，只是整个模式向音阶底部正好向下移动了两个品格。脖子。在乐谱中，这两个音阶看起来相当不同：A小调仅由“自然音符”（A、C、D、E 和 G）组成，而 B 小调五声音阶包含四个自然音符（B、D、E 和 A）以及一个升音（F#）。在吉他上，从一把吉他移动到另一把吉他是完全自然的，因为指法保持完全相同。重要的是几何形状，而不是注释的名称（或者它们在页面上的显示方式）。

McCartney and I aren’t drinking buddies, but I was able to ask Smokey how he managed without being able to read sheet music. He explained to me that for him it’s all geometric: he remembers shapes and patterns, and how they relate to the ear. The so-called first position of the B minor pentatonic scale, for example, is fingered in the same way as the first position of the A minor pentatonic scale, except that the entire pattern is shifted down by exactly two frets toward the base of the neck. In musical notation, the two scales would look rather different: the A minor consists only of “natural notes” (A, C, D, E, and G), while the B minor pentatonic contains four natural notes (B, D, E, and A) but also one sharp (F#). On the guitar it’s completely natural to move from one to another because the fingering remains exactly the same. What matters is the geometry, not the names of the notes (or how they would appear on the page).

无可争议的吉他几何大师是爵士天才帕特·马蒂诺（Pat Martino），他将指板视为一种时钟，具有不同的和弦组，由叠加的几何图形（如正方形和三角形）表示。正如马蒂诺向我解释的那样，他将每种乐器的物理布局视为音乐景观的独特窗口，吉他的物理布局导致了一组与吉他不同的自然运动（几何和音乐）。其他乐器，例如钢琴。马蒂诺本人恰好精通音乐记谱，但他认为记谱只是一种记录（并与他的乐队成员分享）几何形状的工具，而几何形状是他演奏的真正核心。

The undisputed master in the geometry of the guitar is the jazz genius Pat Martino, who sees the fretboard as a kind of clock with different groups of chords represented by superimposed geometrical figures like squares and triangles. As Martino explained to me, he takes the physical layout of each musical instrument to be a distinct window into the landscape of music, with the physical layout of the guitar leading to a different set of natural movements (both geometrical and musical) from that of other instruments, such as the piano. Martino himself happens to be fluent in music notation, but he views notation as merely a tool for recording (and sharing with his bandmates) the geometry that is at the true core of all that he plays.

 

 

如果阅读音乐是可选的，那么听音乐以及能够将听到的内容与演奏的内容联系起来则不是。几乎所有与我交谈过的音乐家都提到改善这种联系是一个关键目标。正如 20 世纪 60 年代顶尖录音室吉他手之一 David Bromberg 所说，在他二十岁出头的巅峰时期，他感觉“[他的]耳朵和[他的]手指之间似乎存在着直接的联系”。音乐进来了，他自然而然地知道要演奏什么，如何装饰声乐旋律，或者如何根据给定的和弦进行创作独奏。汤姆·莫雷洛也说了同样的话，他解释说，他在大学期间每天进行大量练习的目的是为了能够“将[他]头脑中的任何想法直接转化为[他]手指。”

If reading music is optional, hearing music, and being able to connect what you hear with what you play, are not. Nearly every musician I spoke to mentioned improving that connection as a key goal. As David Bromberg, one of the leading studio guitarists in the 1960s, put it, at his peak in his early twenties he felt as if there were “a direct connection between [his] ears and [his] fingers.” Music came in, and he automatically knew what to play, how to ornament a vocal melody, or how to compose a solo that would follow a given chord progression. Tom Morello said much the same, explaining that part of his intensive daily practice during college was aimed at being able to “translate any idea in [his] head directly to [his] fingers.”

耳朵和手指之间的翻译实际上需要几个步骤，认知科学家可能将其称为表征的对齐（或表征之间的校准）。例如，想想棱镜适应研究：这些研究中的猫头鹰不仅需要了解视觉世界是什么样子或听觉世界听起来是什么样子，还需要了解两者之间的关系 - 对齐 - 以便当它们听到声音时声音向右十五度，仰角十五度，他们知道该看哪里，而不仅仅是听哪里。

That translation between ear and fingers actually takes several steps and is something a cognitive scientist might refer to as the alignment of (or calibration between) representations. Think, for example, of the prism adaptation studies: the owls in those studies needed to learn not just what the visual world looks like or what the auditory world sounds like but the relation— the alignment— between the two, so that when they heard a sound fifteen degrees to the right, at an elevation of fifteen degrees, they knew where to look, and not just where to listen.

 

成为一名专业音乐家需要对齐或校准至少四组不同的表示（如果碰巧阅读乐谱则为五组）：音乐家听到的音符、音乐家想要演奏的音符、这些音符在乐器上的位置，以及手指为了在正确的时间弹奏正确的音符而必须进行的物理动作（以及要朗读的音符（如果适用））。音乐家必须在乐器的心理表征与这些元素（例如吉他上的音品或钢琴上的琴键）在给定时刻演奏的乐器上实例化的物理位置之间绘制直接映射。演奏者必须同时具有“以自我为中心”的表征（关于他自己的身体所在的位置）和“非中心”的表征（关于事物在吉他上的位置，与吉他手如何握住吉他无关）——而且最重要的是，能够流利地表达两者之间的映射，必须在他和仪器移动位置时实时更新。（对于弹奏不同吉他的吉他手来说，所有这些都增加了额外的难度，因为不同的吉他在精确的物理布局上通常有所不同；例如，古典吉他上的琴弦比电吉他上的琴弦相距更远.)

Becoming an expert musician requires the alignment or calibration of at least four distinct sets of representations (five if one happens to read sheet music): the notes the musician hears, the notes the musician wants to play, the location of those notes on the instrument, and the physical actions that the fingers must undergo in order to play the right notes at the right time (and, if applicable, the notes to be read). The musician must draw direct mappings between a mental representation of the instrument and a physical location of where those elements (say, the frets on a guitar or the keys on a piano) are instantiated on the instrument being played at a given moment. The player must have both “egocentric” representations (of where his own body is) and “allocentric” representations (of where things lie on the guitar, independent of how the guitarist is holding the guitar)—and, most important of all, fluent mappings between the two, which must be updated in real time as he and the instrument shift position. (All this is bumped up an extra level of difficulty for a guitarist who plays different guitars, since different guitars often differ in their precise physical layout; the strings on a classical guitar, for example, are farther apart than the strings on an electric guitar.)

 

有抱负的摇滚吉他手可能会听到的最重要但看似愚蠢的建议之一是“确保调整你的背带，以便当你站起来（在舞台上）时和站立时吉他与你上半身的关系相同。坐下来。” 吉他手那些不注意这一点的人常常会被非中心坐标系和自我中心坐标系之间的差异所困扰。对齐就是全部。

One of the most important yet seemingly moronic pieces of advice that an aspiring rock guitarist may hear is “Make sure your strap is adjusted so that the guitar is in the same relation to your upper body when you stand up (onstage) as when you are sitting down.” Guitarists who don’t heed it are often skewered by the discrepancy between the allocentric and the egocentric coordinate frames. Alignment is all.

 

 

这个特别的建议非常重要，因为大脑在表征之间进行映射的能力通常是粗糙的：比复杂的三维三角学更多的尝试和错误。例如，考虑一下当你试图帮助别人系领带并面对他时会发生什么：手和眼睛之间通常的关系变得相反。实际上，你所做的只是反转方向，相当于简单地将方程乘以 –1，但大多数人感到完全困惑。

That particular piece of advice is so important because the brain’s ability to map between representations is generally crude: more trial and error than sophisticated three-dimensional trigonometry. Consider, for instance, what happens when you try to help someone else put on a tie and face him: the usual relation between hands and eyes becomes reversed. Effectively, all you’ve done is invert directions, the equivalent of simply multiplying an equation by –1, but most people feel entirely flummoxed.

原则上，您可以想象抽象地记住指板，然后使用某种公式来准确计算您的手指应该去的位置，考虑到您自己的姿势以及给定时刻吉他空间的三维角度和位置。机器人可能会这么做，但人脑却不会那样工作。相反，我们的大脑解决这类问题的方式并不是运行方程，而是利用大型经验数据库，从记忆中检索类似的事件。（这一数据来自研究人员对人类进行的棱镜适应实验：参与者一点一点地重新学习视觉和运动空间之间的映射，而不是通过公式。）
