In principle, you could imagine memorizing the fretboard in the abstract and then using some sort of formula to calculate exactly where your fingers should go, factoring in your own posture and the three-dimensional angle and position in space of the guitar at a given moment. A robot might do exactly that, but the human brain doesn’t work that way. Instead, our brains solve these sorts of problems not so much by running equations as by tapping large databases of experience, retrieving similar episodes from memory. (The data for this come from experiments in which researchers performed prism adaptation experiments on human beings: participants relearn mappings between visual and motor space bit by bit, rather than by formula.)

 

结果是双重的。首先，我们的视觉空间和运动空间之间的映射是零散的，这意味着我们需要大量的练习。其次，我们对指板和手指动态之间关系的了解很脆弱；与我们习惯的微小改变都会减慢我们的速度或导致错误。

The upshot is twofold. First, the fact that our maps between visual space and motor space are piecemeal means we need an enormous amount of practice. Second, our knowledge of the relation between the fretboard and the dynamics of one’s fingers is fragile; tiny alterations from what we are accustomed to can slow us down or lead to error.

 

这就是为什么即使是专业音乐家也应该在上台前进行热身的原因之一。热身可以发挥身体作用——​​增加手指、手腕和前臂的血液流动——但是它们可能还发挥着心理作用：热身可以刷新大脑关于音符的抽象（以自我为中心）表示与演奏它们所需的精确（以他为中心）的身体运动之间的校准的记忆。

This is one reason why even expert musicians should do warm-ups before going onstage. Warm-ups have a physical role to play— increasing the flow of blood to the fingers, wrists, and forearms— but they probably also have a mental role to play: a warm-up refreshes the brain’s memories about the calibration between the abstract (egocentric) representation of notes and the precise (allocentric) physical movements needed to play them.

 

 

当表述不一致时，结果就会大不相同。例如，大多数“音调较差的歌手”（不管你信不信，这是文献中的一个技术术语）都可以很好地识别旋律；他们并不是真正的五音不全，即使他们长期以来一直被告知他们是五音不全的。事实上，糟糕的歌唱通常是一个对准问题，一个通常可以纠正的问题，即将他们在内部听到的音高与他们需要将喉部调整到给定音符的正确位置所需的精确运动运动对齐。

When representations aren’t aligned, the results are quite different. Most “ poor-pitch singers” (believe it or not, a technical term in the literature), for example, can recognize melodies just fine; they are not literally tone-deaf, even if they’ve long been told they are. In reality, poor singing is generally an alignment problem, an often correctable issue of properly aligning the pitch they hear on the inside with the precise motor movements they need to adjust their larynx into proper position for a given note.

因此，大量的歌唱训练（明确或隐含地）是为了帮助新手学习协调声道的运动控制和他们想要发出的声音的内部模型。尤其重要的是所谓的胸声（丰富而响亮，但音调较低）和头声（薄弱且音调较高）之间的复杂映射。业余爱好者会在头声和胸声之间粗暴地“翻转”，在音域之间转换时会出现明显的中断。有效歌唱的第一步是将这两种“声音”（从字面上讲，由两种不同的控制发声器官的技术组成）协调成一个平滑的混音。专业歌手能够毫不费力地完成这样的转变，无需有意识的思考，正是因为他们学会了将所有代表性的鸭子排成一排。

A great deal of singing training is thus (explicitly or implicitly) about helping novices learn to coordinate the motor control of their vocal tracts with their internal models of the sounds they want to produce. Especially important is the complex mapping between so-called chest voice (rich and resonant, but lower in pitch) and head voice (thin, and higher pitched). Amateurs “flip” crudely between head and chest voices, with noticeable breaks as they shift between registers. The first step toward effective singing is to coordinate those two “voices” (which, literally speaking, consist of two different techniques for controlling the vocal apparatus) into a single smooth mix. Expert singers are able to perform such shifts effortlessly, and without conscious thought, precisely because they’ve learned to put all their representational ducks in a row.

 

顺便说一句，在熟练的技术表现中，仅仅靠猜测然后根据试错反馈进行调整是不够的。如果您曾经在《摇滚乐队》或《吉他英雄》等游戏中对着麦克风唱歌，您就会看到跟踪您的音调的小箭头时间，以及一组不同高度的线条，指示您应该唱的音高。如果你尝试某件事，但不起作用，你可以修改它。如果音调太低，可以通过缩短声带来提高音调；如果你的音调太高，你可以通过相反的方式降低音调。这种反馈对于学习唱歌非常有用，但在实际表演中不能总是依赖它。例如，在传统的意大利美声唱法中（就像您在歌剧中听到的那样），歌手必须从一开始就准确地唱出音符。在摇滚乐或布鲁斯音乐中，你可能会稍微适应一下地方，但在美声唱法中，相当于上层英国用语的音乐，你必须从正确的地方开始; 其他任何事情都不是板球。在唱美声时，大脑必须预测需要做什么——用内部所需的音调正确校准声带——并且不要停下来等待反馈。除非（或直到）一个人的所有内部表征都完全一致，否则这一切都不会发生。

Incidentally, in skilled technical performance, it’s not enough to simply guess and then adjust according to trial-and-error feedback. If you’ve ever sung into a microphone in a game like Rock Band or Guitar Hero, you’ve seen the little arrow that tracks your pitch over time, along with a set of lines at different heights that indicate the pitch you are supposed to sing. If you try something, and if it doesn’t work, you can tinker with it. If you come in too low, you can raise your pitch by shortening your vocal cords; if you come in too high, you can lower your pitch by doing the opposite. Such feedback can be extremely useful in learning to sing, but in actual performance one can’t always rely on it. In traditional Italian bel-canto-style singing (like you would hear at the opera), for instance, the singer must hit the note squarely from the outset. In rock or blues, you might get away with a bit of gliding into place, but in bel canto, the musical equivalent of upper-crust British diction, one must start at the right place; anything else just isn’t cricket. In singing bel canto, the brain has to anticipate what needs to be done— calibrating the vocal folds properly with the internal desired pitch— and do so without stopping to wait for feedback. None of which can happen unless (or until) all one’s internal representations are perfectly aligned.

 

在专业人士中，这些表示是如此一致，以至于音乐家可以知道他或她的乐器会发出什么声音，即使他或她实际上听不到正在演奏的乐器。在所有关于音乐的科学文献中，我最喜欢的研究可能是一项研究，其中要求十几位熟练的钢琴家在经过电子静音的数码钢琴上演奏各种作品，其中大部分是不熟悉的——这意味着钢琴家实际上无法听听他们在玩什么。问题是，之后他们被要求听这些歌曲的听觉回放，其中一些是根据他们自己演奏的数字记录重建的，另一些是根据其他演奏过相同作品的音乐家的数字记录重建的。为了让事情变得更加困难，实验控制了节奏和整体响度。即便如此，钢琴家们还是很难识别出自己的演奏。仅凭想象力，通过利用手指、大脑和耳朵听到的声音之间的微妙排列，钢琴家们成功地将手指所做的事情与他们将创造的声音联系起来。

In a professional, those representations are so well aligned that a musician can know what sound his or her instrument would produce even if he or she can’t actually hear the instrument being played. In the whole scientific literature on music, my favorite study may be one in which a dozen skilled pianists were asked to play a variety of pieces, mostly unfamiliar, on digital pianos that had been electronically muted— which meant that the pianists couldn’t actually hear what they were playing. The catch was that afterward they were asked to listen to auditory playbacks of those songs, some reconstructed from the digital records of their own playing, others from the digital records of other musicians who had played the same pieces. To make things even harder, the experiments controlled for tempo and overall loudness. Even so, the pianists were way above chance at being able to identify their own playbacks. By imagination alone, by exploiting the exquisite alignment between their fingers, their brains, and what their ears would have heard, the pianists managed to relate what their fingers had done with the sounds they would have created.

 

 

1920 年代末，在我的家乡巴尔的摩，一位受过古典音乐训练的作曲家奥托·奥特曼 (Otto Ortmann) 在皮博迪音乐学院建立了一个实验室，其想法是利用高速摄影等当时的创新技术来观察熟练钢琴家的动作' 手指。奥特曼测量了从手臂重量到手腕弯曲和手指长度的一切，发现了一种极其复杂的舞蹈编排。熟练的钢琴家不仅仅是在正确的时间用正确的手指弹奏出正确的音符；他们（无意识地）提前计划：钢琴家的食指甚至可能在中指敲击与第二个音符相对应的琴键之前就开始向乐句中的第三个音符移动。（我们声道中的发音器官也做类似的事情；甚至在你发音某个辅音之前，你的嘴唇可能已经撅起以形成以下元音。）用技术术语来说，这个过程被称为协同发音——其中发音的本质是一个运动会影响下一个运动。这样的结果显示出高度的预期，这是我们相对较慢的肌肉能够应对产生语音和创作音乐的速度密集型需求的唯一方法，而这些是人类能做的最快节奏的事情之一。钢琴家必须解决一个复杂的问题，因为有多个手指可能敲击任何琴键，并且到达该琴键的方式也有多种；吉他手也是如此。奥特曼的研究以及随后的许多研究表明，专业音乐家的标志之一就是卓越的效率。

In the late 1920s, in my hometown of Baltimore, a classically trained composer named Otto Ortmann set up a laboratory at the Peabody Conservatory, with the idea of using then-innovative technologies such as high-speed photography to look at the motion of skilled pianists’ fingers. Measuring everything from arm weight to wrist flexion and finger length, Ortmann discovered an astonishingly complex choreography. Skilled pianists didn’t just hit the right notes at the right time with the correct fingers; they planned (unconsciously) in advance: a pianist’s index finger might start moving toward the third note in a phrase even before the middle finger had struck a key corresponding to the second note. (The articulators in our vocal tract do something similar; even before you pronounce a given consonant, your lips might already be pursing to form the following vowel.) In technical terms, this process is known as co- articulation— in which the nature of one motor movement influences the next. Such results show a high degree of anticipation, which is the only way our relatively slow muscles can cope with the speed-intensive demands of producing speech and making music, which are among the fastest-paced things humans can do. The pianist must solve a complex problem, since there are multiple fingers that might strike any key and multiple ways of getting there; so, too, with a guitarist. Ortmann’s studies, and many that have followed, show that one hallmark of expert musicians is remarkable efficiency.

讽刺的是，专家的另一个标志在于他们所犯的错误类型。新手所犯的错误可能多种多样，而专家所犯的错误则主要分为三种类型。最无趣的也许是国际象棋大师可能称之为“ Fingerfehlers”的简单错误——德语中“手指失误”的意思。不用说，初学者总是会做这些；专家的频率要低得多。

Another hallmark of experts lies, ironically, in the kinds of errors they make. Whereas the errors of novices may be all over the map, the errors of experts tend to be of three main types. The least interesting, perhaps, are the kinds of simple mistakes that chess masters might call Fingerfehlers— German for “slips of the finger.” Beginners, it goes without saying, make these all the time; experts far less often.

 

第二种错误，称为预期错误，密切配合提前计划：在记忆的古典音乐作品中，你对一首曲子了解得越多，你的手指提前准备得越多，你就越有可能不经意地向前跳，提前演奏一个音符——排序就像你想说“我把车开到商店”时却说“我把商店开走了”。新手必须痛苦地一张一张地计划每个音符，而不为未来做太多规划，实际上比专家犯的这些特殊错误要少。

The second type of mistake, known as the anticipation error, goes hand in glove with advance planning: in a memorized work of classical music, the better you know a piece, and the more your fingers are preparing in advance, the more likely you are to inadvertently skip ahead, playing a note ahead of schedule— sort of like saying “I took the store” when you meant to say “I took the car to the store.” Novices, who must painfully plan out each note, one by one, without doing much planning for the future, actually make fewer of these particular errors than experts do.

 

第三种常见错误类似于语言学家所说的语义替换错误，例如将葡萄柚称为橙子。当初学者犯错误时，他们可能会演奏一个完全跑调的相邻音符，与要演奏的旋律无关。当专家凭记忆演奏时，如果他们犯了错误，他们通常会用同一调的其他音符来替换，通常是用当前用作伴奏的和弦来替换。

A third common kind of mistake is analogous to what linguists would call a semantic substitution error, like calling a grapefruit an orange. When beginners make errors, they may play, say, an adjacent note that happens to be entirely out of key, unrelated to the melody that was to be played. When experts play from memory, to the extent that they make errors, they typically substitute other notes from the same key, frequently from the very chord that is currently serving as the accompaniment.

 

从实用角度来看，这种用相关音符替换音符的趋势是一件好事，因为和弦内的错误往往会混入其中，而且研究表明听众很少注意到此类错误。从科学的角度来看，替换错误有助于阐明大脑内部发生的事情：新手的大脑将单个音符表示为字母表中他可能无法理解的语言中任意的、几乎毫无意义的字母。在专家的大脑中，每个音符都是更大含义的一部分，正是因为这首歌可以从音阶和和声等方面更抽象地理解，而不仅仅是某些作曲家碰巧写下的随机音符。对于新手来说，鲍勃·马利的《救赎之歌》的第一个小节，G、A、B、G这些音符，也可能是某种神秘的咒语；对于专家来说，它们只是 G 大调五声音阶的上下变化。

On the practical side, this tendency toward replacing notes with related notes is a good thing, since within-chord errors tend to blend in, and studies show that listeners rarely even notice such mistakes. On the scientific side, substitution errors help to illuminate what’s going on inside the brain: the novice’s brain represents individual notes as arbitrary, almost meaningless letters in an alphabet in a language he may not understand. In the brain of the expert, each note is part of a larger meaning, precisely because the song is understood more abstractly, in terms of things like scales and harmonic motion, rather than just random notes that some composer happened to have written. To the novice, the first measures of Bob Marley’s “Redemption Song,” the notes G, A, B, G, might as well be some mysterious incantation; to the expert, they are simply a ride up and down the G major pentatonic scale.

 

专家的音乐知识也体现在“转移”研究中，即教授音乐家一首曲子，然后要求演奏另一首相关但不同的曲子，例如相同的曲子。不同指法的节奏，或相同指法不同节奏的节奏。新手往往与他们所学内容的具体细节紧密相关，因此（例如）将节奏从左手翻译到右手可能会构成严峻的挑战，而专家则几乎毫不费力地进行这种转换，并且几乎没有错误，大概是因为他们的整体音乐表现系统处于更深的层次。

The expert’s knowledge of music also comes through in studies of “transfer,” in which a musician is taught one piece and then asked to play a second piece that is related yet different, for example, the same rhythm with different fingering, or the same fingering with different rhythm. Novices tend to be tightly tied to the specific details of what they learned, such that (for instance) translating a rhythm from the left hand to the right can pose a serious challenge, whereas experts make such transfers almost effortlessly, and with little error, presumably because their overall system of musical representation is at a much deeper level.

 

 

对于计算机来说，效率、抽象性和流畅的映射都变得很容易。将 MIDI 乐谱（本质上是机器可读形式的乐谱）输入计算机中的 GarageBand 等程序中，它将能够以任何速度、任何调播放该乐谱，而无需费力或费力。一个失误。真正的艺术家与机器或能完美视奏却缺乏灵魂的音乐学校毕业生的区别是什么？

Efficiency, abstractness, and fluid mappings all come easy for computers. Feed a MIDI score (essentially sheet music in machine-readable form) into your computer, in a program such as GarageBand, and it will be able to play back that score at any tempo, in any key, without ever breaking a sweat or making a mistake. What is it that distinguishes a true artist from a machine or from a music school graduate who can sight-read perfectly yet plays with little soul?

最大的秘密之一在于时机。如果机器需要像节拍器一样演奏，那么人就需要以有趣的方式偏离节拍器。

One of the biggest secrets lies with timing. If it takes a machine to play exactly like a metronome, it takes a person to deviate from a metronome in interesting ways.

 

节奏在音乐中的重要性一直是显而易见的。节奏是关于音符在时间上的间隔，如果两个音乐家一起演奏并且不协调他们的时间感，他们听起来就会不同步。如果一支放克乐队——鼓、贝司、铜管乐器和吉他——准确地演奏，我们会惊叹不已。为了确保演奏者同步演奏，录音室表演现在经常播放到“节拍音轨”，允许所有音乐家一起演奏，即使实际上（现在经常出现这种情况）每个音乐家都会录制他或她的声音曲目在不同的时间 - 甚至可能在不同的地点，就像邮政服务乐队的首张专辑（最著名的是歌曲“Such Great Heights”）。

It’s always been obvious that timing is important in music; rhythm is about the spacing of notes in time, and if two musicians play together and don’t coordinate their sense of time, they sound out of sync. If a funk band— drums, bass, brass, and guitar— plays exactly in time, we drop our jaws in admiration. To make sure players perform in sync, studio performances are now often played to a “click track” that allows all the musicians to play in time together, even if in reality (as is often the case these days) each musician records his or her tracks at a separate time— perhaps even in a separate location, as with the debut album of the band the Postal Service (best known for the song “Such Great Heights”).

 

但纯粹的同步并不是时间安排的唯一重要因素；专家的音乐性也常常涉及相对于音乐的微妙变化。否则看似稳定的脉搏。关于这一事实的一些最早的科学文献出现在 1932 年，当时爱荷华州的一位博士。一位名叫 Leroy Ninde Vernon 的学生开始检查由专业音乐家准备并在自动钢琴上播放的钢琴卷轴。甚至在弗农进行研究之前，就已经很明显，直接根据乐谱准备的钢琴卷轴听起来并不好；尽管它们在技术上可能是完美的，但听起来却常常平淡无奇。像 Duo-Art 公司这样的自动钢琴制造商不希望他们昂贵的设备听起来机械或枯燥，因此他们聘请了真正的音乐家来演奏，将他们的演奏记录在纸卷上，然后将纸卷送入机器中。弗农分析了这些卷轴，看看为什么它们听起来比直接转换乐谱更好。

But sheer synchrony isn’t the only thing important about timing; expert musicality is also often about subtle variations relative to an otherwise seemingly steady pulse. Some of the first scientific documentation of this fact came in 1932 when an Iowa Ph.D. student named Leroy Ninde Vernon began to examine piano rolls that had been prepared by professional musicians to be played back on player pianos. Even before Vernon’s research, it had become obvious that piano rolls prepared directly from sheet music didn’t really sound good; although they could be technically perfect, they often sounded flat. Manufacturers of player pianos, like the company Duo-Art, didn’t want their expensive gadgets to sound mechanical or sterile, so they contracted real musicians to play, recording their performances onto the rolls of paper that would then be fed into the machines. Vernon analyzed those rolls to see why they sounded better than straight conversions of sheet music.

 

弗农发现，即使乐谱和实际演奏中音符的相对顺序相同，敲击音符的确切时刻以及它们保持的持续时间也是不同的。

What Vernon discovered was that even if the relative sequence of notes was the same in a piece of sheet music and an actual performance, the exact moments at which notes were struck— and the durations for which they were held— differed.

 

有些变化可能只是随机的，有些则可能是随机的。机器可以遵循完美的节拍器时间，永远不会偏离，但人类音乐家可能会发现很难准确地按节拍演奏，即使他或她尝试了。由于单个神经元放电中的“噪音”（本质上是随机变化），一个人——即使是训练有素的音乐家——试图用节拍器在完美的时间敲击，有时会犯错误。在一首每分钟 120 节拍的中快节奏歌曲中，例如迈克尔·杰克逊的“Billie Jean”或麦当娜的“Borderline”，大多数人的敲击声在大多数节拍上都会在目标时间的百分之几内，但很少有人会这样做把它钉在每一个节拍上。对于新手来说，有些错误可能高达 3% 到 6%，而且即使是专家也不是完美的。

Some of the variation might have just been random; machines can follow perfect metronomic time, never deviating, but a human musician may find it difficult to play exactly on the beat, even if he or she tries. Because of “noise” (essentially random variation) in the firing of individual neurons, a human— even a trained musician— who tries to tap in perfect time with a metronome will at some point make an error. In a moderately fast-paced song, 120 beats per minute, such as “Billie Jean” by Michael Jackson or “Borderline” by Madonna, most people’s taps would come within a few percent of the target time on most beats, but few people would nail it on every beat. For novices, some errors could be as big as 3 to 6 percent, and even experts aren’t perfect.

 

 

如果某些时间变化显然是随机的，或者是偶然的，或者至少超出了人类自愿控制的范围，那么其中一些——将其分开的部分来自业余爱好者的专家——更加系统化。任何傻瓜都可能会不小心错过几毫秒的节拍；专业人士与新手的区别在于对时间的刻意操纵。

If some of the timing variation is apparently random, or accidental, or at least beyond voluntary human control, some of it— the part that separates experts from amateurs— is far more systematic. Any fool can miss the beat by a few milliseconds here or there by accident; what separates the professional from the novice is the deliberate manipulation of time.

例如，弗农发现，人类钢琴家经常会在伴奏之前几毫秒演奏歌曲的主旋律（通常用右手）。这种微小的差异——略小于百分之一秒，并且在乐谱中没有标注——足以突出主奏或旋律乐器，并将其与伴奏区分开来，这是音乐家使用微观变化的多种方式之一及时让音乐变得有意义。

Vernon discovered, for instance, that human pianists often did things like play the lead melody of a song (typically with the right hand) just a few milliseconds ahead of the accompaniment. This tiny difference— slightly less than a hundredth of a second and notated nowhere in the score— is enough to highlight the lead, or melodic instrument, and separate it from the accompaniment, and it’s one of the many ways in which musicians use microscopic changes in timing to make music meaningful.

 

首先，在其他条件相同的情况下，缓慢地演奏一个部分（或一个乐句，甚至一个音符）往往会使该段落听起来悲伤；快速弹奏会让听起来快乐或充满活力。就任何人所知，这种普遍趋势在全球范围内都是如此。放慢一首萨米约克（Sami yoik） ——一种传统的、类似约德尔语的斯堪的纳维亚民歌，通常是无伴奏合唱——你会听到悲伤、甚至哀伤的约克（yoik）；加快速度，你的yoik听起来可能会更快乐，甚至更有活力；事实上，你听不懂歌词对你的主观印象影响不大。

To begin with, playing a section (or a phrase, or even a note) slowly tends, other things being equal, to make that passage sound sad; playing it quickly makes it sound happy or energetic. Insofar as anyone can tell, this general tendency is true around the globe. Slow down a Sami yoik— a traditional, yodel-like Scandinavian folk song, often sung a cappella— and you get a sad, even mournful yoik; speed up, and your yoik will likely sound happier and even bouncy; the fact that you won’t understand the lyrics makes remarkably little difference to your subjective impressions.

 

微妙的时机线索的力量不仅超越了文化背景，也超越了专业知识。经常聆听特定类型音乐的新手几乎可以像专家一样欣赏它们。唯一真正的区别是，专家通常可以报告新手可能无法明确识别的节奏变化，并且专家可以更好地控制节奏变化，以便他们可以随意产生它们；新手很难保持稳定的节拍，更不用说熟练演奏者特意对节奏进行细微的改变了。

The power of subtle timing cues transcends not just cultural background but also expertise; novices who listen regularly to particular genres can appreciate them nearly as well as experts. The only real differences are that experts can often report tempo changes that novices might not explicitly recognize and that experts have much better control over tempo variations, such that they can produce them at will; a novice has enough trouble keeping a steady beat and much less facility with the deliberate micro-changes in tempo that characterize expert playing.

 

 

专业古典音乐家如何记忆复杂的作品？理解学习的最好方法是研究人们所犯的错误心理学家罗杰·查芬（Roger Chaffin）就是这样做的。在一项研究中，他对大提琴家 Tânia Lisboa 进行了三年的跟踪研究，观察她准备并最终演奏了 JS 巴赫的《大提琴独奏第六组曲》中一首要求很高的前奏曲。

How do expert classical musicians memorize complex pieces? The best way to understand learning is to study errors that people make along the way, and the psychologist Roger Chaffin has done just that. In one study, he followed a cellist, Tânia Lisboa, over a period of three years as she prepared for— and ultimately performed— a demanding prelude, from J. S. Bach’s Suite No. 6 for Solo Cello.

查芬发现，并非所有音符都是平等创建的。从一页乐谱来看，任何音乐作品表面上都可以被认为是一长串音符和休止符，没有一个音符或休止符比下一个更重要或更难记住。对于自动钢琴这样的机器来说，奏鸣曲中的第117个音符与第118个音符具有完全相同的地位；每个都有一个音高和持续时间，仅此而已。

What Chaffin found was that not all notes are created equally. Looked at on a page of sheet music, any musical piece could ostensibly be thought of as a long stream of notes and rests, no one note or rest any more important or harder to remember than the next. To a machine such as a player piano, the 117th note in a sonata has exactly the same status as the 118th note; each one has a pitch and a duration, and that’s all there is to it.

 

对于人类音乐家来说，情况则截然不同。对音乐家错误的研究表明，作品的记忆不仅仅是长长的任意音符流，而是结构化的层次结构。例如，一首协奏曲作为一个整体，通常由三个乐章组成，每个乐章可以分为由多组乐句组成的小节，各个乐句通常可以根据它们与诸如旋律、和弦和音阶。而且，引人注目的是，音乐家往往在乐句和乐段之间的断层线上犯错误。在练习中，熟练的钢琴家很少会绊倒一首曲子的第一个或最后一个音符。他们所犯的错误往往发生在较大单元之间的连接处，这可能是因为大脑以较小的块的形式存储较长的音乐片段；一个块中的内容是完全掌握的，但有时音乐家无法从一个块到下一个块进行正确的切换。

To a human musician, the situation is rather different. Studies of musicians’ errors have shown that pieces are memorized not simply as long streams of arbitrary notes but instead as structured hierarchies. A concerto as a whole, for instance, typically consists of three movements, and each movement could be divided into subsections, which consist of sets of phrases, and individual phrases can typically be conceptualized in terms of how they relate to entities such as melodies, chords, and musical scales. And, strikingly, the errors musicians tend to make lie at the fault lines between phrases and sections. In their practice sessions, skilled pianists rarely stumble over the first or last note of a piece. The errors they make tend to be at the junctures between larger units, probably because the brain stores longer pieces of music in terms of smaller chunks; what’s inside a chunk is fully mastered, but sometimes the musician fails to make the right switch from one chunk to the next.

 

真正优秀的钢琴家知道这一点（直观地，如果不是明确地），因此经常将大部分练习投入到较大单元之间的过渡上。正如查芬所说，专家们“在关键点放置表现线索，以提供安全网，以防表现因记忆故障或注意力不集中而中断。” 此类提示有时最初是乐谱上的物理注释，但最终必须转化为必须记住的心理注释。表演者使用这样的提示既可以指示乐曲各部分之间的正式边界，也可以指示“表达边界”（代表音乐感觉的变化），以及节奏或技术发生变化的地方（例如，对于大提琴家来说） ，鞠躬方向的转变）。从本质上讲，这些过渡时刻是音乐家最不能处于自动驾驶状态的时刻：当事情发生变化时，演奏者需要保持警惕。古典吉他老师 Meliset Abreu 要求她的学生在离开乐器时（例如，在上班的地铁上）思考自己的作品，告诉他们，在哪里他们会发呆或忘记自己在做什么。这正是他们返回仪器时需要关注的地方。专业知识的很大一部分来自于诊断自己可能犯的错误。

The really good pianists know this (intuitively, if not explicitly) and therefore often devote the greatest portion of their practice to the transitions between larger units. As Chaffin puts it, experts place “performance cues at key points to provide a safety net in case a performance is disrupted by a memory failure or lapse in attention.” Such cues sometimes begin as physical annotations on the score but ultimately must become transformed into mental notes that must be remembered. Performers use cues like these both to indicate formal boundaries between sections of a piece and to indicate “expressive boundaries” (which represent changes in musical feeling), as well as places where there are changes in tempo or technique (such as, for a cellist, a shift in the direction of bowing). In essence, these transitional moments are the moments at which the musician can least afford to be on autopilot: when something changes, the player needs to be alert. The classical guitar teacher Meliset Abreu asks her students to think about their pieces when they are away from their instruments (for example, on the subway on the way to work), telling them that the place where they space out or forget what they are doing is precisely the place they need to focus on when they return to their instruments. A good part of expertise comes from diagnosing one’s own likely mistakes.

 

 

当一个人在观众面前现场演奏时，又会出现另一套技能，在技术行业中称为主要动作，或者更通俗地说，称为表演技巧：自发的动作和面部表情，这些动作和面部表情并不是表演所严格要求的。音乐可以传达情感并让观众参与其中。歌手拥有最大的身体自由（想想迈克尔·杰克逊和月球漫步），但吉米·佩奇和皮特·汤森德会在乐句休息时挥动手臂；吉米·亨德里克斯（Jimi Hendrix）出名的部分原因是他的音乐，部分原因是他砸吉他的习惯（以及在背后用牙齿弹奏，甚至在吉他着火的情况下演奏）。查克·贝里单腿跳过舞台。尼尔斯·洛夫格伦有时会在蹦床上玩耍，在布鲁斯·斯普林斯汀的演出中，我曾经看到他在吉他独奏中间做了一个空翻。

When one is playing live in front of an audience, yet another set of skills can come in, known in the technical trade as primary movements, or, more colloquially, as showmanship: voluntary actions and facial expressions that aren’t strictly required for the music but that convey emotion and keep the audience involved. Singers have the most physical freedom (think Michael Jackson and the moonwalk), but Jimmy Page and Pete Townshend would windmill their arms during rests between phrases; Jimi Hendrix became famous in part for his music but also in part for his habit of smashing guitars (as well as playing behind his back, with his teeth, and with his guitar on fire). Chuck Berry hopped across the stage on one leg. Nils Lofgren sometimes plays on a trampoline, and at a Bruce Springsteen show I once saw him do a flip right in the middle of a guitar solo.

即使没有上跳下跳，吉他手也可以通过利用指板的冗余给人留下深刻的印象。由于吉他的性质，通常可以在指板上的多个位置，许多吉他手会在指板上上下滑动双手，这并不是因为他们必须这样做（从音乐上来说），而是因为突然的戏剧性动作让观众保持参与（并且看起来比实际情况更困难）。小提琴也有一定程度的冗余（意味着某些音符可以在不同琴弦上的多个位置演奏），早在摇滚乐发明之前，十九世纪早期的小提琴家尼科洛·帕格尼尼就开发出了最巧妙的动作之一最重要的是，即使小提琴上有一两根琴弦断了，他仍能继续演奏。据传说，他的辉煌时刻是在一根弦上完成的独奏。

Even without jumping up and down, guitarists can make an impression by exploiting the redundancy of the fretboard. Because of the nature of the guitar, it is often possible to play a single melody at multiple places on the fretboard, and many guitarists will slide their hands up and down the fretboard not because they have to (musically speaking) but just because the sudden dramatic motions keep the audience engaged (and seem more difficult than they really are). Violins, too, have a certain degree of redundancy (meaning that some notes can be played in multiple places on different strings), and long before rock and roll was invented, the early-nineteenth-century violinist Niccolò Paganini developed one of the slickest moves of all, a trick of continuing to play even if a string or two on his violin broke. His shining moment, according to legend, was a solo finished on a single string.

 

 

与其他音乐家一起演奏还需要另一套技能，首先是强大的听力能力，特别是预测乐队成员将演奏的内容。正如 20 世纪 80 年代摇滚乐队 The Bongos 的主唱 Richard Barone 所说，“我在舞台上学到的第一件事就是倾听的重要性。” 根据多才多艺的科学家、作曲家和长号手彼得·凯勒的说法，个体之间的音乐协调至少涉及三种技能。首先，也是最根本的，一个人必须适应其他音乐家的节奏变化，无论这些偏差是偶然的还是有意的（也许是为了表达一种情绪或描绘结构）。第二项技能——对于初学者来说极其困难——是学会将自己的注意力分配到自己的演奏和合奏中其他人的演奏上。第三，最近的研究表明，专业音乐家经常使用相当于心理想象的听觉来预测自己和其他表演者即将发出的声音。

Playing in a group with other musicians requires still another set of skills, starting with a strongly developed capacity for hearing and, especially, anticipating what one’s bandmates will play. As Richard Barone, lead singer for the 1980s rock band the Bongos, put it, “The first thing I learned onstage is the importance of listening.” According to the versatile scientist, composer, and trombonist Peter Keller, at least three skills are involved in musical coordination between individuals. First, and most fundamentally, one must adapt to changes in tempo made by other musicians, whether those deviations are accidental or intentional (perhaps to express a mood or to delineate structure). A second skill— extremely hard for beginners— is learning to divide one’s attention between one’s own playing and the playing of the other people in the ensemble. Third, recent work suggests that expert musicians frequently use the auditory equivalent of mental imagery to anticipate the upcoming sounds of both themselves and other performers.

在工作室严格控制的范围之外，这一切可能会更加困难，就像我的一些朋友最近面临的情况一样。他们的乐队——Jessie Murphy in the Woods——擅长精致的和声，但在这个特殊的场合，他们发现自己在一个小房间里演奏，实际上是在一个更大的夜总会内，其中每个扩音器显然都在十一点后打开。结果，杰西和她的同伴们不仅需要像在任何一个平常的夜晚那样互相照顾，而且还需要互相照顾。他们还必须同时过滤掉从隔壁传来的四人在地板上的重击声（通常与他们自己的节奏不同）。对于音乐家来说，这相当于站在战区前线平静地刷牙。

Outside the carefully controlled confines of the studio, all this can be even more difficult, as in a situation that some friends of mine recently faced. Their band— Jessie Murphy in the Woods— specializes in delicate harmonies, but on this particular occasion they found themselves playing in a smallish room that was literally inside a larger nightclub, in which every amplifier was apparently turned up past eleven. As a result, Jessie and company didn’t merely have to attend to one another, as they would have to do on any ordinary night; they also had to simultaneously filter out the loud four-on- the-floor thumping that leaked through from next door (usually at different tempos from their own). It was the musician’s equivalent of calmly brushing one’s teeth while standing on the front lines of a war zone.

 

正如莱尼·凯向我解释的那样，归根结底，音乐家之间的同理心几乎比其他一切都重要。凯本人不读乐谱，他承认他仍然无法区分属七和弦和大七和弦，更多地依赖于几何学和精心排练的模式，而不是明确的形式知识。然而帕蒂·史密斯已经和他在一起近四十年了。为什么？因为凯有能力预测帕蒂的举动和情绪，知道她要去哪里，并在她到达时在那里等她。众所周知，史密斯可以选择吉他手，并且肯定可以负担得起演奏速度更快或技术水平更高的吉他手，但没有人比凯更了解她，这就是她坚持选择他的原因。或者，正如 Terre Roche 所说，“一支乐队在同一个房间里度过的时间是无可替代的。这包括货车。”

As Lenny Kaye explained to me, in the final analysis, empathy between musicians can outweigh virtually all else. Kaye himself doesn’t read sheet music, and he confessed that he still could barely distinguish between a dominant seventh chord and a major seventh chord, relying more on geometry and well-rehearsed patterns than on explicit formal knowledge. Yet Patti Smith has stuck with him for nearly forty years. Why? Because of Kaye’s ability to anticipate Patti’s moves and moods, to know where she is headed and to be there waiting for her when she arrives. Smith is well enough known to have her choice of guitarist and could certainly afford someone who plays faster or has more technical skill, but nobody knows her better than Kaye, and that’s why she sticks with him. Or, as Terre Roche put it, “There’s no substitute for the amount of time a band spends in the same room with one another. And that includes the van.”

 

 

当我第一次见到 Doug Derryberry（与 Bruce Hornsby 合作的吉他手）时，他提到他是“一个超级坚持调音的人”，但直到后来我拜访他的工作室时，我才真正理解了调音的范围。他这是什么意思。作为一个认真的初学者，我已经知道在每次练习之前给吉他调音是多么重要。与电脑键盘不同，吉他是一种物理乐器，其确切的声音取决于温度和温度等因素。湿度。为了使琴弦相互组合时发出良好的声音，每次演奏时都必须对琴弦的长度进行微妙的调整。一些音乐家可以通过耳朵来做到这一点，将琴弦相互比较或与一些外部参考音符（例如在钢琴上演奏的 E）进行比较。其他人（比如我）使用监控振动的电子设备来检测特定吉他在特定时刻弹奏的音符，提供有关该音符是否准确、太尖锐（高）或太平（低）的反馈。

When I first met Doug Derryberry (the guitarist who works with Bruce Hornsby), he mentioned that he was “a super stickler for tuning,” but it was only later, when I visited him in his studio, that I truly understood the scope of what he meant by this. As a conscientious beginner, I already knew how important it is to tune one’s guitar before each practice session. Unlike a computer keyboard, a guitar is a physical instrument whose exact sounds depend on factors such as temperature and humidity. In order to have the strings sound good in combination with one another, one has to make subtle adjustments to the length of the strings each time one plays. Some musicians can do this by ear, comparing the strings with one another or with some external reference note (say an E played on a piano). Others (like me) use electronic gadgets that monitor vibrations to detect what note a particular guitar is playing at a particular moment, supplying feedback as to whether that note is spot-on, too sharp (high), or too flat (low).

我和大多数其他初学者这样做的方式总是通过调整吉他上的“空弦”，也就是说，当我在不按住音品的情况下扫弦时，确保每根弦都与特定的参考音高相匹配；低音弦调至 E，下一根弦调至 A，依此类推。

The way I, and most other beginners, do this is invariably by tuning the “open strings” on the guitar, which is to say I make sure each string matches a particular reference pitch when I strum it without holding down a fret; the bass string is tuned to E, the next string to an A, and so on.

 

当我与 Derryberry 交谈时，我意识到这是一个完全不同的世界。西方音乐使用一种称为平均律的音阶，其中每个音符的频率乘以一个常数值（一加二的十二分之一）以得出下一个音符。不幸的是，平均律系统并不十分完美（并且由于复杂的数学原因，没有一个系统可以做到这一点）。例如，五度音程听起来比 3:2 的理想比例稍微平坦一些。对于初学者来说，这种差异几乎不会被注意到，但 Derryberry 是一个曾经为了乐趣而调钢琴的人。

When I talked with Derryberry, I realized that there was a whole different world. Western music uses something called an even-tempered scale, in which the frequency of each note is multiplied by a constant value (one plus the twelfth root of two) to yield the next. Unfortunately, the even-tempered system isn’t quite perfect (and for complex mathematical reasons, no single system can be). Intervals of a fifth, for example, sound slightly flatter than the ideal ratio of 3:2. To a beginner, the difference would be scarcely noticeable, but Derryberry is a guy who used to tune pianos for fun.

 

Derryberry 没有像我（以及几乎所有其他业余爱好者）那样采用一刀切的方法，而是针对每首歌曲对吉他进行不同的调音，同时考虑到哪些特定的和弦和旋律音符可能在其中发挥重要作用。歌曲。如果歌曲的大部分都在脖子中间徘徊，他会优化调音以使该部分变得完美；如果歌曲主要由在琴颈顶部演奏的开放和弦组成，他可能会围绕第二音调调音。我愉快地没有意识到的妥协对于 Derryberry 来说至关重要。（我后来了解到，从事录音室工作的专业人士有时会重新调音吉他，以便用单个和弦配音。）

Instead of taking the one-size-fits-all approach that I (and virtually every other amateur) might take, Derryberry tunes his guitar differently for each individual song, taking into account what particular chords and melody notes might play a prominent role in that song. If most of the song hovers around the middle of the neck, he optimizes the tuning to get that part perfect; if the song consists mainly of open chords played at the top of the neck, he might instead tune around the second fret. Compromises that I was blithely unaware of were of the utmost importance to Derryberry. (I later learned that professionals doing studio work will sometimes retune a guitar for the purpose of dubbing in a single chord.)

 

除此之外，还有一个完整的替代调音领域（或者古典乐手所说的 scordatura），其中不包括调整单个音符的音高，而是改变指板上可用的音符组及其所在位置。初学者几乎总是坚持使用所谓的西班牙语或标准调音。但乔尼·米切尔 (Joni Mitchell)、瑞·库德 (Ry Cooder) 和基思·理查兹 (Keith Richards)（部分向库德学习）等吉他手以将吉他重新调音到不同的参考音符、改变现成的音符调色板而闻名。这是有代价的——替代调弦会进一步加重吉他手的记忆力，因为许多痛苦学习的和弦形状的许多指法都会相应改变——但一些吉他手很乐意付出代价，因为替代调弦往往会开辟新的音乐领域。例如，开放式 D 调弦可以让吉他发出比平常更深的一个音符。

Beyond this, there is an entire realm of alternate tuning (or what classical players refer to as scordatura), which consists not of tweaking the pitching of individual notes but rather in changing the set of notes available on the fretboard and where they are located. Beginners almost always stick to something called Spanish or standard tuning. But guitarists like Joni Mitchell, Ry Cooder, and Keith Richards (who learned in part from Cooder) are famous for retuning their guitars to different reference notes, changing the palette of notes that are readily available. There is a cost to this— alternative tunings tax the memory of a guitarist even further, since many of the fingerings of many painfully learned chord shapes change accordingly— but some guitarists happily pay the price because alternate tunings often open new musical frontiers. Open-D tuning, for example, allows the guitar to sing, as it were, one note deeper than it ordinarily could.

 

像 Derryberry 这样的人不仅知道他的吉他手同伴使用的歌曲、旋律和装备，还知道他们使用什么调音以及哪些歌曲。例如，有一次，他对我说：“我用标准调弦或开放 E 弹奏滑音吉他，就像杜安·奥尔曼 (Duane Allman) 或埃尔莫尔·詹姆斯 (Elmore James) 那样。我没有对吉他做过太多的开放 G 调音。我知道很多人都这么做。” （理查兹在《Honky Tonk Women》中的吉他作品直接源自他从 Cooder 那里学到的开放 G 调。）其他替代调弦旨在使某些和弦更容易或扩展吉他的音调范围（如 Robert Fripp 的“新标准调音”）。每个交替调音都以某种方式巧妙地改变音乐家的选择，改变哪些和弦容易演奏以及哪些和弦容易过渡到下一个和弦的动态。

A guy like Derryberry knows not only the songs and melodies and gear that his fellow guitarists use, but what tunings they use, and for which songs. At one point, for example, he said to me, “I play slide [guitar] in standard tuning or open E, like Duane Allman or Elmore James. I haven’t done much open-G tuning on guitar. I know a lot of guys do.” (Richards’s guitar work on “Honky Tonk Women” grew directly out of a lesson he got from Cooder in open G.) Other alternate tunings are designed to make certain chords easier or to extend the pitch range of the guitar (as in Robert Fripp’s “New Standard Tuning”). Each alternate tuning in some way subtly alter the musician’s options, changing the dynamics of which chords are easily played and which chords transition easily to the next.

 

 

专家还必须掌握他们所演奏的流派的惯用语。例如，重金属吉他手演奏每个音符的方式比民谣吉他手更尖锐。流派的定义不仅仅是旋律和节奏，还有他们喜欢的和声，甚至各个音符如何发声和保持的细节。正如一位音乐家所说，“伊扎克·帕尔曼是一位伟大的小提琴家，但这并不意味着他可以演奏克莱兹默。” 即使掌握了所有基础知识，每种新类型也需要不同的细微差别。例如，识别表达时间差异的能力是针对特定类型进行调整的；了解爵士乐的人会注意到爵士乐作品中的微小变化，但有时会错过古典乐曲中相应的微小变化，反之亦然。我毫不怀疑，如果帕尔曼愿意的话，他可以学习成为一名伟大的克莱兹默演奏家，但音乐家可以学习的东西以及应用于新音乐的东西是无穷无尽的。

Experts must also come to master the idioms of the genres in which they play. A heavy metal guitarist, for example, strikes each note in a sharper way than a folk guitarist might. Genres are defined not just by melodies and rhythms but also by the harmonies they favor and even by details about how individual notes are sounded and held. As one musician put it, “Itzhak Perlman is a great violinist, but that doesn’t mean he can play klezmer.” Even once one has mastered all the basics, each new genre demands a different kind of nuance. The capacity to recognize expressive timing differences, for instance, is tuned to particular genres; people who know jazz notice micro-variations in jazz compositions but sometimes miss equivalent micro-variations in classical compositions, and vice versa. I have no doubt that Perlman could learn to be a great klezmer player if he wanted to, but the list of things a musician can learn— and bring to bear on new music— is endless.

 

“我可以演奏吉米·亨德里克斯曾经演奏过的每一个音符，”吉他之神史蒂夫·瓦伊曾经说过。“我可以完全按照他演奏的方式演奏每个音符，但我无法想象他最初是如何想到的。”

“I can play every note that Jimi Hendrix ever played,” the guitar deity Steve Vai once said. “And I can play each note exactly the way he played it, but I can’t imagine how he thought of it in the first place.”

成千上万的音乐家已经掌握了我一直在努力解决的所有细节——比如坚如磐石的时间感，以及快速流畅地知道在哪里可以找到所有音符和和弦——但没有在音乐上留下任何痕迹。Vai、Yngwie Malmsteen 和 Joe Satriani 等少数人主要因其技术熟练程度而闻名，但 Lenny Kaye 等音乐家明确表示，技术实力只是众多途径中的一条。音乐家可以凭借其作品的原创性（就像鲍勃·迪伦所做的那样，尽管缺乏古典旋律的歌声）、动态的调制（齐柏林飞艇魔法的一部分）或纯粹的舞台表现力（想想《KISS》或《奥兹》）来留下自己的印记。奥斯本）。许多朋克摇滚歌手几乎无法演奏他们的乐器，但却发展出了一种新的能量——侵略性和尖锐——吸引了大批粉丝。正如NY Rock 1996 年发表的一篇文章，略带讽刺地写道：

Many thousands of musicians have mastered all the minutiae I was struggling with— like a rock-solid sense of time and fast and fluent knowledge of where to find all the notes and chords— without making any sort of mark musically whatsoever. A few— like Vai, Yngwie Malmsteen, and Joe Satriani— are known primarily for their technical proficiency, but musicians like Lenny Kaye make it clear that technical prowess is just one route among many. Musicians can make their mark with the originality of their compositions (as Bob Dylan did, despite lacking a classically melodic singing voice), with their modulation of dynamics (part of Led Zeppelin’s magic), or with their sheer stage presence (think KISS or Ozzy Osbourne). Many punk rockers could barely play their instruments but developed a new kind of energy— aggressive and biting— that drew legions of fans. As a 1996 article in NY Rock put it, somewhat sarcastically:

 

大约 20 年前，当雷蒙斯乐队第一次踏上摇滚舞台时，所有成员都至少对各自的乐器有了基本的掌握。例如，汤米·雷蒙 (Tommy Ramone) 在乐队在 CBGB 举行首场演出之前花了两周的时间来掌握鼓。

When the Ramones first hit the rock circuit roughly 20 years ago, all members had at least a fundamental grasp of their respective instruments. Tommy Ramone, for instance, spent the better part of two weeks mastering the drums before the band played its first gig at CBGB.

 

正如大西洋唱片公司前总裁丹尼·戈德伯格（Danny Goldberg）对我说的那样，“能够复制某些东西和能够创造某些东西之间有一个单独的类别。第一个需要大量的技术技能和音乐性。但作为作家即兴创作和创作新音乐的能力是一项单独的技能。有些人两者兼而有之，而有些人（例如经典录音室音乐家）擅长演奏，而不擅长写作或创造新事物。这是两种不同的天赋。有时它们会嵌入到同一个人身上，就像亨德里克斯同时拥有这两种才能。”

As Danny Goldberg, former president of Atlantic Records, put it to me, “There’s a separate category between being able to replicate something and being able to create something. The first requires enormous technical skill and musicality. But the ability to improvise and create new music as a writer is a separate skill. Some people possess both, and some, such as classic studio musicians, are people great at playing, not great at writing or creating something new. Those are two different talents. Sometimes they are embedded in the same person, like Hendrix had both talents.”

 

 

业余爱好者只是将他或她的乐器视为发现的、不可改变的物体，而真正的艺术家常常试图突破极限。莱斯·保罗（Les Paul）几乎发明了实心电吉他，基思·理查兹（Keith Richards）从他的一些吉他上去掉了整个低音弦，虽然不那么引人注目，但仍然具有相当大的影响。（你可以在“Honky Tonk Women”和“Brown Sugar”等歌曲中听到这一点。）用他的话来说，“我发现我对整个六弦、常规调音的东西有点厌倦，[所以]我真的需要一些东西让我振作起来并重新开始。” 吉米·佩奇 (Jimmy Page) 在吉他上放了一把小提琴弓。史蒂夫·旺德 (Stevie Wonder) 是第一批尝试合成器的钢琴演奏家之一，披头士乐队 (Beatles) 是最早采用 Mellotron 的人之一，Mellotron 是钢琴键盘和磁带录音机的邪恶混合体，在《永远的草莓地》和《永远的草莓地》中都有突出表现。首先将录音室本身用作乐器，通过倒带和配音创造新的声音。

Whereas the amateur simply takes his or her instrument as a found, unalterable object, the true artist often tries to press the limits. Les Paul pretty much invented the solid-body electric guitar, and less dramatically but still with considerable impact Keith Richards removed the entire low bass string from some of his guitars. (You can hear this on songs like “Honky Tonk Women” and “Brown Sugar.”) In his words, “I found I was getting sort of jaded on the whole six string, the regular tuning stuff, [so] that I really needed something to perk me up and start again.” Jimmy Page brought a violin bow to his guitar. Stevie Wonder was among the first piano players to experiment with synthesizers, and the Beatles were among the earliest adopters of the Mellotron, an unholy hybrid between a piano keyboard and a tape deck that is featured prominently in “Strawberry Fields Forever,” and among the first to use the studio itself as an instrument, creating new sounds with backward tapes and overdubs.

吉米·亨德里克斯不仅操纵吉他的调音，还操纵吉他本身的本质，几乎监督其构造的每一个细节。正如传记作者 Dave Henderson 所说，Hendrix 更喜欢 Fender Stratocaster，部分原因是它们易于改装。他首先会“用手弯曲颤音杆”几个小时，使其[音调]下降三级，而不是通常的，同时使其足够靠近身体，以便他可以敲击个人琴弦并升高和降低音调。” 这也使得亨德里克斯能够在操纵音调控制的同时演奏打击杆。有时亨德里克斯甚至会拆掉吉他的后面板，以便他可以从后面触及琴弦，以创造一种新的声音。他还重新卷绕了吉他上的电磁拾音器，尝试了不寻常的琴弦组合（低音侧超重，高音侧超轻），在演奏时摆弄吉他的调音，并使用了特殊的琴颈板用回火钢固定，这样他就可以安全地弯曲吉他的琴颈。Hendrix 也是使用变声踏板的先驱，例如法兹踏板、哇音踏板（后来被认为是 1970 年代的放克）和变调 Octavia（可以将他演奏的音调降低整个八度） ）。最终的结果是吉他和踏板的结合，可以产生大量当时原始的声音，并进入声音空间的新部分。

Jimi Hendrix manipulated not just the tuning of his guitars but the very nature of the guitars themselves, overseeing virtually every detail of their construction. As the biographer Dave Henderson tells it, Hendrix preferred Fender Stratocasters in part because they were easy to modify. He would begin by bending the tremolo (whammy bar) “by hand for several hours to get it to go down [in pitch] three steps, in stead of the customary one, also get it near enough to the body so he could tap individual strings and raise and lower their pitch.” This also allowed Hendrix to play with the whammy bar at the same time as he manipulated the tone controls. Sometimes Hendrix would even remove the back panel of the guitar so that he could reach the string from behind, in service of creating yet a new kind of sound. He also re-coiled the electromagnetic pickups on his guitar, experimented with unusual combinations of strings (extra heavy on the bass side, superlight on the treble), fiddled with the tuning of his guitar while he was playing, and used a special neck plate anchored with tempered steel so that he could safely bend his guitar’s neck. Hendrix was also a pioneer in the use of sound-altering pedals, like fuzz pedals, the wah pedal (subsequently identified with 1970s funk), and the pitch-shifting Octavia (which could drop the pitch of what he was playing by an entire octave). The net result was a conjunction of guitar and pedals that could produce a vast array of then-original sounds and an entrée into new parts of sonic space.

 

探索的传统仍在延续。帕特·麦瑟尼 (Pat Metheny) 将他的吉他技能的一个重要部分归功于他在他的第一件乐器——小号上的体验，以及有意识地努力把他在小号上学到的知识——尤其是如何清晰地表达乐句（音符序列）——到吉他。同样，汤姆·莫雷洛（Tom Morello）表示，在大学的成长岁月中，他每天大约四分之一的练习时间都在尝试“怪异”和奇怪的声音，其中一些是通过快速切换决定吉他声音放大方式的拾音器开关而产生的。他说，即便如此，他更像是一个录音室音乐家。直到 20 世纪 90 年代初，当他开始仔细聆听 Dr. Dre 和 Jam Master Jay 等 DJ 的音乐时（最重要的是，思考如何将他们刺耳的颤音和合成纹理导入到吉他中），他才真正成为一名真正的艺术家，不仅仅是重新创作别人的声音，而是创作和演奏自己的声音。

The exploratory tradition continues. Pat Metheny attributes an important part of his skill on the guitar to experience he had on his first instrument, the trumpet, and to a conscious effort to bring what he had learned on trumpet— especially about how to articulate phrases (sequences of notes)—to the guitar. Likewise, Tom Morello said that in his formative years in college he spent roughly a quarter of his daily practice regimen experimenting with “eccentricities” and weird noises, some created by rapidly toggling the pickup switch that determines how the guitar’s sounds get amplified. Even then, he said, he was still more of a studio musician. It was only in the early 1990s, when he started listening carefully to DJs like Dr. Dre and Jam Master Jay— and, crucially, thinking about how to import their scratchy warblings and synthesized textures into guitar— that he truly became a genuine artist, not just re-creating other people’s sounds, but composing and playing his own.

 

 

音乐史上最令人着迷的飞跃之一，无论是在个人内部还是在整个音乐领域，都是鲍勃·迪伦在发行第一张专辑后采取的上述戏剧性步骤。

One of the most intriguing leaps forward in the history of music, both within an individual and in the field of music as a whole, was the aforementioned dramatic step Bob Dylan took after the release of his first album.

甚至在迪伦录制他的第一张专辑之前，他就具有一定的魅力。他在格林威治村培养了一批追随者，并在二十岁时被传奇人物约翰·哈蒙德（John Hammond）发现（他早些时候发现了本尼·古德曼（Benny Goodman）、比莉·哈乐黛（Billie Holiday）和艾瑞莎·富兰克林（Aretha Franklin）等人）。但当时很多人仍然无法理解哈蒙德为何签下他。迪伦的声音粗哑，他的笛子远不如西纳特拉或埃尔维斯的优雅。彼得、保罗和玛丽如此受欢迎的微妙的三声部和声，是迪伦无法企及的。最糟糕的是，迪伦为哥伦比亚唱片公司制作的第一张专辑失败了，第一年仅售出 5000 张。许多人认为哥伦比亚公司搞砸了，整个事件很快就被称为“哈蒙德的愚蠢行为”。

Even before Dylan had recorded his first album, he had a certain charisma; he’d developed a following in Greenwich Village and at the age of twenty was discovered by the legendary John Hammond (who had earlier discovered Benny Goodman, Billie Holiday, and Aretha Franklin, among many others). But at the time, many people still couldn’t understand why Hammond had signed him. Dylan had a gruff voice and was endowed with a set of pipes far less elegant than Sinatra’s or Elvis’s; the delicate three-part harmonies that made Peter, Paul, and Mary so popular were wildly out of Dylan’s reach. To top it off, Dylan’s first album, for Columbia Records, flopped, selling only five thousand copies its first year. Many thought Columbia had goofed, and the whole episode soon became known as “Hammond’s Folly.”

 

剩下的就是历史了。迪伦很快就开始认真创作原创歌曲，并几乎立即产生了巨大的影响。1961 年 11 月，迪伦录制了他的第一张专辑，到 1962 年夏天，他录制了他的第二张更令人印象深刻的专辑，这之间发生了什么？是一万个小时的紧张起草和重新起草歌曲吗？声乐课？约得尔调练习？

The rest is history. Dylan soon started writing original songs in earnest and made a huge impact almost immediately. What happened between November 1961, when Dylan recorded his first album, and the summer of 1962, when he recorded his second, far more impressive album? Was it ten thousand hours of intense drafting and redrafting of songs? Vocal lessons? Yodeling practice?

 

根据迪伦自己的说法，以上都不是。有练习当然，很多，甚至可能还上一两堂歌唱课（尽管迪伦没有表现出来，谁知道呢？）。但就迪伦而言，真正的关键并不是练习，而是有意识地、刻意地努力寻找自己的音乐道路。迪伦描述说“他的大脑里充满了诗歌”，并无休止地聆听其他音乐家的歌曲，试图理解他们的旋律和结构。有两件事在他的记忆中尤为突出——观看了一部特定的音乐作品，并听到了一位当时默默无闻的特定音乐家的声音。在那之前，迪伦（据他自己的说法）基本上是伍迪·格思里（Woody Guthrie）的崇拜者，固守格思里的风格，但没有添加太多原创内容。他还参加了贝尔托·布莱希特和库尔特·威尔创作的歌曲的戏剧制作。

By Dylan’s own account, none of the above. There was practice aplenty, to be sure, and maybe even a singing lesson or two (though Dylan didn’t let on, and who could tell?). But the real key, in Dylan’s case, was not so much practice as a conscious, deliberate effort to find his own musical path. Dylan describes “cramming [his brain] with poems” and listening endlessly to the songs of other musicians, seeking to understand their melodies and structure. Two incidents stand out in his memory— seeing a particular musical production and hearing a particular musician who at that point was unknown. Until then, Dylan had largely been (by his own account) a Woody Guthrie wannabe, wedded to Guthrie’s style without adding much that was original to it. And he sat in on a theatrical production of songs written by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill.

 

我的观点……即将改变。空气的强度很快就会增强，变得更加强大。我在宇宙中的小小屋即将扩建成一座辉煌的大教堂……[我]立即被歌曲的原始强度所唤醒……语言粗俗的歌曲……不稳定、不节奏、断断续续。……每首歌……臀部口袋里似乎都有一把手枪、一根棍棒或一块砖头。……它们就像民歌……但也不同于民歌，因为它们很复杂。

My perspective … was about to change. The air would soon shoot up in intensity and become more potent. My little shack in the universe was about to expand into some glorious cathedral…[I] was aroused straight away by the raw intensity of the songs … songs with tough language … erratic, unrhythmical and herky-jerky. … Every song … seemed to have a pistol in its hip pocket, a club or a brickbat. … They were like folk songs … but unlike folk songs, too, because they were sophisticated.

 

迪伦对一首名为“海盗珍妮”的歌曲以及它如何使用关于一艘黑色货船的“幽灵合唱”感到特别震惊；他在脑子里一遍又一遍地盘旋这首歌，试图找出是什么让它响起。“每个短语都是从十英尺高的地方向你袭来，然后迅速穿过马路，然后另一个短语就像是一记重拳打在你的下巴上。......这是一首令人讨厌的歌曲，由一个邪恶的恶魔演唱，当她唱完时，......它让你喘不过气来......它的结构和对已知的旋律模式的确定性的漠视......[给了它最前沿的。” 迪伦受到了启发。

Dylan was especially struck by a song known as “Pirate Jenny” and how it used a “ghost chorus” about a black freighter ship; he swirled the song over and over in his head to try to determine what made it tick. “Each phrase comes at you from a ten-foot drop, scuttles across the road and then another one comes like a punch on the chin. … It’s a nasty song, sung by an evil fiend, and when she’s done singing, … it leaves you breathless.…[T]he structure and disregard for the known certainty of melodic patterns…[gave] it its cutting edge.” Dylan was inspired.

 

不久之后，约翰·哈蒙德给迪伦带来了一张专辑当时的人们（包括迪伦）都听说过：三角洲蓝调之王——由一位名叫罗伯特·约翰逊的歌手演唱。用迪伦的话来说：

Not long after, John Hammond brought Dylan an album few people at the time (including Dylan) had ever heard of: King of the Delta Blues— by a singer named Robert Johnson. In Dylan’s words:

 

当约翰逊开始唱歌时，他看起来就像是从宙斯的头顶上跳出来的人。……我立即区分了他和我听过的其他人。……我抄袭了约翰逊的话……这样我就可以更仔细地检查歌词和模式……自由联想……闪闪发光的寓言，包裹在无意义抽象的硬壳中的大真理。……我没有任何这些梦想或想法，但我要实现它们。

When Johnson started singing, he seemed like a guy who could have sprung from the head of Zeus. … I immediately differentiated between him and anyone else I had ever heard. … I copied Johnson’s words … so I could more closely examine the lyrics and patterns … the free association … the sparkling allegories, big-ass truths wrapped in the hard shell of nonsensical abstraction. … I didn’t have any of these dreams or thoughts but I was going to acquire them.

 

迪伦将他从格思里那里学到的东西与布莱希特、威尔和约翰逊的新发现结合起来，发明了一种新的艺术形式；他的巨大而辛勤的劳动和艰苦的研究是不可或缺的，但他的洞察力和综合能力使他达到了一个新的水平。

In combining what he’d already learned from Guthrie with his new discoveries from Brecht, Weill, and Johnson, Dylan invented a new art form; his enormous, searing labors and painstaking investigations were indispensable, but his insight and synthesis were what brought him to a new level.

 

当保罗意识到他可以在自己的直接经历之外写关于虚构人物的歌曲时，披头士乐队可能经历了类似的革命。情歌消失了，埃莉诺·里格比进来了，死在教堂里，与她的名字一起埋葬，不久之后凯特先生就得到了好处。

The Beatles may have undergone a similar revolution when Paul realized that he could write songs about fictional characters outside of his own immediate experience. Out went love songs, in came Eleanor Rigby, died in a church, buried along with her name, and soon there after there were benefits for Mr. Kite.

 

像这样的激进创新本身与实践无关，但正如法国生物学家路易斯巴斯德所说，“机会青睐有准备的头脑。” 麦卡特尼和迪伦都积累了足够的技术积累，他们可以立即将他们的新见解付诸实践。

Radical innovations like these aren’t about practice per se, but as the pioneering French biologist Louis Pasteur said, “Chance favors the prepared mind.” McCartney and Dylan had both accumulated enough technical chops that they could put their new insights to immediate work without delay.

 

 

唱片业高管丹尼·戈德堡 (Danny Goldberg) 解释说：“对于我所钦佩并与之合作过的一些艺术家，我注意到的一件事是，有些艺术家变得非常成功——迪伦就是当然是其中之一，史蒂夫·厄尔（Steve Earle）是其中之一，斯普林斯汀（Springsteen）是其中之一，埃尔顿·约翰（Elton John）是彻底研究艺术形式的人。他们不仅是艺术家，而且对历史和之前的事情拥有丰富的百科全书式知识。然后每隔一段时间你可能会遇到一个完全由内心引导的人。”

“One thing I’ve noticed about some of the artists that I’ve admired and worked with,” the record industry executive Danny Goldberg explained, “is that there are certain artists who became very successful— Dylan is certainly one of these, Steve Earle is one, Springsteen is one, Elton John is one— who study the art form exhaustively. Not only are they artists, but they have this tremendous encyclopedic knowledge about the history, what came before. And then every once in a while you might meet somebody who is totally inner directed.”

戈德堡接着列举了两个立即可识别的表演（未记录）并补充道，“他们知道一些音乐，但很明显这些音乐来自他们内心的某些东西，而不是来自大量的研究。最引人注目的音乐来自内部，而不是外部，尽管您可以在外部学习一些语法和工具。一些伟大的大师平衡了他们从外部吸收的东西与内心的声音。对我来说，这就是迪伦和斯普林斯汀所做的。”

Goldberg went on to name two immediately recognizable acts (off the record) and added, “They know some music, but it’s just clear the music is coming from something inside them, and not from enormous study. The most compelling music comes from inside, not outside, although you can learn some of the grammar and tools outside. [S]ome of the great masters balance what they can absorb from outside with an inner voice. To me that’s what Dylan and Springsteen do.”

 

 

有一次，我问道格·德里贝里（Doug Derryberry）他与其他音乐家的工作关系：他们谈论过技术细节吗？不多; 他二十岁出头的时候，这样的对话有很多，但现在他已经是一位颇有造诣的音乐家了，这样的对话就很少见了。他只记得最近与一位音乐家同事（一位贝斯手）就安东尼奥·卡洛斯·若宾（Antonio Carlos Jobim）的音乐进行了一次严肃的音乐对话。我问，他们是用手中的乐器聊天，还是更像国际象棋大师，对棋步了如指掌，即使面前没有棋盘也能说话？“不，”道格笑着说，“我们手里没有乐器，我们手里拿着饮料。”

At one point, I asked Doug Derryberry about his working relationship with other musicians: Did they talk technicalities? Not much; he had a lot of such conversations in his early twenties, but now that he was an accomplished musician, such conversations were rare. He could recall just one recent serious conversation about music with a fellow musician— a bass player— about the music of Antonio Carlos Jobim. Did they chat with instruments in hand, I asked, or were they more like chess masters, knowing the moves so well they could speak without a board in front of them? “No,” Doug said, chuckling, “we didn’t have our instruments in our hands, we had drinks in our hands.”

后来，Derryberry 讲述了多年前 Derryberry 加入乐队后不久，他与老板 Bruce Hornsby 的一次谈话。他回忆起向霍恩斯比询问“和声参数”的问题，例如，“你是否认为这个[和弦]是另一个和弦的替代主音，因为它会转到这个和弦？” 而且，正如德里贝里所说，霍恩斯比对他不予理睬，说了一些诸如“是啊，是啊，是啊，那太好了，那太好了”之类的话——根本没有真正深入探讨这个问题。我问是否这意味着霍恩斯比不知道他的理论。“哦，不，”道格用田纳西州的轻快语气慢吞吞地说，“[布鲁斯]很深沉，很深沉。他去了伯克利大学和迈阿密大学。他知道[他的音乐理论]，但他想留在另一边。意思是更内在、更情感的一面。就像，你已经了解了为什么比尔·埃文斯会玩他所做的事情或基思·贾勒特为什么会玩他所做的事情的理论机制，然后你就掌握了这一切。然后你就会出现在另一边并创作自己的艺术。”

Later, Derryberry related a conversation he’d had years ago with his boss Bruce Hornsby, not long after Derryberry had joined the band. He recalled asking Hornsby about “harmonic parameters,” like, “Do you think of this [chord] as a substitute dominant for this other chord because then it goes to this chord?” And, as Derryberry tells it, Hornsby brushed him off, saying something like, “Yeah, yeah, yeah, that’s great, that’s good”—without really digging into the question at all. I asked if that meant Hornsby doesn’t know his theory. “Oh, no,” Doug drawled in his Tennessee lilt, “[Bruce] is deep, deep. He went to Berklee and the University of Miami. He knows [his music theory], but he wants to stay on the other side. Meaning on the more visceral, emotional side of it. Like, that you’ve gone through the mechanics of the theory of the whys and wherefore of why Bill Evans would play what he does or why Keith Jarrett would play what he does, and then you grasp all that. And then you emerge at the other side and make your own art.”

 

 

重金属

HEAVY METAL

 

是什么让这一切变得值得

What Makes It All Worthwhile

 

从任何合理的标准来看，我个人的追求都是成功的。一年半后，我终于对许多基本和弦感到满意，并且可以在它们之间顺利地改变，至少在节奏上是大致的。像形成和弦这样的基础知识已经从我只能抽象地谈论的痛苦、缓慢的陈述性知识变成了我的手指实际上可以自动且几乎毫不费力地执行的程序。我的耳朵也变得更好了。我开始能够区分不同的音乐音程，并且我终于学会了计算歌曲中的节拍。尽管我的歌曲曲目仍然很少（宽容地说），但我学会了即兴创作并创作自己的音乐。也许还不足以成为一支乐队的主唱，但足以与我的朋友一起即兴演奏，并且足够好到我想在余生中继续演奏和学习音乐。

By any reasonable standard, my personal quest had been a success. A year and a half in, I was finally comfortable with many of the basic chords and could change between them smoothly, and at least roughly in tempo. Fundamentals like forming chords had gone from being painful, slow bits of declarative knowledge that I could talk about only abstractly to procedures that my fingers could actually carry out, automatically and almost effortlessly. My ears had gotten better, too. I was starting to be able to distinguish different music intervals, and I’d finally learned to count the beats in a song. Although my repertoire of songs was still tiny (to put it charitably), I’d learned to improvise and to make up my own music. Not well enough to headline a band, perhaps, but well enough to jam with my friends, and well enough that I wanted to keep playing and studying music for the rest of my life.

与开始该项目时相比，我对听到的音乐也有了更好的理解。我可以挑选出低音线，识别不同的击鼓模式，并告诉不同的吉他手使用什么技术。我已经培养了一种编曲感以及如何将不同的歌曲组合在一起的感觉。听迈尔斯·戴维斯的《Kind of Blue》，我最喜欢的爵士乐录音，成为一种超凡的体验。我可以理解音乐家们想要做什么——他们演奏音阶的方式以及他们正在探索的节奏。

I also understood the music I heard vastly better than when I’d begun the project. I could pick out bass lines, recognize different drumming patterns, and tell what techniques different guitarists used. I had developed a sense of arrangement and how different songs were put together. Listening to Miles Davis’s Kind of Blue, long my favorite jazz recording, became a transcendent experience. I could understand what the musicians were trying to do— the way they were playing around with scales and the rhythms they were exploring.

 

我的大脑也发生了变化。虽然不像专家那样，但我能感知到的东西以及我能产生的东西的差异确实令人惊讶。如果我还不是一名真正的音乐家，那我肯定已经在路上了。我没有找到神奇的捷径，但练习——尤其是旨在发展特定技能和弥补弱点的仔细有针对性的练习——是有效的，即使对于像我这样先天性心律失常的人也是如此。

My brain had changed, too. Not to the extent that it would in an expert, but the differences in what I could perceive— and what I could produce— were truly astonishing. If I wasn’t yet a bona fide musician, I was certainly on my way. I had found no miraculous shortcuts, but practice— especially carefully targeted practice aimed at developing specific skills and remedying weaknesses— worked, even for someone as congenitally arrhythmic as me.

 

我可能不会像一个熟练的孩子那样很快地拿起乐器，但作为一个成年人，我仍然有一些优势。我对音乐理论的抽象概念有了更强的理解能力，对音乐创作的整体感觉也有了更好的认识。如果练习、决心和更深入的概念理解还没有完全克服年龄和缺乏天赋的双重障碍，那么他们至少是一场势均力敌的比赛。而且，正如我逐渐意识到的那样，没有人真正具有与生俱来的音乐本能。相反，音乐是一种每个人都需要重新构建的技能，这些技能甚至在音乐出现之前就已经进化了广泛的大脑功能。每个人，无论天赋如何，都必须面对掌握节奏、旋律和和声的所有挑战，建立无缝和自动的连接，让耳朵、大脑和身体在时间和音乐空间中一起流动。天赋可以帮助一些人更快地实现这一目标，甚至可以让他们走得更远；年轻也可能有帮助。但即使在我这个年纪，甚至在我的天赋明显缺乏的情况下，在一位好老师和一堆书籍和听力训练软件的帮助下，进步不仅是可能的，而且是完全可以实现的——有时令人恐惧，可以肯定的是，但总体而言非常令人满意。

I might not be picking up an instrument as quickly as an adept child might, but as an adult I still had some advantages. I had a greater capacity to understand the abstractions of music theory and a better sense of music composition as a whole. If practice, determination, and a greater conceptual understanding hadn’t entirely overcome the twin obstacles of age and lack of talent, they had at least made for an even match. And, as I had come to realize, nobody was literally born with an instinct for music. Instead, music was a skill that each person would need to construct anew, from a wide range of brain faculties that evolved even before music existed. Everyone, no matter how innately gifted, would have to face all the challenges in mastering rhythm, melody, and harmony, in building the seamless and automatic connections that allow ear, brain, and body to flow together in time and musical space. Talent could help some people get there quicker, and maybe take them further; youth might be helpful, too. But even at my age, and even in my case, where innate talent was notably lacking, with the help of a good teacher and a pile of books and ear-training software, progress was not just possible but eminently realizable—frightening at times, to be sure, but on the whole immensely satisfying.

 

我并不打算辞掉我的日常工作，但我参加了一场录音室演唱会，然后又进行了一场现场演出，弹奏主音吉他并为主唱披头士乐队的翻唱歌曲“With a Little Help from My Friends”。在布鲁克林的尤克里里音乐节上，音乐制作人罗杰·格林纳瓦特 (Roger Greenawalt) 在全国范围内举办的披头士乐队全集音乐会上，在 200 人面前。

I was not about to quit my day job, but I participated in a studio singing gig and then had a live gig, playing lead guitar and singing lead vocals to a Beatles cover—“With a Little Help from My Friends”—in front of two hundred people, at the music producer Roger Greenawalt’s nationally covered Beatles Complete on Ukulele festival, in Brooklyn.

 

十八个月后，我什至开始接受我的宿敌——节奏。圣诞节前夕，罗杰（一直在给我上课）给我留了一张纸条，说：“你昨天取得了突破。那确实是你正在演奏的音乐。干得好。你已经走了很长很长的路。” 从任何意义上来说，我真的变得有音乐天赋了。

After eighteen months, I had even started to come to terms with my nemesis, rhythm. Just before Christmas, Roger (who had been giving me lessons) dropped me a note to say, “You had a breakthrough yesterday. That was really music you were playing. Good work. You’ve come a long, long way.” I really had, in every sense of the word, become musical.

 

 

然而，毫无疑问，成为音乐人是我从事过的最困难的项目。除了国际象棋之外，没有什么比这更需要如此多的学习了。问题依然存在：我为什么要这么努力？为什么有人，尤其是一个不希望将音乐作为职业的业余爱好者，要投入如此多的时间和精力？

Yet becoming musical has been, without question, the hardest project I’ve ever taken on; nothing else, except maybe chess, has required as much study. The question remains: Why do I try so hard? Why would anyone, especially an amateur who had no hope of making music into a career, put in so much time and effort?

在某些方面，随着技术的飞速发展，这个问题近年来变得更加尖锐。这不仅是因为我们大多数人永远无法像吉米·亨德里克斯那样富有想象力和灵巧地演奏，甚至没有人能够像 CD 播放器那样再现交响乐等声音：几十年内，可能没有人能够像机器那样完美地弹奏吉他。认知心理学家菲尔·约翰逊·莱尔德（Phil Johnson-Laird）开发了一种软件，可以以心理上真实的方式即兴演奏爵士乐，不久前，丰田公司还创造了第一位机器人小提琴手。帕特·梅瑟尼最近与一支完全由机器人组成的乐队进行了巡演。自从大约 1842 年第一架自动钢琴问世以来，人们就一直在接受终生的训练，以实现机器可以瞬间完成的任务。

In some ways, that question has only become more acute in recent years, as technology has raced ahead. It’s not just that most of us will never be able to play with the imagination and dexterity of Jimi Hendrix, or even that no single human being will ever be able to reproduce the sounds of, say, a symphony the way a CD player can: within a few decades, it may be that no human being will be able to play a guitar with the technical perfection that a machine might. The cognitive psychologist Phil Johnson-Laird has built software that improvises jazz in psychologically realistic ways, and not long ago Toyota created the first robot violinist. Pat Metheny recently toured with a band that consisted entirely of robots. Ever since the first player piano, circa 1842, there has been a kind of poignancy in training for a lifetime to do what a machine could do in an instant.

 

在 iPhone 管弦乐队的时代，我不禁想知道：为什么我要花这么多时间尝试演奏传统乐器，而机器凭借其无限的耐心和完美的时间和音高感，几乎可以做我想要的所有事情。能做得更好吗？

In the era of the iPhone orchestra, I couldn’t help but wonder: Why was I investing so much time trying to play a traditional musical instrument when machines, with their infinite patience and perfect sense of timing and pitch, can do nearly everything I can do so much better?

 

 

技术总是在改变音乐。早些时候我讨论了亨德里克斯和披头士乐队等艺术家如何使用 20 世纪 60 年代出现的技术；在 20 世纪 80 年代，其他艺术家用合成器、鼓机和采样器开辟了道路。如今，有一些聪明的软件工具，例如 Tristan Jehan 的 Swinger，它接收音频文件并修改每个节拍，使其具有摆动的节奏，每个节拍的前半部分比后半部分长。该节目的“Every Breath You Take”的爵士乐演绎并没有让你大吃一惊，但它仍然相当令人惊叹。

Technology is always changing music. Earlier I discussed how artists like Hendrix and the Beatles used technologies that emerged in the 1960s; in the 1980s, other artists blazed trails with synthesizers, drum machines, and samplers. Today, there are clever software tools like Tristan Jehan’s Swinger, which takes in an audio file and modifies each beat so that it has rhythm that swings, the first half of each beat longer than the second. The program’s jazzy rendition of “Every Breath You Take” doesn’t quite take your breath away, but it’s still pretty amazing.

世界上大量的青少年和一些成年人已经从《吉他英雄》中获得了音乐乐趣。正如该游戏的联合创始人之一 Eran Egozy（后来联合创立了 Harmonix 公司，也是竞争产品《摇滚乐队》的制作人）告诉我的那样，一些音乐家已经开始思考他们的歌曲如何融入游戏，修改贝斯线和吉他独奏，使摇滚乐队中的它们更有趣。说唱明星 Snoop Dogg 重新混音了整张专辑的歌曲，使它们更好地融入游戏中。与此同时，最新版本的《吉他英雄》和《摇滚乐队》正在扩展计算机辅助教学的传统，帮助获取音乐的过程变得更加民主。未来，计算机可能会释放传统乐器无法比拟的音乐可能性。（例如，Jehan 和我谈到了 Photoshop 的未来类似物，它可能会让你改变歌曲的流派，就像 Photoshop 滤镜可以使照片看起来像印象派绘画一样。）

Already, a great number of the world’s teenagers, and some adults, get their musical fix from Guitar Hero. As one of the game’s co-founders, Eran Egozy (who has since co-founded the company Harmonix, producers of the competing product Rock Band), told me, some musicians have already begun to think about how their songs fit into the game, tinkering with bass lines and guitar solos to make them more fun in Rock Band. The rap star Snoop Dogg remixed an entire album’s worth of songs to make them fit better into the game. Meanwhile, the latest versions of Guitar Hero and Rock Band are extending a tradition of computer-aided instruction that is helping the process of acquiring music become more democratic. In the future, computers might unlock musical possibilities that more traditional musical instruments can’t match. (Jehan and I, for example, talked about a future analogue to Photoshop that might let you change the genre of a song in much the way that a Photoshop filter can make a photograph look like an Impressionist painting.)

 

我与 Jehan 和 Egozy 等尖端音乐技术专家交谈得越多，我就越开始想知道为什么我们更喜欢（或认为我们更喜欢）人生成的音乐而不是机器生成的音乐，最重要的是，为什么它是我们人类坚持从事劳动——比如弹钢琴或解决数独难题——而这些劳动很容易被机器取代。

The more I talked with cutting-edge music technologists like Jehan and Egozy, the more I began to wonder why it is that we prefer (or think we prefer) music generated by people to music generated by machines, and, most important, why it is that we humans persist in labors— like playing piano or solving Sudoku puzzles— that could so easily be replaced by machines.

 

如果用1%的努力就能得到40%的收益，后代的年轻人还用得着真正的乐器吗？

If one can get 40 percent of the benefit with 1 percent of the effort, will future generations of young people bother with real instruments?

 

 

坚持学习音乐最明显的原因之一是它实际上可能对你的大脑有益。过去十年的十几项研究表明，音乐训练与其他领域的成就之间存在相关性。有理由认为，接受过音乐训练的人可能更擅长学习外语，而且平均而言，他们的智商往往更高。一项仔细的分析表明，音乐家在诺贝尔奖获得者中所占比例过高。

One of the most obvious reasons to persist in learning about music is that it may actually be good for your brain. Over a dozen studies in the last decade have shown correlations between musical training and achievement in other domains. There is reason to think that people with musical training may be better at learning foreign languages, and they tend, on average, to have higher IQs. One careful analysis suggests that musicians are disproportionately represented among Nobel Prize winners.

但这些事实也应该引发怀疑。这些相关性是因果关系吗？或者，例如，聪明的人会被音乐所吸引，而与成就的相关性是否是一般智力促进两者的偶然？或者纯粹的Sitzfleisch（意第绪语，意为耐心坐在背后足够长的时间来完成某件事）可能是音乐和其他成就的重要组成部分吗？也许最自律的人在音乐和学校都表现最好，并不是因为音乐让你变得更聪明，而是因为愿意在音乐上最努力的人往往是在音乐上最努力的人。学校也一样。

But such facts should also trigger skepticism. Are these correlations causal? Or could it be, for example, that brighter people gravitate toward music and that the correlation with achievement is an accident of both being facilitated by general intelligence? Or might pure Sitzfleisch—Yiddish for the patience to sit on one’s behind long enough to get something done—be a vital component in both music and other kinds of achievements? Maybe the people who have the most self-discipline do best both in music and in school not because music makes you smarter but simply because people who are willing to work the hardest in music tend to be the people who are willing to work the hardest in school, too.

 

只有少数研究试图破解这个因果关系，主要是通过比较音乐与其他类型的培训（例如戏剧课和绘画课）中的成功之间的关系，表明音乐可能与学业成功有更大的相关性。加拿大音乐家兼发展心理学家格伦·谢伦伯格 (Glenn Schellenberg) 进行的一项最佳研究表明，这可能会产生适度但系统性的影响。在提高智力方面，音乐确实可能比戏剧课更有效，但数据（目前）还不是压倒性的，只有极少数经过精心控制的音乐课程。将学生随机分配到各组的研究。谢伦伯格本人持相对悲观的观点，他最近表示“几乎所有可用数据都可以简单地解释：智商较高的人比智商较低的同龄人更有可能参加音乐课程，而且他们也可能表现更好几乎适用于任何认知能力测试。”

Only a few studies have tried to crack the causal nut, mostly by comparing the relation between music and success in other kinds of training, such as drama lessons and painting classes, suggesting that music might have a larger correlation with academic success. The single best study, done by the Canadian musician and developmental psychologist Glenn Schellenberg, suggests that there may be modest but systematic effects. Music may indeed be more effective than, say, drama lessons in eliciting intellectual improvement, but the data aren’t (for now) overwhelming, with just an extremely small number of carefully controlled studies in which students were randomly assigned to groups. Schellenberg himself takes a relatively dark view, suggesting more recently that “almost all of the available data can be explained simply: Individuals with higher IQs are more likely to take music lessons than their lower-IQ peers, and they are also likely to perform better on virtually any test of cognitive abilities.”

 

即使音乐真正地灌输了自律或其他认知益处，即使音乐在这方面比戏剧课更胜一筹（一些证据表明上戏剧课的学生表现出社会优势），我们仍然会拥有在我们能够确定音乐是某种神奇的教育灵丹妙药之前，还有很多研究要做。例如，就每小时努力投入的认知回报而言，学习计算机编程可能比音乐课程更有效。对当前文献最乐观但公正的解读是，音乐训练确实带来了一些超越乐器本身的智力回报，但这些回报可能还不够大，无法证明许多人需要花费数千小时来学习音乐。才能成为真正的高手。无论音乐对教育有什么好处，结果都是一种额外的好处，而不是学习本身的原因。

Even if music genuinely instills self-discipline or other cognitive benefits, and even if music turns out to compare favorably with, say, drama lessons in this regard (some evidence suggests that students with drama lessons show social advantages), we would still have a lot of research left to do before we could safely decide that music is any kind of magic educational elixir. Learning to program computers, for example, might be more efficient, in terms of cognitive payoff per hour of hard work invested, than music lessons. The most optimistic but fair read of the current literature is that training in music does bring some intellectual rewards that extend beyond an instrument in itself, but that those rewards still may not be of great enough magnitude to justify the thousands of hours many people require in order to become truly skilled. Whatever educational benefits music has turn out to be a bonus, not the reason in itself for learning.

 

 

如果音乐的好处不大，为什么不直接玩电子游戏呢？《吉他英雄》比真正的吉他容易得多，很多人都非常喜欢它；对于那些没有一万个小时可以燃烧的人来说，《吉他英雄》提供了对成为一名真正的音乐家的模拟（尽管不完美）。它可能不会灌输同样的纪律意识，追星族也只是想象中的，但《吉他英雄》及其竞争对手《摇滚乐队》的票房收入已超过 30 亿美元。显然，即使不是真正的音乐，音乐模拟游戏仍然对人类的心理产生巨大的拉动。

If the benefits of music are modest, why not just play a video game instead? Guitar Hero is a lot easier than real guitar, and many people enjoy it tremendously; for someone who doesn’t have ten thousand hours to burn, Guitar Hero offers a simulation (however imperfect) of what it is to be a real musician. It may not instill the same sense of discipline, and the groupies are only imaginary, but Guitar Hero and its competitor Rock Band have grossed over three billion dollars. Clearly, even if they are not real music, music simulation games still exert a huge pull on the human psyche.

在某些方面，《吉他英雄》和《摇滚乐队》似乎头脑简单，几乎毫无意义。及时将彩色按钮与落下的圆点混合在一起似乎不太像是一项运动。由于顺序和时间是由游戏软件提供的，因此人们甚至不需要知道歌曲。不需要提前制定战略（如国际象棋），不需要强大的肌肉（如足球），也不需要虚张声势地战胜对手（如扑克）。很少有游戏对玩家的要求更低；我怀疑猴子可以被训练来演奏，并且至少有两个不同的研究团队已经建造了机器人，一个被称为 Slashbot，另一个被称为 Guitar Heronoid，它可以在 Expert 上浏览《吉他英雄》，而无需了解一点音乐。然而——根据我的经验——这款游戏可以让人感觉非常有价值。

In some ways, Guitar Hero and Rock Band seem so simple-minded as to be almost pointless; mashing colored buttons in time with falling dots hardly seems like a sport. Since the sequence and timing are provided by the game software, one doesn’t really even need to know the songs. There’s no need to strategize ahead (as in chess), no need for big muscles (as in football), and no need to bluff past one’s opponent (as in poker). Few games demand less of the player; I suspect monkeys could be trained to play, and at least two different teams of researchers have built robots, one known as Slashbot, the other as Guitar Heronoid, that can cruise through Guitar Hero on Expert, without knowing one bit about music. Yet—and I speak from experience—the game can feel intensely rewarding.

 

吸引力的一部分显然是社交性的：人们总是喜欢互相分享音乐，而像《摇滚乐队》（以及新版本的《吉他英雄》，其中几个人可以同时演奏不同的乐器）这样的游戏带来了这种体验，以一种更广泛的方式。比只是坐在那里听唱片专辑更积极的方式。而且（就像在真正的乐队或任何团队运动中一样），集体工作做得很好会带来不可否认的快乐。

Part of the appeal is obviously social: people have always enjoyed sharing music with one another, and games like Rock Band (and the newer version of Guitar Hero, in which several people can play different instruments simultaneously) bring that experience, in a far more active way than just sitting around listening to record albums ever could. And (as in a real band or in any team sport) there is an undeniable joy in the sense of a collective job well done.

 

吸引力的一部分是幻想感，就像任何视频游戏或虚拟现实模拟一样。这种幻想在《吉他英雄》和《摇滚乐队》中得到了很好的体现，心​​理学家称之为控制幻觉：我们越相信自己能够控制，我们就越快乐。在一组著名的研究中，参与者被要求坐在一个随机间隔突然发出噪音的房间里解决简单的算术问题。一组受试者别无选择，只能听，其他受试者则有一个紧急按钮，可以按下，以防噪音太大。尽管很少有参与者真正按下按钮，但仅仅控制感就让整个体验变得更容易忍受。在另一项著名的研究中，狗被放置在一个环境中，它们所做的一切都与它们的处境无关。结果就是所谓的习得性无助——本质上是抑郁症的一种形式。

And part of the appeal is a sense of fantasy, much as in any video game or simulation of virtual reality. That fantasy, implemented exceptionally well in Guitar Hero and Rock Band, is what psychologists call the illusion of control: the more we believe ourselves to be in control, the happier we are. In one famous set of studies, participants were asked to solve simple arithmetic problems while sitting in a room in which sudden blasts of noise occurred at random intervals. One group of subjects had no choice but to listen, the others had a panic button they were allowed to press in case the noise became too much. Though few participants actually pressed the button, the mere feeling of control made the entire experience considerably more bearable. In another famous study, dogs were put in an environment in which nothing they did correlated with their situation; so-called learned helplessness— essentially a form of depression— was the result.

 

然而，事实证明，尽管我们人类非常喜欢掌控一切，但我们并不总是那么善于判断我们是否真的拥有掌控权。《吉他英雄》旨在让您在没有真正掌控的情况下产生一种掌控的错觉。推断控制实际上是推断因果关系的练习。我们想知道 A 是否导致 B，但有时我们只知道当 A 发生时，B 也会发生。用技术术语来说，在这种情况下，我们错误地从时间偶然性推断出因果关系。《吉他英雄》和《摇滚乐队》利用这一事实提供了我所见过的最强大的控制幻觉之一：如果玩家在正确的时间按下按钮，计算机就会播放特定音符（或一组音符）的录音）由专业音乐家演奏。如果没有，则不会播放该音符（并且您可能会听到嘟嘟声或感觉到嗡嗡声，这是负面反馈）；塑料控制器增加了这种错觉。最终效果是，您感觉好像是您而不是基思·理查兹在弹吉他。你的意识可能更清楚——并意识到这只是一个诡计，你并没有真正产生音乐——但你的潜意识完全被愚弄了。

It turns out, however, that although we humans are quite fond of being in control, we aren’t always so good at telling whether we actually have it. Guitar Hero is designed to yield an illusion of control when you don’t really have it. Inferring control is really an exercise in inferring causality; we want to know whether A causes B, but sometimes all we know is that when A happens, B happens too. In technical jargon, in such cases we mistakenly infer causality from temporal contingency. Guitar Hero and Rock Band exploit this fact to deliver one of the most potent illusions of control I’ve ever seen: if the player presses the button at the right time, the computer plays back a recording of a particular note (or set of notes) played by a professional musician. If not, the note doesn’t play (and you might hear a beep or feel a buzz, by way of negative feedback); the plastic controller adds to the illusion. The net effect is that you feel as if it were you and not Keith Richards playing the guitar. Your conscious mind may know better— and realize that it’s all just a ruse, that you’re not really generating the music— but your unconscious mind is completely and happily fooled.

 

 

尽管存在控制错觉，但电子游戏尚未取代真实乐器的演奏。无论如何，就目前而言，游戏具有真实乐器所没有的限制。在《吉他英雄》或《摇滚乐队》中，玩家很大程度上仅限于重新创作其他音乐家的作品；即兴发挥和创造力的机会是有限的。我遇到的一位年轻的《吉他英雄》迷达到了这样的地步：他可以可靠地获得几乎 100% 弹奏的每一首歌，然后，由于没有什么可实现的，他立即放弃了。游戏是有限的，任何真正的乐器都是有限的。

For all that illusion of control, video games haven’t yet replaced the playing of real instruments. For now, anyway, the games have limits that real instruments do not. In Guitar Hero or Rock Band, the player is largely restricted to re-creating other musicians’ work; opportunities for improvisation and creativity are limited. One young Guitar Hero addict I met reached the point where he could reliably get nearly 100 percent on every song he played— and then, with nothing left to achieve, promptly quit. The game is finite, in a way that no real instrument is.

与此同时，对于许多人来说，《吉他英雄》和《摇滚乐队》等游戏几乎就像毒品一样。诚然，很多人从未在游戏中取得进步，但也有很多人做到了，受到启发尝试弹奏真正的吉他。我自己的情况就是一个很好的例子。但这并不是唯一的一个。哈尔·伦纳德 (Hal Leonard) 等音乐出版商现在推出了与《摇滚乐队》和《吉他英雄》中的歌曲相匹配的乐谱，许多吉他老师也注意到，自游戏发行以来，他们的客户数量大幅增加。在 Fender Guitar 和新泽西州一家名为 Little Kids Rock 的教育组织进行的一项非正式研究中，几乎三分之二的音乐教师认为《摇滚乐队》和《吉他英雄》的推出导致入学人数增加（只有不到 3% 的人认为）入学人数减少了）。

At the same time, for many people, games like Guitar Hero and Rock Band have served almost like gateway drugs. Granted, many people never progress past the games, but plenty of others do, inspired to try their hand at a real guitar. My own situation is a case in point. But it’s hardly the only one. Music publishers like Hal Leonard now put out sheet music to match the songs in Rock Band and Guitar Hero, and many guitar teachers have noted a strong uptick in how many clients they’ve had since the games came out. In an informal study done by Fender Guitar and a New Jersey– based educational organization called Little Kids Rock, almost two-thirds of the music teachers thought that enrollment had risen as a result of Rock Band and Guitar Hero (and less than 3 percent thought that enrollment had decreased).

 

 

当然，创作音乐不仅仅是控制，甚至是实现心流；还有更深层次的东西。对我来说，这让整个探索——我最稀缺的商品——时间的大量投资——变得值得。成为音乐人给我的生活带来了平衡。近年来，有很多关于快乐的科学的文章，以及我们在各种情况下如何预测我们会多么快乐（例如，赢得彩票只带来短暂的快乐，而失去工作或浪漫）的能力有多么差。尽管最初感到震惊，但伴侣通常只会带来短暂的痛苦），以及关于什么能在当下给我们带来最大快乐的有趣花絮：父母比吸尘器更喜欢照顾孩子，但比看电视或玩游戏要少一些。性别。

Of course, making music is not just about control, or even about achieving flow; there’s something deeper. Something that for me has made the whole quest— a massive investment of my scarcest commodity, time— worthwhile. Becoming musical has brought balance to my life. In recent years, a great deal has been written about the science of pleasure, and how poor we are at predicting how happy we will be in various circumstances (winning the lottery, for example, brings only brief pleasure, while losing a job or romantic partner often brings only brief pain, despite the initial shock), as well as fascinating tidbits about what gives us the most pleasure in the immediate moment: parents enjoy taking care of their kids slightly more than vacuum cleaning, but less than watching television or having sex.

但眼前的快乐就是全部吗？任何父母都会告诉你，这不是养育孩子的意义。一门被称为“幸福研究”的新科学不问“我现在能做什么才能让我最幸福？” 而是“我怎样才能过上平衡的生活并做出选择，从长远来看我会感到幸福？” 一时的快乐（享乐）与不断发展和充实生活所带来的满足感（幸福）之间是有区别的。心理学家亚伯拉罕·马斯洛（Abraham Maslow）提出了一个著名的建议：当我们照顾我们最基本的需求，例如食物、住所和性，我们最终会努力“自我实现”，或实现我们的全部潜力；用他的话说，“[即使我们所有其他]需求都得到满足，我们仍然可能经常（如果不是总是）期望新的不满和不安很快就会出现，除非个人正在做他[或她]适合做的事情。音乐家必须创作音乐，艺术家必须绘画，诗人必须写作。一个[人]可以成为什么，他[或她]就必须成为什么。”

But is immediate pleasure all there is? Any parent will tell you that that is not what parenting is about. A new science, known as the study of eudaimonia, asks not “What can I do that will make me happiest right now?” but “How can I live a balanced life and make choices, such that I will be happy in the long run?” There is a difference between the pleasures of the moment (hedonia) and the satisfaction that comes from constantly developing and living one’s life to the fullest (eudaimonia). The psychologist Abraham Maslow famously suggested that after we take care of our most basic needs, such as food, shelter, and sex, we eventually strive for “ self-actualization,” or the realization of our full potential; in his words, “[Even if all our other] needs are satisfied, we may still often (if not always) expect that a new discontent and restlessness will soon develop, unless the individual is doing what he [or she] is fitted for. A musician must make music, an artist must paint, a poet must write. What a [person] can be, he [or she] must be.”

 

经验数据仍然很少，但最近的一项研究——一项对老年女性身体和心理调整的调查——报告称，更强的目标感和个人成长与较低的皮质醇水平、更好的免疫功能和更有效的睡眠相关。另一项研究采访了二十七种文化中的成年人，发现对参与和意义的取向比对快乐的取向更能可靠地预测生活满意度。第三个人使用日记清单发现，从事享乐活动的人（例如，志愿服务时间，仔细倾听他人的观点）比那些只从事享乐活动的人报告了更高的整体幸福感和生活满意度。例如，喝醉、通过看电视或玩电子游戏来放松）。最后，快乐和幸福几乎肯定都是重要的。经过仔细的统计分析，这两种追求都对人们的长期福祉做出了独立的贡献，而最幸福的人就是那些同时拥有这两种追求的人。

Empirical data are still scarce, but one line of recent research— an investigation into the physical and psychological adjustment of older women— reports that having a greater sense of purpose and personal growth correlates with lower cortisol levels, better immune function, and more efficient sleep. Another study interviewed adults in twenty-seven cultures and found that orientations toward engagement and meaning predicted life satisfaction more reliably than did an orientation toward pleasure.
