A third used diary checklists and found that people who engaged in eudaimonic activities (for example, volunteering time, listening carefully to the points of view of other people) reported greater overall well-being and life satisfaction than those who engaged in exclusively hedonic activities (for example, getting drunk, relaxing by watching television or playing video games). In the end, hedonia and eudaimonia almost certainly both matter. In careful statistical analyses, both pursuits contributed independently to people’s long-term well-being, and the happiest people are those who find room for both.

 

音乐可能特别有效——特别是对于表演者来说——因为它有可能将当下享受音乐的享乐与不断进步的幸福感结合起来，因为音乐家不断学习新技术、创作新歌曲、创作新歌曲。发现。从“自私基因”的严格角度来看——我们所做的一切都是由我们个人基因的利益驱动的——音乐可能永远没有意义，特别是对于像我这样的笨蛋：弹吉他不会增加我生孩子的数量，也不会让他们更健康。但也许，只是也许，重塑的艺术和获得新技能可以给我们一种美好生活的感觉。

Music may be especially potent— particularly for performers— because of its potential for combining the hedonia of enjoying music in the moment with the eudaimonia of a constant sense of progress, as the musician continues to learn new techniques, create new songs, and make new discoveries. From the strict perspective of the “selfish gene”—in which all that we do is driven by the interests of our individual genes— music may never make sense, especially for duffers like me: playing guitar won’t increase how many babies I have, nor will it make them healthier. But maybe, just maybe, the art of reinvention and acquiring new skills can give us a sense of a life well lived.

 

 

当我对音乐和技术的双重兴趣最终集中在最近才发布的 Moog 吉他上时，所有这一切都变得尤为明显。吉他是有史以来最通用的乐器之一。他们可以演奏和弦，他们可以演奏旋律，轻柔而响亮，节奏或主奏。与羽管键琴不同，在吉他上您可以改变音符的响度，与钢琴不同，您可以在音符之间弯曲。萨克斯管提供了更具表现力的音域音符，但它们不能真正演奏和弦。然而吉他也一直有一个弱点：当你弹奏一个音符的那一刻，它就开始消失。你可以快速弹奏，或者使用各种效果小工具，但真正的延音，就像你踩下钢琴踏板时所发生的那样，一直是不可能的。穆格吉他解决了这个问题，通过使用电磁机制系统——完全模拟（不涉及合成器）——来真正振动吉他的琴弦并保持它们运动。我在朋友的朋友家里玩了一把，立刻就被迷住了。我可以利用我已经学到的一套技能来制作一套全新的声音。这感觉是我能想象到的最接近赋予吉他小提琴表现力的事情。我熬夜观看了有关吉他的 YouTube 视频，找到了法里德·哈克 (Fareed Haque)，他是 Garaj Mahal 乐队的获奖主音吉他手，也是最了解如何使用这把不寻常吉他的单身人士。

All of this became especially clear when my twin interests in music and technology eventually converged on something known as the Moog Guitar, which had only recently been released. Guitars are among the most versatile instruments ever invented; they can play chords, they can play melody, soft and loud, rhythm or lead. Unlike on a harpsichord, on a guitar you can vary the loudness of a note, and unlike on a piano, you can bend between notes. Saxophones offer more expressive range note for note, but they can’t really play chords. Yet guitars have always had a weakness, too: the instant you play a note, it starts to die. You could play fast, or use various effects gadgets, but true sustain, like what happens when you hold down the pedal on a piano, had always been out of the question. The Moog Guitar solves this problem, by using a system of electromagnetic mechanisms— entirely analog (no synthesizers involved)—to literally vibrate the guitar’s strings and keep them in motion. I played one at the house of a friend of a friend and immediately became enraptured; I could take the set of skills I’d already learned and produce an entirely new set of sounds. It felt like the closest thing I could imagine to giving the guitar the expressive power of a violin. I stayed up half the night looking at YouTube videos about the guitar and found my way to Fareed Haque, the award-winning lead guitarist of the band Garaj Mahal and the single person who best knew what to do with this unusual guitar.

自从我把吉他带到魁北克姻亲的小屋并开始摸索我的第一个和弦以来，已经快两年了，我飞出去跟哈克一起上课。突然我发现自己处于最前沿，配备了工具（我买了一把穆格吉他）我自己）和世界上几乎没有其他人拥有的专业知识（由哈克提供）。我能够创造出以前从未听过的声音和纹理。我可能永远不会成为吉米·亨德里克斯，但有那么一刻，我能感受到探索新音乐景观的感觉。

Almost two years to the day since I had brought my guitar to my in-laws’ cottage in Quebec and begun to fumble with my first chords, I flew out to take lessons with Haque. Suddenly I found myself on the cutting edge, equipped with a tool (I’d bought a Moog Guitar for myself) and know-how (courtesy of Haque) that almost nobody else in the world yet had. I was able to create sounds and textures I had never heard before. I might never be Jimi Hendrix, but for a brief moment I could sense what it was like to explore a new musical landscape.

 

没有哪个音乐家，也没有哪个科学家能够梦想更多。

No musician, and no scientist, could ever dream of anything more.

 

 

结语

Epilogue

 

音乐给我带来了两笔意想不到的意外之财。第一个是一个巨大的新朋友圈，每个人都以自己的方式富有创造力和启发性。在许多人中，有罗杰·格林纳瓦特（Roger Greenawalt），他是一位非常聪明的唱片制作人和尤克里里大师，他已经开始给我上课（现在我会弹一把还算不错的吉他），还有他曾经的同谋戴夫·巴拉特（Dave Barratt），一位同样才华横溢的唱片制作人他写了一首因罗伯特·普兰特和艾莉森·克劳斯而闻名的歌曲。特雷·罗什（Terre Roche）慷慨地与我分享了她作为明星和音乐教育家的音乐生活故事；受过古典音乐训练的硬摇滚键盘手 Carla Capretto，曾在《今夜秀》中演奏；还有杰西·墨菲 (Jessie Murphy) 和她才华横溢的三人组，他们在客厅（纽约精英俱乐部）演奏后的第二天晚上在我的客厅里演奏。其中有玛丽·法布德 (Mary Farbood)，她是羽管键琴演奏家和非凡的音乐极客，她很快就成为我最亲密的合作者。Tam Lin，也许是他这一代人中最聪明的创作歌手；凯西娜·布莱恩特 (Kathena Bryant)，身高 5 英尺 3 英寸，来自德克萨斯州加兰的火花塞移民，她是贾尼斯·乔普林 (Janis Joplin) 的近代化身；Tobias Hurwitz，Shred-o-Meter 发明营主任；和作曲家、小提琴家和富有远见的戴夫·索尔迪尔 (Dave Soldier)，他的时间主要花在神经科学和专业音乐上；更不用说电子音乐先驱莫顿·苏博特尼克（Morton Subotnick）和大卫·罗滕伯格（David Rothenberg）了，后者是一位哲学家、博物学家、单簧管演奏家和作家，拥有现代文艺复兴时期人物的称号。这样的例子还在继续。我已经和音乐一起生活和呼吸了两年（在我写这篇文章时），仅在友谊中，音乐所带来的回报远远超出了我的想象。

Music has brought two windfalls that I never anticipated. The first is a huge new circle of friends, every one creative and inspiring in his or her own way. Among many others there’s Roger Greenawalt, the ever-clever record producer and master ukulele player who has begun (now that I play a half-decent guitar) to give me lessons, and his sometime co-conspirator Dave Barratt, an equally talented record producer who wrote a song made famous by Robert Plant and Alison Krauss. There’s Terre Roche, who generously shared stories with me of her life in music, both as a star and as a music educator; the hard-rocking, classically trained keyboard player Carla Capretto, who once played on The Tonight Show; and Jessie Murphy and her talented trio, who played my living room the night after playing at the Living Room (an elite New York club). There’s Mary Farbood, harpsichordist and music geek extraordinaire, who has quickly become my closest collaborator; Tam Lin, perhaps the smartest singer-songwriter of his generation; Kathena Bryant, a five-foot-three-inch spark-plug émigré from Garland, Texas, who is the latter-day incarnation of Janis Joplin; Tobias Hurwitz, the Shred-o- Meter-inventing camp director; and the composer, violinist, and visionary Dave Soldier, who splits his time between neuroscience and professional-level music; to say nothing of the electronic music pioneer Morton Subotnick and David Rothenberg, a philosopher, naturalist, clarinetist, and author with a legitimate claim on the title of modern Renaissance man. The list goes on. I have lived and breathed music for (as I write this) two years, and in friendship alone music has brought rewards far greater than I could have imagined.

第二个意想不到的附带好处是一种全新的表达形式，不一定像书面文字那么精确，但在某些方面要强大得多。在我弹吉他的第二年中期，我开始有足够的信心开始写歌，一周去参加每周一次的课程，罗杰准备写我的第一首歌曲。一周后，我知道，我将去拜访我的叔叔大卫，我担心，这也许是最后一次。大卫最近作为北卡罗来纳州的一名教育学教授退休了，他一直是我的灵感来源，但在过去的几年里，他病得很重。我本能地知道，我要写的歌曲必须是为他而写的，并且是关于他的。罗杰要求我自由交往。我手里拿着笔和纸，回想起在我几岁的时候，大卫是如何给我带来数学书的——他是我的直系亲属之外第一个认真对待我作为知识分子的人——而我的母亲，作为一个孩子，却无法做到这一点。他没有念出他的名字，这导致了他的家人至今都知道他的绰号。更重要的是，我试图捕捉他一生的作品——作为一名道德教师和一个从未停止奋斗寻找精神道路的人。我演奏了一些小和弦，我认为这些和弦体现了大卫的严肃目的，不到一个小时罗杰就帮助我将这首歌制作成一个美丽、连贯的整体。副歌部分（“大卫叔叔挣扎着，挣扎着作为一个犹太人的意义”）被设置为一些快速的和弦变化——A小调到D小调，然后在两小节的空间内返回，然后到E7并返回到 A 小调——如果是在几个月前，我是做梦也不敢尝试的。

The second unanticipated fringe benefit is a whole new form of expression, not necessarily as precise as the written word, but in some ways vastly more powerful. In the middle of my second year of efforts to play guitar, I began to have enough confidence to start writing songs and one week went to my weekly lesson with Roger ready to write my first. A week later, I knew, I’d be visiting my uncle David, perhaps, I feared, for the last time. David, who had recently retired as a professor of education in North Carolina, had always been an inspiration to me, and for the last several years he had been quite ill. I knew, instinctively, that the song I was to write had to be for him— and about him. Roger asked me to free-associate. Pen and paper in hand, I recalled how David had brought me math books when I was just a few years old— the first person outside my immediate family to take me seriously as an intellectual— and how my mother, as a child, couldn’t pronounce his name, leading to a nickname by which he is known to his family to this day. More than that, I tried to capture his life’s work— as a moral teacher and as a person who never ceased to struggle to find a spiritual path. I played a few minor chords that I thought captured David’s seriousness of purpose, and within an hour Roger had helped me to craft the song into a beautiful, coherent whole. The refrain (“Uncle David struggles, struggles with the meaning of what it is to be a Jew”) was set to some rapid chord changes— A minor to D minor and back in the space of two measures, then on to E7 and back to A minor— that I wouldn’t have dreamed of trying a few months earlier.

 

当我飞往北卡罗来纳州时，我知道这首歌很好，但我不知道是否可以在公共场合播放它。我一直很紧张，没有告诉妈妈，以免我退缩了，让她的希望破灭。在我和妈妈在北卡罗来纳州度过的最后一晚，全家人——大卫、他的妻子、伊莱恩、他们的女儿、她的丈夫和孙子们——聚集在一起，不知何故，在一把 1934 年的旧马丁客厅吉他的帮助下我从我表弟的丈夫那里借来了这首歌，我表演了这首歌，错误不超过两三个。大卫给了我一个拥抱——这是他给过我的最大的拥抱——并且用恰到好处的赞扬和讽刺的方式将我描述为“新生的鲍勃·迪伦”。

As I flew to North Carolina, I knew the song was good, but I didn’t know if I’d be able to play it in public. I was nervous the whole time and didn’t tell my mother, lest I dash her hopes if I chickened out. On the last night my mom and I spent in North Carolina, the whole family— David, his wife, Elaine, their daughter, her husband, and the grandchildren— gathered, and somehow, with the aid of an old Martin parlor guitar from 1934 borrowed from my cousin’s husband, I performed the song, making not more than two or three mistakes. David gave me a hug— the biggest he’d ever given me— and, with just the right mixture of praise and irony, described me as “a nascent Bob Dylan.”

 

那天晚上晚些时候，在其他人都离开聚会后，大卫、伊莱恩和我进行了我们有生以来最深入的谈话。早上，我和妈妈飞回北方。五周后，大卫走了。

Later that night, after everyone else had left the party, David and Elaine and I had the deepest conversation we’d ever had. In the morning, my mother and I flew back north. Five weeks later, David was gone.

 

当我写下这些话时，我情不自禁地哭了，但我也知道，为大卫写这首歌让我和他最后一次联系在一起，这是我无法做到的。为此，我很感激，这是言语无法表达的。

I can’t help but cry as I write these words, but I also know that writing that song for David connected me to him one last time in a way that nothing else I could have possibly done ever could. And for that I am grateful, in ways that words alone could never express.

 

 

致谢

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

 

写书往往是一种孤独的存在，作家被锁在书房里，除了笔记本电脑和互联网之外什么都没有。《吉他零》绝对不是我作为作家以来最愉快的经历。

Book writing can often be a lonely existence, a writer locked in a study with nothing other than a laptop and the Internet. Guitar Zero was anything but, the most pleasurable experience I have ever had as a writer.

当我试图从一个单纯的听众转变为一个可以为自己演奏的人时，我偶然遇到了我遇到过的三个最好的人社区：音乐家、音乐老师和研究音乐的科学家。事实上，我一路上遇到的每个人都热情地欢迎我。也许第一个是我的新朋友和同事玛丽·法布德（Mary Farbood），她既是世界级的羽管键琴演奏家，又是音乐学者，现在是我最亲密的合作者之一。

As I tried to transition from being a mere listener to being someone who could play for himself, I chanced upon three of the nicest communities of people I’ve ever encountered: musicians, music teachers, and the scientists who study music. Virtually everyone I met along the way welcomed me warmly. Perhaps the first was my new friend and colleague Mary Farbood, who is both a world-class harpsichordist and a scholar of music, and now one of my closest collaborators.

 

帕特·马蒂诺 (Pat Martino) 和道格·德里贝里 (Doug Derryberry) 等吉他大师邀请我去他们家做客。汤姆·莫雷洛 (Tom Morello) 和伦尼·凯伊 (Lennie Kaye) 都同样慷慨地投入了时间。露丝·阿尔珀森 (Ruth Alperson)、杰米·安德烈亚斯 (Jamie Andreas)、丽贝卡·切里 (Rebecca Cherry)、科特·吉尔 (Curt Gill) 和米歇尔·霍纳 (Michele Horner) 等音乐老师都欢迎我进入他们的教室，而教学先驱玛丽安·乌兹勒 (Marienne Uszler) 和埃德温·戈登 (Edwin Gordon) 则提供了历史视角。甚至格莱美奖获得者和唱片公司总裁，如拉斯·蒂特曼、丹尼·戈德堡和鲍勃·赫维茨，也花时间与我交谈。最特别的是令人难以置信的帕特·梅瑟尼 (Pat Metheny)，他在一个罕见的星期六早上，在他不在路上的时候，花了三个小时来我自己的家里拜访我，回答了我能想到的关于吉他、技术和音乐的所有问题。爵士乐的历史，换来的无非是一个帮助传播音乐福音的机会。

Master guitarists like Pat Martino and Doug Derryberry invited me into their homes. Tom Morello and Lennie Kaye both gave no less generously of their time. Music teachers like Ruth Alperson, Jamie Andreas, Rebecca Cherry, Curt Gill, and Michele Horner all welcomed me into their classrooms, while pedagogical pioneers Marienne Uszler and Edwin Gordon supplied historical perspective. Even Grammy Award–wining producers and record label presidents, like Russ Titelman, Danny Goldberg, and Bob Hurwitz, took the time to talk to me. Most extraordinary of all was the incredible Pat Metheny, who took three hours out of a rare Saturday morning in which he wasn’t on the road to visit me in my own home, answering every question I could imagine on the guitar, technology, and the history of jazz, in exchange for nothing more than a chance to help spread the gospel of music.

 

在学术方面，几乎与我交谈过的每个人都很乐意提供帮助。彼得·凯勒阅读了手稿的每一个字，并为我在世界科学节上与梅西尼的公开对话做好了准备。劳雷尔·特雷纳 (Laurel Trainor) 帮助我更好地了解了节奏问题的可能根源。罗伯特·罗帮助我认识了纽约大学的许多音乐学者，弗雷德·莱尔达尔、雷·杰肯多夫和吉恩·纳尔莫尔都花了很多时间分享他们关于他们帮助创建的音乐科学的智慧。大卫·罗滕伯格仔细地评论了一份早期草稿，并打开了他的名片盒。

On the academic side, virtually everyone I spoke to was delighted to help. Peter Keller read every word of the manuscript and prepped me for a public conversation with Metheny at the World Science Festival. Laurel Trainor helped me better understand the likely origins of my troubles with rhythm. Robert Rowe helped me to get to know many of the music scholars at New York University, and Fred Lehrdahl, Ray Jackendoff, and Gene Narmour all spent hours sharing their wisdom on a science of music that they helped create. David Rothenberg carefully critiqued an early draft and opened his Rolodex.

 

写这本书的最大乐趣之一就是我对 Ruth Alperson、Richard Barone、Dave Barratt、Perry Beekman、Tim Burke、Sterling Campbell、Carla Capretto、Marilyn Crispell、Eran Egozy、Mark Freundt、Michael Geezil、Cirt 的采访吉尔,丹尼·戈德堡,杰森·冈斯基,埃德温·戈登,法里德·哈克,汉克·海金克,斯莫基·霍梅尔,米歇尔·霍纳,Hot Lixx Houlihan,大卫·休伦,埃莉斯·杰肯道夫,雷·杰肯道夫,特里斯坦·杰汉,菲尔·约翰逊-莱尔德,兰尼·凯,保罗·拉米尔,西里尔·兰斯,丽莎·马古利斯,帕特·马蒂诺,帕特·麦森尼,汤姆·莫雷洛,丹·莫里斯,帕特里克·奥布莱恩,卡罗琳·帕尔默,阿尼·帕特尔,特雷·罗什,莫顿·苏博特尼克,劳雷尔·特雷纳,比约恩·图罗克,玛丽安娜·乌斯勒,保罗·沃,邓肯·瓦茨,和布莱恩·惠特曼。Meliset Abreu、Alex Demos、Anders Ericsson、Susan Fast、Paul Hoffman、Panos Mavromatis、Paul O'Keefe、Caroline Palmer、Adena Schachner 和 Glen Schellenberg 回复了电子邮件，内容涵盖从如何发挥想象力在地铁上练习吉他等各个方面国际象棋大师的缺点，而佐兰·约西波维奇和迈克尔·多夫曼则确保我看到了所有最新的研究。丹尼·戈德堡和布雷迪·布洛克安排我采访了无与伦比的汤姆·莫雷洛。乔勒杜把我介绍给了莱尼·凯。法里德·哈克（Fareed Haque）向我介绍了帕特·马蒂诺（Pat Martino），查尔斯·林赛（Charles Lindsay）向我介绍了穆格吉他。

One of the greatest pleasures in writing this book was the interviews I did, with Ruth Alperson, Richard Barone, Dave Barratt, Perry Beekman, Tim Burke, Sterling Campbell, Carla Capretto, Marilyn Crispell, Eran Egozy, Mark Freundt, Michael Geezil, Cirt Gill, Danny Goldberg, Jason Gonsky, Edwin Gordon, Fareed Haque, Hank Heijink, Smokey Hormel, Michele Horner, Hot Lixx Houlihan, David Huron, Elise Jackendoff, Ray Jackendoff, Tristan Jehan, Phil Johnson-Laird, Lenny Kaye, Paul Lamere, Cyril Lance, Lisa Margulis, Pat Martino, Pat Metheny, Tom Morello, Dan Morris, Patrick O’Brien, Caroline Palmer, Ani Patel, Terre Roche, Morton Subotnick, Laurel Trainor, Björn Türoque, Marienne Uszler, Paul Vo, Duncan Watts, and Brian Whitman. Meliset Abreu, Alex Demos, Anders Ericsson, Susan Fast, Paul Hoffman, Panos Mavromatis, Paul O’Keefe, Caroline Palmer, Adena Schachner, and Glen Schellenberg answered e-mails on everything from how to use your imagination to practice guitar on the subway to the foibles of chess masters, while Zoran Josipovic and Michael Dorfman made sure I saw all the latest studies. Danny Goldberg and Brady Brock set up my interview with the inimitable Tom Morello. Joe LeDoux introduced me to Lenny Kaye. Fareed Haque introduced me to Pat Martino, and Charles Lindsay introduced me to the Moog guitar.

 

十几位音乐家和科学家慷慨地阅读了这本书的草稿，包括 Doug Bemis、Iris Berent、Carla Capretto、Alex Denker、Lila Gleitman、Aaron Kheifets、Dave Rothenberg、Dave Soldier 和 Morton Subotnick。Elika Bergelson、Mary Farbood、Erin Hannon、Josh McDermott、Ezequiel Morsella 和 Athena Vouloumanos 都值得特别感谢，他们对本书的早期版本做出了详细、令人难以置信的敏锐评论，每一位都带来了一些原本不会出现的重要内容。卡拉以专业文案编辑的敏锐眼光进行编辑，迈克尔·多夫曼提出了许多我记不清的有用建议。Ken Perlin、Ofter Tchernichovski 和 Zach Woods 在早期章节中提供了宝贵的帮助，并且很乐意完成更多内容。即使在所有这些杰出的读者中，特雷·罗什（Terre Roche）也脱颖而出，他提供了一种作者只能梦想的评论，逐行的回应让我笑，哭，并伸手去剪切和粘贴；我从来没有遇到过比我更支持我的读者，也没有给我的手稿带来如此多的新内容。

More than a dozen musicians and scientists were gracious enough to read drafts of the book, including Doug Bemis, Iris Berent, Carla Capretto, Alex Denker, Lila Gleitman, Aaron Kheifets, Dave Rothenberg, Dave Soldier, and Morton Subotnick. Elika Bergelson, Mary Farbood, Erin Hannon, Josh McDermott, Ezequiel Morsella, and Athena Vouloumanos all deserve special thanks for the detailed, incredibly perceptive comments they made on early versions of the book, each bringing something significant that would not have otherwise been there. Carla edited with the sharp eyes of a professional copy editor, and Michael Dorfman made so many helpful suggestions I lost count. Ken Perlin, Ofter Tchernichovski, and Zach Woods lent a valuable hand with early chapters and would happily have labored through more. Even among all these exceptional readers, Terre Roche stands out, supplying the kind of comments an author can only dream of, line-by-line responses that made me laugh, cry, and reach for the cut-and-paste; never I have had a more supportive reader, nor one who brought so much new to a manuscript.

 

特雷、法里德·哈克、大卫·索尔迪尔、保罗·弗雷泽和马龙·切里后来在我位于村里的公寓里开会，让我参加了一场精彩的即兴演奏会。Soldier 还带我进入剪辑工作室，观看小提琴家 Rebecca Cherry 和格莱美奖获得者 Rory Young 的充满活力的二人组。杰西·墨菲 (Jessie Murphy)、艾米·希尔迪奇 (Amy Schildige) 和玛西娅·韦伯 (Marcia Webb) 也毫不逊色，当我努力唱“With a Little Help from My Friends”时，他们甚至在台上勇敢地支持我。（凯西娜·布莱恩特也提供了帮助；罗杰·G. 演奏尤克里里琴。戴夫·巴拉特帮助录制了录音室表演。）

Terre, Fareed Haque, David Soldier, Paul Frazier, and Marlon Cherry later convened in my apartment in the Village and allowed me to sit in on an amazing jam session. Soldier also brought me into the editing studio to watch the dynamic duo of the violinist Rebecca Cherry and the Grammy-winning Rory Young. Jessie Murphy, Amy Schildige, and Marcia Webb were no less welcoming and even gamely backed me onstage when I endeavored to sing “With a Little Help from My Friends.” (Kathena Bryant lent a hand, too; Roger G. played ukulele. Dave Barratt helped record a studio performance.)

 

Richard Barone 带我进入了 Gibson 吉他的世界，甚至还帮我了解了 Dave Brubeck 录制新版本的“Take Five”的情况。

Richard Barone brought me inside the world of Gibson guitars and even helped me peek in on Dave Brubeck recording a new version of “Take Five.”

 

Jason Gonsky 将我介绍给了 Michele Horner，并慷慨地允许我观看令人惊叹的 Shiloh 作为吉他手的第一步。

Jason Gonsky introduced me to Michele Horner and graciously allowed me to watch the amazing Shiloh’s first steps as a guitarist.

 

Michael Raitzyk 向我介绍了 Tobias Hurwitz 和 Day Jams 的精彩世界。托比亚斯·赫维茨（Tobias Hurwitz）让我参加了 Day Jams，并为我带来了作为音乐家的第一场演出。

Michael Raitzyk introduced me to Tobias Hurwitz and the wonderful world of Day Jams. Tobias Hurwitz let me sit in on Day Jams and got me my first gig as a musician.

 

塞斯·奥斯汀、凯西娜·布莱恩特、特里·古利、罗杰·格林纳瓦特、法里德·哈克、托拜厄斯·赫维茨、杰西·墨菲、特雷·罗奇、泰勒·沃尔克、保罗·温菲尔德和另一位不愿透露姓名的绅士给我上了一堂课，每个人都耐心地以绝对的态度接受了我的指导。好奇心远多于天赋的初学者。罗杰帮助我写了我的第一首真正的歌曲。

Seth Austen, Kathena Bryant, Terry Gourley, Roger Greenawalt, Fareed Haque, Tobias Hurwitz, Jessie Murphy, Terre Roche, Tyler Volk, Paul Weinfeld, and another gentleman who prefers to remain anonymous gave me lessons, each one putting up patiently with an absolute beginner who had far more curiosity than talent. Roger helped me write my first real song.

 

雅典娜阅读并改进了无数的草稿，提供了她一贯的尖锐评论和情感寄托，而从未要求我在她和我的吉他之间做出选择。

Athena read and improved countless drafts, supplying her usual mixture of laser-sharp comments and emotional sustenance, while never once demanding that I choose between her and my guitar.

 

妈妈、爸爸、琳达、朱莉、佩格、维基、尼克和乔治一如既往地支持我，尽管他们比任何人都清楚整个努力一开始看起来是多么荒谬。埃德和史蒂夫从一开始就在那里，并在从选择经纪人到选择标题的所有事情上提供帮助。乔西、埃里克、扎克、桑迪、蒂姆、克里斯蒂安、肯和凯蒂带来了友谊。在这段旅程的开始，迈克尔·多夫曼只是朋友的朋友；最终，他成为我最坚定的盟友之一。在我的第一次个人表演中，大卫、伊莱恩、南希、加布、乔和迈克尔站在我身边。（迈克尔甚至借给我他的传家宝吉他。）佐伊和克莱尔帮助我保持体形。

Mom, Dad, Linda, Julie, Peg, Vickie, Nick, and George supported me, as they always do, even though they knew better than anyone else how ridiculous the whole endeavor seemed at first. Ed and Steve were there from the beginning and helped with everything from choosing agents to choosing titles. Josie, Eric, Zach, Sandy, Tim, Christian, Ken, and Katie brought friendship. At the beginning of this journey, Michael Dorfman was just a friend of friends; by the end, he was one of my staunchest allies. David, Elaine, Nancy, Gabe, Joe, and Michael stood by me during my first solo performance. (Michael even loaned me his heirloom guitar.) Zoe and Clare helped keep me in shape.

 

丹尼尔·格林伯格成功地将一个在非常不确定的市场中未完成的提案变成了与业内最好的出版商之一的图书合同；他的搭档吉姆也给予了极大的支持。安·戈多夫是出版界第一个看到这本书潜力的人。金妮·史密斯（Ginny Smith）帮助将一个单纯的书籍提案变成了一本真正的书，她阅读的草稿多得我数不清，并且比我见过的任何编辑都表现出更多的耐心和热情。Bruce、Ingrid、Mally 和 Meighan 都参与了最终产品的制作。

Daniel Greenberg managed to turn an unfinished proposal in a very uncertain market into a book contract with one of the best publishers in the business; his partner Jim, too, was incredibly supportive. Ann Godoff was the first person in the publishing world to see the book’s potential. Ginny Smith helped shape a mere book proposal into a real book, reading more drafts than I can count and showing more patience and enthusiasm than any editor I have ever met. Bruce, Ingrid, Mally, and Meighan all helped in creating the final product.

 

我感谢所有这些人，但最重要的是我感谢格里尔、莱利、瑞安和莎拉给了我打球的机会。

I thank all of these people, but most especially I thank Greer, Riley, Ryan, and Sarah for giving me a chance to play.

 

词汇表

GLOSSARY

 

绝对音高：听到给定音高并识别它所代表的音符的能力；例如，能够听到一根弦以每秒 440 次的频率振动，并将其识别为中音 C 之上的 A 音符。

absolute pitch: The ability to hear a given pitch and identify the musical note it represents; for example, to be able to hear a string vibrate at 440 cycles per second and identify it as the A note above middle C.

小调五声音阶： A 调小五声音阶的示例；也就是说，它从音符 A 开始，进行到 C、D、E 和 G，然后返回 A。

A minor pentatonic, the: An example of the minor pentatonic scale that is in the key of A; that is, it begins with the note A and proceeds to C, D, E, and G before returning to A.

杏仁核：大脑内部杏仁状的区域，与情绪有关。

amygdala: An almond-shaped interior region of the brain, implicated in emotions.

升序：用于描述一系列音符，如升大二度，其中每个连续音符的音高都高于前一个音符。

ascending: Used to describe a sequence of notes, as in an ascending major second, in which each successive note is higher in pitch than the previous note.

试听：埃德温·戈登（Edwin Gordon）的术语，指的是想象和理解音乐的过程。

audiation: Edwin Gordon’s term for the process of imagining and comprehending music.

听觉皮层：大脑颞叶的一部分，负责处理声音。

auditory cortex: The part of the brain’s temporal lobe that is responsible for processing sound.

自动性：行为变得更快、更少意识和更少努力的过程。

automaticity: The process by which a behavior can become faster, less conscious, and less effortful.

巴雷和弦：一种和弦，其中一根手指（通常是食指）同时按住多根弦，通常平放在琴颈上。对初学者来说具有体力挑战。

barre chord: A chord in which one finger, usually the index finger, holds down multiple strings at the same time, typically by lying flat across the neck. Physically challenging for beginners.

基底神经节：大脑底部的一种结构，与运动控制和学习有关。

basal ganglia: A structure in the base of the brain that has been linked to motor control and learning.

布罗卡区：大脑左半球的一部分，通常与语言相关，但也参与音乐。

Broca’s area: The part of the brain’s left hemisphere that has often been tied to language but also participates in music.

小脑：大脑半球下方的一个有条纹的区域；与动作、时间和节奏相关；也可能在语言中发挥作用。

cerebellum: A striated region of the brain tucked beneath the cerebral hemispheres; associated with movement, timing, and rhythm; may also play a role in language.

大脑半球：大脑外部、有皱纹的部分的左半部和右半部区域。

cerebral hemispheres: Left-and right-half regions of the outer, wrinkled part of the brain.

和弦：一组音符，通常是三个或更多，同时演奏。例如，C 大调和弦由同时演奏的 C、E 和 G 音符组成。

chord: A set of notes, generally three or more, played simultaneously. For example, the C major chord consists of the notes C, E, and G played simultaneously.

和弦进行：一系列和弦，例如 C 大调、F 大调、G 大调，可在“La Bamba”和“Like a Rolling Stone”的副歌中找到。

chord progression: A series of chords— for example, C major, F major, G major, which is found in the choruses of “La Bamba” and “Like a Rolling Stone.”

协和音：听起来很自然的音符组合，如音符 C 和 G，形成纯五度。

consonance: Combinations of notes that sound natural together, as in the notes C and G, which form a perfect fifth.

胼胝体：大脑左右半球之间的主要连接。

corpus callosum: The major connection between left and right hemispheres of the brain.

关键期：发展的关键时期，（根据假设）必须获得某种技能才能正确获得该技能。

critical period: Crucial period in development in which (by hypothesis) a certain skill must be acquired in order for it to be properly acquired.

降序：用于描述一系列音符，如降大二度，其中每个连续音符的音高都低于前一个音符。

descending: Used to describe a sequence of notes, as in a descending major second, in which each successive note is lower in pitch than the previous note.

不协和音：冲突或听起来不自然的音符组合，如升 C 音符和升 F 音符，形成三全音。

dissonance: Combinations of notes that clash or sound unnatural together, as in the notes C and F-sharp, which form a tritone.

属和弦：主和弦之上纯五度的和弦。例如，在C大调中，G大调和弦被认为是属和弦。这个和弦会产生张力，并且往往会让听众期待回到主和弦（本例中的 C）。

dominant chord: A chord that is a perfect fifth above the tonic. For example, in the key of C major, the G major chord is said to be the dominant chord. This chord creates tension and tends to leave the listener expecting a return to the tonic chord (C in this example).

五度：见纯五度。

fifth: See perfect fifth.

fMRI：功能磁共振成像，一种基于磁特性局部变化来检查大脑活动的技术。

fMRI: Functional magnetic resonance imaging, a technique based on local changes in magnetic properties for inspecting the activity of the brain.

梭状回：大脑颞叶的一部分，与面部识别相关。

fusiform gyrus: The part of the brain’s temporal lobe that is associated with face recognition.

和声：音符、和弦或（随着时间的推移）和弦进行的组合，（通常）产生令人愉悦的效果。另外，还有与旋律相伴的伴奏。

harmony: Combinations of notes, chords, or (over time) chord progressions that (generally) yield a pleasing effect. Also, the accompaniment that goes along with a melody.

赫施尔回：大脑听觉皮层的一部分，与音调和语言相关。

Heschl’s gyrus: A part of the brain’s auditory cortex associated with pitch and language.

海马体：大脑颞叶内侧（内部）部分的一部分，与记忆相关。

hippocampus: A part of the medial (interior) portion of the brain’s temporal lobe, associated with memory.

全息理论：这种观点认为，在人类起源中，语言短语出现在单个单词之前。

holophrastic theory: The idea that in the origins of the human species, linguistic phrases emerged before individual words.

音程：一对音符之间的关系。例如，从 C 到 G 的音阶称为纯五度；从 C 到 D 的音阶称为大二度。

interval: The relationship between a pair of notes. For example, the step from C to G is known as a perfect fifth; the step from C to D is known as a major second.

键：歌曲或歌曲小节的音乐中心。调决定了哪些音符在一起听起来更和谐或不和谐。例如，C 大调由 C、D、E、F、G、A 和 B 音符组成（恰好是键盘上的白键）钢琴）; 在这种情况下，也就是说，在主要由这些音符组成的乐曲中，升 C、升 D、升 F、升 G 和升 A 音符（对应于钢琴上的黑色音符）声音不和谐。相反，升F大调的调由所有升音符（黑键）和两个白键（B和F，一些古典音乐家将其称为E升）组成；在这种情况下，黑键以及 B 和 F（均为白色）听起来是协和的，而其余的白键（C、D、E、G 和 A）听起来是不协和的。

key: The musical center for a song or subsection of a song. The key determines which notes sound more and less harmonious together. For example, the key of C major consists of the notes C, D, E, F, G, A, and B (which happen to be the white keys on the piano); in that context, which is to say in a composition consisting primarily of those notes, the notes C-sharp, D-sharp, F-sharp, G-sharp, and A-sharp (which correspond to the black notes on a piano) sound dissonant. Conversely, the key of F-sharp major consists of all the sharp notes (black keys) and just two white keys (B and F, which some classical musicians would refer to as E-sharp); in that context the black keys and B and F (both of which are white) sound consonant, while the remaining white notes (C, D, E, G, and A) sound dissonant.

大二度：恰好两个半音的音程，例如 C 和 D 之间的间隙（跳过升 C）或 F 和 G 之间的间隙（跳过升 F）。

major second: An interval of exactly two semitones, such as the gap between C and D (which skips over C-sharp) or the gap between F and G (skipping over F-sharp).

大三度：恰好四个半音的音程，例如 C 和 E 之间的间隙（跳过升 C、D 和升 D）或 F 和 A 之间的间隙（跳过升 F、G 和升 G 调）。

major third: An interval of exactly four semitones, such as the gap between C and E (which skips over C-sharp, D, and D-sharp) or the gap between F and A (skipping over F-sharp, G, and G-sharp).

旋律：一系列单独的音符。

melody: A sequence of individual notes.

中C：大约位于钢琴88个键的中心的音符，对应于每秒262个周期的频率。

middle C: The note that is approximately at the center of the eighty-eight keys of a piano, corresponding to a frequency of 262 cycles per second.

小调五声音阶：小调音阶的五音子集，常用于蓝调和摇滚乐中。确切的音符取决于调。例如，在A调中，A小调五声音阶由音符A、C、D、E和G组成。

minor pentatonic scale: A five-note subset of the minor scale that is commonly used in the blues and rock. The exact notes depend on the key. For example, in the key of A, the A minor pentatonic scale consists of the notes A, C, D, E, and G.

小调音阶：听起来悲伤的音阶，也称为风神调式，在 C 调中由 C、D、降 E、F、G、降 A 和降 B 音符组成。（旋律小调和和声小调音阶是两种具有独特声音的变奏。）

minor scale: A sad-sounding scale, also known as the Aeolian mode, that in the key of C consists of the notes C, D, E-flat, F, G, A-flat, and B-flat. (Two variations with their own distinct sound are the melodic minor and the harmonic minor scales.)

单音：音乐，例如格里高利圣歌，其中所有声音或乐器齐声发出相同的音符；与复调音乐形成对比。

monophony: Music, such as in Gregorian chant, in which all voices or instruments create the same note, in unison; contrasts with polyphony.

运动皮层：大脑中参与计划和控制自主行动的部分。

motor cortex: The part of the brain involved in planning and controlling voluntary action.

音乐调：参见调。

musical key: See key.

八度音程： (1) 正好十二个半音的音程，例如中间 C 和上面的 C 之间的间隙。(2) 一组音符的规范，例如“中 C 的八度音阶”，由中 C 和高于其的 11 个音符组成。将音符增加一个八度相当于其频率加倍。

octave: (1) An interval of exactly twelve semitones, such as the gap between middle C and the C above it. (2) A specification of a set of notes, such as “the octave of middle C,” which consists of middle C and the eleven notes that ascend above it. Increasing a note by an octave is equivalent to doubling its frequency.

Organum：一种复调音乐形式，通常只有两个声部，在中世纪很常见。

organum: A form of polyphony, typically with just two voices, that was common in the Middle Ages.

五声音阶：由五个音符组成的音阶，在西方音乐中最典型的是小五声音阶或大五声音阶。

pentatonic scale: A musical scale consisting of exactly five notes, in Western music most typically either the minor pentatonic or the major pentatonic.

完美五度：恰好七个半音的听起来悦耳的音程，例如 C 和 G 之间的间隙（跳过升 C、D、升 D、E、F 和升 F）或 F 之间的间隙和 B 升音（跳过 F 升音、G、G 升音、A、A 升音和 B）。

perfect fifth: A pleasant-sounding interval of exactly seven semitones, such as the gap between C and G (which skips over C-sharp, D, D-sharp, E, F, and F-sharp) or the gap between F and B-sharp (skipping over F-sharp, G, G-sharp, A, A-sharp, and B).

纯四度：恰好五个半音的听起来悦耳的音程，例如 C 和 F 之间的间隙（跳过升 C、D、升 D 和 E）或升 F 和 A 之间的间隙（跳过升 F、G、升 G 和 A)。

perfect fourth: A pleasant-sounding interval of exactly five semitones, such as the gap between C and F (which skips over C-sharp, D, D-sharp, and E) or the gap between F and A-sharp (skipping over F-sharp, G, G-sharp, and A).

音高：通常是音符的基频。例如，当敲击吉他上第二细的（空 B）弦（代表中音 C 下方的 B 音符）时，该弦将以每秒 247 个周期的速度振动（以及称为整数谐波的其他共振频率）。 247 的倍数）。

pitch: Ordinarily, the fundamental frequency of a note. For example, when the second-thinnest (open B) string on a guitar is struck, representing the note known as B below middle C, the string will vibrate at 247 cycles per second (along with other resonant frequencies known as harmonics that are integer multiples of 247).

颞平面：大脑韦尼克区（定义如下）的三角形部分，与语言和音乐相关。

planum temporale: A triangular portion of the brain’s Wernicke’s area (defined below), associated with language and music.

可塑性：当有机体学习时，大脑发生物理变化的能力。

plasticity: The capacity for the brain to physically change, as an organism learns.

复调音乐：多种声音或乐器的声音，创造出多个不同的音符；大约在公元900 年之前并不常见。

polyphony: The sound of multiple voices or instruments creating more than one distinct note; uncommon before approximately A.D. 900.

多节奏：两个不相称的节奏并列，例如一种乐器将每个小节分为三个部分，而另一种乐器将每个节奏分为四个部分。相对容易欣赏（在某些情况下），但对于初学者来说很难玩。

polyrhythm: Two incommensurate rhythms juxtaposed, as when one instrument divides each measure into three parts and another divides each rhythm into four parts. Relatively easy to appreciate (in some instances), but very difficult for a beginner to play.

强力和弦：一种简化的和弦，由一个音符和其上的五度音组成，听起来既不是小调也不是大调；常见于摇滚和重金属。

power chord: A simplified chord, consisting of a note and the fifth above it, that sounds neither minor nor major; common in rock and heavy metal.

前额皮质：大脑额叶的前部，与推理、决策和许多其他反射过程相关。

prefrontal cortex: The front part of the frontal lobes of the brain, associated with reasoning, decision making, and many other reflective processes.

本体感觉：对四肢位置的内部感觉。

proprioception: An internal sense of where one’s limbs are.

相对音高：在给定参考点的情况下识别一个音符的能力；例如，在听到标记的 C 音符后识别 G 音符的能力。

relative pitch: The ability to identify one note given a reference point; for example, the capacity to identify a G note after hearing a labeled C note.

节奏：有规律重复的声音模式。

rhythm: A regular repeated pattern of sound.

右前额皮质：位于大脑右半球的前额皮质部分，与记忆、自我识别和许多其他认知过程有关。

right prefrontal cortex: The portion of the prefrontal cortex that is in the brain’s right hemisphere, implicated in memory, self-recognition, and many other cognitive processes.

词根： (1) 一首曲子的音乐中心或发源地。例如，在一首从 C 大调到 F 大调再到 G 大调再回到 C 大调的歌曲中，根音（或主音）将被视为 C 大调。(2) 和弦的起点。在 C 大调和弦中，音符 C 被视为根音。（大和弦还包括根音以上的大三度音，因此 C 大调中的 E，以及根音以上的纯五度音，因此 C 大调中的 G。）

root: (1) The musical center or home of a piece. For example, in a song that proceeded from C major to F major to G major and back to C major, the root (or tonic) would be considered C major. (2) The starting point for a chord. In the chord C major, the note C is considered the root. (Major chords also include a note that is a major third above the root, hence E in the key of C major, and a note that is a perfect fifth above the root, hence G in the key of C major.)

音阶：一组音符，通常按严格的升序或降序练习，即使排列为不同的顺序，组合在一起听起来也不错。西方常见的音阶包括大调音阶、小调（风神）音阶、大五声音阶和小五声音阶。其他文化中存在许多其他声音，每种声音都有自己的特色。

scale: A set of notes, often practiced in strict ascending or descending order, that sound good together, even when permuted to different orders. Common scales in the West include the major scale, the minor (Aeolian) scale, the major pentatonic, and the minor pentatonic. Many others exist in other cultures, and each has its own characteristic sound.

十六分音符：长度为全音符长度的十六分之一。确切的持续时间取决于乐曲的整体节奏，因此每分钟 120 拍的歌曲中的十六分音符比每分钟 80 拍的歌曲中的十六分音符要短。

sixteenth note: A duration that is one-sixteenth of the length of a whole note. The exact duration depends on the overall tempo of the piece, so that a sixteenth note is briefer in a song that is 120 beats per minute than in a song that is 80 beats per minute.

次属和弦：位于根和弦之上的纯四度和弦（例如 C 大调的 F 大调）；通常用罗马数字 IV 表示。

subdominant: A chord that is a perfect fourth above the root chord (for example, F major in the key of C); often referred to by the Roman numeral IV.

颞上回：大脑颞叶的一部分，大致位于耳朵后面，包含韦尼克区，与声音和语音识别相关。

superior temporal gyrus: The part of the brain’s temporal lobe that is roughly behind the ear and contains Wernicke’s area, associated with recognition of sound and speech.

颞叶：大脑任一半球的下外侧叶；包括听觉皮层、海马体和颞上回等区域。

temporal lobe: The lower lateral lobe of either hemisphere in the brain; includes regions such as the auditory cortex, the hippocampus, and the superior temporal gyrus.

音色：区分一种乐器与另一种乐器的声音特性；例如，小提琴与长笛。

timbre: The sonic properties differentiating one instrument from the next; for example, a violin versus a flute.

主音：一首乐曲的音乐中心或归宿。例如，在一首从 C 大调到 F 大调再到 G 大调再回到 C 大调的歌曲中，根音（或主音）将被视为 C 大调。

tonic: The musical center or home of a piece. For example, in a song that proceeded from C major to F major to G major and back to C major, the root (or tonic) would be considered C major.

三连音：一组三个音符，通常在通常被两个音符占据的插槽中快速演奏。

triplet: A set of three notes, often played quickly, in a slot that would ordinarily be occupied by two notes.

tritone（三全音）：正好六个半音的听起来不愉快的音程，例如 C 和 F 升号之间的间隙（跳过 C 升号、D、D 升号、E 和 F）或 F 和 B 之间的间隙（跳过升 F、G、升 G、A 和升 A）。曾经被认为是不可接受的，现在却得到了更广泛的容忍。

tritone: An unpleasant-sounding interval of exactly six semitones, such as the gap between C and F-sharp (which skips over C-sharp, D, D-sharp, E, and F) or the gap between F and B (skipping over F-sharp, G, G-sharp, A, and A-sharp). Once considered unacceptable, now much more widely tolerated.

前庭系统：位于内耳的用于保持平衡和空间定向的系统。

vestibular system: The system for keeping track of balance and spatial orientation, located in the inner ear.

韦尼克区：大脑颞上回的一部分，与语言和音乐相关。

Wernicke’s area: A part of the brain’s superior temporal gyrus associated with language and music.

 

笔记

NOTES

 

调整

Tuning Up

 

2精灵：柯蒂斯，1977 年。

2 Genie: Curtiss, 1977.

2 个差异通常更多地与口音有关： Newport，1990。

2 differences typically pertain more to accent: Newport, 1990.

2接近母语的流利程度： Birdsong，2009。

2 near-native fluency: Birdsong, 2009.

3真正保持血液流动： Mozolic、Hayasaka 和 Laurienti，2010 年。

3 literally keeping the blood flowing: Mozolic, Hayasaka, and Laurienti, 2010.

3 位第二十六位最伟大吉他手： http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/5945/32609/32772。

3 twenty-sixth-greatest guitarist: http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/5945/32609/32772.

3直到他十七岁才开始： Morello，作者访谈，2010 年 5 月 20 日。

3 didn’t start until he was seventeen: Morello, interview with author, May 20, 2010.

3帕蒂·史密斯：史密斯，2010 年。

3 Patti Smith: Smith, 2010.

6确实必须尽早开始： Deutsch et al., 2006。

6 must indeed start early: Deutsch et al., 2006.

6不控制练习总量： Watanabe、Savion-Lemieux 和 Penhune，2007 年。

6 don’t control for total amount of practice: Watanabe, Savion-Lemieux, and Penhune, 2007.

6练习越多，效果就越好： Ericsson、Krampe 和 Tesch-Römer，1993；格拉德威尔，2008。

6 the more you practice the better you get: Ericsson, Krampe, and Tesch-Römer, 1993; Gladwell, 2008.

8 Knudsen 的原始结果： Knudsen 和 Knudsen，1990。

8 Knudsen’s original results: Knudsen and Knudsen, 1990.

8 只成年猫头鹰经常可以得到： Linkenhoker and Knudsen，2002。

8 adult owls can often get: Linkenhoker and Knudsen, 2002.

带我去河边

Take Me to the River

 

沉浸式课程中的11 种第二语言： Genesee，1987。

11 second languages in immersion programs: Genesee, 1987.

11人类大脑需要大量的接触……而我们往往会忘记： Anderson 和 Schooler，1991。

11 it takes the human brain a great deal of exposure … and we tend to forget: Anderson and Schooler, 1991.

11铃木法：铃木，1969。

11 Suzuki method: Suzuki, 1969.

12 “十年”或“一万小时”： Ericsson、Krampe 和 Tesch-Römer，1993 年；埃里克森、普里图拉和科克利，2007 年。

12 “ten years” or “ten thousand hours”: Ericsson, Krampe, and Tesch-Römer, 1993; Ericsson, Prietula, and Cokely, 2007.

12 “刻意练习”：爱立信，2008 年。

12 “deliberate practice”: Ericsson, 2008.

12大多数学习者达到了稳定状态： Ericsson 等人，2006 年。

12 most learners reach a plateau: Ericsson et al., 2006.

12 “最近发展区”： Vygotsky，1978。

12 “zone of proximal development”: Vygotsky, 1978.

12既不太难也不太容易： Fisher 等，1981。

12 neither too hard nor too easy: Fisher et al., 1981.

13挑战程度 ： Salen 和 Zimmerman，2004 年；汤普森，2007。

13 the level of challenge: Salen and Zimmerman, 2004; Thompson, 2007.

13弹奏钢琴瞬间！：休斯顿，2004 年。

13 Play Piano in a Flash!: Houston, 2004.

13完整的吉他手： Shipton，2001。

13 The Complete Guitar Player: Shipton, 2001.

16速成课程：原声吉他： Mead，2004 年。

16 Crash Course: Acoustic Guitar: Mead, 2004.

17多巴胺激增： Knutson 和 Cooper，2006 年。

17 surge of dopamine: Knutson and Cooper, 2006.

18手指的大脑表征： Elbert et al., 1995。

18 brain’s representation of fingers: Elbert et al., 1995.

19失去中指的猴子： Merzenich 等人，1984 年。

19 monkey that lost its middle finger: Merzenich et al., 1984.

19获取一些神经组织： Bavelier 和 Neville，2002 年。

19 taking some of the neural tissue: Bavelier and Neville, 2002.

19音乐家的大脑与非音乐家的大脑不同：有关这些研究的回顾，请参阅 Münte、Altenmüller 和 Jäncke，2002 年；哈比卜和贝松，2009。

19 the brains of musicians differ from those of nonmusicians: For a review of these studies, see Münte, Altenmüller, and Jäncke, 2002; Habib and Besson, 2009.

20颞平面： Keenan 等人，2001 年。

20 the planum temporale: Keenan et al., 2001.

20小脑： Schlaug 等人，1995 年。

20 the cerebellum: Schlaug et al., 1995.

音调、节奏和音色方面的20 个轻微偏差： Kraus 等人，2009 年；吕塞勒等人，2001。

20 slight deviations in … pitch, rhythm, and timbre: Kraus et al., 2009; Rüsseler et al., 2001.

20 位音乐家的首选乐器： Pantev 等人，2001 年。

20 musician’s instrument of choice: Pantev et al., 2001.

20 位歌剧歌手表演专业： Kleber 等人，2009 年。

20 Opera singers show specializations: Kleber et al., 2009.

20追踪了两组儿童： Hyde 等人，2009a；施劳格等人，2009。

20 tracked two groups of children: Hyde et al., 2009a; Schlaug et al., 2009.

21大脑变化与行为变化的大小相关： Hyde 等人，2009b。

21 brain changes correlated with the size of behavioral changes: Hyde et al., 2009b.

21掌握至少三套不同的技能： Uszler，2003。

21 master at least three distinct sets of skills: Uszler, 2003.

一分钟 22,800 个音符： Münte 、Altenmüller 和 Jäncke，2002 年。

22 eighteen hundred notes in a minute: Münte, Altenmüller, and Jäncke, 2002.

学习爬行

Learning to Crawl

 

23最后三个月结束时： Moon 和 Fifer，2000 年。

23 by the end of the final trimester: Moon and Fifer, 2000.

24 “音乐本能”：举四个例子，“音乐本能”一词用作最近 PBS 纪录片的标题、丹尼尔·莱维汀 (Daniel Levitin) 的书《这是你的音乐大脑》中的章节标题、以及作者的一本书的标题。菲利普·鲍尔 (Philip Ball)，以及史蒂文·米森 (Steven Mithen) 最近发表的一篇期刊文章的标题。曼内斯，2009；列维京，2006；球2010；米森，2009。

24 “music instinct”: To take four examples, the phrase “the music instinct” served as the title of a recent PBS documentary, as a chapter title in Daniel Levitin’s book This Is Your Brain on Music, as the title of a book by Philip Ball, and as the title of a recent journal article by Steven Mithen. Mannes, 2009; Levitin, 2006; Ball 2010; Mithen, 2009.

24当婴儿在一系列较小的跳跃中听到较大的音乐跳跃时： Stefanics 等人，2009 年。

24 When infants heard large musical leaps amid a series of smaller leaps: Stefanics et al., 2009.

24低音底鼓突然消失： Winkler 等人，2009 年。

24 sudden absence of bass kick drum: Winkler et al., 2009.

24识别音色的变化： Háden et al., 2009。

24 recognize changes in timbre: Háden et al., 2009.

24区分协和音……与不协和音： Perani et al., 2010。

24 distinguish consonance … from dissonance: Perani et al., 2010.

24更喜欢 听协和音而不是不协和音： Trainor、Tsang 和 Cheung，2002 年。

24 prefer listening to consonance rather than dissonance: Trainor, Tsang, and Cheung, 2002.

24 只幼年黑猩猩： Sugimoto 等人，2010 年。

24 infant chimpanzees: Sugimoto et al., 2010.

25即使已被移调，也能识别短旋律： Plantinga 和 Trainor，2005 年。

25 recognize a short melody even when it has been transposed: Plantinga and Trainor, 2005.

25有时会记住几个星期的旋律： Saffran、Loman 和 Robertson，2001 年。

25 sometimes remember melodies for weeks: Saffran, Loman, and Robertson, 2001.

25 个10 个月大的孩子比成年人更有能力： Hannon 和 Trehub，2005 年。

25 ten-month-olds are better able than adults: Hannon and Trehub, 2005.

25年幼的婴儿对某些语言差异很敏感： Werker 和 Tees，1992。

25 young infants are sensitive to some linguistic distinctions: Werker and Tees, 1992.

25 个婴儿出生时就具有完美或绝对音高： Saffran 和 Griepentrog，2001 年，但另请参阅 Plantinga 和 Trainor，2005 年，了解不同的观点。

25 babies are born with perfect or absolute pitch: Saffran and Griepentrog, 2001, but see also Plantinga and Trainor, 2005, for a different perspective.

26只需几个月的时间就可以认识一些基本节奏： Soley 和 Hannon，2010 年。

26 only a few months to recognize some of the basic rhythms: Soley and Hannon, 2010.

26 个离散音符，直到至少为两个： Davidson、McKernon 和 Gardner，1981；道林，1982。

26 discrete notes until they are at least two: Davidson, McKernon, and Gardner, 1981; Dowling, 1982.

26罕见的完美音高现象： Deutsch、Henthorn 和 Dolson，2004 年。

26 rare phenomenon of perfect pitch: Deutsch, Henthorn, and Dolson, 2004.

26遗漏了许多单独的注释： Dowling，1982。

26 miss many of the individual notes: Dowling, 1982.

26认识大调和弦： Kastner 和 Crowder，1990；达拉·贝拉等人，2001。

26 recognizing that major chords: Kastner and Crowder, 1990; Dalla Bella et al., 2001.

26检测出乎意料的和弦： Trainor 和 Trehub，1994 年。

26 detecting chords that are merely unexpected: Trainor and Trehub, 1994.

26麻烦注意背景和谐：同上；穆格，1976 年。

26 trouble paying attention to a background harmony: Ibid.; Moog, 1976.

26节奏并不容易： Moog，1976。

26 Rhythm is no easier: Moog, 1976.

26跟着音乐一起跳波普： Phillips-Silver 和 Trainor，2005 年。

26 bop along to music: Phillips-Silver and Trainor, 2005.

26无法 及时跳动： Rainbow，1981；弗雷加，1979；Eerola、Luck 和 Toiviainen，2006 年。然而，最近的一项研究确实表明儿童有能力保持当他们的鼓声融入社交场合时，时间就会改善：Kirschner 和 Tomasello，2009 年。

26 can’t bop in time: Rainbow, 1981; Frega, 1979; Eerola, Luck, and Toiviainen, 2006. One recent study does, however, suggest that children’s capacity to keep time improves when their drumming is embedded in a social situation: Kirschner and Tomasello, 2009.

27精确的旋律感： Welch、Sergeant 和 White，1998 年。

27 a precise sense of melody: Welch, Sergeant, and White, 1998.

27掌握保持调性的能力： Davidson，1985；戴维森、麦克农和加德纳，1981。

27 Mastering the ability to stay in key: Davidson, 1985; Davidson, McKernon, and Gardner, 1981.

27 “孩子们进入学校”： Welch、Sergeant 和 White，1998 年。

27 “children enter school”: Welch, Sergeant, and White, 1998.

27永远学不会调性唱歌： Pfordresher 和 Brown，2007 年；达拉·贝拉、吉盖尔和佩雷茨，2007 年。

27 never learn to sing in key: Pfordresher and Brown, 2007; Dalla Bella, Giguère, and Peretz, 2007.

27当一只年轻的斑胸草雀活到九十天时： Zann，1996 年。

27 By the time a young zebra finch reaches the age of ninety days: Zann, 1996.

27没有任何明显的更正或反馈： Kroodsma，2005。

27 without any obvious correction or feedback: Kroodsma, 2005.

27很少有人能说出同样的话： Welch，2008。

27 Few humans can say the same: Welch, 2008.

27比大多数人更好的音高感： Friedrich、Zentall 和 Weisman，2007 年。

27 better sense of pitch than most humans: Friedrich, Zentall, and Weisman, 2007.

27弗洛伊德可能是[有趣的]： Roth，1986。

27 Freud may have been [amusical]: Roth, 1986.

28对音乐的更多与生俱来的兴趣： McDermott 和 Hauser，2005 年。

28 much more innate interest in music: McDermott and Hauser, 2005.

语言的28 个方面可能具有跨文化通用性：关于通用语法可能包含的内容的两篇非常容易理解的讨论可以在 Pinker, 1994 和 Baker, 2001 中找到。

28 aspects of language that might be cross-culturally universal: Two exceptionally accessible discussions of what universal grammar might consist of can be found in Pinker, 1994, and Baker, 2001.

29阅读 利用 了 一组早于阅读本身的电路： Dehaene 和 Cohen，2007 年；拉穆斯，2004。

29 reading draws on a set of circuits that predate reading itself: Dehaene and Cohen, 2007; Ramus, 2004.

颞叶皮层的29 个回路： Rauschecker，2005；Rauschecker、Tian 和 Hauser，1995。

29 circuits in the temporal cortex: Rauschecker, 2005; Rauschecker, Tian, and Hauser, 1995.

30比单独音乐所需的精确得多： Trehub，2001。

30 far more precise than would be necessary for music alone: Trehub, 2001.

30与其他哺乳动物共享的神经结构： Stein 和 Meredith，1993。

30 neural architecture, shared with other mammals: Stein and Meredith, 1993.

30识别元音： Kuhl 和 Meltzoff，1982。

30 recognize when a vowel: Kuhl and Meltzoff, 1982.

30节奏正确： Patel，2003。

30 true for rhythm: Patel, 2003.

30和推介： Ross、Choi 和 Purves，2007 年；柯蒂斯和巴鲁查，2010。

30 and pitch: Ross, Choi, and Purves, 2007; Curtis and Bharucha, 2010.

30 名婴儿更喜欢母亲的声音而不是器乐： Standley 和 Madsen，1990。

30 infants prefer their mother’s voice to instrumental music: Standley and Madsen, 1990.

30唯一的其他研究： Marcus 等人，1999 年。

30 only other study: Marcus et al., 1999.

31 名婴儿无法掌握这些模式： Marcus、Fernandes 和 Johnson，2007 年；Gervain、Berent 和 Werker，2009 年。

31 infants couldn’t grasp the patterns: Marcus, Fernandes, and Johnson, 2007; Gervain, Berent, and Werker, 2009.

31更多地关注节奏模式： Phillips-Silver 和 Trainor，2005。

31 paid more attention to rhythmical patterns: Phillips-Silver and Trainor, 2005.

31任何两种意义上的信息都可以结合在一起： Lewkowicz，2002。

31 information in any two senses goes together: Lewkowicz, 2002.

31音乐与运动之间的耦合： Stein 和斯坦福，2008 年。

31 The coupling between music and motion: Stein and Stanford, 2008.

32梭状回对面孔的反应更大： Grill-Spector、Knouf 和 Kanwisher，2004 年。

32 the fusiform gyrus responds more to faces: Grill-Spector, Knouf, and Kanwisher, 2004.

32大脑区域的巨大混合：关于音乐和前额皮质，参见 Bengtsson、Csíkszentmihályi 和 Ullén，2007 年；贾纳塔，2009；威尔逊等人，2009；利弗等人，2009；Limb，2006 年。关于音乐和颞上回，请参阅 Chen、Penhune 和 Zatorre，2009 年。

32 a vast mélange of brain regions: On music and the prefrontal cortex, see Bengtsson, Csíkszentmihályi, and Ullén, 2007; Janata, 2009; Wilson et al., 2009; Leaver et al., 2009; Limb, 2006. On music and the superior temporal gyrus, see Chen, Penhune, and Zatorre, 2009.

32颞上回：Hickok 和 Poeppel，2004 年。

32 the superior temporal gyrus: Hickok and Poeppel, 2004.

32布罗卡区……语言： Grodzinsky，2001；恩比克等人，2000。

32 Broca’s area … language: Grodzinsky, 2001; Embick et al., 2000.

32颞平面也是如此： Hickok、Okada 和 Serences，2009 年。

32 Ditto for the planum temporale: Hickok, Okada, and Serences, 2009.

32各种听觉分析： Rauschecker、Tian 和 Hauser，1995；霍华德等人，2000。

32 all kinds of auditory analyses: Rauschecker, Tian, and Hauser, 1995; Howard et al., 2000.

32我们是否在听演讲： Hickok 和 Poeppel，2004 年。

32 whether we are listening to speech: Hickok and Poeppel, 2004.

32小脑是各种运动的关键参与者： Ito，2008。

32 cerebellum is a key player in all kinds of movements: Ito, 2008.

32杏仁核与一切事物都有关联：关于其在恐惧中的作用，请参阅 Rogan、Stäubli 和 LeDoux，1997 年；Phelps 和 LeDoux，2005。关于其在欲望中的作用，请参阅 Baird 等人，2004。关于其在焦虑中的作用，请参阅 Wilson 和 Junor，2008。

32 the amygdala is implicated in everything: On its role in fear, see Rogan, Stäubli, and LeDoux, 1997; Phelps and LeDoux, 2005. On its role in lust, see Baird et al., 2004. On its role in anxiety, see Wilson and Junor, 2008.

32意外的和弦可能会触发杏仁核： Koelsch、Fritz 和 Schlaug，2008 年。

32 Unexpected chords might trigger the amygdala: Koelsch, Fritz, and Schlaug, 2008.

32电击也会如此： Phelps 和 LeDoux，2005 年。

32 so will electric shocks: Phelps and LeDoux, 2005.

33进化的时间远远早于人类： Moreno 和 González，2007 年；波伦巴等人，2004。

33 evolved long before human beings did: Moreno and González, 2007; Poremba et al., 2004.

33随着人们学习杂耍而增加： Draganski 等人，2004 年。

33 increase as people learn to juggle: Draganski et al., 2004.

这并不容易

It Don’t Come Easy

 

38最流行的理论并不完全正确： Marcus 等人，1992。

38 the most popular theory wasn’t quite right: Marcus et al., 1992.

40 “一个没有学过德语的人”：吐温，1880。

40 “A person who has not studied German”: Twain, 1880.

42我们依赖“线索”： Marcus，2008；安德森和尼利，1996。

42 we rely on “cues”: Marcus, 2008; Anderson and Neely, 1996.

45儿童和未经训练的成年人： Trehub、Trainor 和 Unyk，1993 年。

45 Both children and untrained adults: Trehub, Trainor, and Unyk, 1993.

45旋律的大致方向： Dowling，1982。

45 the general direction a melody is going: Dowling, 1982.

45大飞跃和小飞跃之间的区别： Yust，2010。

45 the difference between big leaps and smaller leaps: Yust, 2010.

45对音乐来说太不精确： Cuddy 和 Cohen，1976 年。

45 too imprecise for music: Cuddy and Cohen, 1976.

45每秒识别几个间隔： Burns 和 Ward，1999。

45 recognize several intervals every second: Burns and Ward, 1999.

46一个更常见的技巧： Smith 等人，1994 年。

46 A more common trick: Smith et al., 1994.

46相当大的大脑重组： Fujioka 等人，2004 年。

46 considerable brain reorganization: Fujioka et al., 2004.

47 个手指自然不会独立移动： Lang 和 Schieber，2004 年。

47 fingers don’t naturally move independently: Lang and Schieber, 2004.

49听觉错觉： Repp 和 Bruttomesso，2009。

49 auditory illusions: Repp and Bruttomesso, 2009.

49 Art Blakey：关于 Blakey 计时准确性的惊人说明可以在http://musicmachinery.com/2010/02/08/revisiting-the-click-track/上找到。

49 Art Blakey: An amazing illustration of the accuracy of Blakey’s timing can be found at http://musicmachinery.com/2010/02/08/revisiting-the-click-track/.

50演变为一对一：萨默斯，2002 年。

50 devolves into one against one: Summers, 2002.

50 个溢出错误： Soska、Galeon 和 Adolph，正在出版。

50 overflow errors: Soska, Galeon, and Adolph, in press.

50独立的幻觉： Peters 和 Schwartz，1989；萨默斯，2002；德语，1983。

50 illusion of independence: Peters and Schwartz, 1989; Summers, 2002; Deutsch, 1983.

51速度与精度的权衡： Fitts，1954；维克格伦，1977。

51 speed-accuracy trade-off: Fitts, 1954; Wickelgren, 1977.

51自动化或程序化： Anderson，1992；摩尔和德豪威尔，2006。

51 automatization or proceduralization: Anderson, 1992; Moors and De Houwer, 2006.

51 个更高效、更大的单位： Rosenbloom 和 Newell，1986。

51 more efficient, larger units: Rosenbloom and Newell, 1986.

52为其他任务留出空间：例如，专业足球运动员变得非常习惯运球，以至于他们可以运球通过回转，并且仍然有足够的智力资源来识别回转结束时屏幕上投影的形状（史密斯和张伯伦，1992）。

52 leave room for other tasks: Expert soccer players, for example, become so accustomed to dribbling that they can dribble a ball through a slalom and still have enough mental resources left to identify shapes projected on a screen at the end of the slalom (Smith and Chamberlin, 1992).

52 个精心协调的过程：关于音乐学习期间灰质的变化，请参阅 Schneider 等人，2005。关于技能学习期间白质的变化，请参阅 Scholz 等人，2009。

52 carefully coordinated processes: On changes to gray matter during music learning, see Schneider et al., 2005. On changes in white matter during skill learning, see Scholz et al., 2009.

52提高效率： Harms 等人，2008 年。

52 made more efficient: Harms et al., 2008.

52 个新的树突棘： Xu 等人，2009。

52 new dendritic spines: Xu et al., 2009.

必须合成52 种蛋白质： Luft 和 Buitrago，2005。

52 proteins must be synthesized: Luft and Buitrago, 2005.

52 种心理表征：关于前额皮质，参见 Grol 等，2006；Poldrack et al., 2005。关于运动皮层，参见 Debaere et al., 2004。关于海马体和基底神经节，参见 Rémy et al., 2008。

52 mental representations: On the prefrontal cortex, see Grol et al., 2006; Poldrack et al., 2005. On the motor cortex, see Debaere et al., 2004. On the hippocampus and basal ganglia, see Rémy et al., 2008.

会说话的头像

Talking Heads

 

54 项双胞胎反射： Katz 和 Pesetsky，2009 年。

54 twin reflexes: Katz and Pesetsky, 2009.

54 种可以及时跳舞的生物： Patel et al., 2009；沙赫纳等人，2009。

54 creatures that can dance in time: Patel et al., 2009; Schachner et al., 2009.

55仍然无法获得完美的音高： Deutsch et al., 2006。

55 still fail to acquire perfect pitch: Deutsch et al., 2006.

55 个不同的“模块”： Alossa 和 Castelli，2009。

55 distinct “modules”: Alossa and Castelli, 2009.

55音乐能力受损： Gall，1825。

55 impaired musical abilities: Gall, 1825.

55 种音乐障碍……以及正常的语言能力： Peretz 等人，1994 年。

55 musical impairments … alongside normal linguistic abilities: Peretz et al., 1994.

55 种语言能力受损……但音乐能力基本保留： Tomaino，2010。

55 impaired language abilities … yet largely preserved musical abilities: Tomaino, 2010.

55 人设法识别出很久以前学过的歌曲： Vanstone 等人，2009 年。

55 manage to recognize songs learned long ago: Vanstone et al., 2009.

55痴迷的整形外科医生：萨克斯，2007 年。

55 orthopedic surgeon who became obsessed: Sacks, 2007.

56前额皮质，它与一切事物都有关联：关于讽刺，参见 Shammi 和 Stuss，1999；关于音高感知，参见 Zatorre 和 Gandour，2008；关于性高潮，参见 Tiihonen et al., 1994；关于爵士乐即兴创作，请参见 Bengtsson、Csíkszentmihályi 和 Ullén，2007 年。前额皮质也与自我认知（Keenan 等人，2000 年）和公平感（Knoch 等人，2006 年）相关。

56 prefrontal cortex, which has been implicated in everything: On sarcasm, see Shammi and Stuss, 1999; on pitch perception, see Zatorre and Gandour, 2008; on orgasm, see Tiihonen et al., 1994; on jazz improvisation, see Bengtsson, Csíkszentmihályi, and Ullén, 2007. The prefrontal cortex has also been tied to self-recognition (Keenan et al., 2000) and the perception of fairness (Knoch et al., 2006).

56神经科学家最近的评论：帕特尔，2008 年。

56 recent review by the neuroscientist: Patel, 2008.

56最系统的综述： Marin 和 Perry，1999。对三分之一的估计可能低估了实际比例，因为许多同时患有这两种疾病的患者可能并不被认为异常，值得在文献中报告。

56 the most systematic review: Marin and Perry, 1999. The estimate of a third is likely an underestimate of the real proportion, since many patients who have impairments in both probably aren’t deemed unusual enough to merit reporting in the literature.

56个人讲声调语言： Pfordresher 和 Brown，2009 年。

56 people who speak tonal languages: Pfordresher and Brown, 2009.

56干扰人们的句子理解： Slevc、Rosenberg 和 Patel，2009。

56 interfered with people’s sentence comprehension: Slevc, Rosenberg, and Patel, 2009.

56识别言语中的情绪： Thompson、Schellenberg 和 Husain，2004 年。

56 identify the emotions in speech: Thompson, Schellenberg, and Husain, 2004.

将57 个较小的单元分解为较大的单元： Fadiga、Craighero 和 D'Ausilio，2009 年。

57 smaller units into larger units: Fadiga, Craighero, and D’Ausilio, 2009.

57允许我们使用工具： Higuchi 等，2009。

57 allow us to use tools: Higuchi et al., 2009.

57所谓的肌肉记忆： Albouy 等人，2008 年。

57 so-called muscle memory: Albouy et al., 2008.

大脑区域57 个星座： Marcus，2006。

57 constellation of brain areas: Marcus, 2006.

57大量利用我们的神经资源进行记忆： Snyder，2000。

57 draw heavily on our neural resources for memory: Snyder, 2000.

58我们的记忆缺乏整齐的表格形式： Marcus，2008。

58 our memories lack the neat tabular form: Marcus, 2008.

58听众迷路：同上。

58 Listeners get lost: Ibid.

58 位音乐家学习菲利普·格拉斯的作品：玛丽·法布德，个人交流。

58 musicians learning Philip Glass pieces: Mary Farbood, personal communication.

58音乐剧“原始语言”：达尔文，1874 年。

58 musical “protolanguage”: Darwin, 1874.

58歌唱的尼安德特人： Mithen，2005。动物行为学家 Tecumseh Fitch 也捍卫了类似的观点：Fitch，nd

58 The Singing Neanderthals: Mithen, 2005. The animal behaviorist Tecumseh Fitch has defended a similar view: Fitch, n.d.

59母亲语可能并非真正与生俱来： Ingram，1995。

59 motherese may not be truly innate: Ingram, 1995.

59婴儿对此更加关注： Fernald，1985。

59 infants pay more attention to it: Fernald, 1985.

59本质上听起来很快乐： Singh、Morgan 和 Best，2002 年。

59 intrinsically sound happy: Singh, Morgan, and Best, 2002.

59发展高尔夫技能……探戈： Jäncke 等人，2009 年；萨科等人，2006。

59 developing skill at golf … tango: Jäncke et al., 2009; Sacco et al., 2006.

60 人对音乐几乎不感兴趣： McDermott 和 Hauser，2005。

60 show almost no interest in music: McDermott and Hauser, 2005.

60音盲……无法在音高上可靠地唱歌： Pfordresher 和 Brown，2007 年。

60 tone-deaf … can’t reliably sing on pitch: Pfordresher and Brown, 2007.

60甚至提取简单的音程： Trehub、Schellenberg 和 Hill，1997 年。

60 extracting even simple musical intervals: Trehub, Schellenberg, and Hill, 1997.

60似乎非常难以置信： Tallerman，2007；比克顿，2009。

60 seems deeply implausible: Tallerman, 2007; Bickerton, 2009.

60象牙长笛： Conard、Malina 和 Münzel，2009 年。

60 ivory flute: Conard, Malina, and Münzel, 2009.

60至少五万年前： Klein 和 Edgar，2002。

60 at least fifty thousand years ago: Klein and Edgar, 2002.

60几百万年： Bickerton，2009。

60 a few million years: Bickerton, 2009.

更早之前的60种其他工具：Semaw 等人，2003 年。Iegor Reznikoff 在 2005 年发表的一篇不寻常的文章认为，洞穴壁画（大约来自同一时代）被放置在洞穴的异常共鸣区域，但雷兹尼科夫没有指出任何绘画描绘任何可以合理解释为音乐意象的东西。

60 other kinds of tools far earlier: Semaw et al., 2003. An unusual 2005 article by Iegor Reznikoff argues that cave paintings (from roughly the same era) were placed in exceptionally resonant regions of caves, but none of the paintings Reznikoff points to depict anything that could reasonably be construed as musical imagery.

61 首歌词比旋律更容易记住： Peretz、Radeau 和 Arguin，2004 年。

61 lyrics are more easily remembered than melodies: Peretz, Radeau, and Arguin, 2004.

61 名四岁儿童考虑两首歌： Serafine 等人，1986 年。

61 four-year-olds consider two songs: Serafine et al., 1986.

61最近的一项研究表明： Lebedeva 和 Kuhl，2010。

61 A more recent study has shown: Lebedeva and Kuhl, 2010.

61极具影响力的书： Lerdahl 和 Jackendoff，1983 年，以及 2009 年《音乐感知》特刊中的论文，庆祝该书问世 25 周年。

61 enormously influential book: Lerdahl and Jackendoff, 1983, and the papers in a 2009 special issue of Music Perception, celebrating the book’s twenty-fifth anniversary.

61 Jackendoff 分解了一杯咖啡的制作过程： Jackendoff，2007 年。

61 Jackendoff broke down the process of making a cup of coffee: Jackendoff, 2007.

62两者……都取自广泛的重要认知资源： Jackendoff 的观点在 Jackendoff, 2009 中得到了进一步解释。

62 both … draw from a wide range of important cognitive resources: Jackendoff’s view is further explained in Jackendoff, 2009.

62甚至是平凡的活动： Zacks、Tversky 和 ​​Iyer，2001 年。

62 even mundane activities: Zacks, Tversky, and Iyer, 2001.

63 “写音乐就像跳舞建筑”： http://www.paclink.com/ascott/they/tamildaa.htm和http://theonlinephotographer.typepad.com/the_online_photographer/2010/07/ot-we-听到-martin-mull.html。

63 “Writing about music is like dancing about architecture”: http://www.paclink.com/ascott/they/tamildaa.htm and http://theonlinephotographer.typepad.com/the_online_photographer/2010/07/ot-we-hear-from-martin-mull.html.

63 “最受欢迎”：希夫，1997 年。

63 “the most popular”: Schiff, 1997.

63 “以慵懒的颤音开始”：罗斯，2007 年。

63 “begins with a languid trill”: Ross, 2007.

64 interpretation and imagination of the clarinetist: Schwartz, 1979.

64 three physicists wrote an entire article: Chen, Smith, and Wolfe, 2008.

64 “音乐表达”：科普兰，1957 年。

64 “Music expresses”: Copland, 1957.

66 “[学生的注意力通常过多”： Lehmann、Sloboda 和 Woody，2007 年。

70 what makes music teaching effective: Buttram, 1996.

79 cult-classic book: Andreas, 2005.

80 个记忆随着时间的推移而固化： Luft 和 Buitrago，2005 年；赖特和萨宾，2007 年。

摇滚学院

School of Rock

 

91逐渐开始下降： Giedd 等，1999。

91 gradually begins to decline: Giedd et al., 1999.

92 no firm break in the curve: Hakuta, Bialystok, and Wiley, 2003.

92记忆能力慢慢下降： Salthouse，2009。

92 memory skills slowly decline: Salthouse, 2009.

92 interference and habits: Iverson et al., 2003.

93 “less is more”: Newport, 1988.

93 Bulgarian kids learning to play: Rice, 1994, with thanks to Erin Hannon for the example.

93 adults were systematically better: Savion-Lemieux, Bailey, and Penhune, 2009.

93 watch the same episode of a TV show: Crawley et al., 1999.

94 known as chunking: Miller, 1956.

真正的人才

True Talent

 

97 “新研究表明”： Ericsson、Prietula 和 Cokely，2007 年。

97 “New research shows”: Ericsson, Prietula, and Cokely, 2007.

97 “给我一打健康的婴儿”：沃森，1925 年。

97 “Give me a dozen healthy infants”: Watson, 1925.

97 种令人惊讶的方式：格拉德威尔，2008 年。

97 surprising ways: Gladwell, 2008.

99自闭症可能有所帮助：理查德在这方面并不是唯一一个。有关自闭症儿童音乐能力的一般讨论，请参阅 Miller，1989。

99 The autism likely helped: Richard is not alone in this regard. For a general discussion of the music ability of children with autism, see Miller, 1989.

100投入了大约两千个小时： Weisberg，1999。

100 put in more like two thousand hours: Weisberg, 1999.

101两人只见过一次面：布朗，1993 年。

101 the two met only once: Browne, 1993.

101甚至在现代遗传技术出现之前： Scheinfeld 和 Schweitzer，1939 年。

101 Even before modern genetic techniques were available: Scheinfeld and Schweitzer, 1939.

102遗传学是更好的预测因子： Bouchard 等人，1990。

102 genetics is a better predictor: Bouchard et al., 1990.

102天赋很重要……从体育到国际象棋，从写作到音乐： Vinkhuyzen 等人，2009 年。

102 talent matters … from sports to chess to writing to music: Vinkhuyzen et al., 2009.

102从基因到……行为的因果链： Marcus，2004 年。

102 The chain of causality from gene to … behavior: Marcus, 2004.

102 FOXP2：费舍尔和马库斯，2006 年。

102 FOXP2: Fisher and Marcus, 2006.

102影响内存效率： Cowansage、LeDoux 和 Monfils，2010。

102 affects memory efficiency: Cowansage, LeDoux, and Monfils, 2010.

103调节好奇心： Ackermann 等人，2010。

103 modulate curiosity: Ackermann et al., 2010.

103对绝对音高的敏感度： Theusch、Basu 和 Gitschier，2009 年。

103 sensitivity to absolute pitch: Theusch, Basu, and Gitschier, 2009.

103另一项最近的研究表明： Ukkola 等人，2009 年。

103 Another recent study shows: Ukkola et al., 2009.

103在社交互动中的重要作用： Turner 等人，2010。

103 important role in social interaction: Turner et al., 2010.

103统计控制： Ruthsatz 等，2008；梅因茨和汉布里克，2010。

103 statistically controlled for: Ruthsatz et al., 2008; Meinz and Hambrick, 2010.

103先天与后天的共同作用：马库斯，2004 年。

103 nature working together with nurture: Marcus, 2004.

103对同卵双胞胎的研究： Coon 和 Carey，1989 年。

103 study with identical twins: Coon and Carey, 1989.

103 Ericsson 等人的原始研究： Ericsson、Krampe 和 Tesch-Römer，1993 年；斯洛博达，1996；乔根森，2002。

103 the original study by Ericsson and others: Ericsson, Krampe, and Tesch-Römer, 1993; Sloboda, 1996; Jorgensen, 2002.

103 岁，但没有像其他只打过 8 场比赛的人一样出色：埃里克森、克兰佩和特施-罗默，1993 年。

103 without becoming as good as others who had played for only eight: Ericsson, Krampe, and Tesch-Römer, 1993.

104音乐能力研究：戈登，1967 年。

104 study of musical aptitude: Gordon, 1967.

104直接影响节奏感知： Trainor 等，2009。

104 directly affect rhythmic perception: Trainor et al., 2009.

世界上最难听的歌

145与神经机制直接相关： Chen、Penhune 和 Zatorre，2008 年；格拉恩和罗，2009。

145 directly tied to neural machinery: Chen, Penhune, and Zatorre, 2008; Grahn and Rowe, 2009.

145 “音乐是一种万花筒”： Payzant，1986。一些哲学家将汉斯利克的万花筒比喻视为对音乐的贬义挖苦，类似于康德将音乐视为空洞装饰的观点。无论其意图如何，他对音乐的描述似乎都非常恰当。

145 “Music is a kind of kaleidoscope”: Payzant, 1986. Some philosophers have taken Hanslick’s kaleidoscope metaphor to be a pejorative dig against music, akin to Kant’s perspective of music as empty decoration. Regardless of how it was intended, his characterization of music seems remarkably apt.

不知道就知道

148遵循降序旋律： Starr 和 Waterman，2003。

152 seemed to have much the same intuitions: Bigand, 1990.

153 “Telling More Than We Can Know”: Nisbett and Wilson, 1977.

155爵士乐几乎总是需要一种混合： Johnson-Laird，2002。

155 jazz almost always requires a kind of mixture: Johnson-Laird, 2002.

155传奇即兴演奏家： http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio3/bach/bachatozi.shtml。

155 legendary improviser: http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio3/bach/bachatozi.shtml.

155 位古典传统表演者经常即兴创作： Haynes，2007 年。

155 performers in the classical tradition improvised frequently: Haynes, 2007.

158 Zollo 采访詹姆斯·泰勒： http://bluerailroad.wordpress.com/james-taylor-the-bluerailroad-interview/。

158 Zollo interviews James Taylor: http://bluerailroad.wordpress.com/james-taylor-the-bluerailroad-interview/.

159 “这个[不寻常的]和弦”：有关和弦的确切身份存在争议。詹姆斯·泰勒 (James Taylor) 很清楚，他可能问过麦卡特尼 (McCartney)，他声称这是 F13，但多米尼克·佩德勒 (Dominic Pedler, 2003) 根据声音和视频，认为有问题的和弦是 F7#9。不管怎样，和弦在当时的流行音乐中并不常见。

159 “this [unusual] chord”: The exact identity of the chord in question is in dispute. James Taylor, who is in a good position to know, possibly having asked McCartney, claimed it was an F13, but on the basis of sound and video, Dominic Pedler, 2003, argues that the chord in question was instead an F7#9. Either way, the chord was not very common in the pop music of the time.

180平均律系统：关于广泛使用的平均律调音系统及其开发方式的非常容易理解的讨论，可以在 Isacoff, 2001 中找到；说明性的声音示例可以在http://www.yuvalnov.org/temperament/找到。

187披头士乐队可能也经历过类似的革命：埃弗里特，1999 年。根据埃弗里特的说法，“平装本作家”可能是保罗的第一个性格研究，因为他受到一位阿姨的刺激，她想知道为什么他所写的都是爱情。

187 The Beatles may have undergone a similar revolution: Everett, 1999. According to Everett, “Paperback Writer” was perhaps the first of Paul’s character studies, after he was goaded by an aunt who wondered why all he ever wrote about was love.

重金属

193即兴爵士乐软件： Johnson-Laird，1987；约翰逊-莱尔德，2002。

197控制幻觉：Langer ，1975；韦格纳，2002。

197 the illusion of control: Langer, 1975; Wegner, 2002.

197 famous set of studies: Glass and Singer, 1972.

199非正式研究： http://multiplayerblog.mtv.com/2009/01/15/fender-survey-shows-music-games-drive-students-to-play-real-instruments/。

199 informal study: http://multiplayerblog.mtv.com/2009/01/15/fender-survey-shows-music-games-drive-students-to-play-real-instruments/.

199快乐的科学：吉尔伯特，2006 年。

199 the science of pleasure: Gilbert, 2006.

199 eudaimonia：沃特曼，2008 年。

199 eudaimonia: Waterman, 2008.

199 “我怎样才能过上平衡的生活”： Ryff 和 Singer，1998 年。

199 “How can I live a balanced life”: Ryff and Singer, 1998.

200 “自我实现”：马斯洛，1946。

200 “ self-actualization”: Maslow, 1946.

200更大 的使命感和个人成长： Ryff 和 Singer，2008。

200 a greater sense of purpose and personal growth: Ryff and Singer, 2008.

200 种二十七种文化： Park、Peterson 和 Ruch，2009 年。

200 twenty-seven cultures: Park, Peterson, and Ruch, 2009.

200第三种使用的日记清单： Steger、Kashdan 和 Oishi，2008 年。

200 A third used diary checklists: Steger, Kashdan, and Oishi, 2008.

200 个房间供两人居住： Peterson、Park 和 Seligman，2005 年；Steger、Kashdan 和 Oishi，2008 年；胡塔和瑞安，nd
